PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Tanner moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that:
(1) no sales should occur until all Environmental Impact Statement processes are completed and the future of Sydney West Airport is resolved;

(2) in order to ensure that the Commonwealth achieves the maximum lease payments possible as a result of the processes set out in the Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill, Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport should be included in the first tranche of airports outlined in the Minister for Finance's second reading speech for the Airports (Transitional) Bill, rather than be offered for leasehold sale at some later time; and
(3) the road and other infrastructure developments associated with the Badgerys Creek proposal should proceed where appropriate, regardless of whether Sydney West Airport is built at Badgerys Creek".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from last night, there are a few other remarks that I want to make. In the first bill, the Airports Bill, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) seeks to increase the membership of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. My understanding is that we are not opposed to that bill. One can only hope that his plans in that regard succeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the honourable members for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) and Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) put out a local press release claiming that they have influenced the minister to go ahead with Holsworthy as the second option.I would be most indebted to the honourable members for Lindsay and Macquarie—or, indeed, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), who will be speaking later in this debate—if they could elucidate the details of how they were able to convince the minister to proceed with Holsworthy. Whilst I have made a few remarks about Holsworthy, I did not mention what a ridiculous nomination as a fall‐back position it is. Holsworthy ran second last out of 10 possible sites.

The shadow minister for defence, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), is here. He will know the difficulty of clearing ordnance and, if passengers do not get a bang from that, ANSTO is next door! I guess this is freedom of choice: a conventional bang or a nuclear bang, depending on your predilections.

The terrain around Holsworthy consists of ravines. It will be an interesting exercise, for either civilian or military engineers, to flatten the site to make it suitable for a runway. Then again, we do not want to run over the Olympic shooters who may be participating in the Sydney 2000 Olympics, of which I am sure all honourable members are very proud. Holsworthy has been nominated as part of the Sydney infrastructure for the Olympic Games.

As I said last night, should Holsworthy, in the most remarkable of circumstances, survive an EIS process, then an airport at Holsworthy is many years away. This would be a real breach of faith with the people of Australia, particularly the people of Sydney, concerning this government's intention to proceed with a second airport. I have suggested all along that, by nominating Holsworthy, you are really suggesting that the money that may be available from the sale of airports will be pocketed in consolidated revenue and none of it will be diverted towards building Sydney's second airport.

I want to sum up from a western suburbs perspective, and I note that the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) is to make a significant contribution to the debate. The thing that we are pleased about is that, as opposed to members opposite, we have stood up for our constituents and we have listened to them. We understand their concern about the EIS. Indeed, along with my colleagues, I was delighted when we announced an EIS process. I am happy to acknowledge—or I will be when I actually see the fine print of the guidelines—that the government should be congratulated for putting a go/no‐go clause on it, but they have already missed their deadline.

We have stood up for the people because there should be and can be no sale in advance of the completion of the EIS process. One might ask why this is important. I suppose, when we have a government that proposes to abolish the one authority that would be conducting an EIS, we should have some reservations about ever seeing the whole thing being completed. That is why we are moving the amendment. I invite members opposite to support the amendment that there should be no sale in advance of the EIS process. When I go back to my electorate, people are going to be pleased that we have stood so firmly on this issue.

The second thing we have said is that the infrastructure which caused such general favourable comment in the western suburbs and which was proposed to be built in conjunction with the airport should go ahead whether or not Badgerys Creek goes ahead. There is a significant difference of view on this between members of the government and members on this side. Nevertheless, I invite those members of the government who come from western Sydney—the members for Lindsay, Parramatta, Macquarie, and Macarthur (Mr Fahey) for that matter—to come across to this side and stand up for the people of western Sydney to ensure, no matter what happens, whether it is Badgerys Creek or Holsworthy, that that infrastructure is provided. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because I have been involved for a long time, like the member for Chifley (Mr Price), in this whole discussion of a second airport for Sydney. I do remember the former member for Mitchell and the Prime Minister of the day announcing some time ago that there would be a second airport built at Galston. Gough Whitlam said, `You will get Galston.' That was a decision taken in a moment of pique. It was a decision to put Sydney's second airport in a Liberal electorate. However, the process meant that Labor ultimately lost the seats of Parramatta and Mitchell because of a precipitous decision. It became impossible during the term of Gough Whitlam to make a decision on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the election of the Fraser government, further studies were done. Major airport needs of Sydney was a study conducted over a period of time, and all sites were considered. Ultimately the Fraser government made the decision that a third runway at Mascot would meet the future needs of Sydney. On coming to office, the Australian Labor Party reluctantly agreed, despite the activities of the then members for Barton and Grayndler and other electorates, that the third runway should go ahead. They also sought a second site which was, in fact, a compromised decision. Basically, within the ranks of the Australian Labor Party, the decision was, `Well, you're going to cop it down in the seats of Barton and Grayndler and St George,' as it was in those days, `and you're going to cop it out in the west too.'

The member for Chifley mounted the argument that western Sydney was going to be devoid of job opportunities under the management of the Liberal Party and that an airport would be one way of supplying jobs to western Sydney. The fact of the matter is that all members on the other side of the House in the Australian Labor Party failed to mention the closure of Nirimba and other important institutions in western Sydney—so-called cost‐cutting decisions by the Australian Labor Party that ripped the guts out of the economy of western Sydney. But then a pie in the sky when you die—the promise of Badgerys Creek—was something that was held out to the people of western Sydney as providing jobs. The whole process was pure sophistry and hypocrisy of the government of the day. It was procrastination at every step.

So the government of the day went out of office with a decision to go ahead with Badgerys Creek. I will remind the House that that decision to go ahead with Badgerys Creek precluded any allocations for road links. There was no funding for rail links. It was a very poor proposition. There was even a time schedule published by the previous government of when certain tasks would be completed.

There was a proposal that a complete environmental impact statement would begin at the start of this year and would be completed in July. That EIS was not even commenced under the Australian Labor Party. I questioned the minister and I questioned the House at that time, and not one person could provide me, right up to the day of the election, with any details of the environmental impact statements. There were statements published in the press. Ministers and members, prior to the election, failed to answer my questions about the environmental impact statement.

However I would remind the House that, coming into the election campaign, there was the announcement made that the bulldozers would roll on 30 March. The inquiry had not begun. There was no substance in any claims that there was an inquiry intended, yet the bulldozers were going to roll on 30 March for the construction of Badgerys Creek. So much for consideration, so much for the thought, so much for the care and the concern for the people of western Sydney by the Australian Labor Party. They were pure pawns in the process of what the Australian Labor Party wanted to do in western Sydney, which was, come hell or high water, build an airport at Badgerys Creek. They were afraid of losing face as a government and afraid of failing to provide for the needs of Sydney and Sydney's second airport.

The Australian Labor Party lost the election and today we see the beating of the chest and the claiming that all is wrong with the new government. The new government clearly went to the election with the people of western Sydney voting for the Liberal and National parties on the basis of the policies that they presented—some of which related to Sydney's second airport needs. Those policies, which were clearly enunciated across the west, were that there would be a full environmental impact statement done of Badgerys Creek and that the people of western Sydney would be consulted in that process.

That is something that the Labor Party never undertook. The Australian Labor Party failed at every step to acknowledge that that was necessary. They were prepared to rely on an environmental impact statement which was 12 years old. They were not prepared to make a commitment to a new study and then, reluctantly, the then minister said, `We'll do a half-baked, very minimal thing. We're going to fly Tiger Moths out of Badgerys Creek, and we'll do an environmental impact statement on the Tiger Moth proposition.'

On the other hand, the coalition said, `We will do a full environmental impact study based on the maximum use that could be made of Badgerys Creek. We will look at it as if it were to be an international airport, and we will see what impact that will have on the people of western Sydney.' The Labor Party during the election campaign took this firm commitment, an authentic commitment, to the people of western Sydney—and the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) was one of them—by saying that an international airport was going to be built at Badgerys Creek.

They took the intention, stated so clearly time and again by shadow minister Prosser, that we would do an environmental study on the worst circumstances for Badgerys Creek. We were not going to dub them with some half-baked belated commitment to an environmental impact study. We were going to and will do a proper impact study based on maximum potential use for that airport whether it is the government's intention to go ahead and do that or not. We will not have the situation at some future stage where people in western Sydney say, `You lied to us. You misled us. You said you were going to fly Tiger Moths and now you are flying jumbos.'

That is the way the Australian Labor Party operate in everything they do. They make a minimalist statement, get a conclusion and an acceptance and then suddenly blow out the costs, blow out the size. You lost your integrity and the trust of the Australian people because you were not honest and straightforward with them in the original proposition. You can go through topic after topic, decision after decision of the Keating government and see the way in which the sophistry and hypocrisy of that government so loaded their decisions that people grew to mistrust them.

We have been up front with this. We said we are going to have a full environmental impact statement, a full study done on western Sydney. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has said we are going to look not only at Badgerys Creek but also at the second proposition in Major airport needs of Sydney, and the member knows that. Holsworthy came in second. It was the second proposition in the major airport needs of Sydney study. The documentation is there. You can wave the documents in the air but the propositions of the Australian Labor Party are as worthless as the paper they are written on. The people have rejected that.

Why do you think there are now Liberal members in Lindsay, where there was a 13.6 per cent swing? It is because you lost the trust of the people in that area. They did not trust you any longer. They did not believe you would do what you said you would do. So across western Sydney we saw a massive change in people's voting pattern, because the Australian Labor Party is no longer the party of the people of western Sydney. They can no longer retain trust because of the half‐truths and minimalist statements. When they get a decision they suddenly blow it out and change it. That is the process that the hardworking families of western Sydney have rejected.

Now we are going to do a study of Holsworthy. We will do a study of Badgerys Creek and Sydney will get its best airport. When the minister has finished having the best and most efficient use made of Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport, we will find there is adequate capacity for this process to go through and for a second airport to be constructed in good time.

The Australian Labor Party did not look at what the best solution was but put a political reading on the process. They put a political reading on the process and then bent the facts to suit their political decision. The only way to make proper decisions in government or anywhere else is to get the facts, start with the facts and explain to people why you can or cannot do something for political reasons. To do it the other way round is the reason you lost the election and the trust of the Australian people.

This issue is very clear. The government has been up‐front and straightforward with the people of western Sydney, and no amount of skating around telling half‐truths or presenting manipulated documentation will get the people of western Sydney to change their minds about the coalition government and the integrity of the decisions we have taken and will continue to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Speaker, for the opportunity to speak on these airports bills now before the House. Before I commence, I want to say that the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has lied to this House. He really has. He has actually provided mistruths to this House.
—Mr Speaker—
—Order! The honourable member for Prospect will withdraw that.

—I withdraw the word `lied' at your direction, Mr Speaker. I apologise if the Deputy Leader of the House (Mr McGauran), who is at the table, is offended by that so I replace the word with `mistruths'.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I believe the word `mistruth' also ascribes to the member dishonest motives. I believe `mistruth' should be treated in the same way `lie' is.
—`Lie' is unparliamentary and `mistruth' is marginally acceptable.

—I apologise. I will not use that word again as it is unparliamentary. But I would remind the minister at the table as well as members on the government benches, including the member for Mitchell, that some of the things he said were not correct.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not Prosser who was the shadow spokesman when you were in opposition. It was Senator Parer who made the comments. The other piece of false information he provided to this House, to the people in the gallery and to the Hansard is that no draft environmental guidelines are now being prepared. This commenced in January 1996. There were many public meetings, and I note the member for Mitchell was not present at any of them. The draft guidelines were sent out to all councils and community groups requesting their input so we could go one step further in case anything was missed out when the actual EIS commenced.

If the government are going to tell the communities at large that they are going to do a proper EIS, they are really saying to the community, `We may have changed the law or the guidelines but we are not telling the people.' All the councils and community groups who have already paid consultants to do submissions over this draft EIS are now not being told. We know submissions closed in the first week of April—they were extended by a month by this government, which is fair enough.

There has been no announcement since then as to any change to these draft guidelines. So do not come into this House and tell these falsies about what they are or are not doing. It is not accurate. I believe that we in this House as representatives of our particular constituencies should make sure the truth comes forward at all times, that no‐one is misinformed because someone wants to grandstand on a particular bill before the House.

I must admit I had a certain feeling of deja vu when I started to read the second reading speech on this bill after the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) introduced it last week. It was a certain feeling of deja vu because I thought, `Where have I heard all this before?' Then I realised, `Wait a minute, that's right, it was one of our bills that we introduced when we were in government.' Then I started to read a bit further and I realised it may have been one of our bills but, as usual, when the government tries to take claim for anything, as when in opposition, they miss the shot, drop the ball and then move changes because they think they can make the bill better.

I will go through some of those changes before I comment on why I am supporting the amendments now before the House. The government members are really like contortionists. Last night I watched the government members during the debate. They seemed to twist and turn. In fact, they reminded me of children playing that game Twister, when they do not know which way to go. They have to twist this way; they have to twist that way. I do not believe that the debate on the airports bills now before the House is a joke. The bills should be examined very carefully because of the ramifications not only for the people of today but also for the people of the future. That is also a consideration we should be giving as elected representatives in this House.

Why, the government should ask, has the minister decided to drop from the previous bill the cross‐ownership rules on leasing airports? They were a central part of our bill and dropping them will have dire consequences for the community at large. Gone is the proposed 15 per cent limit on cross‐ownership of Kingsford Smith and Sydney West airports with Tullamarine and Brisbane airports. But—read the Hansard—the minister did not even have the courage to admit in his second reading speech that this was going to happen. If you read the speech—I have read it twice—you will see that admission is very conspicuous by its absence.

It is very clear when you go through the bill why the minister has done this. He recognises the previous Labor government's argument that failing to sell Sydney airport first would result in a loss for the government. By getting rid of cross‐ownership the minister is hoping to offset that shortfall. But it will not work.

By failing to include Sydney airport in the first group of sales, the minister is virtually guaranteeing that bidders will lodge more conservative offers for other airports, keeping their cash in reserve for when Sydney airport comes on the market, if they want to bid at all. Investors, who at first might have received all the exposure they desired in the desperate world of airport management, may not even be interested by the time Sydney airport makes it to the auction block. When the process does not work, Australians will turn around to find that some very shrewd magnate has managed to wrangle a monopoly ownership of our airports. Well done, Minister.

Further, the minister has given himself the power to exempt replacement airport master plans and environmental strategies from the public comment and consultation process. The government have been crowing about being the kings of the environmental impact statement. That is a nice one, Minister. It is deja vu. We are still seeing the government getting their airport facts incredibly wrong—so wrong that it stops being funny and starts to become painfully embarrassing.

I cannot tell you how embarrassed I was on Monday to sit and listen to the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) who, not once but twice, rabbited on about her party's support for an environmental impact study at Badgerys Creek and how the Labor government would not have instigated such a study. She repeated that last night in the debate on this bill. I repeat for her benefit, and for the benefit of every other member on the government benches, that the date on this study is January 1996. I do not believe—I am sure you will correct me if I am wrong, Mr Speaker—that the member for Lindsay was even in the parliament in January 1996, but she achieved it all! Again, let us have some honesty in debate.

The honourable member must get her facts straight. Perhaps she is just a little green. She is very new to the place and perhaps she is overawed by it all. But when she gets up to speak—the same goes for the member for Mitchell, who has experience and should know better—she should at least present the facts which are documented and which have been followed up by press releases and community consultation.

The council in my electorate paid a consultant over $15,000 to prepare a submission on why Badgerys Creek should not take place and, more particularly, a submission to be included in the draft guidelines for the EIS. Are we saying that that council, which is not Labor controlled, got the facts wrong, that the member for Lindsay and the member for Mitchell have their dates wrong, that they must be talking about the wrong year? Why have councils and community groups prepared such submissions if this EIS process is not under way?

It was the Labor government which actually put the wheels in motion. I say to the member for Lindsay and the member for Mitchell that while we have heard about the victors of war—or, in their case, elections—writing their own history, taking such liberties, is beyond the pale. Having so enlightened both members, I look forward to their next contributions on these subjects.

I must admit that when I listened to the minister for transport's second reading speech on the airport bill I had a sense of amusement at first. I thought that he was starting to look a little frayed around the edges. Perhaps he was starting to realise that there was more to his job than cutting ribbons and turning sods of earth. He spoke about the bills currently before the House `substantially' matching those previously put forward by the Labor Party. He spoke about the `decisive' steps that the government had taken to resolve Sydney airport's noise problem. Correct me if I am wrong but, as a Sydneysider and a person who moves around her electorate and the city of Sydney generally, I would say that aircraft noise in Sydney at the moment is worse. It is certainly not better and I totally reject the minister's statement in that regard.

With the changes to remove the Bennelong funnel, something like an extra 142,000 people are now affected by aircraft noise. Why did the government take such an inexplicable path of obstruction in blocking these bills before? They said that the first thing they were going to do was solve Sydney airport's noise problem and open the east‐west runway. The minister has stood up proudly here saying, `We at least met that promise.' But what happened? When we were in government we did not think that submitting another 142,000 people to airport noise was distributing the noise equitably.

The government is very proud that they have opened the east‐west runway. They have sprayed flight paths all over the place. But the minister is saying that he has solved the problem, and he repeated that in question time yesterday. The coalition is really saying that they will stop all the aircraft noise over the seat of Bennelong, the seat of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). That is the problem they have solved. I say to the Prime Minister: it is really great that your party in government supports you to the extent that you now have one of the most self‐serving and base examples of exercising power without conscience. Frank Hardy had it right—the Prime Minister has power without glory.

The good burghers of the North Shore now get to sleep soundly at night. For the residents of Hunters Hill and Lane Cove there is now an `equitable' spreading of aircraft noise across Sydney—read that as meaning no noise for them. I would like to ask the residents of the rest of Sydney, particularly around Kingsgrove and other affected areas, what they think of these new equitable arrangements.

There are a number of other points in this bill that I would like to bring forward. I am particularly concerned by the announcement that a second EIS will be done because the government feels—rightly so, as I have been saying for six years—that the Badgerys Creek proposal might not go ahead so they need the backup of Holsworthy.

They believe that they should not put all their eggs in the one basket. They have to make sure that they have a second option in case the first one fails. I do not believe even the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) would have been surprised, although I doubt that people living in her electorate wouldn't have been blown away by the minister's revelations that we are now going to have an EIS into why Holsworthy should not be considered as an airport.

PARA.BREAK: I believe the member for Hughes, as a member of the Liberal Party, should have reconciled herself long ago—I am glad she is in the House today, because I do feel for her—to the fact that this is how her party operates when it comes to airport policy in Sydney. Whatever side of government, these decisions are made without consultation. Whatever those opposite do—whether they try to change the cognate bills which we had already introduced into the House—they say, `Don't worry, we'll change everything tomor row. We'll make another decision if things do not work out.'

SPEECH.PARA: I have repeatedly wondered what has happened to the member for Hughes. After her election, she must have approached this House with much energy. She had been looking forward, as all of us had, to being a good representative herself for the people of Hughes—the people of her electorate. Now she has been caught up in a political game, and she is miles out of her depth. She has been exposed to that seedy, underhanded side of politics, courtesy of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development and the Prime Minister. My guess is that she would now be extremely disappointed. I am sure that when she has the opportunity she will certainly be saying words like that.

The member for Hughes is either kept in cotton wool in her office—I know that is not the case because I see her working very hard—or she has been instructed by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to keep silent. I can just imagine her saying, `But, Minister, I need to know so that I can talk to my electorate.' These are things we would all say, and it is only right that you say that. But why should you have been told at 8 p.m., the night before it was made public in this House and in this area, that a second EIS was going to be done in Holsworthy when groups in my electorate—because they had a meeting with Mr Wallace, the adviser to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development—were told weeks in advance that it was going to happen? Why were you denied that right?

As the elected member of the Liberal Party representing the electorate of Hughes, why were you denied the information? In my local papers the other day, my airport group, FRAAN, are quoted as saying, `We knew all about it. Didn't the member for Hughes know? We were told when we came in to have a meeting. The minister couldn't see us, but we saw John Wallace and he told us that there is going to be another site under investigation. We came out knowing it was going to be Holsworthy.' Then we found out that the member for Hughes was not even consulted. That is what politics is all about. I believe that members of the Liberal and National parties should hang their heads in shame for denying her that right in government, after winning that seat.

When we, the opposition, first discovered that Holsworthy was going to be considered, I, like everybody else, immediately read the second submission. The first one started in the early 1980s. Finally, after community consultation that went on for something like two to three years, the EIS for Badgerys Creek came out. Prior to that, there was a submission on possible airport sites for the future. As has been mentioned by previous speakers in this House, Holsworthy was certainly the ninth worst. That is why, at that particular time, it was dropped off.

When we raise issues like this in debate, it is our duty to reveal to all Australians that the political ambitions of just a few govern the coalition on airport policy. People need to know that the government's plans for Sydney's airport future are not devised as a result of commonsense management and sensible process; they are arrived at only after a series of merciless power games. Australians—Sydneysiders in particular—need to know that the people involved in these slippery games are the same people presenting these bills before the House. They are the same people who will oversee the passage of this legislation. They are the same people who will control the leasing of our airports. We need to know whether we can trust this government on airports. Can we expect them to do the right thing? On their previous form to date, the answer has to be a resounding no.

The Prime Minister is, to all intents and purposes, willing to have Labor's previous airports policy bills passed now that he has got rid of his `Portnoy's complaint'. The members for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett), Lindsay and Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), led by the equally raw recruit, the Minister for Finance, the member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey), all think they have got a better chance of hanging onto their seats than the member for Hughes. So they are willing to sacrifice her hide to save their own come the next election.

BREAK.PARA: The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has the greasy hypocrisy to drop aircraft noise back on top of the heads of the people living to the east and west of Mascot airport—people who have lived with that steadily growing noise for over the last 20 years—and then says in this House and outside that it is an equitable arrangement. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development are really just trying to paint themselves as generous, open‐minded and sensible thinking politicians.

The Prime Minister portrays himself as the poster boy for honesty and decency in political life. They tell us that they believe in a fair go and that they want to be even‐handed. They remind me of the salesmen you read about in the early western days who raced into town with their coloured vests and had their elixir that was going to fix all the problems. When the townspeople realised that it fixed no problems at all, they hounded the cheap little salesmen out of their towns. This is what will happen with your legislation and statements being made on our airports.

How do the people of Hughes now see the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development? They promised them a better quality of life before the election. Yet they were having their little backroom meetings in which they nodded, winked and did their little secret handshakes, and decided that Holsworthy would be the go once they won office. The people of Hughes, through the member for Hughes, stand betrayed. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development let them plough their savings into new homes. They let them start their children at new schools. They let them start their small businesses, and now they stand revealed. Their facade has now been ripped away.

Unfortunately, it is probably very late for the member for Hughes, who will now have to pay for their deceit. How could anyone believe the Minister for Transport and Regional Development's repeated commitment to Badgerys Creek? Personally, I do not have to tell the House how pleased it makes me. I have been like a drip of water on a rock for the last seven years, and it has been public knowledge that I have opposed Badgerys Creek since 1985. When the minister turns around after giving each of his glowing appraisals of Badgerys Creek and, in the same breath, rattles on about its shortcomings and his lack of faith in the project, quite obviously he is not to be trusted. The thing that really makes me shake my head—I do not know whether it is in delight or in disgust—is how the Minister for Transport and Regional Development can stand at the dispatch box day after day and, with mock solemnity, try to claw back the high moral ground. He has tried to dress down the opposition for not being supposedly bright enough to even run an alternative EIS in Holsworthy from the moment we announced our original EIS of Badgerys Creek in January.

Since the minister began his curious campaign I have had to check Hansard several times to see whether the minister was actually a poultry farmer in private life because he keeps regularly saying, `We are not putting all our eggs in one basket.' I ask the members opposite me to correct me if I am wrong, but I do not seem to remember any mention of an EIS on Holsworthy in the coalition's pre‐election airport policy document Putting people first. If that is the case, then I am wrong. I will admit it, because I reread it last night. So either the minister is trying to disparage Labor for something about which you yourselves even failed to consider—and if this is the case then he is slower than I thought him to be—or it is a pure sign that the Prime Minister and Senator Parer were considering Holsworthy before the election and they just failed to inform the population of Sydney.

What is it to be? Is the minister just simple? Is he slippery or did he only think that all he had to do was get up and make these grand statements and people were going to accept them? Either way I am glad the Labor government was not foolish enough to consider Holsworthy either before or after the election. I say to the House that I am still working on my side in regard to Badgerys Creek because I do not think the answer lays there.

I do not support the government in the way in which it has gone about formulating its policy on Sydney's airport. It has all gone pear‐shaped for the coalition in this respect and as such the situation looks very bleak for Australians and Sydneysiders alike. Just as those opposite have made a habit of blundering in the past, they seem intent on continuing the practice in the future. Adam Smith called man an `animal that bargains'. Unfortunately for the career prospects of the member for Hughes, for the people who live and work—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was astounded by the contribution made by members opposite. I cannot believe that they are getting up in this parliament and speaking about the problems at Sydney airport and the problems that may or may not have occurred at Badgerys Creek. I take up the invitation of the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) to correct her if she is wrong. I am very pleased to do that. First of all, in regards to Putting people first —the coalition's policy on Sydney West airport 29 January 1996—other options are mentioned here, including an aerodrome.
—Where?
—It was mentioned as a possibility. The policy document is in general terms. That is as much as one can expect—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I loathe to do this to the honourable member on his feet. I very succinctly stated that I have read it. I want it spelt out where it was in the policy.
—Order! The honourable member will resume her seat!
—That is all I ask the honourable member to do. Read it out—line by line.
—Order! The honourable member will resume her seat!

—I am astounded by the honourable member's bleatings because this issue of aircraft noise has destroyed the lives of tens of thousands of people in Sydney. You had the opportunity to put forward a policy that would include the opposition at the time to look at a bipartisan approach to the whole issue of aircraft noise. You refused to do that. You were only interested in one thing—the political process that you were determined to pursue to try to ensure that you safeguarded some of the seats that you held then and hold now.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting that when the east-west runway was closed in November 1994 the people who benefited most were the then Minister for Transport, the Premier of New South Wales and the member for Heffron in New South Wales—three Labor held seats and three people with very close connections. Why did the member for Prospect not then get up and say, `Let's be fair dinkum about this. Let's ensure we have a spread of noise.'

I invite the honourable member for Prospect to look at the spaghetti flight patterns over Sydney prior to the closure of the east-west runway in November 1994. Flight paths were all over Sydney—everywhere. After the closure of the east-west runway the flight paths were all concentrated. They were taken away from Labor held seats and concentrated in what was known as the Bennelong funnel.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was quite right and just in saying, `Let's do the decent Australian thing: let's spread the noise; let's spread the pain.' That is what was planned and that is exactly what is occurring. That will bring relief for tens of thousands of Australians who have been subjected to all the noise, not 70 per cent or 80 per cent but 90 per cent of the noise, rendering their lives very hard to cope with.

The other point that the honourable member has raised is in regard to the consultants paid for by her council. I do not know how many councils the honourable member for Prospect has in her electorate but I would suspect it would be more than one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The council in my electorate.
—Which one?
—Fairfield.

—Fairfield council. So the honourable member for Prospect offers the advice that it was one of her councils that paid consultants—her choice of words is very important—to prove that Badgerys Creek was not the right site. I am sure the honourable member for Hughes (Ms Vale), who was in the chamber a few minutes ago, would be very interested to read Hansard . Your council set out to prove that Badgerys Creek was not the right place instead of saying, `Let's look at the impact and let's make sure that—
—It is a Liberal controlled council.

—Well, you raised it today—if the EIS showed that it was not suitable to have an airport built at Badgerys Creek, then that is fine. Why didn't you and the councils then do the right thing and look at whether it is a suitable site to have a second airport? The government you were a part of kept saying, `Fast track Badgerys Creek.' Did the member for Prospect ever get up in this parliament and say, `I disagree with my government?'
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order. I appreciate the question being asked of me. I would refer the honourable member to Hansard . At least on 11 different times—
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will try to stop her constant interjections and the honourable member for Lowe will refer his remarks through the chair.

—The other point that was raised by the honourable member for Prospect is in regard to ownership. I am sure the honourable member has read the minister's second reading speech because she referred to it, but I do not think she has bothered to read the two airports bills in total. Mention is made of ownership. The explanatory memorandum to the bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . each airport will be operated by a separate company, which must not undertake substantial trading or financial activities other than activities related to the development and/or operation of the airport; or activities incidental to this purpose. . .

It goes on to say that there must be majority Australian ownership, a five per cent limit on airline and associated ownership, Commonwealth controls over land use planning and buildings, environmental strategy requirements and financial transparency. That is more than those opposite had said in their policies.

BREAK.PARA: I now come to the bills themselves. I have a particularly strong interest in these bills. The former government, in its dying days in 1995, introduced similar bills with regard to the leasing of the airports. These bills would have seen the leasing of KSA and SWA with no restriction on infrastructure development. In other words, it was going to lease the airports, sell the lease and build right across the east-west runway. That would have meant that the east-west runway would never ever be considered as an option. That was what the people of Sydney were very angry about.

No mention was made in the former government's bill at the time of infrastructure development that would have gone right across the east-west runway. Fortunately, a change of government occurred. That allowed the coalition to set in train our policy on leasing of federal airports.

More specifically as it affects my electorate, the guarantees that were given prior to the election will be and are being acted upon. I will quote from our policy document, which the honourable member for Prospect, who has left the chamber, referred to. She made a lot of interjections but left when I responded. The policy document Putting people first was launched on 29 January 1996, which was, coincidentally, the day after the then Prime Minister called the election. It just so happened that that was the day the then Leader of the Opposition and now Prime Minister launched my campaign in the seat of Lowe. That launch was held at the Fivedock RSL Club. That was when our policy was launched.

This is such an important issue in my electorate, as it is in a lot of other areas. I believe the launching of the policy destined the loss of Lowe which had to occur because the issue of aircraft noise played a very important part in that election. The people of Lowe, in particular the thousands of noise affected residents, read our policy and liked what they read. It gave them hope. We are now delivering on that promise. The policy document states:

We have announced that we will not lease Sydney and Sydney West Airport until there is a satisfactory solution to the current aircraft noise problem in Sydney. The leasing process will be deferred until two conditions are met:
. the east west runway is reopened

A tick for the minister. That was done within eight days of this government being sworn in, despite the fact that we said we would do it in 10 days. He was well ahead of time. The second condition is a very important one; that is, a genuine EIS on Sydney West airport. In fact, as honourable members know, the minister for transport has authorised an additional EIS, as an insurance, in the event that Badgerys Creek is not the right site. The minister has made it very clear in this House on many occasions when the matter has been raised—it is worth repeating—that Badgerys Creek is and continues to be the preferred option for the government.

There are three additional conditions placed, which I list. First, aircraft movements at Kingsford Smith airport are to be limited to 80 per hour. No such assurance was given by those opposite in their policy. The second additional condition is that the lessee of Kingsford Smith airport will not be allowed to undertake major infrastructure developments at KSA that would increase the runway capacity of the airport. Again, those guarantees were not included in the policy of the then government.

Probably the most important of those three conditions is that the lessee will not be allowed to undertake developments that would prevent the full use of the east-west runway. The people of Sydney have learnt a great deal about aircraft noise and about aircraft movements. They have become experts in a very short period of time. They can see through anyone who is trying to pull the wool over their eyes. They saw through the former government. They realised that without the restrictions being placed on infrastructure development at KSA the lessees were going to build and expand and close off the east-west runway as an option forever. That makes three further ticks for the minister for transport.

I turn now to some specific issues contained in the bills that bear highlighting. I am very concerned about the staff currently employed by the FAC. When I first read the bills I was concerned about what was going to happen to the staff in the changeover. The opposition's policy document made no mention of the welfare of the staff. Those opposite claim to represent the workers, the less privileged in the workplace, but they said nothing about the welfare of the staff who are employed in the airport operations. I am very pleased that this bill makes provision to look after those staff. They will be able to transfer to the new airport lessee company without in any way being penalised or downgraded. In other words, in transferring to the new lessee, the airport based staff at the FAC will be able to enjoy the same terms and conditions as those which they currently enjoy.

In addition to the provisions contained in the bill, further controls will be imposed upon the operators of the leased airports. I will detail five provisions in particular that will provide much needed safeguards to not only meet the requirements of the tourism, export and service industries but also protect the interests of the airport users and the local communities. Firstly, the CAA will continue their supervisory role, particularly with regard to standard setting and enforcement. Secondly, the Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995 will remain in place. Thirdly, the federal Department of Transport and Regional Development will continue their role in aviation security controls. Fourthly, the Commonwealth Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act remains in force. Fifthly, the ACCC will administer pricing controls for the airports.

There is only one other issue I would like to address in the short period of time I have left to me, and that concerns the airport master plans. When those opposite were in government they made no provision for any long‐term planning for Sydney airport and Sydney West airport. No business can operate efficiently and effectively without long-term planning. I am very pleased to see that mention is made in these bills for a master plan for Sydney airport and the new airport, whether it be at Badgerys Creek or elsewhere.

The situation as it currently stands is less than satisfactory. I am not in any way, shape or form critical of the staff at the FAC or at Airservices Australia. I do not want to go into any details now, but on a future occasion I will talk about the stress that they were placed under by the former Minister for Transport. A click of the fingers was all that was required from him to virtually change policy and flight plans overnight. The people in this sphere of endeavour, who were working under tremendous stress and strain, had to put up with a very difficult government.

As I have said, I am pleased that there is provision in the bills for long-term planning. I am sure the current airport staff will be relieved to know that they will be able to plan ahead with a degree of certainty, having a plan of action as their guide.

The bills make it mandatory for each and every regulated airport operator to submit for the minister's approval all development plans and environmental strategies before implementation and, just as importantly, after community consultation. As I mentioned earlier, these bills require that operators provide 20‐year long-term airport master plans; environmental impact assessments for all major developments, such as for the increased length of runways or terminal developments; and that they obtain approval for new buildings on airport sites.

These bills, when enacted, will provide the framework for a substantial uplift to the Australian economy and a substantial boost to employment. I urge members opposite to stop playing political games and to support these bills without amendment. Let's get on with the job of providing a top‐class airport system at Sydney airport and at Badgerys Creek, or at any other site after the EIS has been completed. I urge members opposite to support these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). The government's bill contains a proposal for the leasing of airports other than the Sydney airport and the possible Sydney West airport under the government's privatisation program. The government's proposals are similar to those contained in legislation introduced by the previous Labor government in 1995, except that the Labor government bills restricted cross-ownership of airports in Sydney with those in Brisbane and/or Melbourne. Under this current government's proposals, the minister can exempt replacement airport master plans and environmental strategies from the public comment and consultation process. We on this side of the House say that that is something which has the potential for real unfairness.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's bills require, as do the Labor Party's bills, that Kingsford Smith airport and Sydney West airport—should it ever eventuate under this government—be owned by the same entity. When in opposition the Liberal and National parties opposed the Labor government's proposal to lease the airports, pending the reopening of the east-west runway at Sydney.

The opposition's position in proposing these amendments is entirely justified and appropriate, given that the government has not complied with its promises contained in the document Putting people first, the coalition's policy on Sydney airport and Sydney West airport dated 29 January 1996. I note that the previous speaker, the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), commented on that document. What he did not comment on was this passage in the document:

The coalition will continue the existing acquisition and insulation program and will extend it to cover the noise affected areas in the flight paths for the East‐West Runway. We will appoint an independent arbitrator to resolve disputes arising from the scheme.
Indeed, there was a specific admission contained in the document. It continues:

Reopening the East‐West Runway will change the pattern of noise around the airport. We will continue the existing acquisition and insulation program, and extend it to cover the noise affected areas in the east‐west flight path that may qualify under the scheme. If additional funding is required, it will be raised by extending the time period that the aircraft noise levy is imposed at Sydney airport.

There is a further reference to the intention to appoint an arbitrator. The clear and unequivocal fact is that substantial additional funding will be required but has not been forthcoming from the government.

The government boasts of reopening the east‐west runway within eight days rather than 10 working days of coming to office. While they are putting planes over the heads of residents in my electorate, they have allocated not one cent to compensate people or to insulate homes, schools and other buildings. When the task is analysed as to what will be required, one doubts very much whether the government is going to have the strength and commitment to deliver the goods on that promise, which has been ignored to date.

When in government, the Labor government commenced the noise insulation program for homes, schools and businesses under the north‐south runways and committed an amount of $260 million to that task, which was raised by the noise amelioration levy imposed on domestic air travellers. Indeed, the allocation being spent during this current period, 1995‐96, is $105 million. That is an increase of $76.6 million on the amount originally budgeted and it has extended the program to cover noise‐affected areas in accordance with the world's best noise amelioration practices.

As already mentioned, the levy was imposed on jet aircraft using Sydney airport to recover the cost of the noise amelioration program. That has resulted in a levy of approximately $3.40 per jet aircraft passenger landing at Sydney airport. Legislation was introduced as part of the budget to give effect to the levy in 1995 and 1996 and, of the money which is being spent in the current allocation to which I have referred, the breakdown is: schools and colleges, $40 million; other institutions, $15 million; residences, $30 million; property acquisition, $15 million; and program management, $5 million.

That is what the former Labor government did for the areas affected by the north‐south runway. What has this government done to honour its promise to the people affected by the reopening of the east‐west runway? Nothing—it has not offered one cent. The three‐year program commenced by the Labor government is based on a system of first acquiring the worst affected properties under the 40 Australian Noise Exposure Forecast level and then moving out into the less affected areas in an analytical way. That analysis has not even commenced in respect of residents of my electorate.

On 28 May, I received a letter from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to the effect that it is expected that `an initial insulation program' will be able to be put under way in the second half of 1996. Frankly, I will be astonished if anything but a tokenistic attempt is made to insulate homes and schools in the worst affected areas of my electorate. Indeed, as I have mentioned, the government does not have the funds available—which were raised by the noise amelioration levy—to spend on insulating homes in my electorate, because the $260 million allocated by the Labor government has been totally committed to those projects already under way under the north‐south flight paths.

The government's promise to extend the period of the noise amelioration levy will amount to nought. The reason is that the levy and the expenditure have been programmed to 1998. If the government says it is going to extend the period of that levy beyond 1998, it will then start raising money which can be spent on noise amelioration in my electorate of Barton. But what happens in the 2½ years until that period of time locks in? Without a special budgetary allocation, the government has no funds available to insulate homes and buildings and to compensate residents of my electorate, despite its boast of reopening the east‐west runway within eight workings days of coming to office.

To compensate people and insulate homes, schools and other buildings in my electorate it would effectively mean an increase of 59.4 per cent in the current noise amelioration levy, taking the average cost up to about $5.40 per passenger travelling on an aircraft or about $1,000 per passenger jet. The sum is not a trifle. If you talk about figures during the peak movement period, you are looking at anywhere between $50,000 and $80,000 per peak hour being sucked out of our tourist trade as a result of the noise amelioration program. That is an impost which will be aggravated if the government delivers the goods over its promise to residents in my electorate. That additional money will be sucked out of the tourist trade to satisfy the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in respect of his seat of Bennelong and the pressure he is receiving within that seat.

Under the east‐west flight access there are 58,000 people now being affected by the government's decision. There are at least 3,700 homes and at least 58 public buildings which unquestionably require soundproofing. Yet despite flying planes over schools while kids are trying to learn, over the heads of those suffering illness and the elderly in nursing homes and hospitals, and again over the homes of families when parents are trying to put kids to bed of an evening, the government has not done one thing to honour its promise of 29 January to compensate families in Barton and provide noise insulation assistance.

It is not widely known that yesterday the government obtained a legal victory in the Federal Court of Australia in a decision delivered by Justice John Lehane. Normally such a victory would be shouted from the rooftops, but this government is remaining essentially mute on the victory. The reason is that the government cannot be proud of what it has done to the residents of my electorate of Barton and others falling under the east-west flight paths.

Specifically, on 20 March 1996 the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) granted an exemption to the government from the requirements of complying with the administrative procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Specifically, the minister granted the government an exemption from environment protections, including the need for an environmental impact statement, before reopening the east-west runway. Such an exemption was granted, despite the fact that the administrative procedures themselves include a specific direction that the minister shall, in determining whether to exempt a Commonwealth action from all or any of the requirements of the act, have regard to the general principle that it is desirable in the national interest that the requirements of those procedures should, as far as practicable, apply to all Commonwealth actions.

BREAK.PARA: The government succeeded in the Federal Court case on very technical grounds, substantially relating to the difficulty in challenging the exercise of a discretion of a minister of the Crown. It is noteworthy, however, that in exercising his discretion, the Minister for the Environment specifically acknowledged that some other communities in Sydney will be adversely affected by the increase in the use of the east-west runway. In referring to some other communities, he is talking about communities other than those in the Prime Minister's electorate of Bennelong and those falling under the north-south flight path. Further, the minister acknowledged that there will be no assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act of these impacts.

So much for the self-righteous boasts of this government of governing in the interests of all Australians. What happened to the interests of the residents of my electorate of Barton? They were overridden, ignored and eventually discarded by the government. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development stood up here yesterday preaching in self-righteous tones about the environmental impact statements that the government is putting in place for a second time at Badgerys Creek and the new environmental impact statement procedures for this ridiculous proposal at Holsworthy. Indeed, he criticised the former Labor government for an inadequate environmental impact statement prior to opening the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport. That is blatant hypocrisy.

Government ministers use a common language of transparency. The minister's statements to this parliament yesterday were blatantly transparent. They are see‐through hypocrisy because no environmental impact statement procedure was taken at all before opening the east-west runway and so dramatically affecting residents of my electorate of Barton. It is an indication of double standards. When the interests of the residents of the Prime Minister's seat are involved, the minister will bow down to the wishes of the Prime Minister to the detriment of my electors. How dare this government stand up in self-righteous tones and say they are governing in the interests of all Australians!

The decision to reopen the east-west runway is one which cannot be justified on any sane or sensible grounds. It is dramatically affecting and decreasing the ability of the airport to cope with air traffic—hence, the fact that it can only operate during shoulder periods. I view with considerable alarm the minister's new directive that, as from 15 June, planes will be taking off from the western end of the east-west runway and at a point simultaneously landing from the south on the north-south runway. It will quite clearly involve cross-runway operation.

It has not been publicly stated that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has reported that simultaneous operation of runways has not been without incident in the United States. BASI referred to a number of near collisions at Chicago O'Hare airport, which operates such a system. In Australia our position has not been all that different. I should put them on the public record.

On 2 August 1990 a Boeing 747 failed to hold short of runway 7 after landing on runway 37. On 11 August 1990 a McDonnell Douglas DC10 failed to hold short of runway 7 after landing on runway 34. On 18 March 1991 a Boeing 747 landed on runway 34, it appeared that it would not stop before the intersection and a Falcon 900 on runway 25 was instructed to abort its take‐off. On 26 June 1991 a McDonnell Douglas DC10 failed to hold short of runway 25 after landing on runway 34. On 25 July 1991, a McDonnell Douglas DC10 attempted to take off on runway 34 without clearance. There was crossing traffic on runway 25 at the time.

On 12 August 1991 there was a near disaster. That was acknowledged in this parliament and was acknowledged by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. An Ansett aircraft missed a Thai Airways aircraft by simply metres. The Thai aircraft was carrying 185 passengers; the Ansett aircraft, 110 passengers. There is no question that 295 people would have died in that incident if it was not for seconds, if it was not for metres.

I will be carefully monitoring the situation of cross‐runway operations. Should the stupidity continue, after 12 months I will be reporting, regrettably, to this House a number of similar incidents to those I have just read out.

I sincerely trust that these words of mine on this 29th day of May 1996 will not be prophetic. I sincerely trust that a disaster will not occur as a result of the operation of cross-runways at Kingsford Smith airport.

Ultimately, the risk can be removed only by the fast-tracking of a second Sydney airport, which is what the Labor government was doing with Badgerys Creek. This government must be compelled to stop prevaricating. It must immediately cast aside these ridiculous speculations about a second Sydney airport at Holsworthy. That will never occur. They know it will never occur.

The question becomes: when does a decision become a decision become a decision? The Labor government had already set in train the procedures for a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek. That proposal met with the support of government members, and $150 million has already been spent on that task. The Liberal government should stop mucking around and get on with the job. They should be compelled to get on with that job before being able to lease these airports in any way, shape or form. I support the amendment proposed by the shadow minister for transport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I congratulate you on your election to the position of Second Deputy Speaker. I confess to having congratulated in my maiden speech the Speaker on his election. In the context of this debate, I think it is appropriate for me to congratulate one other person, whom I neglected to mention at that time. I refer to an individual who did more for the cause of the coalition in the last election than did perhaps anyone, except for the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: This is an individual who, on virtually every issue he touched in public life, had the effect of causing literally thousands—perhaps hundreds of thousands—of former ALP voters to flood over to the coalition. This was a person whose contribution was so substantial that I suspect there are a number of members in the House at the moment who may not have been here if it was not for him. I refer to the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton).

Wherever I went in the election campaign, and wherever I had to deal with an issue for which the member for Kingsford‐Smith had responsibility—whether it was industrial relations, civil aviation or transport—I found support for the coalition growing. If I walked into a civil aviation hangar and mentioned the member's name, I found that the industry representatives there would have the instinctive reaction to reach into their back pockets and start writing out cheques for my campaign. That is because of the record of this government, particularly on aviation and on the issue of Sydney's second airport.

It is very seldom that a democratic government gets 10 years to implement a major infrastructure project. With the ebb and flow of the democratic process, the comings and goings of government, it is often difficult to maintain momentum on a project such as an airport. But let us not forget that the former government had 10 years since the draft EIS for Badgerys Creek was released in 1985 to do something about it. The previous speaker concluded with this admonition: when is a decision a decision; and when is this government going to get on with doing something about this problem?

When a new government comes in it is almost a tradition in the House to have a fair bit of rhetoric exchanged about the deficiencies of the preceding government. But I suggest that this is an issue on which there is not mere rhetoric. I suggest that the handling of Sydney's second airport has been close to a national disgrace.

I would like to mention the contributions to this debate of a couple of previous speakers. The member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) spoke of the need for a spirit of consultation. He was critical of this government for its lack of consultation since coming into office. Also, I would like to refer to the comments of Holroyd City Council on the subject of consultation. In a letter that was sent to me by that council, the general manager, reflecting on the previous government's record on Badgerys Creek, states:

BREAK.PARA: The council believes that a royal commission should be held into the whole process of the public administration involved in the selection and development of the Badgerys Creek airport in view of the lack of public consultation and information made available to the people of western Sydney about flight paths, noise contours and height. The council is very concerned about the lack of public consultation and in particular delay in providing details of the flight paths for public comment originally scheduled for December 1995.

Flight paths are, of course, the nub of the issue in an election context. It is the time when a decision becomes a decision. It is when the government is prepared to put a line on a map and say, `That is where the planes are going to go.'

Here we are, 10 years after the original EIS and three months out from an election, and the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith could not provide the residents of western Sydney with a decision on flight paths for the airport. This was a government which committed $150 million in funds to build the garage, but they told the whole of Sydney that they have no idea where the driveway is going.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have been impressed by the guts of members on the other side who have stood up to defend their government's position with such alacrity, but I suggest that if we went through the whole record of public administration by various governments since Federation we would have to go a long way before finding such a complete failure of leadership by any government. That failure of leadership was in part caused by the fact that the previous government had fouled its own nest. It had poisoned the community decision making environment within which it was then forced to act. I am referring to the process under which the EIS for the third runway at Kingsford Smith was undertaken. This began the process of alienation of the electorate in Sydney from the former government.

I would like to refer to some comments following the inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney entitled Falling on deaf ears. In doing so, I note the fact that these are not self‐serving expressions of interest by a few local noise‐affected residents; this is not a coalition party committee of sectarian, interested individuals, but this is a committee of the Senate of this parliament. Reflecting on the EIS process for the third runway, the committee said that the process lacked evidence and there was an absence of any real independent input. The committee said it was concerned by the lack of any monitoring process concerning outcomes. The committee said that the EIS had used selective data to substantiate the claim that only 14 per cent of flights would be to the north and, wrapped up into one very telling sentence, the committee said that the EIS was in many respects `an advocate's document prepared to achieve a predetermined result'.

That is the sort of leadership, the sort of public administration, which characterised the previous government's efforts throughout this process from the beginnings of that EIS in 1985. For further authority to support that proposition, I cite none other than the present member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who on 6 June 1994 told this parliament:

Anyone who has followed the debate about airports in Sydney, both at Mascot and at Badgerys Creek, would understand that policy has been geared to the needs of a rather self‐serving centralised bureaucracy instead of the public interest.

That is not my opinion; that is the opinion of the member for Werriwa, who now puffs and spurts and beats his chest with such ferocity on this subject before this House. But he makes some very telling points—that is, that the previous government had entirely lost control of the agenda in relation to the construction of Sydney's second airport; that their policy was not serving the public interest but serving a centralised bureaucracy; and that the minister in charge in fact had lost control of the levers and was being dictated to rather than dictating—and the results of that failure of leadership, that loss of control, are there for all to see.

I rise to oppose the amendment moved by the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). While I am a strong advocate of the need for greater infrastructure in western Sydney, this is simply an example of those people who no longer have responsibility for making decisions having the luxury to stymie them. It is just another request for delay and another request for running down a side alley, a sidetrack. It is another barrier put in the way of resolving this issue.

I want to congratulate the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) in the new government, who has been decisive, who has been very clear, and who is now providing real leadership on this issue. I think that the people of western Sydney can now at least look forward to independence in the EIS process. They can look forward to a genuine process of consultation and, more than anything else, they can look forward to a process which does not involve a predetermined outcome. We are saying to the community that we recognise that, 10 years after the original EIS, things have changed. I note the metropolitan air quality study, and I am very conscious that it states that the highest incidence of asthma in Sydney is in western Sydney. The constituents in my electorate are not merely concerned about aircraft noise; they are also concerned about air quality.

I am not saying that the airport must not be built at Badgerys Creek at any cost; I am simply saying that, after 10 years of mismanagement, indecision and equivocation, we are forced to revisit the issue and put in place a process which will genuinely respond to the needs of the people of western Sydney and to the needs of the aircraft industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a number of remarks this morning about the government's airport bills which are before the House, particularly the legislation which proposes to lease a number of airports around the country. Before I get into the detail of the legislation before the House, I would like to express a few concerns about the government's recently announced decision to consider Holsworthy as an alternative site for Sydney's second international airport. A number of members have quite rightly made the point that they have been looking for a site for Sydney's second airport now for 40 or more years. Many governments have sought to grapple with the issue, and I think the closest opportunity Australia has ever had to lock in that site was the former government's decision to proceed with Badgerys Creek.

BREAK.PARA: I am a little bit confused at how quickly the government has latched on to the Holsworthy site as its alternative to Badgerys Creek. The reason I am a little bit confused as to why the government has decided to give serious consideration to Holsworthy is that, as I understand it, it was about second last on the list of 10 sites that was last considered in a formal process in 1985 and 1986. If I remember rightly, the last two sites—the two sites that were at the top of that list of consideration—were not Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy but Badgerys Creek and Wilton.

The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) is currently using the argument that Sydney desperately needs a second site for our second international airport and that, as a result, he was not prepared to consider sites which would require acquisition of private land. He used that excuse as the reason why the government was not giving further consideration to Williamtown, Richmond or a series of other sites and that, because the site at Holsworthy was owned by the Department of Defence, the federal government, it naturally stood out as the reserve site after Badgerys Creek. That ignores the fact that Wilton was the alternate site for Badgerys Creek and that the land at Wilton is owned by the New South Wales government; it is not privately owned.

The so-called justification argument, which the Minister for Transport and Regional Development is using to suddenly pluck Holsworthy out from second last on the list and place it second highest on the list, simply falls down. I just find it hard to believe that, following a few private meetings between the current Prime Minister, Mr Howard, the then spokesman on aviation policy, Senator Parer, and some private developers in some meetings, we are unable to find out what arguments persuaded the Liberal Party to adopt Holsworthy as its secret second option for Sydney's second international airport. As days go by, I think the information will come out, and we will find out why the government has made this very strange decision to take the site that was second lowest on the list of 10 and place it second on the list for consideration as the airport site.

The legislation which is before the House at the moment seeks to outline a process whereby we will move from having government owned airports to a series of airports which will be privately leased. The former government made a strong commitment towards moving in this direction, but under some very strict conditions. We wanted to make sure that there was competition in the ownership of the leases, and the way we sought to ensure that was to have a cross‐ownership limit of only 15 per cent between people who might be investing in Sydney, Sydney West and the other major airports such as Melbourne and Brisbane. In that way we were trying to ensure that, even if we got a lower price, we were getting at least two major owners of airports in Australia providing some tension on prices and services that were offered to the community.

This had strong support particularly from the people in Victoria because for a long time they believed, rightly or wrongly, that Tullamarine airport had not had as much money spent on it as they believed it deserved. Many people involved in the tourism industry in Victoria were quite looking forward to having a Victorian consortium own Tullamarine. They believed that that would have resulted in additional capital funds being committed to Tullamarine, which would have improved facilities for visitors and the tourism industry in that state.

Last night we had the quite amazing remarks made by the Victorian Premier. He has woken up to the fact that the government, having reopened the issue of where Sydney's second airport should be, has generated a great deal of difficulty for itself. Because the government has stated that Badgerys Creek is no longer the preferred site for Sydney's second airport—Badgerys Creek is no longer the site at which the second international airport is going to be built—the government can no longer proceed with the leasing of Sydney and Sydney West. The reason that is a difficulty is that the current government has advice from BZW stating that, unless you lease the biggest, the busiest and the most profitable airport—that is Kingsford Smith, obviously—you will end up getting a lower total price, a lower return to the taxpayer.

My understanding is that BZW estimated that the taxpayer would be $200 million worse off if Melbourne, Brisbane and the others were leased before the biggest, the busiest and the most profitable airport was leased—and that is Sydney. The government argues that they have overcome that difficulty by abolishing the cross-ownership provisions and that, as a result, they will be able to allow people to bid now for Melbourne and Brisbane and that, at a later date, when they have made their decision about the second international airport for Sydney, the same people will be able to also bid for Sydney and Sydney West.
This is the problem that Jeff Kennett sees with that proposal. Last night, at a National Farmers Federation function, he said:
