. . . if, as I hear, there is a potential that Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne might all be able to be sold to the one purchaser, then we are going to have no competition whatsoever and we are going to transfer a government monopoly, in terms of FAC, into a private monopoly situation. And if we're serious about agriculture and we're serious about transporting fresh food or manufactured products, then we've got to have among those airports a competitive environment. And it is just no value at all to any of us to see them sold off to one potential buyer.

That is the view of the second most important Liberal politician in Australia. The Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, says that he does not want to simply transfer a government monopoly into a private monopoly because of the concern that the new private monopoly owner would, of course, maximise their company's profits by jacking up the cost of using airports.

This will ultimately mean that people who want to transport freight and people who want to create jobs will be unable to do so because the prices charged will be too high and tourists who want to use the airports in Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne will be slugged with higher air charges—higher ticket prices. That is why Jeff Kennett went on record last night stating that he opposes this Liberal government's abolition of those cross‐ownership limits—the former Labor government's attempts to make sure that there are at least two owners of airports in Australia; something which is crucial.
I was also intrigued—and I am sure you will enjoy this, Mr Deputy Speaker—by what an ABC reporter stated in an interview with Jeff Kennett. The reporter said:
When a spokesman for the Premier was asked if Mr Kennett had raised his concerns about the airport sell-off with the Federal Government before making his speech, the answer was: Why should he?

So even Jeff Kennett's spokesman says that there is no point whatsoever in bothering to tell this Minister for Transport and Regional Development in advance that he is going to launch a massive assault on the whole philosophy behind the government's proposals to lease the airports. The response is: why should he? Why should he bother to tell the minister for transport his views on these issues?

We turn then to some of the arguments that have been put forward by those who seek to move towards looking at this alternative site at Holsworthy. Under the former government, as I mentioned, we had a commitment to build Badgerys Creek. Yes, we did have a commitment to make sure we went through a proper environmental impact statement—one that had proper community consultation and one that the member for Chifley (Mr Price), and other members who represent western Sydney, persuaded the previous government should be comprehensive and should investigate all of the issues that needed proper study. That would then have ensured that the owners or the lessees of Sydney West would have had very strict environmental conditions placed on them. That might have required additional capital expenditure at Badgerys Creek, but all of the effort put into developing Badgerys Creek would have been put to good use.

The taxpayers have spent over $150 million in acquiring land at Badgerys Creek. The previous government made a massive commitment to ensuring that the infrastructure was there for the opening of the Sydney West airport. I can detail that for you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In last year's budget, there was a commitment of $260 million just for roadworks for Sydney West. Two hundred million dollars was allocated for the Prestons to Cecil Park part of the western Sydney orbital. Also, another $60 million was allocated to upgrading Elizabeth Drive to four‐lane arterial road standard, which would have been the access road to Badgerys Creek airport, the Sydney West international airport. That funding would have ensured that the road links were up and running. That would have provided the infrastructure that was needed for Sydney West when it was opened for the Olympics.

All of that has been swept aside and placed at risk. We will be watching very closely whether that funding, those commitments in the forward estimates in last year's budget, will be there come 20 August. We will be watching very closely to see whether this government is cutting back the funding for upgrading the roads in western Sydney, which is not just going to help Sydney West airport but going to improve the whole of the road infrastructure in the western suburbs of Sydney. We also made a commitment with the New South Wales government to fund the design work for the rail link, and we also made a commitment to ensure that the New South Wales government and the federal government would meet the cost of that rail link.

We should compare that with the position in which the government has now placed us where we do not even know whether Badgerys Creek is going to be the site for the second international airport for Sydney. We are almost back where we were throughout all of those 40 years of arguments about where the second site for Sydney's airport should be, and it is all because the Liberal Party is arguing that we have to desperately make a decision now.

While it was okay for Mr Howard to delay and interfere with the lease process in the last parliament, this government cannot afford to have a further delay of more than a few months because it is going to throw their whole process in doubt. If it was okay for the Liberal and National parties to delay the lease process in the last parliament, why can't they wait until we get a decision on whether the new airport in Sydney is going to be at Badgerys Creek, at Holsworthy or at another place?

If we wait that long, then you can do as BZW recommended. You can lease Sydney first, as a result of which you will maximise the return for the taxpayer, and you can keep the cross-ownership rules and make Jeff Kennett happy. You can make sure that you can have at least two owners and provide some competition for people. In that way, if the government simply delayed the decision on the leasing of these airports until we finished the EIS process and we knew where the second international airport would be, you would be able to make sure that Sydney was the first cab off the rank. In that way you make sure that you are maximising the price, the return to taxpayers.

Of course, this will be the first occasion when the government has to make a choice between encouraging competition, getting the money from privatisation or a leasehold contract, and getting that money as soon as possible. This will not be the first occasion when the government is going to have to make this choice between getting the most competitive environment for an industry or getting the money as soon as it can. It is going to happen in Telstra and in many other areas. In the first test between competition and the money, this government fails. This government does not do what Jeff Kennett recommended and go for a competitive ownership regime to keep the prices low. This government votes for wanting the money as soon as possible before there is a decision on all of these issues.

Despite the reference in the minister's second reading speech to the new lessees of the airports being subject to a price cap mechanism or a price ceiling—a CPI minus X formula was the way the minister referred to it—I cannot find any reference in these bills to the new CPI minus X formula which is going to be established. I am a little bit confused as to why the way the regulations will work is not explained in the legislation that is before the House.

That is going to be a crucial issue for the Australian tourism industry. The tourism industry know that ultimately they and the freight industry will be the ones paying the bills. They will be the ones paying the prices which are extracted by the lessees of the new airports. If you had at least two owners, there would be some guarantee to the tourism industry that there would be some tension on prices, that there would be some competition. But, under the proposal that is now before the parliament, the government is quite prepared to have one consortium own all of the major airports in Australia.

Ultimately that means the freight industry and the people who travel, international and domestic tourists, will be those paying higher prices. Ultimately that means we will have fewer people employed in the tourism industry. You will have fewer jobs and less investment if the prices are that much higher. So, for all of those reasons, we are really quite concerned about the impact that this bill will have on the Australian tourism industry and employment in that industry.

One of the other areas that causes us to be concerned is the way that the Holsworthy proposal was kept secret during the election campaign. We know that there were secret meetings between the Prime Minister, the aviation spokesman, Senator Parer, and the developers. In response, the Prime Minister said, `Laurie Brereton's staff'—that is, the staff of the member for Kingsford‐Smith—`were also briefed by the same developers, the same consortium.'

Yes, they may have briefed the previous government, but the essential difference is that we rejected their proposal. We told them we thought Badgerys Creek was Sydney's preferred site for the second international airport. What did the Liberal and National parties say when the current Prime Minister and the aviation spokesman met them? They said that they would give it consideration. The Labor Party said it would reject it, but they said they would give it consideration.

I have no problem with that, but why could the Prime Minister not make it clear to the Liberal candidate in Hughes or to the electors of Hughes when he was there campaigning for the Liberal Party that there was a possibility of Sydney's second international airport being built at Holsworthy? Why could the Prime Minister not let the electors and the people who live near Holsworthy into his confidence and tell them that the place they had selected to build their new home might be underneath the flight path for a new international airport?

We can understand the outrage of the residents in places like Wattle Grove, of people who have taken out mortgages and purchased homes in a new suburb they thought was going to be nowhere near the flight paths for Kingsford Smith, Badgerys Creek or any other airport that was under consideration. Out of the blue the government has announced that Holsworthy is being seriously considered.

For all of these reasons we think there are real question marks over this. There are also question marks on other more basic grounds, not just that the government deceived the electors of Hughes and that the project does not make sense. The Holsworthy site has 60‐metre ravines in it, which will cost a fortune to fill. The Holsworthy site has unexploded ordnance scattered all over it. There are also other difficulties with the Holsworthy site. They will have to relocate the existing Department of Defence facilities from Holsworthy. All these reasons mean it will be a very expensive site.

I ask again: why was the second site on the list of 10 back in 1986, Wilton, not given some consideration by the government? Wilton is owned by the New South Wales state government. There is no private land involved in the Wilton development. For the life of me, I just do not understand why the government has chosen the second lowest site on the list of 10 rather than the second highest site, Wilton. On this side of the House we think that, having spent $150 million of taxpayers' money acquiring land in Badgerys Creek, this parliament and this government should remain committed to the Badgerys Creek proposal while at the same time conducting a full environmental impact statement that examines all these issues.

For all these reasons we think this legislation is quite ill founded. We think that Jeff Kennett is right when he says that it is a great mistake to transfer a government monopoly into a private monopoly by walking away from the cross-ownership rules that the former government proposed. We do not believe that this legislation should be before the House until the EISs are completed. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware from the list, I have entered this debate only after hearing the sorts of contributions that have been made in this House on an issue which truly should be bipartisan. After 15 years, it would not be a bad idea if we actually gave New South Wales and, more importantly, Sydney a second airport. Maybe we should all be trying to get together to give it the best possible service that is available considering all the factors.

SPEECH.PARA: It is just outrageous to think that the whole issue has been one of politics for the last 13 or 14 years. Unlike the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), I have been here during that period and seen it all. I remember the day that Wal Fife, our then minister, came into the old House and made the commitment to build an additional runway at Sydney airport—not where it is now but in a position that on good advice we considered would create fewer difficulties for the people of Sydney. Immediately upon election, the Labor government knocked that on the head.

That was their choice, but what did they do about a solution? Nothing. They talked up this site. They talked up that site. They talked about Badgerys Creek. Eventually, we reached a situation where aircraft were stacked up over Sydney airport for up to half an hour and public pressure was such that they broke an election promise which resulted, amongst other things, in the resignation of one of their ministers and in their deciding to build the runway. They put it in the wrong place. They even put a hotel at the end of it just to make it a bit more difficult to get in there. But they did it, and it is too little too late.

BREAK.PARA: Instead of going to the experts and asking, `How do we now manage the corridors, the departures, the arrivals and everything?' they said, `Let's go to the world and see how others do it.' I will come back to this point. I landed at Hong Kong airport the other night and in the time that it took my plane to taxi to the terminal I heard three other aeroplanes land. Okay, I would not say that we exactly want what Hong Kong has at the moment in terms of public nuisance, but the point I make is there is so much expert opinion around the world.

I have sat at Denver airport in Colorado and watched the snow ploughs go up and down between the landings. The world is there to help us on that issue. Managing the corridors, et cetera, was not their criteria. Their criteria for departures and arrivals seemed to be based on Laurie saying: `How much can I punish Liberal voters? How can I make sure the noise goes over only the Liberal electorates?' That is pretty silly.

Of course we should have continued to use the east-west runway. A near collision at Sydney basically had nothing to do with visibility or anything. I have had direct advice on that matter. The fact was that the captain of the plane that was landing saw the other plane coming up. He knew it was there, knew it was going to cross his runway, so he took control of the aircraft and said to his copilot, who was actually managing the landing, `I'm in control.' In other words, he said, `I will fly around.' The copilot forgot to take his hands away from the joystick sufficiently, and that created the problem. I know you try to protect yourself in those situations, and fortunately there was not a crash, but a new instruction came out as to how to manage these fly‐by‐wire aeroplanes so that did not happen again.

Just because of a near miss, the entire process of giving Sydney a second airport was put on hold. The previous speaker, who was a minister, told us how much the former government had spent on Badgerys Creek. They bought some land and they budgeted some money. But they were always budgeting money that they did not spend. They were always selling something three budgets in a row and counting the revenue so they could trumpet their deficit position. They never stopped doing that. But all they ever did in 13 years with respect to this matter was buy the land. And then they did not buy enough for a buffer zone. Everyone has rushed out there to buy land to be close to the airport—they always do, and then they complain about it.

Now you are in opposition are you going to give Sydney another airport or are you going to give people a scare campaign? For goodness sake, let's settle down and ask ourselves a few questions about how we can resolve the problem.

I come from Western Australia and I do not know what we are worrying about. We have an airport that was well designed when we were a little town. I live 2½ minutes car drive from the domestic terminal. I am not inconvenienced by the airport at all because of the good design criteria in the first place. All the land is purchased for both ends of what will eventually be a parallel runway system, with an industrial zone at one end and a rural zone at the other. On the sides we have a residential zone. There is a maximum of public convenience and a minimum of public nuisance. I am not saying there is no nuisance—there is—but it is minimised.

We have such an opportunity at the moment. It appears that you have left Badgerys Creek too late to apply those two criteria. It is 40 miles from Sydney with no electric trains and no roads. It was an idea to have something a bit closer to Sydney so we started looking for options. Amongst those options is Holsworthy, a huge area of land, some hundreds or maybe thousands of hectares—I have only seen it on a map—which is very long in the direction in which the runways would operate.

But the opposition wants to tell us about unexploded ordnance. I drew that to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) and he drew it to the attention of the House yesterday. The electorate of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has a large ex‐military firing range in its heartland, currently almost entirely covered with houses and business premises. A company with which I am associated owns one of those business premises. We have not been blown up yet. The heavy foot of our overweight Leader of the Opposition tramped the whole area campaigning and he did not set one bomb off.

The reality is that the area was all cleaned up. I would not be surprised if the Leader of the Opposition gave the order for the clean‐up when he was Minister for Defence. So why talk about it? People are living on top of a military range in the Leader of the Opposition's electorate. Of course it can be cleaned up. As the Minister for Defence quite properly told us, there is always a minor risk but, since it is considered reasonable to have people living on top of a military range in the electorate of the Leader of the Opposition, why is there a scare campaign?

If we put that matter aside, what other fundamental reasons are there to stop such a project? Is it the construction problem? There are some mountains and ravines but they are not all that big. If you drive up the Pacific Highway—an area known to you, Mr Deputy Speaker—you will see the cut and fill. That is just a construction task. If you have a hill here and a ravine there, you do not have to cart the dirt very far to fill the ravine.

I had the privilege of seeing the new airport being constructed in Hong Kong. If you think we have problems, you should look at what Hong Kong is having to do. You want to ask yourselves how six million people can sort it all out in a matter of four or five years, particularly when the project required negotiations with the Chinese government, which were more difficult than anything else.

Hong Kong has an infrastructure problem. They have had to build a suspension bridge longer than the Golden Gate Bridge just to get to the airport, which, of course, is on an island that they had to build to accommodate it. We are talking about six million people. There is not much difference between the population of Sydney, if they had to build it themselves, and the population of Hong Kong.

The construction problem of a few hills and a few ravines is sometimes simpler than the construction problem of undulating land which, I understand, is the problem at Badgerys Creek. Cut and fill is a straight‐out engineering challenge. It all comes down to how much it is going to cost.

As I understand the two propositions—I am not arguing for either; I am just trying to put some fundamental issues before us—one, Holsworthy, already has basic transport infrastructure. The Hong Kong people are not saying that their airport costs a certain amount because that is what it costs to build an airport; they are saying that their airport costs a certain amount because they have to build this huge airport infrastructure to get there.

When you build a new airport the total cost is not the only consideration. Badgerys Creek cost $150 million for the land—a big cost—but there is not enough land for an adequate buffer zone. We have the land at Holsworthy for nothing and we have an adequate buffer zone, from what I can see on the map. It depends where you locate the runways but, surely, if it costs a little more to locate the runways dead centre so that there is minimum inconvenience to the people at each end, we should spend the money and take that into account in the assessment. That is all we are doing. But when it comes to taking the assessment into account, and we add up the total cost, we add the convenience and nuisance factors because they are relevant. Why wouldn't you consider the site when in this modern day and age you can clean up the ordnance problem and do the necessary construction? It is only a matter of what it might cost as against the outcomes.

I have owned an earthmoving company, and to suggest that a 60‐foot ravine is a real problem in this day and age is ridiculous. You want to go up to the great mines of the Pilbara to see how they can dig holes and fill them in again. But that is just part of the problem. There are problems wherever you go. If you want to put up two or three other options—I do not know what it would cost to do that—do it so that we have a genuine solution as quickly as possible.

I have heard the minister say, `We'll keep looking at Badgerys Creek. We think the momentum has been lost because of inadequate original planning. We'd like a fall‐back position.' On the face of it—I have only looked at a map—there are some substantial

arguments on the basis of convenience and minimisation of public nuisance that might come out very positively for Holsworthy. As the previous speaker said, if there were some other site that should be considered on that test, we will talk about it. I do not mind. There is a limit as to how many sites we can talk about. We do not get EISs for the cost of a postage stamp.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the original one.

—As I understand, the original one is Badgerys Creek. That is still the preferred option. But is it the best option? Perth airport is right in the heart of Perth, yet it is not a substantial nuisance. It operates 24 hours a day. I live 2½ minutes away and I am not inconvenienced. I know that is not the total situation; I do not want to say it is. Let us cut out the scare campaigns and the politics. Let us sit down and discuss the problem of Sydney needing another airport. I am not sure that an airport 40 miles away is the solution. I am not sure that the fact that insufficient land was purchased for an adequate buffer zone will ever address the nuisance problem. Let someone else tell us that. I do not want to be the arbiter of that.

BREAK.PARA: We should not be talking about ordnance disposal and earthmoving. They are part of the problem and must be considered on a relative basis, whatever the options are. If you do not have to provide a new road and rail link, for the same money you can do an awful lot of earthmoving. It all has to come together in one price. Then we must take into account the fundamentals of convenience and nuisance—one is positive, one is negative—and we have to try to balance those. Let that be the focus of the debate, not whether there is a particular electorate that is more inconvenienced than another, nor whether Labor voters are going to be inconvenienced more than Liberal voters.

PARA.BREAK: My view is we should do our very best to inconvenience nobody. But, on the other hand, if we do not build another airport for Sydney, we can see what might happen to Sydney. Jeff Kennett has some worries about competition, but he must be laughing his head off when he compares what New South Wales is doing with Melbourne's well‐located air port, which is basically available for 24‐hour operation. History around the world—particularly in major American areas—shows that, where a particular airport was not speedily developed, another town has achieved massive growth and become the centre for business. These are the sorts of issues that I ask the House to consider.

BREAK.PARA: I am truly disappointed when I hear the debate as it is running—all about `My dad can beat your dad'—when there is a serious issue that has to be addressed. I congratulate the minister and do that without any great political emphasis. He stood up and said, `Badgerys Creek will proceed. There are now perceived problems with it, and I have heard them from members of the Labor Party. We don't want to wait until we're told it's no longer a goer and then have to start again.' He has put up Holsworthy. I do not know how many EISs we can have running concurrently, but he has certainly come up with an alternative. On the map, Holsworthy appears to be closer to Sydney with existing transport infrastructure. As somebody who knows a bit about earthmoving, I do not know that those difficulties are as big as have been posed. I will wait and see. But let us get down to the practicalities and fix the situation for Sydney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on these airports bills to express my concern about one particular element which may have an impact on my constituents. I know other members share concern about these changes to the previous government's bill. There is provision by the coalition government for the minister to exempt replacement airport master plans and environmental strategies from public comment and the consultation process. That clearly fails to adequately safeguard the public interest and is one of the reasons we have objections to these bills.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) is currently reassuring people by saying that the application of this exemption will be limited, there is no guarantee of that and it does not preclude a wider interpretation of the legislation at a later date. I know that people in my electorate will be alarmed by the prospect of there being no proper environmental impact of this kind. Experience in my own electorate with Jandakot airport extension plans clearly demonstrates the need for public interest to be given much greater priority in airport planning and management.

Jandakot is one of the busiest general aviation airports in Australia. It had more than 371,000 aircraft movements in 1994‐95 and that figure is increasing rapidly. It was once a sparsely populated semi‐rural area but is now encircled, given growing residential development in Perth, by substantial developments. Aircraft noise has become a problem for many residents, particularly with recent expansion of flying colleges for overseas pilots who do their circuit training over the residential area. There is nothing designed to drive people madder than circuit training. I get a lot of complaints and I am sure other members—particularly the member sitting opposite, the member for Tangney (Mr Williams)—do too.

The airport's management proposes to expand the airport with a fourth runway which will take its capacity up to 500,000 movements per annum. That will spray those planes all over the surrounding suburbs. Not surprisingly, it has outraged residents who are experiencing adverse noise levels even at current capacity. The Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency assessed the FAC's environmental impact statement for the runway and made a number of observations, including:

Discussions . . . have revealed fundamental differences over the interpretation of the aircraft noise impacts of current and future use of the airport . . . we believe that the current level of information is insufficient to enable an adequate assessment of the noise issue.
This is not just a problem for Jandakot; it is a problem as to how well noise impacts are tolerated by residents. CEPA went on to say:
. . . we believe there is a need for further investigation of the noise issue and suggest that an independent survey and analysis be conducted.

I have to say that the Federal Airports Corporation was very resistant to taking any account of residents' concerns and particularly to take the advice of CEPA. I am very worried by proposals that I hear emanating from the government that the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, CEPA, may well be disbanded so this sort of advice would not be available to local residents in the future.

As minister at the time, I obtained my own advice on the issue from the Australian Hearing Services in early 1985 because of that resistance by the Federal Airports Corporation. The Australian Hearing Services, too, raised serious concerns about shortcomings in previous studies and recommended, as CEPA had done, further survey and analysis. I would like to point out that the Federal Airports Corporation, I think it is fair to say, had a fairly poor relationship with local residents. That meant that any study it commissioned on its own behalf, as part of its own environmental obligations, was bound to be viewed with considerable scepticism.

I, too, along with residents, would have preferred an independently commissioned study of the noise impacts, especially with the proposed fourth runway, with residents' inputs to the design of that study to give the community much greater confidence in its findings. Frankly, they got to the point where they did not trust the corporation at all and were likely to view any of its findings with considerable scepticism.

However, I was finally reassured that the terms of the FAC commissioned study and its findings would be closely scrutinised by the Department of Transport, CEPA and the Australian Hearing Services—an unfortunate outcome in lots of ways but a necessary one. At this point the social survey component of the study, which looks at the impact on residents as well as the measured noise levels, should be close to conclusion.

As the local member, although now in opposition, I will be making sure that those commitments are met. The problem has not, however, gone away. If we are going to abolish the need to do these sorts of surveys, we will be placing a great many people at risk, not just in the Sydney area but right around the country including my own electorate.

In February this year, in recognition of those continuing problems, the federal Labor government committed itself to a series of very practical measures to alleviate the noise impact, which we already know is substantial. That was to establish a weekend curfew on all training activities after dusk, to introduce a 9 p.m. curfew for circuit training flights on weekdays, to recommend against the development of the fourth runway because there were proposals for another runway in the northern suburbs of Perth, and to seek a report on the scope for removing noisy aircraft types from training activities. A lot of these aircraft have no muffling at all and they are extremely loud when flying at low altitude.

The coalition appeared to make similar undertakings to residents—and I say `appeared' because it was not clear at all that it meant to follow them through—and the terms were very vague. It was designed just to win the election, the coalition thought—something it has done in other cases. At the same time, I now understand it was privately reassuring the Royal Aero Club and the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association that it would not really be making any changes. So no doubt the coalition will renege on its promises to residents. The member for Canning (Mrs Johnston), the member for Tangney, in particular, and Senator Ian Campbell, who has been involved in this issue, will be very closely observed by me to see that they follow through with at least the spirit of their commitments in relation to the people who live near Jandakot airport.

I must say I am pleased that the state government, in its planning for a second general aviation airport in Perth, has finally agreed to establish a bipartisan ministerial task force to look at this issue to examine options for sites in the northern suburbs. This should ensure that the sorts of problems that are being encountered at Jandakot are not replicated elsewhere. I think that is absolutely critical. In the long term, it should also alleviate some of the traffic pressure at Jandakot.

I think one of the problems with this whole debate about where to site airports is that the argument is often advanced that residents, particularly in the case of Jandakot, knew that the airport was there before they moved into the area and they were foolish to do so. Certainly they did know of the existence of the airport, but no‐one could have predicted the very dramatic growth in the number of aircraft movements. There have been significant changes over and above just the simple increase in population and industry. There have been those big aircraft training schools. No-one understood, either, the significant change in the nature of the aircraft using the airport.

In any case, that is not an argument for not addressing the problem. People still have rights. They still deserve to have their amenities protected. Similarly, those affected have been labelled—sometimes, I must say, by the Federal Airports Corporation itself—as a noisy minority who want the airport closed. I have not found that to be their view. In my experience of the residents, they have recognised the value to the local economy of the 70 businesses and the hundreds of jobs associated with the airport. They just want a fair go. Again, calling them a noisy minority who moved there knowing the airport was there is no argument for failing to develop measures to ameliorate the noise impact on residential areas.

I think in this area, as in others, there is always room for compromise and agreement. We need a decent good‐neighbour policy from all of our airports around Australia. There is no real desire, as I have seen it, on the part of the Federal Airports Corporation, particularly in Perth, to consider the community interest and to develop a good‐neighbour policy. They have basically tried to brush aside the concerns of the residents as unreasonable. Indeed, the FAC has resorted to issuing legal threats to residents on a number of occasions. You would have to say that has not been a stunning public relations success.

In my view, it is essential that the public interest—and that means proper consultation—is clearly enshrined in the legislation. The community will undoubtedly be the loser from any vague form of words in the legislation which does not safeguard the public interest in situations where you are seeing development such as at Jandakot, and where on occasions there is little goodwill. I think all residents should be assured that this legislation contains provisions which mean the minister cannot unilaterally set aside the need for decent environmental impact statements. That would be a very retrograde step in my view.

That concludes the remarks I want to make on this issue. I have other reservations about this legislation, but I particularly wanted to draw attention to the fact that if we eliminate conditions which ensure residents' rights are protected then we are taking a very serious backward step. For that reason, I have grave reservations about the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to participate in this debate but, having heard the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), I felt there was a need to respond to some of his comments and to echo some of the comments of my colleagues on this side. I am delighted that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has come into the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern I have is in respect of the comments the member for O'Connor made regarding the choice of an alternative site to Badgerys Creek for examination through an EIS process. I accept that the new government of the day might maintain that the previous government's decision to choose Badgerys Creek as the site of Sydney's second airport was the appropriate one and that the former government acquired a lot of land there. Also, people knew about that decision, and their decisions about home ownership and about industrial development that occurred on land in the Badgerys Creek area have all been geared around that decision. I accept that that is the case.

The member for O'Connor has said in this place—indeed, so has the minister—that it is still the preferred option that Badgerys be developed as Sydney's second airport. The thing that concerns me, though, as I have said privately to the minister and a number of other colleagues, is: why choose Holsworthy as another site for further examination?

The original EIS that was done on the choice of Sydney's second airport site occurred back in the early 1980s. I remember it well. Why? Because there were two sites adjacent to the city of Wollongong and to the Illawarra region which were included in that original EIS and examined closely. One was Darkes Forest and the other was Wilton. In fact, after my election in December of 1984 I was a very strong and passionate advocate for Wilton being chosen as the site for Sydney's second airport. I did so because I thought the economic benefit that would come to a city like Wollongong and to our region of the Illawarra was substantial.

I recall that at the time I was a member of Wollongong City Council and that we had established a task force within that council. I chaired that task force—in my former life I was an urban and regional planner—with the view of promoting Wilton and trying to encourage the then government to accept Wilton as the site of the second Sydney airport. As history shows, it was not chosen.

The EIS process occurred. Variously the 10 sites were ranked and listed. Badgerys Creek was ultimately chosen and the rest were put in some sort of descending order based on the assessment through that EIS process. It is worth recording again that, from memory, Holsworthy was second from the bottom. Even Wilton was higher on the list from that original EIS process in terms of a preferred site.

From discussions with former aviation ministers and ministers for transport, I think they too recognised that Wilton was a much better site than it was first given credit for. It happens to be in the middle of the Sydney water catchment area but, as I understand it, Holsworthy also is in the middle of a water catchment segment for Sydney. With today's technology, the advances in technology and the way in which buffer zones can be created and so on, I would have thought Wilton should have been one of the sites for re‐examination if the honourable the minister decided to choose a second site for that. It should have been put on the list in front of Holsworthy.

I will argue that case now. I will put in a bid now, while the minister is here, for him to take Holsworthy off the list and put Wilton back on—for all the regional economic benefits that would come to the Illawarra, for the fact that the land is in government ownership, albeit state government ownership. I would imagine that some sort of a deal might be done with the New South Wales government to acquire however much land is required for this. Everybody does a lot of deals on your side of the parliament these days, so I see no reason why another deal could not be done about that. In a very serious vein, Minister, I put to you that the economic benefits that would flow to the Illawarra for the choice of Wilton as the second Sydney airport site would be just enormous.

I know that there has been an argument about distance. I put that to one side. I remember that at the time, about 10 years ago, distance came up as an argument in respect of Wilton when we were looking at the EIS. With modern technology, with high‐speed rapid transit lines that could be constructed and so on, I would imagine that that would dissipate as a problem. I also point out to the minister that a major freeway system is established now with the Wilton interchange—Commonwealth moneys have been invested in developing that—so that there are very fast road transport links from Wilton into the city. I also point out to the minister that the centre of the city of Sydney has now moved. I think in terms of population and geography Parramatta is just about the centre of the urban conurbation that is the city of Sydney.

We in Wollongong like to regard Sydney as our northern suburbs and will continue to do so. We would see that a second airport in Wilton which can service not only the industrial heartland of Australia—which is the Illawarra—but also the city of Sydney makes a lot of sense.

I also say something to the minister about the tourism implications of the decision to reopen this Pandora's box that is the decision on Holsworthy. I think it was encapsulated very well yesterday in a newspaper report I saw. The tourism task force was quoted as saying that continuing uncertainties occasioned by these sorts of decisions, particularly in delays associated with constructing the second Sydney airport, are going to throw into turmoil not only planning for the Olympics in the year 2000 but more importantly, beyond that, Australia as a tourist destination for people coming from all over the world.

Where we are struggling at the moment to maintain our market share in some of our more traditional markets like Japan, as was reported in yesterday's Financial Review, the Australian Tourist Commission, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade through their affiliates, and people generally in the tourism area are out there marketing Australia as a destination like crazy. One of the things we have always marketed is that Sydney is the gateway to Australia. Why would it not be? As I said, it is Wollongong's northern suburbs, a superb part of Australia. People coming into Sydney, a tremendous destination—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Melbourne?

—I know my colleague the shadow minister would like me to be talking about Melbourne in these ways, but I am sorry: Melbourne is not quite the southern suburbs of Wollongong as Sydney is our northern suburbs. Nevertheless, it is the international gateway. If you ask tourists from around the world where they want to go, you will find that they basically want to go to Cairns to have a look at the Barrier Reef, they want to go to Central Australia to have a look at Ayers Rock and they want to go to Sydney. They want to go to Sydney to see the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House and just get to know the harbour and feel the dynamics of that part of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We are seeing other regions of Australia promoting themselves, and I think that is right. There is a lot to offer in Perth. There is a lot to offer in Melbourne. Every opportunity of expanding air routes into those cities should be taken. We should continue to promote Australia as a whole as a tourist destination. But, at the end of the day, they still want Sydney.

When the former government was accused of procrastinating over the development of the parallel runway at Mascot—the third runway, as it is colloquially known—who was bagging it for the delays in construction? It was the then opposition, the present government, the present Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Who stood up in this place and in other forums on many occasions and bagged us in government for not constructing and hastening the development of that parallel runway at Mascot? It was the current Prime Minister. He was saying that it was scandalous for the tourism industry that, as we looked into the next century, the gateway to Australia was in some way being shut or only half opened because we did not have the capacity there.

What have we now seen? We have seen caps put on the number of movements that can happen in the place. We have seen the east-west runway opened up under the guise that we wanted to share the pain and burden of aircraft noise around Sydney, when we all know it was really done to take the planes away from the Prime Minister's own electorate. We have seen a lot of nonsense introduced into this debate.

To those members of the government who have an interest in aviation policy, tourism policy, and the development of second Sydney airport—you don't have to be Albert Einstein to work out that it will be needed sooner or later—I say: do the right thing, support Sydney for what it is. Look at Badgerys Creek, if that is the preferred site. It certainly was with everybody until this nonsense started up because of secret meetings or whatever. We are still to find out all the information related to that.

PARA.BREAK: If you are going to look at a second or third site and revisit some of those that happen to be in the EIS process, don't spend a million dollars. Don't give a bribe down here to the mob in Canberra. As reported in the Canberra Times this morning, the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory has been given a million dollars to do another study to see whether Canberra could be an international destination. Don't waste your money on that. This is a great place to come, a tremendous tourist destination. This parliament is one of the great wonders of the world. We are getting tourists in here at the rate of knots—and so we should—to see the way in which the parliament of this country works. But don't spend the money here. Spend it some where where there will be economic benefit—the Illawarra, south‐western Sydney, the electorate of my colleague the member of Werriwa (Mr Latham), who has just come into the chamber. In his electorate, as in my own, unemployment levels are still unacceptably high. If Badgerys Creek is not acceptable to your government, put Wilton back on the map so that we can take advantage of that, so that the economies in our local areas can be expanded. Despite what my friend the member for O'Connor said about his experience in bulldozing, which I had not been aware of, and filling in holes—

TALK.START.PARA: —It does figure, though.

—It could. Despite what he said about filling in ravines and cut and fill, my understanding of the Holsworthy site is that it would be a touch dangerous to cut and fill, to get in the old bulldozers that dodge around all those unexploded bombs and ordnances, watching out for—as the paper said today—100,000 grey‐haired bats that reside out there. You reckon there's a problem with the ordnances out there. If there is a koala colony or grey‐haired bats out there, you ain't seen nothing yet. If the environment movement get hold of this, they might decide to put up the barricades. My friend the Minister for Transport and Regional Development knows that that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude, because I know the minister is here to wrap up the debate, and I think we will need to have a vote on this. The shadow minister was here, but he has gone. I simply say to the minister again: if you think there is some problem about Badgerys Creek as a site—even though it has been acquired and all the work has gone on before, and some degree of certainty was introduced into the planning process in New South Wales about the future of that part of the world—I most genuinely and sincerely put in a bid for Wilton instead of Holsworthy.

The honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) has been reported in The Illawarra Mercury as saying that she is going to stand up to both you and the Prime Minister about this, that it will not go in there. I endorse all the comments that she has made for all the reasons she has pointed out it should be opposed. Those same problems and difficulties do not exist at Wilton. The economic benefit that would come to the Illawarra, to south‐western Sydney, if you decide that Badgerys Creek is not a goer, is enormous. Given that you, after all, are the minister for regional development, that would be an enormous stimulus to our part of the world.

For those reasons, I think we should reconsider these issues. Holsworthy was about No. 9 on the list of 10 sites in the original EIS. Wilton was a bit further up the list. Give us a go, we would like to think that we can get it there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to strongly support the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the airports bills moved by the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). To date, most discussion in the chamber has concerned the airport arrangements relating to Sydney. That is scarcely surprising, given the massive fraud which was perpetrated on voters in the electorate of Hughes prior to the last election. If ever a seat was won on false pretences, it was this one. The Liberal Party said absolutely nothing about its interest in Holsworthy as an alternative to Badgerys Creek until the election was over. There is no doubt in my mind that Robert Tickner would still be an MP in this place had the Liberal Party registered its interest, had it come clean about this arrangement before the election.

SPEECH.PARA: The issues that I wish to raise concern the future of Melbourne airports. In particular, I want to support the amendment because it retains the cross‐ownership provisions of Labor's original legislation concerning the leasing of Australian airports.

I note in particular the comments of Victorian Premier Kennett this morning, which were earlier described to the House by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). It is a pity that Premier Kennett apparently has no sway with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and that he is forced to make these comments publicly. Mind you, if I had been the victim of the car phone conversation in the way the Prime Minister was a victim of the car phone conversation between the Premier and Andrew Peacock, perhaps he would not have any sway with me either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member shall contain his remarks to the bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Premier's comments, as reported this morning, were absolutely right: this is a piece of legislation which is anti-competitive and anti‐Melbourne. I note that in the past we have had the Liberal Party describing the Keating government as a Sydney based government. Yet we have seen the Prime Minister move the prime ministerial residence to Sydney, and one of his first acts as Prime Minister has the potential to stifle Melbourne in terms of its tourism industry, its industry competitiveness and the like. I agree absolutely with the Premier. If we do not have appropriate cross‐ownership provisions, as were provided in Labor's legislation, we risk having a public monopoly simply transferred to a private monopoly and Melbourne will miss out.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Premier Kennett to complain now. What he, in fact, should have done last year and before, using his best endeavours, was to prevent the federal Liberal Party from blocking Labor's bill in the Senate. In my view, the removal of the cross‐ownership restrictions radically changes this bill and makes it one which is very difficult to support. I believe that it needs to be amended in the way suggested by the member for Melbourne in his proposed amendment, and preferably amended in this House to make it more acceptable and very much more in the public interest than it presently is.

The second issue I wish to raise concerns the future of Essendon airport. I am sure I am not Robinson Crusoe in wanting to raise this issue. I dare say that many of the private operators—the potential lessees—of the Tullamarine airport want to know what will happen at Essendon airport. More than that, my constituents in their thousands wish to know what the present government's intentions are in relation to Essendon airport in the light of this legislation.

You may recall that the previous government had resolved to sell Essendon airport and to redevelop the site. In my electorate there is great concern that, if this leasing arrangement were to go to Essendon airport as a going concern, it would lead to the abandonment of the curfew and the abandonment of other relevant restrictions that help make life bearable for residents who live around Essendon airport.

Presently, Essendon is a major loss‐making operation. It seems to me that no private sector purchaser would want to run it as an airport unless they were able to get some of the present restrictions lifted and to increase its level of activity. Those sorts of things would have a very adverse effect on residents who live within the vicinity of Essendon airport.

It is my strong view that Essendon has a poor safety record and, for that reason alone, it should be redeveloped. Recently we have had the report of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation into the crash of a de Havilland Dove back in December of 1993. That report indicated the reasons for that crash but, regrettably, made no recommendations whatsoever which could give the public any confidence that such a crash might not recur. That crash was, in fact, the third serious crash involving Essendon airport since it became a general aviation airport following the transfer of larger craft to Tullamarine consequent upon the construction of Tullamarine airport.

A light plane crashed into the area west of the airport killing the members of the Gulle family. In 1986 an air ambulance crashed to the north of Essendon airport where all those aboard were killed, and it was a miracle that that plane happened to land in the only non-housing area surrounding the airport. Thirdly, we had the crash of a plane in 1993 in Gilbertson Street, Essendon, into five residential houses. Once again, it was a miracle that there was no loss of life.

Given that poor safety record and given the history of incidents and near misses, with large craft seeking to land at Essendon airport having mistaken that airport for Tullamarine, it certainly seems to me and local residents that Essendon airport operations should be relocated elsewhere and that site should be redeveloped.

BREAK.PARA: The fact that we have this bill before the parliament means that many people will have an interest in knowing whether Essendon airport is to continue or not, and the decision about what sort of price they are going to pay for the lease on Tullamarine airport will no doubt be influenced by that. So they have a right to know as well.

In conclusion, I would stress my support for the amendment, which I believe is very much in Melbourne's best interests. If this government is fair dinkum about its commitment to Melbourne, it would retain those cross‐ownership provisions and retain the prospect that we should have a lessee of Melbourne's Tullamarine airport who is truly committed to the welfare of that airport and truly committed to the welfare of Melbourne. Secondly, I seek from the minister some advice regarding his view of the future of Essendon airport in the light of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise concerns on two fronts on this legislation. One relates to representing local government in Australia. They have a concern that under this legislation the future development of airports will circumvent local government planning powers. If we are moving forward with privatisation with private leases for the reason that these days airports are much more like retail centres than transport modes, surely some of the planning concerns should have direct regard for local govern ment retail strategy. I advise the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) that he should take account of that and use local government as a means by which their planning powers can be respected in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second concern I have relates to Sydney West airport and the issue of the suitability of the Holsworthy site. The minister has said that he is using Holsworthy as an insurance policy. It is fair and reasonable for this House to ask: who is paying the premium for this minister's decision to use Holsworthy as a so-called insurance policy? The people who are paying the premium are the 500,000 residents in south-west Sydney—the people who are directly affected by this proposition. The people who are directly paying the premium for his insurance policy are those property owners in Wattle Grove, Holsworthy and Ingleburn, Minto and Macquarie Fields in my electorate who have had their properties devalued as a product of this decision. He is holding the insurance policy, but they are paying the premium. They are the residents who moved in in good faith, many of them as part of a federal government scheme through the Defence Housing Authority by which they could find their dream suburb and their dream lifestyle. They have had that dream turned into a nightmare by this minister's decision.

Who else is paying the premium for the minister's insurance policy? The Department of Defence has had all its forward defence planning thrown in the air as a product of the uncertainty about the Holsworthy site. The Sydney 2000 Olympics is paying a premium for the minister's insurance policy. It has had its planning for the shooting range at Holsworthy thrown in the air as a product of this minister's determination to hold an insurance policy—a policy at no cost to himself and to the landed gentry in the Goulburn district but at a direct cost to land values and lifestyle aspirations in suburbs such as Holsworthy, Wattle Grove and east Liverpool in the electorate of Hughes and at a cost to land values in suburbs such as Ingleburn, Minto and Macquarie Fields in my electorate of Werriwa.

Those residents are paying the premium already. They have paid the money already by the devaluation of their property. They are paying the premium for the insurance policy that is being held by the minister. Why are they doing it when they were not told about it before the election? It is incomprehensible and totally beyond belief that those opposite had no plans for Holsworthy up until 2 March. It is unbelievable that only after 2 March would they overturn 10 years of planning on Badgerys Creek to hold an expensive insurance policy at Holsworthy.

I would suggest to the House that any sensible or reasonable person would conclude that this is an act of deceit whereby the coalition had been planning their Holsworthy option for a long time. They thought it was more important to talk to big business about this plan than the people in the south-west of Sydney. They thought it was more important to keep their plans secret than to have a charter of airport honesty—to be open, transparent and disclose their intentions to the 500,000 residents in the south-west of Sydney.

For all the problems at Holsworthy, what could be driving the government's plan? For all the problems of the unexploded bombs; the big cost to the Department of Defence; the Olympics planning; the coal reserves; the sacred sites; the koala colony; the hospital that is halfway under construction; the relocation of all those defence facilities; the fact that Holsworthy ranked second last in the assessment in 1995; the compensation that needs to be paid to Delfin for revenue lost on their Wattle Grove construction project; the closure of Bankstown airport, with 3,000 lost jobs and the massive cost of relocating a general aviation facility in Sydney; the environmental study at Holsworthy, which is yet to be released; the 500,000 residents, and the 20,000 that are directly affected by the 25 ANEF noise contour; the loss of property values; the uncertainty—for all the things that are wrong with the Holsworthy proposition which any sensible and reasonable person would know, what is driving the minister?

What is driving the minister that overrides a list of concerns as long as your arm, that somehow makes Holsworthy suitable for his insurance policy? It is big business, it is big money and big financial interests that are driving this minister. His secret plan, revealed only after the election, was to go ahead with Holsworthy at any cost. It is a shameful day for the democracy and the reputation of this parliament when big business is more important than the needs of middle Australia—those home owners and families in suburbs such as Wattle Grove who have had money ripped out of their pockets. They are paying the premium, Minister, for your insurance policy. They are the people who are paying for your associations with big business. They are the people who are already paying for your secret plan, hatched prior to the election. They are paying the cost for your deceit and that of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this particular issue.

When people talk about the Prime Minister, as they do quite frequently in the south-west of Sydney these days, they refer to Little Johnny Coward. Little Johnny Coward wouldn't reveal his plan before the election and held it secret. Only after the election did he decide to tell people in the south-west of Sydney that they would be affected by an EIS, their properties would lose value, their lifestyles would be thrown in the air, their expectations would be destroyed and they would have to pay the premium for the insurance policy that this minister and the Prime Minister hold with big business. It is a disgrace. It should not be happening. The government should amend this legislation to abandon the Holsworthy site as soon as possible. It is a farce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank members of the House for participating in this debate, particularly those members from our side who have made contributions. It has been a very interesting debate. Whilst a debate like this is wide ranging and provides the opportunity for many members to discuss any issue relating to airports, there has been a particular focus on the government's decision of last week to do parallel environmental impact studies on both Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy, as we come to the resolution of a second airport for Sydney.

PARA.BREAK: The tenor of the debate of the Labor Party has been the government's decision to con sider Holsworthy as a second airport option for Sydney. I make the point—it is a very important point to make—that, in discussing that issue, as members of the Labor Party have throughout this debate, the first thing to remind ourselves of is the fact that Badgerys Creek is our first preference. The only reason we feel we have a need to look at a site other than Badgerys Creek when doing an environmental impact study is the failure of the previous Labor government to address the option of Badgerys Creek as the second airport for Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this is very important. The previous government undertook an environmental impact study of a number of sites in 1985 and selected Badgerys Creek as their preferred site in February 1986. From February 1986 through to 1989, the government did nothing at Badgerys Creek. Then in 1989 the government announced that they would be having a staged development of Badgerys Creek airport which would see the airport operational by June of 1995.

What had happened by June 1995? Absolutely and utterly nothing. Not a sod had been turned, not a runway had been built and not a building had been constructed on the site that was supposed to be an operating airport by June 1995. Late in 1995, the former Minister for Transport announced that there would be no operational airport at Badgerys Creek until well beyond the year 2000.

In the course of that 10‐year delay, the environmental problems for Badgerys Creek have increased. We have seen an enormous encroachment of urban development around the Badgerys Creek airport site, particularly under potential flight paths for Badgerys Creek airport. That encroachment of housing in those areas has led to the loss of the unique opportunity that existed at Badgerys Creek in 1986; that is, Badgerys Creek was relatively untouched by urban development in and around the site and under the flight paths. The delay of the former Labor government in doing anything at Badgerys Creek has led to those environmental problems developing. It has caused us considerable difficulty as we look at solving Sydney's airport problems.

BREAK.PARA: It is worth noting that in the course of all of that the then government was unable to determine a rail link to Badgerys Creek airport. Indeed, it was unable to satisfactorily negotiate, until just recently, the establishment of a road link to Badgerys Creek airport. This former Labor government had 10 years to do all of the things that needed to be done in order to develop an airport at Badgerys Creek. They absolutely and utterly failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Fahey abandoned the link.

—When we listen to the feigned outrage of people such as the member for Werriwa who in this House go on about what a shocking situation this all is, I remind people that the reason we are in this situation is the failure of the former Labor government to do something to construct an airport at Badgerys Creek when they first decided to build an airport there 10 years ago. They did nothing. They fast‐talked and slow‐tracked. They talked up what they were going to do at Badgerys Creek and in reality did nothing.

BREAK.PARA: That problem is now the inheritance of the new coalition government. It is our determination to build a second airport in Sydney as quickly as possible. That is why we are doing what we are doing at the present time. If members opposite do not like what we are doing, then they might like to look back at their own history of government and blame themselves—I am sure most reasonable people would—for the delay of 10 years in doing something about Badgerys Creek airport.

I refer to a number of the aspects of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). The amendment has been the subject of some discussion. I understand that the honourable member for Melbourne, following this stage, will be moving further amendments which relate to cross‐ownership. I might take the opportunity during that debate to refer to those cross‐ownership matters rather than deal with them now.

The government welcomes the comments of the shadow minister and members of the Labor Party that they do not intend to oppose the bill as such. We note that they have some amendments they wish to move. There is good reason why the Labor members of this parliament should not oppose this bill. Essentially, this bill that was introduced last week into the House is the same as, or very similar to, the bill that was put forward by the former Labor government last year.

We have made some amendments to the original Labor government bill. One of those relates to the cross‐ownership requirement, which I will refer to in later debate; the other relates to environmental and planning arrangements, which we believe we have enhanced and made less cumbersome. We have also ensured that a more pro‐competitive regime applies to the airport to fit within the requirements of the Hilmer process and that in the long-term lease of these airports—as it is more accurately described—a very pro-competitive environment exists.

Those are the basic changes we have made. It is for that reason that it is sensible for Labor members of parliament, now in opposition, to support this bill. Essentially, it is the very same bill that they put forward when they were in government.
I will refer particularly to the first item in the amendment, which reads:
No sales should occur until all Environmental Impact Statement processes are completed and the future of Sydney West Airport is resolved;

We are determined not to sell Sydney Mascot airport and Sydney West airport until such time as we have satisfactorily completed the environmental impact studies and decisions are made in relation to that. We will not be putting on the market Sydney Mascot and Sydney West airports until such time as we fulfil our election commitment, made by the former shadow minister for aviation, Senator Parer—and indeed reiterated by the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard), then opposition leader—that we will not do so until such time as we have been able to satisfactorily resolve Sydney's aircraft noise problems.

One has to be mindful of the fact, when we look at all of these amendments and the actions of the government in the last week, that they are all born out of a desire of this government, the Liberal and National parties, to satisfactorily resolve the aircraft noise problem for the people of Sydney. There is no doubt in Sydneysiders' minds, and in the minds of the government, that the problems of Sydneysiders as a result of aircraft noise came about because of the mismanagement of the former Labor government in dealing with that aircraft noise problem. It has caused enormous anxiety and distress for Sydney people, and we are now left with that problem. We are trying to deal with it as best we can. One of the commitments we made in opposition that we are determined to fulfil in government is that we will ensure that we will not sell long‐term leases for Mascot or Sydney West airports until we have in our minds satisfactorily resolved the aircraft noise problems of Sydney. I go to the second part of the amendment, which says:

...in order to ensure that the Commonwealth achieves the maximum lease payments possible as a result of the processes set out in the Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill, Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport should be included in the first tranche of airports outlined in the Minister for Finance's second reading speech for the Airports (Transitional) Bill, rather than be offered for leasehold sale at some later time;

All of us would support a proposal that would enhance the value of the airports that it is proposed will be sold by this legislation. I think every sensible member of parliament would say that that is a worthy goal because, at the end of the day, we want to achieve maximum value for the taxpayer. But there are differences of opinion. One of the opinions that I think predominates in the market at the moment is that it would be deleterious to the value of Sydney's airport if it were to be put up for sale at this present time without a satisfactory resolution of the question of a second airport for Sydney.

So we would say that the best way to deal with this issue is to exclude Sydney's airport from the sale process at this time, deal with the second airport problem, deal with the aircraft noise problem—which is also a factor that impacts on the potential value of Sydney's airports—and, once you have dealt with those satisfactorily, then put them on the market and you will achieve the highest possible value for those airports when you put them up for sale. So we believe that that is the appropriate approach to achieve the goal of obtaining the highest value for Sydney's airports.
The third aspect of the amendment put forward by the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) is the following:
the road and other infrastructure developments associated with the Badgerys Creek proposal should proceed where appropriate, regardless of whether Sydney West Airport is built at Badgerys Creek.

If you take the hypothetical situation and assume for a moment—but do not pretend that this is our intention—that Badgerys Creek airport does not proceed, it would be ridiculous to build the rail system to Badgerys Creek airport if it is not to exist. Yet the intent of the third aspect of the amendment would require us to build the rail line to Badgerys Creek airport even if we do not build an airport there. So we see that aspect of the amendment as contradictory and somewhat lacking in logic. It is for that reason we certainly cannot support that aspect of the amendment.

I say to the House that the government is determined to put to the market as quickly as possible those airports that we have outlined in our speech. One thing that members of the Labor Party need to recognise is that there is a very strong view in the business community that any further unnecessary delays to the sale of those airports will have an impact on the value of those airports. Further uncertainty will impact on the value of those airports and therefore disadvantage the taxpayers of Australia by reducing the value of those airports. I think it is a view that members opposite would appreciate exists in the marketplace. So now is the time for us to proceed with the passage of this legislation as quickly as possible so that we can ensure that those airports that have been listed for sale can be presented to the market to receive offers to benefit the taxpayers of Australia.
The government will be opposing the three aspects of the amendment outlined by the honourable member for Melbourne as put forward in his speech earlier in this session.

BREAK.PARA: 47C Meaning of unacceptable cross‐ownership situation

For the purposes of this Act, an unacceptable cross‐ownership situation exists in relation to a pair of airport‐operator companies (the first company and the second company ) and in relation to a particular person if:

The amendments I have moved relate to the reinstatement of cross-ownership rules in the airports legislation. As the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) briefly pointed out beforehand, the legislation which has been introduced by the government with respect to the sale of airport leaseholds is essentially the same as the legislation that was introduced by the former Labor government. But probably the most important difference between the legislation that is before the House today and the legislation that our government introduced is that the cross-ownership rules—which, in effect, limited any one leaseholder to no greater than 15 per cent ownership of either both Sydney and Melbourne or both Sydney and Brisbane—have been deleted from the legislation.

The opposition has a position on this issue which is consistent with what its position was when in government; namely, we do not want to see a private monopoly in airport administration replace the current public monopoly. Without the cross-ownership provisions, there is a serious risk that that is precisely what will occur.

I understand that—and perhaps the minister could clarify this when he comes to the dispatch box—the cross-ownership rules were in the original legislation that went to cabinet with the minister's recommendation. But when it came out of cabinet at the other end, as a result of the actions of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), they were not there any more.
Even Jeff Kennett last night, as has been illustrated by a couple of members, spoke out on this issue. I quote from his speech to the National Farmers Federation:

. . . one of my great fears, and it was a fear under the previous government and it's a fear under this in part, is what's going to happen with our airports, because if, as I hear, there is a potential that Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne might all be able to be sold to the one purchaser, then we are going to have no competition whatsoever and we are going to transfer a government monopoly, in terms of FAC, into a private monopoly situation.

And if we're serious about agriculture and we're serious about transporting fresh food or manufactured products, then we've got to have among those airports a competitive environment. And it is just no value at all to any of us to see them sold off to one potential buyer.

I should mention that Mr Kennett actually has a fair bit of expertise about creating private monopolies out of public ones. He did that with the TAB in Victoria, for example, so it is slightly amusing to see him taking this line. However, I hasten to add that I agree 100 per cent with his point: we should be reinstating the cross-ownership rules in the legislation.

It is true that, by and large, airports do not compete; destinations do. But significant competition does occur at the margins, and this competition is, of course, relevant, particularly to the costs that are imposed on the users of freight services. Some of the examples that Mr Kennett cited in his speech to the National Farmers Federation are, in fact, very good examples of why we should be concerned about the absence of cross-ownership provisions.

Without these provisions, we will not, or may not, have the basis for comparing different airports under different administrations to ensure that we get the maximum level of efficiency of operations in airports and the minimum degree of imposition of costs on both the direct users of airports, the airlines, and the indirect users, those people who fly with the airlines and those people who actually transport freight. The amendments I have moved simply reinstate the identical provisions in their entirety that were in the legislation previously presented to the House by the former Labor government. I commend those amendments to the House.

What about the certainty that you have ripped out of their expectations for their families and their children?

It is disgraceful. I am just tidying you up. I am holding you accountable for the things you put to the House earlier on. The truth of the matter is that you have double standards when it comes to competition policy. It is all right for the labour market but not for airports. It is all right for low skill and low productivity workers in a bad bargaining position but when it comes to the BAA, AMP, Lend Lease or any big financial interest he says, `No way. There'll be a monopoly product market.' That is your standard. (Time expired)
