TALK.START.PARA: —Given that you afforded the previous speaker, the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), a wide‐ranging opportunity to digress from the amendments, I make the point that the very problems he highlighted are problems born of the 10 years of failure of the previous Labor government. If it had not been for their doing nothing once they decided in February 1986 to build a second airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek, we would not be here today talking about this very issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems he has highlighted today are born of the Labor government's failures. The amendments which we are dealing with today have been moved by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) and they relate to two aspects. Cross‐ownership is probably the principal aspect that he is concerned with, which relates to amendments Nos 1 to 7 and 10. We received those amendments just a short while ago.

In the debate on the second reading last week we made particular reference to the cross‐ownership provisions. Some members of the Labor Party have said that we made no reference to those provisions so I will read what I said in my second reading speech:

The government, in recognition of the excision of Sydney/Sydney West airports from the first set of sales, has not set down cross ownership provisions in the bill. Such restrictions could reduce the number of potential bidders for the first tranche airports.

I was referring there to the fact that in the bill moved by the former Labor government there were cross‐ownership provisions designed to stop someone owning a Sydney airport and a Brisbane airport, or a Sydney airport and a Melbourne airport. We believe we have met the intent of those proposed cross‐ownership provisions by our withdrawal from the first tranche of sales of Sydney and Sydney West airports.

We will consider the other points raised by the amendments moved by the honourable member for Melbourne as this bill moves to the Senate. I conclude my remarks today on behalf of the government by saying that, whilst we do not necessarily require these amendments to enhance the bill, we will consider them and determine our action when the bill reaches the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) does not seem to recognise that the leases involved here are the ultimate in long‐term leases and the investments are just about as large as can be made in this country. Companies that are looking to investment in the major airports at Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane are looking at massive investments where the decision to invest must be viewed in the overall context. In removing the cross‐ownership provisions the government is arguing that they do not matter because Sydney and Sydney West airports are not for sale in the first tranche and that will ensure there is no monopoly.

BREAK.PARA: The Federal Airports Corporation was established as the overall federal authority with a monopoly on the provision of a public utility right across the country. If you have investment in Sydney and Melbourne, you have the game by the throat because you have the resources, the market and the growth. All the other airports—in Hobart, Adelaide, Perth, Alice Springs and Darwin—will hang from them. They are all lesser resourced airports with less access to the market and less capacity to expand operations and benefit from the economies that come with size. It is nonsense to suggest that without cross‐ownership provisions you can make such a large investment and still be covered later on.

The minister and I have sat many hours together on matters aviation related. I know that he knows better than that. I do not know what is driving him, what has placed him in this position. I think that he went to cabinet with a brief and he lost. That is not unusual. Lots of ministers lose in the cabinet room. But he went in with one brief and came out with another. The hairy‐chested members of cabinet who have taken out the cross‐ownership requirements have put him in this pickle. I feel for him a bit.

We can both smile, can't we, Minister? I do have sympathy for you but, colleague, this bill is not good enough. You will have to change things. I know, and you know, that you are following the wrong course. Fancy sending you out to bat for Holsworthy. Do you know how many times we have looked at airport needs for the Sydney region? This is the 50th year—not the 20th, 30th or 40th—because the studies go back to 1946 with the report on the development of an international airport at Sydney. In 1969‐70, for the Holt government, there was a report on major airport requirements for Sydney. For the Whitlam government in 1971‐74 there was a major benefit cost study of alternative airport proposals.

Then there was the study of the major airport needs for Sydney for the Fraser government in 1977‐79. The Fraser government sat there for seven years and could not make a decision. Former Minister Nixon received the report but could not agree on where it should go. Former Prime Minister Fraser and his then Treasurer—now Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—got 10 proposals for a second airport site down to two—Badgerys Creek and Scheyville. Holsworthy was thrown out.

According to the minutes, of the 10 proposed sites that were left in 1985‐86, Holsworthy was the second one excluded. That was because of unexploded ordnance; it would mean the closure of Bankstown airport; and, in 1984‐85 dollars, the estimated cost of site preparation was $375 million and relocation of defence facilities was $360 million, making the site the second most expensive to acquire and develop after Scheyville.

Minister, what is the game? Why have you been placed in this position? I could understand you proposing a site like Wilton, or something that ran in the first five, but why something that ran a furlong behind the pack? You must come clean about this. Either this is a stunt or you were locked into the secret discussions that went on prior to the last election. I think the parliament is owed a proper explanation of what has gone on and what secret commitments have been entered into. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) and also to raise a few points about what the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) said earlier in the debate. It would seem from this airports legislation that the government intends to wreck the process of the sale of airports around Australia. It seems to have adopted the rather bizarre approach of putting up for sale a number of Commonwealth assets in airports worth varying amounts of money, while holding onto the jewel in the crown. Sydney airport is not going to be in the round of sales, but the government is going to flog off the lesser airports.

SPEECH.PARA: Any sensible businessman who wants to buy into airport operations would want to buy the airport that made the most money. What the big players and the people with the money will be looking to will be bidding on Sydney—not Launceston, Devonport or even Melbourne or Brisbane. The large scale players will really want to bid on Sydney, particularly when business is starting to wake up to what the government's real aim in this exercise is.

If we had some commitment from the minister here in the House that, when they sell off the first round of airports, the minister will prohibit anyone who owns one of the other airports from being involved in the purchase of Sydney, that might be an interesting thing to hear from him. But all we have heard the minister say is that somehow or other the government is going to resolve the problem that the previous government saw by not selling Sydney yet.

We have no commitment from the government—nor the minister—that it will not allow a person or a consortium that is involved in the ownership of Melbourne or Brisbane to be part of a consortium that owns Sydney. That is the crux of the matter. If there is going to be competition between these gateways, they must be kept as separate entities which are interested in competing with each other.

A lot of business people in Sydney are now waking up to what the government's real plan is. With the obfuscation about Holsworthy and the talk about how we desperately need to have a high‐powered EIS for Holsworthy and for Badgerys Creek, the government's real plan is to have no second airport for Sydney. That will mean that the government will have to bring in a piece of legislation to do away with the previous government's legislation on the number of flight caps and the curfew at Sydney airport. The government is working towards no second airport, and then the only way that Sydney will be able to be operational will be to smash the curfew and to ratchet up the number of flights per hour that are allowed through Sydney.

The outcome of that will be that, with traffic densities increasing at the rate they are, commuter aircraft will have to be pushed out of Sydney. That will suit the National Party minister because that will cause hubbing in some large country centres outside Sydney. That will make his mate, the member who represents western New South Wales, happy because they might get some sort of secondary airport out there.

What the big money is saying is that Sydney airport is going to become much bigger than it is. British Airways, the company that is interested in buying Sydney airport, is already factoring this into its arrangements. It knows the government's plan. There will be no second airport. The capacity of Sydney airport will be increased. The curfew will be done away with. Southern Sydney will be wrecked.

This will come back to haunt the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). It will show what a sham the promises of the Liberal Party were in the last election campaign. The government does not intend doing anything about aircraft noise in Sydney. It intends to ruin the last chance we have for sanity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —While I support the general thrust of the airports bills in the interest of a more efficient airline industry, debate so far has underlined the complete confusion and disarray in both the government and opposition on the question of airport planning. While I fully support the leases, how is any company or corporation supposed to make a sound business decision to sink millions of dollars into a long-term lease of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport when the question of what will happen with regard to a second major airport for Sydney remains up in the air?

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, the level of thought on the future of airport planning in Sydney that we have seen from both this government and the previous government would be enough to make serious investors pack their bags and catch the next flight out of the country. This act sets up a system for regulating airports: one at Kingsford Smith airport, which we know we have; the other, called Sydney West, is, for the purposes of the act, `to be taken to be an airport at a particular time', even if at that time it is merely intended to be developed for use as an airport or is being developed for use as an airport. What does this phrase `to be taken to be an airport at a particular time' mean?

BREAK.PARA: Imagine that you went to Canberra airport tomorrow to catch a plane to Victoria only to be told that there was no saying when the aircraft would be arriving: `It would arrive at a particular time.' Would you hand your money over for a ticket? I think not.

This is a bill about the privatisation of major assets, one of which does not exist. The bill includes a range of sensible management plans for the leasing and management of airports, land use planning, environmental management, and protection of air space around airports. But the tiara in the crown—Sydney West airport—is either the dream of the aviation industry or the nightmare of the Sydney population, wherever it is located.

It is too late for a second Sydney airport. This was pointed out by the opposition and the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) from the government benches last night. Sydney has now developed to the west and south‐west to such a degree that an airport would be a gross invasion into the lives of those populations, whether it be located at Badgerys Creek or at Holsworthy. Either location would also be an electoral disaster for whichever government located it there. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) can promise all the environmental impact studies he likes, but nothing is going to change this simple fact.

The other problem is the fast approaching Olympics. This is distorting all fair judgment about a new airport for Sydney. A decision made with limited options could condemn Sydney to `airport syndrome' for the next 100 years. What is needed is a long‐term visionary approach to our aviation requirements and to the development of transport infrastructure within Australia.

One suggested option that has been revived in recent weeks is Goulburn. Whilst superficially attractive, this option probably can be ruled out because of fog. However, it deserves serious study. It has obvious merit and would be far cheaper than Sydney West. However, I believe the Parkes inland airport project is a far better option.

The IMC—Inland Marketing Corporation—is seeking a funding injection of approximately $50 million to extend the existing former wartime air force runway at Parkes. Malaysia Airlines, for one, has already endorsed the proposal and has agreed to help the Parkes base region export products from the north, south and west of inland Australia, and back load freight to the already substantial rail highway interconnection.

Such a project could easily be expanded to an international passenger airport at substantially less cost than anything planned for Sydney. What is more, the land is as flat as the floor of this chamber. There is no unexploded ordnance. Landing and take‐off patterns would cause minimum disruptions. It is an airport that the vast majority of people west of the mountains support.

After the Olympics, incoming passenger habits will return to normal; destinations of visitors will be substantially other than Sydney. How better to generate more business for our regional airline system than to have these operators hub and spoke to other capitals, such as Darwin and Alice Springs, out of Parkes. Are we afraid to be too visionary in this? How about a very fast train from Parkes to Sydney on which all necessary customs matters could be attended?

What is the alternative? Here we have a government desperate to rake in revenue to balance the books. I agree that the government should be anxious about the situation, but not desperate. We must not go down the path of a Holsworthy, having abandoned the Badgerys Creek option, not because it fails the EIS but because, by any sensible judgment, it is not the place for an international airport.

One‐third of all traffic coming in and out of Kingsford Smith does not need to be there, it is using it as a hub. The proposed Sydney West airport will have a runway length of 2,900 metres, meaning it will not be able to take jumbo jets. As far as passenger needs go, it will only be able to operate as a secondary domestic airport. Five billion dollars is a lot to pay for a secondary domestic airport. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could follow the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren) and on his behalf ask the Minister for Transport and Regional Develop ment (Mr Sharp) to agree, in his summing up, to at least fund a feasibility study into the proposal at Dubbo—
—Parkes.

—I beg your pardon, Parkes. Given it is in the electorate of Parkes I understand that Mr Cobb, the National Party member for that seat, would probably welcome the minister agreeing to at least provide funding for a thorough and proper feasibility study. The former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was quite impressed with the potential for that airport to become an airport for the export of vegetables and other Australian produce to Asia. I think at the very least the government could afford to fund a feasibility study for the measure.
—It has passenger options too.
—Yes, it has passenger options too, as the member for Calare suggests.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue I would like the minister to respond to is the statement which was made last night by the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, to the National Farmers Federation. Jeff Kennett said there was not much point in converting a government monopoly into a private monopoly and by implication was strongly supporting the former government's proposals to have cross‐ownership restrictions between Sydney and Melbourne and Brisbane. I hope that is an issue that the minister could give further consideration to given the powerful advocacy that Jeff Kennett, the Liberal Premier of Victoria, has put into this issue overnight.

I wish to make one minor correction to remarks that I made earlier today. I said that I thought there was no provision in legislation for the CPI minus X pricing ceilings. I understand now that there is provision for regulations to be made but there is no indication other than the minister's second reading speech as to what those regulations will be and what effect they will have.

Can the minister give the House an assurance today that those CPI minus X formulas will be implemented in regulations? Will he give the House an assurance that X will be a positive number so that we will not have increases of more than the CPI? And will he agree to allow the ACCC to set the value of X so that we can have confidence that there is an independent competition regulator, the ACCC, investigating what is best for consumers or what is best for further investment in the market?

In that way we can have an assurance that the government will not allow X to be set at a very low figure, if not zero or a negative number. In that sense the tourism industry and people involved in the freight industry can have some assurance that prices will not go through the roof after the leases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has acknowledged by default that his heart is not in the decision that was taken by cabinet to remove the cross-ownership rules from the legislation and I welcome his indication that the government may be prepared to reconsider its position between now and when the legislation goes to the Senate. However, because the matter is clearly not entirely in his hands we will still be seeking to divide on this issue. But with respect to the second round of amendments, given what he has indicated I do not think we will be seeking to divide.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make one point on the substantive question of cross‐ownership rules in response to what the minister has said. I find his suggestion that in some way they are no longer necessary because the sale of Sydney/Sydney West is going to be delayed rather bizarre because I do not quite see what would stop a Melbourne leaseholder or a Brisbane leaseholder or a Melbourne and Brisbane leaseholder from two or three years later or whenever then purchasing the leasehold with respect to Sydney and Sydney West when they are finally sold.

Maybe the intention is to reconsider the issue at some stage down the track when the prospect of Sydney and/or Sydney West being sold starts to become close to reality, I do not know, but I found his response on that particular point most unconvincing. I would say on behalf of the opposition that we are happy to discuss the content of any cross‐ownership regulations.

BREAK.PARA: Although we have put forward today the provisions that we proposed when we were in government, we are not necessarily wedded to those and should the minister want to propose some alternative means of ensuring that we do not end up with a private monopoly across major airports across the country that is in some way different from the proposition that we advanced then we would be happy to consider that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by referring to the remarks of the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren), who put forward a proposal for a second Sydney airport at Parkes, which is one of many such proposals that I have received over the last few years. In fact, at dinner last night I received a proposal that will no doubt be described as yet another secret deal, that Melbourne should be a second airport for Sydney, which is a somewhat novel approach. Indeed, many of these proposals for a second airport for Sydney could be described as novel.
—Jeff?
—No, it was not Jeff, although I am sure if he had thought of it he would have said it.
—He would say Sydney was a second airport for Melbourne.

—He would, too. We had people from Narrandera here last week putting forward a proposal that their area be considered for an international airport—not for Sydney but for freight. There are many proposals floating around, as anyone who has had anything to do with this issue for some time will be aware. But let me say that we will look at the whole issue of airfreight airports for regional centres through the course of this year and, of course, Parkes will be included in that consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I go to the remarks of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who referred to the CPI minus X requirements, and I thank him for correcting his comments made in earlier debate. I inform him that it is the intention of the government that CPI minus X will be a part of the regulations and that the X will not be a negative figure. Can I also say that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission—ACCC—has been given a very important role to oversight competitive arrangements within this legislation and so he needs to be made aware of that, and I think those of us who are interested in competition can draw some comfort from the fact that they are in there. As far as the honourable member's comments are concerned, I think he can be reasonably assured by that.

Again, I go to the issue of a switch from a government monopoly to a private monopoly and say that it is not the intention of this government to provide anybody with a private monopoly. The government has, in the existing legislation, provided the minister of the day with quite wide discretionary powers to determine the suitability of purchases and to take into account the national interest. Of course, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is also given a very important role in the application of this legislation. I make those points to address some of the concerns raised by members in this debate.

I conclude my remarks by saying, as I have said to the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), that the aspects raised in his amendments will be considered by the government as the legislation is transmitted from here to the Senate. However, at this stage we will be supporting our bill as it stands without amendments.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Tanner's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill and the associated Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1996 are part of the Commonwealth's response to the horrific events at Port Arthur. This tragedy has concentrated attention on the fact that there are large holdings of types of rapid‐fire weapons in our community which are simply not justifiable in the overall national interest.

All Australian governments are acting swiftly on tighter gun control, a significant element of which is a 12‐month amnesty and compensation scheme. This scheme, likely to begin formally on 1 July, will require gun owners to hand in those guns to be the subject of nationwide bans in return for fair and proper compensation. This covers all self‐loading rifles, self‐loading shotguns and pump‐action shotguns, whether licensed or unlicensed, subject to very narrow exceptions.

Through a one‐off increase of 0.2 per cent in the Medicare levy, these bills will raise the necessary funds to reimburse states and territories for the direct cost of payments they will have made to relevant gun owners. I am reluctant at any time to add to the financial burden on Australians, but this bill imposes a special one‐year impost which I think most Australians will regard as necessary in the circumstances. Through contributing an amount estimated to cost someone on average weekly earnings a total of around $70, or $1.40 a week, Australians can assist in the greatest reduction of firearms ever contemplated in this or most other countries.

A very large total cost is involved. The estimate is that the increase in levy will raise around $500 million. The Commonwealth judges it to be in the national interest to offer assistance on such a scale to the states and territories, notwithstanding that gun control falls largely within their responsibilities. National leadership needs to be exercised so that the problem of the proliferation of these guns is confronted swiftly and adequately. The terms of the buyback scheme will be subject to national agreement and I have made it clear to premiers and chief ministers that funding by the Commonwealth is based on the strong agreement of all states and territories to implement the measures agreed at the meeting of police ministers on 10 May.

I note that a recent University of Canberra study supports the government's conclusion that an increase in the Medicare levy for this purpose is the most desirable of several options, including on equity and efficiency grounds. The rate of Medicare levy will be raised from 1.5 per cent to 1.7 per cent for the 1996‐97 income year only. The terms of the bill ensure that the rate will be returned to the present level of 1.5 per cent for the 1997‐98 and subsequent income years.

The bill will allow imposition of a proportion of the full Medicare levy, equivalent to a rate of 0.2 per cent, on members of the defence forces, and in some circumstances members of their household, who are currently exempt from the Medicare levy. Again, this will be just for the duration of the 1996‐97 income year. The same income thresholds, reduced levy and phasing‐in arrangements applying to other taxpayers will apply. This measure puts defence personnel in the same position as other Australians required to meet this special community‐wide impost.

The figure of $500 million represents the best advice about the costs states and territories could face in meeting the direct cost of buyback arrangements. Any surplus will be returned to taxpayers through the Medicare levy system. Details of the national amnesty and buyback scheme are being worked on by a working party of senior Commonwealth and state officials. The clear objective is to offer incentives which secure a significant return of firearms as expeditiously as possible. This includes a regime of fair and proper compensation with values set by people with appropriate expertise. It also includes significant penalties for those who fail to return banned weapons at the expiration of 12 months, with more serious penalties applying in respect of high firepower weapons.

I understand that the thinking at this stage is that the scheme of compensation will involve a schedule of values for particular categories of firearm, depending on condition. Such values would be set by a national panel which includes government and gun industry representation and independent valuation expertise.

I am gratified by the response of most Australians to the leadership shown by all governments on gun control. Many will be inconvenienced by this and other elements of the gun control package. It is a matter of honest regret that taxpayers need to meet this cost, and that law‐abiding gun owners need to surrender guns which they have found useful to them in one way or another. The rural community in particular are likely to feel the brunt of tighter restrictions, though primary producers will be able to use smaller magazine, low powered semiautomatics where there is a demonstrable occupational need which cannot be met by other means. My experience of this community gives me every confidence that they will shoulder responsibly the burden that the new state gun laws will impose.

I do not enjoy for one moment imposing this degree of additional regulation and inconvenience, which reaches into many law‐abiding Australian homes. But, when the whole of the matter is weighed, there is a greater good to be served in taking such comprehensive measures. The profound national trauma which followed the gun violence at Port Arthur has caused us to ask fundamental questions about what sort of firearms are acceptable in our community.

Logic, not emotion, has carried all governments collectively to a conclusion that the availability of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns should be severely circumscribed and that there should be greater rigour generally in gun licensing and registration systems. All of us with public duties in this matter need to fully implement the agreement reached by police ministers and to keep our compact with the Australian people. These historic measures are designed to avoid any slide into a gun culture in this country. It is our obligation to build a better and a safer community for all Australians.

In recording my thanks to the governments of the Australian states and territories, can I also record my thanks for the wholehearted bipartisan support extended to the government on this occasion by the Labor Party opposition and by the Australian Democrats in the Senate. I commend the bill to honourable members. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill and to the Income Tax Assessment Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tanner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The bill makes consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in relation to the payment of a proportion of the full Medicare levy, equivalent to a rate of 0.2 per cent, by defence personnel and their relatives or associates who are currently exempt from the Medicare levy. This allows such persons to be subject to the community‐wide impost which is designed to raise funds to reimburse states and territories for pay ments made under the gun buyback scheme. I commend the bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tanner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move amendments Nos 8 and 9:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 71, page 59, lines 5 and 6, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclauses:
(2) Subject to subsection (3), the Minister may, by written notice given to the company, exempt the draft plan from sections 69 to 70.

(3) The Minister shall only exempt the draft plan from sections 69 and 70 where the final master plan is being replaced by a draft plan which varies the original master plan only with respect to proposed changes which have already been the subject of public comment or consultations pursuant to sections 69 and 70.
(9) Clause 117, page 96, lines 24 and 25, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclause:
(2) Subject to subsection (3), the Minister may, by written notice given to the company, exempt the draft strategy from sections 115 and 116.

(3) The Minister shall only exempt the draft strategy from sections 115 and 116 where the final environmental strategy is being replaced by a draft strategy which varies the original strategy only with respect to proposed changes which have already been the subject of public comment or consultations pursuant to sections 115 and 116.
These amendments relate to one quite significant change which has been made to the legislation in comparison with the equivalent legislation introduced to the House by the former Keating government.

The change was explained in the second reading speech by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and it relates to the power on the part of the minister to exempt a private leaseholder of an airport from engaging in a process of public consultation and public comment with respect to a draft plan or strategic plan for the airport and for environmental considerations.

BREAK.PARA: The reason for it, as explained by the minister in the second reading speech, the opposition finds quite reasonable but we believe that the initial component of the legislation that has been put forward by the government is far broader than the intention announced by the minister.

The minister indicated that it was his intention to give the minister a power to exempt the leaseholder from public consultation and comment processes where those processes have previously occurred, a draft strategy plan was in place and, as a result of those processes having occurred, there was a need for an amendment to the plan and, therefore, under the previous government's legislation there would have had to be another round of public consultation. That arrangement opened up the possibility of an endless cycle of public consultation/amendment/further public consultation.

The opposition does not oppose the intention of the government. However, what we are concerned about is the fact that the provision that has been inserted effectively gives the minister the power to exempt a leaseholder from any public consultation process at all, including that with respect to the original plan or the original strategy that is under consideration.

The two amendments that I have put forward in effect narrow the scope of the ministerial power to the specific situation that the minister identified in his second reading speech, namely where there has been a draft plan put forward, where it has been subject to public consultation and comment and, as a result of that consultation and comment, a change is proposed to be made by the leaseholder. We think it is reasonable in those circumstances that, if the changes proposed have already been the subject of some public comment and consultation, there should not necessarily be a requirement for further consultation about making that change. The intention of our amendments is to narrow the power of the minister to exempt the leaseholder from any public comment to that particular situation.

The minister has indicated previously a preparedness to consider these amendments. I understand he will be opposing them at this stage but will give further thought to the matter prior to the bill going to the Senate. On the basis that he accepts at least the intention and logic of what the opposition is putting forward here, if not the precise words, and that he will give some consideration to the proposition that we are advancing and reconsider the position prior to the matter going to the Senate, it is not the opposition's intention to divide on this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the remarks made by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) in this regard. As he has pointed out, the intention of the government was to streamline the process and to make it more efficient. If we did not have this exemption in there, it would lead to an ongoing, endless round of consultations followed by amendments following which would require more consultations which would require more amendments which would just see us never getting anything done. I think the shadow minister has made that point quite clearly in his remarks and I appreciate that. We will consider the matter between now and when the bill passes through the Senate. When the bill comes to the Senate you will know what our response is. I thank the member for his decision to not divide on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence I rise to speak in this debate because the electorate of Banks is situated next to the Holsworthy site. I believe that this is a ridiculous proposal. The Holsworthy site is within three kilometres of some of the fastest growing residential areas in Sydney. In 1985, an environmental impact study found that Holsworthy was the second worst of 10 possible airport sites. Unexploded ammunition and the rugged terrain—

—I rise on a point of order. I know the honourable member sought your indulgence in making his contribution today, but what we have been debating is only two amendments—Nos. 8 and 9—and I suspect that what the honourable member is trying to do is engage in debate that we have already had.

—I understand what the minister is saying, but the question is that the bill be agreed to with these amendments either in or out of it, so the honourable member for Banks, as there is no point of order, has the right to resume.

—The point that needs to be made is the comparison in relation to what we did on these proposals and what the now government is doing. An environmental impact study in 1985 found that Holsworthy was the second worst of 10 possible airport sites. Unexploded ammunition and the rugged terrain ruled out its development. These problems still exist. The expenses involved in converting it to an international airport would be phenomenal. The Howard government's proposal would be catastrophic for the Banks electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed site is to the south‐west of East Hills, in the neighbouring electorate of Hughes. The Bankstown‐St George area already suffers considerable noise pollution from Kingsford Smith and Bankstown airports. It is an outrage that, despite having knowledge of the Holsworthy proposal, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) chose not to inform the electors of Banks of this proposal prior to the election or, indeed, any of the electors in the south‐west region. I am totally opposed to this project.

The Prime Minister's attempts to insulate his own electorate from any aircraft noise and inflict it upon the people of Bankstown is unjust and must be stopped. I assure the electors of Banks that I will be doing everything that I can to stop this proposal. It is an outrage.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
