DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (NEWLY ARRIVED RESIDENT'S WAITING PERIODS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"the House is of the opinion that the Bill should be withdrawn, redrafted and re‐presented to the House in a form which applies the two year waiting period only to those payments to which the six month waiting period currently applies because in its current form, and despite assurances from the Prime Minister that the measure simply extends the six month waiting period to two years, the Bill—
(1) extends the waiting period to a new group of citizens and residents;
(2) extends the waiting period to a wide range of new payments, benefits and entitlements;
(3) provides an inadequate safety net; and
(4) is retrospective".

I would introduce my comments on this legislation, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill, by referring to remarks which were included in the 1996 State of the World's Children Report, a publication of UNICEF. Speaking of children in states of war they said:

The plight of children in war‐time contradicts not only every normal human concern for their welfare but also the professed beliefs and legal obligations of those responsible. . . UNICEF believes that insisting on the rights of children is one of the best ways of reasserting core humanitarian values.

This is a useful way to introduce debate on this legislation because it is important that we focus on the professed beliefs of this government and the core humanitarian values it asserts that are undermined by this heinous piece of legislation.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), when he was Leader of the Opposition, set forth a number of key principles prior to the last election. Included in his approach towards the area of immigration was a commitment to principles of multiculturalism and non‐discriminatory practices and outcomes. In his speech to ACOSS he committed himself to an approach which would protect those who are least well off and most vulnerable in our society.

However, this legislation undermines both those commitments. It is discriminatory and it impacts most adversely on those who are most vulnerable and least well off in our society. If you take a child's eye view of this legislation, that child would be asking, `Why, unlike all other children of permanent residents of Australia and citizens of this country, am I hungry? Why is it that I alone have parents who are not able to access the normal rates of family allowance that I in my destitution require for my food and sustenance? And despite the harsh special benefits tests that are being proposed in this legislation, and even though the department has assessed that my family through no fault of its own could not have anticipated the circumstances that have arisen to affect me and my family, why is it that I am being treated in this discriminatory way?'

The differences are not trivial. The harshness in this legislation is not merely to exclude all but 10 per cent of those persons who might ordinarily have come forward to seek access to special benefits, and that is the estimate from the advisers to the government on this point, but it is harsh also to say that even those people who fit the very tough test that has been set, who show that their hardship could not have been possibly anticipated, that their change of circumstances arose through no fault of their own and in circumstances where they could not have possibly anticipated it, do not have access to full family allowance in breach of what was asserted by the Prime Minister before the election and thus leaving the children of those families in great poverty.

The difference is not slight. For example, taking a family with five kids, the difference is this: if you assume that three of those children are triplets—and there are special benefits for multiple births which that family will not now be eligible for—then the access to the special benefits safety net with a minimum family payment will be $113.50 a fortnight; that is, $22.70 per child.

However, if that family is in destitution and needs, as the rest of the community does, a support basis that is able to sustain them because of their poverty and indigence through no fault of their own, they would normally have access to a maximum family payment of five times $93.10—a total sum of $465.50 a fortnight. In addition, they would be eligible for a multiple birth allowance of $90.90, a family supplement of $15 and rent assistance of $97.40—a total of $668.80. That exceeds by $550 per fortnight that which would be available to new arrivals in indigent circumstances.

What is the history of these measures? Why do we find ourselves in circumstances where anyone applying the UNICEF test—that is, looking at this legislation in terms of the rights of a child—finds that a child member of a resident family is being treated in this discriminatory way? Why is this the outcome?

The government says that all they are doing is extending a principle introduced by the former Labor government. So it is important to look at some of the history.In 1993, the then government introduced a six‐month waiting period for new arrivals to this country to ensure that those new arrivals and their sponsors met some of the incidental costs of their initial settlement. The six‐month period was selected as a balance. We had to meet our responsibilities as an Australian community to welcome and accept those who were here to become our new citizens—to provide for them a range of universal benefits through the health system, through educational opportunities and through welfare benefits. We had to provide for them a network of access and equity opportunities, and training in skills that are necessary for them to be able to take advantage of their new residency in this country, for example, language training.

We put on one side our responsibility for these universal approaches, and on the other side we put the responsibility of those who sponsor new arrivals to meet the costs that are incidental to that new settlement. Six months was an appropriate balancing point. We made two exceptions to this: first, those who came here as refugees, or who came under the humanitarian program; and second, marriage partners of Australians.

We took the view, and it was not contested at the time, that it was not part of this government's responsibility, or any government's responsibility, to tell Australians whom they could marry. To apply a waiting period to new arrivals coming here as the spouses of long‐term residents and citizens of this country would intrude into one of the most fundamental rights of Australians, which is that of being able to select their life partner. We did it to enable that person to immediately form their family without their children being prejudiced in the way that I described before, and without their partner being subject to discriminatory tests which excluded them from a range of benefits that are otherwise available to the Australian community.
In its run‐up to the last election, the coalition addressed the question of a six‐month waiting period. In its policy document, `Meeting our commitments', released in February, it said:
Access to welfare benefits for migrants other than refugee and humanitarian migrants will be available after two years under a Coalition Government.
The document went on:

Full access to Family Allowance and Medicare will be maintained for all migrants immediately upon arrival. As well, the Coalition will provide a `safety net' in the form of a special allowance for those migrants whose circumstances change significantly after arrival in Australia for reasons beyond their personal control.
Those savings referred to in `Meeting our commitments' were costed at $616 million, but the coalition gave assurances that they

BREAK.PARA: would not be applied in a way which was inconsistent with the ordinary understanding of an extension of the previous government's safety net. The then shadow minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Jim Short, in a press release of 19 February said:
The Coalition's proposal to extend the six months to two years is simply an extended application of the principle established by Labor in 1993.

That is, they merely extended the period for the excluded benefits—jobsearch, newstart, youth training, parenting and sickness allowance—without any mention of an extension to new classes of persons who might be subject to exclusion or of extending the range of measures which would be subject to those exclusions. Indeed, the now Prime Minister gave a personal pledge on 16 February during the election campaign.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. I refer to the fact that the national accounts figures for the March quarter released today show growth in the March quarter of 1.8 per cent and 4.8 per cent for the 12 months to March. In light of these figures, does the Treasurer acknowledge that the growth forecasts for the years 1995‐96 and 1996‐97 of 3¼ per cent on which his revised budget forecasts were based are now completely out of date? Does he agree that, as the growth is now considerably stronger than that forecast in the 1995 budget, the so‐called $8 billion black hole which he has tried to make so much of does not now exist? Will he now concede that the only black hole is the $4 billion worth of unfunded election promises which he is yet to explain to this parliament or the Australian people?
—I call the Treasurer.
—Your ideas have disappeared out the backdoor. Where is all the smug arrogance? Do you want a little bit of protection for the little boy?
—Order! You have asked the question. There is an answer forthcoming.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Agitation is a sign of a guilty conscience, may I say to the Leader of the Opposition. In relation to the last part of the question, the Leader of the Opposition—Australia's foremost failure as Minister for Finance in the Keating government—is still, of course, smarting from his defeat during the election campaign when, with the resources of the Department of Finance, he was unable to punch one single hole in any of the coalition's election program. Not only did he put the whole of the finance department onto the work but when he got the results back he sat on them for a week and then tried to doctor them in his own office—and you know you did. But throughout the whole of that period you could not ask them what the forecasts were for the 1996‐97 year. You had the `Don't ask, don't tell' policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The last thing you wanted to know in the course of the election campaign was what you were already in possession of and could have got at any moment whatsoever from the Treasury and the finance department—material that was produced for us before 2 March. No wonder you are smarting today. No wonder you were agitated about it.

Let me say in relation to this that this government is a government that welcomes growth. This government is pleased to be able to say that the Australian economy is growing. And I have to tell you: expect more of it, expect more growth under the Australian economy by the time we take all of the measures that Labor failed to take—a slothful government of absolute failure which put Australia in a position after 19 quarters of positive growth of still running deficits, and deficits projected at the order of $8 billion.

As I said to this House before, and I will say it over and over again, you will live forever with your failure to disclose during the election campaign the true state, which was always available to you. No amount of joviality, no amount of interjection, no amount of agitation, no amount of confected laughter—and it is the confected laughter that we like the best—will ever hide the true deceit that you practised during the campaign, and we will make sure with our charter of budget honesty that nobody can ever do a Beazley in Australia again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House of the outcome of the March quarter national accounts released earlier today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics? Are there any implications for the government's announced fiscal consolidation program resulting from these figures?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the background noise, Treasurer, do you want the question repeated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Speaker, we have learned to put up with persistent minorities over on that side of the House. The national accounts show strong growth in GDP of 1.8 per cent in the March quarter and 4.8 per cent in the year to March—growth that we welcome.
—Well done, Ralph.

—Thank you. The government takes the congratulations. We are particularly pleased to say that private business investment grew strongly, at around seven per cent during the March quarter, with rapid growth in plant and equipment, consistent with earlier indications from the ABS that firms were deferring investment from the first half of 1995‐96 into later in the year and, of course, the business confidence effects from the election of the coalition government on 2 March.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been hearing for weeks from that side of the House that fiscal consolidation would bring on some new kind of recession—and I have never seen a group of people so disappointed by strong growth. We on this side of the House have always maintained that fiscal consolidation would have confidence effects—confidence effects from a government which is prepared to put Australia in a position to develop savings, which is prepared to put Australia in a position where micro‐economic reform goes forward and which is prepared to put Australia in a position for industrial relations reform. The business and confidence effects of that, and the prospects of setting up for Australia a climate for long‐term investment, are things that only a coalition government can deliver.

Let me make it clear that this government will not be a government, unlike the failed Labor administration, that runs up debt and bequeaths it to our children—intergenerational theft, a tripling of Commonwealth debt over four years, persistent deficits after 19 quarters of economic growth. This government will not, like the Labor profligate government, have the intergenerational effects on young people which denies them opportunity. We will make sure that we have fiscal consolidation. We will make sure that we attend to all of those matters which are so important for long‐term growth. This is a government which will not shirk its responsibilities and will deliver for the national interest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does he recall saying about then Prime Minister Keating during the election campaign in relation to the budget:

QUESTION.PARA: What I'm saying is if the material already in the public domain has materially changed and he knows it he has a moral obligation to make that public.

Was that a confidence builder or a confidence trick? Following the joint economic forecasting group round that would normally follow the release of the national accounts today, will he ensure that the revised economic forecast for 1995-96 and 1996-97 and the revised budget starting point numbers that will be based on those economic forecasts are released just as soon as they are available, as he demanded from us?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell the Deputy Leader of the Opposition what I will ensure. With the support, I hope, of both sides of the parliament, I will ensure that the law of this country is changed so that when the next election is held the estimates will be automatically published. It will be very interesting to see whether your leader votes for that measure.

—Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question under standing order 152. Will the Prime Minister release the revised forecasts of the joint economic forecasting group, which is what you were asked to answer?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We had a supplementary question yesterday. I appreciate that over the years on a very infrequent basis supplementary questions have been asked. It is also a convention of the House that supplementary questions would only be asked on an infrequent basis and in particular circumstances. I draw your attention to the fact that the Procedure Committee in both 1986 and 1993 has referred to and examined the question of whether or not there should be supplementary questions. The previous government refused to accept those recommendations. So, on that basis, I ask you to exercise the discretion that you have and rule the question out of order.

—Order! The Leader of the House raises a very interesting point. I would always unequivocally retain the option of seeing a supplementary question asked. But in this instance, as the original question was asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the supplementary was being asked by the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the Opposition's supplementary question is ruled out of order.
—Can I relieve you of that dilemma by asking a supplementary question myself? In the same terms, will he release the JEFG forecasts as soon as they are made?

—In the spirit of comity—I do not like to see them too embarrassed with their procedures—I say additionally to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that there will be some further forecasts of future economic activity released in less than three month's time when the budget is brought down. I promise the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that if in the unlikely—
—But here it is. You have a moral obligation—

—Are you going to hand me a question time roster again, are you? I say to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that if in the unlikely event there is another election between now and when the budget is brought down I can assure you that the revised forward estimates will be released when the election campaign starts.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House whether he believes that all taxpayers should be equal before the law? Is the Treasurer aware of any situation under the previous Labor government where this was not the case? If so, can he advise the House how such an anomaly arose and what action the government is taking to address such an inequality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does believe that all taxpayers should pay their due and lawful tax requirements. I would have hoped that that was a principle shared by both sides of the House, but apparently it is not. It has been brought to my attention that members of the Building Workers Union have organised a protest and demonstration today seeking exemption from travel allowances from this government.
—Tell us about your family trust.

—I notice that the honourable member for Batman, Mr Martin Ferguson, interjects. I see that the rally on exemption from income tax was led by a Mr Andrew Ferguson of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union. He wouldn't be any relation, would he? He wouldn't be out there on the barricades claiming that there should be an exemption from taxation for him and his members in relation to travel allowances, would he?

ANSWER.PARA: It is the policy of this government that allowances should be subject to taxation. Unfortunately, in December of last year, on the eve of the election, the then Treasurer, Mr Willis, announced that there would be a new law introduced into the parliament to exempt building workers' travel award allowances from income tax.

Let me make it entirely clear, Mr Speaker, that this government does not support the policy of introducing new legislation to exempt a privileged minority of the work force from taxation. Building workers' travel allowances are subject to tax as are other allowances from other employees under other awards—indeed, from employees generally.

Unless the opposition can bring itself to come out and condemn this demonstration—it ought to be condemning this demonstration—it must wear the stigma of blatant and outright support for tax and special exemptions sought by privileged minorities of the work force. This opposition should be making it clear that there would be no comity in relation to exemption from taxation of award allowances. That is certainly the position of this government.

There is no point in tax avoiders who seek to avoid capital gains tax or capital taxes of any other kinds, or tax avoiders of any other kind, having rallies down the street or seeking to invade the Australian Taxation Office. They will not get exemptions from this government through the use of industrial muscle.

If we ever see a demonstration of capital gains tax avoiders in Burke Street or anywhere else, let me make it entirely clear to them that they will not be getting exemptions from taxation, any more than building workers will be getting exemption from taxation. I would also hope that if there be demonstrations of capital gains tax avoiders in the streets they will not have the support of the Labor Party. I would hope that would be their principle, that the Labor Party would not distinguish on the basis of the special or powerful interests that control it and, in relation to this matters, lead it by the nose. This is a government which will make sure that the taxation system is uniformly applied, regardless of the nature of the occupation, and that it is applied in accordance with law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Given that growth in the first three quarters of 1995-96 has already exceeded the revised budget forecasts for those three quarters by a whopping 1.3 per cent, does the Treasurer not accept that the growth outcome for 1995‐96 is certain to be well above the revised budget forecast and, indeed, above the original budget forecast for 1995-96? As that stronger growth will bring stronger revenue growth and reduce outlays, does he not also accept that the budget outcome for 1995-96 is certain to be much better than the revised forecast? With a much better budget base for 1996-97 and better growth prospects for 1996-97, does he not now also accept that the revised budget forecasts for 1996‐97 are now totally out of date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the outcome for 1995-96, during the conduct of the previous Labor administration the position has slipped considerably. The Labor Party had relied on a capital repayment by Jeffrey Kennett to disguise the way in which the accounts had slipped. It had relied on a capital transaction as revenue to try to disguise the slippage in relation to that. The 1995-96 forecasts, leaving outside those special and one‐off transactions, will be for a deficit, and a sizeable deficit. In relation to 1996-97, of course there will be continual updates in relation to forecasts. As the Prime Minister has said—
—And when will we be told about them?

—You will be told about them. They will be contained in the budget, as they always are—in 2½ months, I believe it is. In relation to the figures today—figures which we welcome, figures which this government is proud to say it stands—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never seen so many people so upset by growth before. I have never seen you get so agitated by the successes of this government. In relation to 1996-97—
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: we have never seen a government so embarrassed by growth before.

—The member for Burke has tested my patience once too often. The terms of standing order 304A are hereby applied. Remove yourself from the chamber for one hour. If I have any other candidates, we will address the same problem just as effectively.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Burke thereupon withdrew from the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the 1996-97 forecast, they will be updated. There is nothing in today's figures which mean that those forecasts which were prepared by Treasury and released in March are markedly out of date. They will be updated and released in relation to August.

ANSWER.PARA: On no basis whatsoever would the projected $3.4 billion surplus ever have been achieved. In fact, that headline had turned to a deficit of $4.9 billion. That was the $8 billion turnaround which you refused to disclose and which you now refuse to take responsibility for. You will live with that forever.

That material was available to you. It was held down in the Treasury. All through the election campaign on the instructions of the then Prime Minister, with the connivance of the then finance minister, you refused to disclose it. That was the material which the Australian people were entitled to know about and that is the hole for which you will always bear responsibility. Let me make it entirely clear that we will never again allow the measure of deceit practised by Mr Beazley in relation to that to occur.

We will ensure that, in relation to future governments—as the Prime Minister has said—a charter of budget honesty will legislatively require this material to be released so that this can never be done again. I notice that the first thing you did after the election as Leader of the Opposition was state that you did not agree with a charter of budget honesty. Of course you would not agree with it. You would no more agree with a charter of budget honesty than a thief would approve of improving the criminal theft laws. You would never agree with a charter of budget honesty, because it would never allow people to do what you did in relation to those forecasts.

I hope that the opposition reconsiders its position in relation to this, that it does support a charter of budget honesty, and that it makes sure that, in respect of the information that is known, the people of Australia are let in on the secret during the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware of renewed discussion in various parts of the country about decriminalising the use of marijuana. Is the government taking any action in relation to Customs which would, in effect, allow small quantities to be brought into Australia for what is commonly known as `personal use'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable members will be aware of the debate that is taking place not only in Victoria but also, I suspect, in other parts of Australia, about the question of decriminalising the use of marijuana. I say at the outset that I think the Premier of Victoria and others who have been associated with promoting this debate deserve the congratulations of the community for the courage that they have displayed in raising and confronting such a sensitive issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is fair to say that this issue cuts across normal party political divisions. I have no doubt that, within my own party, there are people who hold widely divergent views on this subject; and I have no doubt that, within the ranks opposite, there are people who hold widely divergent views on this subject. This is one of those issues where political leaders do have some responsibility to enter the debate and express a view and not simply hide behind the obvious fact that the primary legislative responsibility for these things does belong to state and territorial governments.
I would have to say that I would be extremely reluctant to see any weakening in the existing laws. I know that, in saying so, I will probably be—

TALK.START.PARA: —This would be a way to distract attention from the growth figures, would it? You can see the headlines tomorrow—
—The member for Melbourne. You have waved your arms once too often.

—I will probably be widely criticised by some in the community and probably by some within my own ranks. I know there are arguments about consistency; there are arguments addressed to the hypocrisy of laws which permit the legal consumption of alcohol and tobacco, yet impose penalties on the consumption of marijuana. However, I also know that it is an undoubted fact that, if the laws relating to marijuana are relaxed, that sends an unambiguous signal to the community that there is less disapproval of the consumption of a substance which, on all of the available medical evidence, does considerable damage or has the potential to do considerable damage to both the body and the mind. All of the medical evidence, as distinct from the other evidence, indicates that the proposition that marijuana can be freely consumed without any damage being done is absolute nonsense.

ANSWER.PARA: The other observation that ought to be made is that those in the community who have responsibility should not only examine the clinical, medical and scientific evidence, they should also take into account the perceptions that are formed by changes of direction in this area. I have no doubt that, if there were significant nationwide changes in the laws, that would send a very negative signal to many parents in Australia who are struggling to promote a particular view about the conduct of their children. Those who imagine that you can simply approach this issue on the basis of the clinical evidence and not take into account the impact of such decisions on the attitudes of the young and the attitudes of the community generally towards the prohibition of particular substances are being quite unrealistic.

In making these observations, I do not seek to impose any moral judgments. I simply propose to make the realistic observation that, when society contemplates taking a course of action which is going to in some way signal a greater acceptance of a substance which demonstrably does harm to people, society should pause before it takes that step.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer to reports that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is pursuing across‐the‐ board cuts to university funding of between five and 12 per cent and increases in HECS and other fees. Has the Prime Minister seen reports of comments by the Vice-Chancellor of La Trobe University, Professor Osborne, who said today:

QUESTION.PARA: I haven't heard her—
that is, Senator Vanstone—
say anything that leads me to think that she has a vision for education for the next five years.
Specifically, on the government's proposal to increase HECS fees, he said:
It wasn't long ago that only people from wealthy backgrounds could go to university. Over the last 10 years, we have done very well in Australia, trying to open up opportunities for everyone.
Is the Prime Minister also aware that Professor Osborne said about the proposed cuts:
This is the worst moment that higher education has ever faced. This is going to lead to turmoil, worry, stress and hell for just about everybody.

Will the Prime Minister guarantee that the government will not cut university funding by between five and 12 per cent and that HECS will not rise? In light of the nationwide concern expressed by vice‐chancellors—

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I accept that the Leader of the Opposition is allowed some latitude with regard to the length of the questions he can ask, there is a limit. I suggest that you draw his attention to that limit.
—The Deputy Prime Minister's points are noted. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to quickly draw his question to a conclusion.

—Finally, in light of the nationwide concern being expressed by vice-chancellors about the performance of the minister for education, does the Prime Minister continue to have confidence in the minister?

—I certainly do continue to have complete confidence in the minister, both publicly and privately. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that I will not respond to the speculation about the budget responses to the higher education sector, beyond saying two or three things. The first of those is that the coalition continues to place an enormous amount of store on the importance of higher education in this country. The contribution of higher education to Australia and to Australia's future is immense and it will continue to be regarded as such by this government. It is obvious that the government, faced with the need to achieve significant public savings and having regard to areas of priority, must examine all of the areas of government outlay.
—You have been blown out of the water.

—The member for Hotham says we are blown out of the water. I am indebted to him once again. The opposition are getting very excited about the fact that there was a higher growth figure, which I welcome enthusiastically.
—You made a promise.

—I will come back to that, but you were kind enough to interject. You remind me of the irony of this. The fact that we have higher growth is not only good but also demonstrates how negligent you were in allowing the budget to be in such an appalling state of deficit. Just imagine the problem we would have faced if we had had much lower growth in the March quarter. After that very welcome interjection from the member for Hotham, I return to the question of higher education. I am not going to respond to every piece of speculation. I have been approached by the vice‐chancellors and I propose to have a discussion with them over the next couple of weeks.
—You said you would come back to the promises, John.

—As far as promises are concerned, I say to honourable members opposite—and I take the opportunity of saying to the entire Australian community—that when the budget is brought down on 20 August it will be made very plain to those opposite that, of all the governments that have occupied the treasury bench in this country in recent years, none will have placed a greater store on keeping promises than the government that I am proud to lead.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister clarify the scope of the protections in the government's industrial relations package against discrimination on the basis of gender?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly can. In fact, the equal pay for work of equal value principle is a very important principle. It is a principle which the government is determined to uphold, and the package does, in fact, do so in a number of ways. We have included within the objects of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill a specific object to highlight the importance which the government places on anti-discrimination provisions, which include anti‐discrimination provisions in respect of awards, agreements, certified agreements and the like. We will therefore require the commission, in its award making function, to abide by that criteria. In the certified agreement process the commission is also required to take that into account, and the principle of equal pay for work of equal value is a minimum condition for those entering into Australian workplace agreements. I have had very constructive meetings with a number of women's organisations which have raised this issue with me. Let me stress that the principle is upheld in this legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The only debate and remaining issue for discussion has been a matter of process in regard to that principle in respect of overaward payments. In that matter I suppose the policy choices have been whether or not people would make application to the Industrial Relations Commission or to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We have opted for the latter because we think it is a better means to proceed. In fact, our support for doing so is actually endorsed by a paper which canvassed these issues some years ago entitled Just rewards which was under the auspices of the then Sex Discrimination Commissioner, who pointed out the validity of people making claims to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —It only applies to individual cases.

—There is an interjection that it only applies to individual cases. In fact, you can have complaints covering a much broader range than an individual one in an application to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. I have actually spoken to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and, whilst I acknowledge there are differences of opinion as to how these things can be approached, in fairness it is—
—This is one of your stooges!

—I am tempted. It is a fact that the principle is not at stake. The principle is upheld. There has been a debate about process but I think, on any fair evaluation of the genuine debate on these issues, we have upheld the principle and ensured that remedies are available to people. On that basis, the provisions are very fair and reasonable.

—My question to the Minister for Industrial Relations also relates to the impact of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Bill on lower paid workers, in particular reference to women. Is the minister aware there are 18,317 workers employed in the hospitality industry who receive superannuation entitlements from their employers under the applicable award, even though their income is less than the statutory threshold? If awards can no longer provide for superannuation, will these low paid employees, 65 per cent of whom are women, be completely denied access to superannuation? Won't these employees be worse off under your proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's proposal in the award simplification process is that a number of matters should be within the jurisdiction of the commission and that a number of matters which today fall within the wider powers of the commission should no longer do so. We have a list of allowable matters in the legislation, and it does not include superannuation. That is true. If you went back to the 1994 Working Nation policy proposals, for example, you would see that it was not proposed by the previous government that superannuation be an award matter either.
—What are you talking about? You are taking it away.

—It is amazing that we get these questions. What we see happening within the opposition ranks is that they are now recanting on a whole series of propositions which they publicly advanced and said would be beneficial and would actually improve the circumstances of working people. They are regressing into the tightly knit little group run by the ACTU, which has for so long dictated their policy approach and which for so long has seen the previous government withdraw from its publicly stated comments as to what ought to be done.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect to superannuation, the fact is that we have federal law which prescribes the conditions which apply to superannuation. That federal law will provide people with the protection which is necessary and which the parliament has deemed as being appropriate in terms of the access to superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What are the government's plans in relation to the importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia? What justification is there for allowing chicken meat into Australia?
—Order, or we will be cooking somebody else's goose!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the question. I was not quite sure which honourable member it was going to come from. It is a question that is of importance to a number of people in this place and which actually goes to the heart of the costs and benefits to this country of trade liberalisation. Australia exports about 80 per cent of its agricultural output. The simple situation is that we simply cannot press our access concerns with other countries if we ourselves are not prepared to consider access requirements made of us.

PARA.BREAK: Australia has benefited enormously from trade liberalisation, with vastly improved acc ess to America and Canada for beef. We now have rice going into Japan, and we have very significantly increased access to the Philippines and America for citrus.

ANSWER.PARA: I come back to the issue of chicken meat. I note that the Director of Quarantine has not yet acted on the AQIS import analysis. Applications were received by AQIS from several countries quite a few years ago to import fresh, frozen and cooked chicken meat.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about uncooked?

—Uncooked as well. It was decided then to look firstly at cooked chicken meat. Prior to the 1996 election, I gave a commitment—I advised the poultry industry—that it was my intention to suspend the approval of any new import protocols pending the Nairn review findings later this year. This will be honoured in relation to such issues as salmon imports and fresh chicken. However, in relation to cooked chicken meat, we found a very different situation, one forced upon us by the mismanagement of the previous government. That is the simple fact of the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: AQIS recommended in June 1994 that cooked product should be admitted, providing it met certain strict conditions, including time temperature parameters which would inactivate disease agents of concern, including Newcastle disease. I would have thought that this was a matter of considerable importance to many people on both sides of the House, including the member for Hunter.

In the consultation phase that followed, the effectiveness of AQIS's proposed time temperature parameters as a minimum treatment against disease agents of quarantine concern was agreed by a wide range of independent scientific authorities. In other words, it was very widely reviewed by independent assessors and agreed by the Australian Poultry Industry Association and the national poultry association.

AQIS advised the former minister on 30 May 1995 that the technical assessments were complete and that access would be granted to the USA and Denmark and possibly to Thailand. The previous minister signed off on 2 June last year. He said he wanted to undertake a little bit of final consultation. Nine months went by and he did not do it. What did he do by stalling for nine months? He exposed the director of AQIS to legal challenge and Australia to reaction internationally for not keeping our commitments in relation to access. This is the result of mismanagement by the previous minister and his comments have reflected that he knows that that is the case.

What was the situation the government faced in government? Firstly, AQIS had concluded its technical assessment a year ago. Secondly, the decision is the Director of Quarantine's to take under the Quarantine Act. Thirdly, AQIS is required to make a decision without unreasonable delay. Fourthly, there is widespread agreement on the scientific analysis being carefully crosschecked and, therefore, there is no strong reason to question the AQIS analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about those affected?
—In relation to those affected, since that is what you want to know about, there is to be a further round of talks with the industry on 5 June to discuss the matter—
—Don't you want that?
—Don't you want us to have it?
—We want you to stick to your promises. Do not break them.

—We will sort out the mess that your previous minister left. Are you arguing that we ought to go back on our trade access conditions and what we have committed ourselves to? We are meeting with the industry again next week to continue the constructive negotiations on the questions of ensuring that the processing systems in exporting nations are up to scratch and to work through any adjustment questions. I conclude by saying that we give the assurance that no compromise on proper and thorough scientific analysis will be enabled.

—The minister was quoting extensively from notes; I wonder whether he might table those. Given that we gave him the question yesterday, he has had all day to prepare the response. We would like to have a copy of it.
—The minister declines your very kind offer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I seek further clarification on an aspect of the Workplace Relations Bill. Minister, yesterday in response to questions on the bill, your answers referred only to people remaining in the same job. My question refers to the 370,000 young people who will start in a new job over the next year. I take the case of a 16-year-old who has just completed year 10 and wins a job as a trainee in the textile industry and spends a third of their working time in training. Is it not true that at present their wage cannot fall below $149 per week? Is it not true also that, under your bill, their wage can be as low as $130 per week—a 15 per cent difference? Is this because your bill allows young people's wages to be discounted twice—once for age and once for training? Do you still, therefore, claim that young workers will not be worse off under your bill? Will you amend the bill to ensure that they are not?
—I do claim that they are not worse off.
—Well, will you amend it if we show that is the case?

—I am happy to answer the question. I do so on the basis of a table which I just so happen to have with me about the national training wage. It refers to 16-year-olds and lists what they are to be paid.
—In the textile industry?

—In a series of industries. They are retail, wholesale, metals, accommodation, restaurants, finance, insurance, property and business, public sector, health and community, child care, and transport. As I understand it, under the national training wage you can have a discount both against the junior rate as well as—
—Well, we have our information.
—I would be happy to be corrected on that.
—You didn't answer it yesterday.

—Just wait. You have put a figure to me. Under the national training wage—and your question is a bit like the question we had yesterday—if you work half the time and train half the time, then in those circumstances you are paid at 50 per cent the rate. In fact, in each and every one of those classifications that I have just read out to you, in respect of junior wages—that is the actual title on the table—the weekly wage rate for those employees is $128. So are they worse off? No, they are not. This is simply the application of the principle which you yourself have endorsed.

BREAK.PARA: It is absolutely amazing that this question is premised on the claim that we should deny the principle that people should be paid on the basis of their productive outwork. We ought to have question time for those opposite for a change. My question for the shadow minister for industrial relations is this: why are you today letting your colleague walk away from the very principle you publicly endorsed only as recently as last Thursday night? Is the deal fair for young people? Of course it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table documentation for the assistance of the minister that highlights this discrepancy that I have alluded to. It seems to me that the minister does not understand what this bill does.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of the strong feeling among women around Australia in favour of greater gun control? Is the government determined to implement the decisions of the recent police ministers conference to ensure that the outcome is both practical and successful?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of it, and I dare say that so is the Leader of the Opposition. Both of us participated earlier today in the launch of a petition which has been sponsored by what I might say is an extraordinarily wide spectrum of women's groups, stretching from the peace movement right through to the Country Women's Association, the Catholic Women's League and women's organisations from many of the other churches. I say to the honourable member for Lindsay and to all members that certainly the sense of strong support for the measures is coming through not only from women but also from men right across this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I also take the opportunity of saying to the House that there is no intention on the part of the government to sponsor any changes to the principles adopted at the police minister's conference. I have seen some reports which, to the extent that they are suggesting that any of the policy is going to be changed, are wrong. I would caution people, in commenting on this matter, not to confuse examination of the practical implementation of decisions taken with any attempts to alter those decisions. The decisions announced are going to be adhered to in full.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Given your responsibilities for Australian families, will you repudiate the offensive comments the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman, made in Senate question time yesterday—specifically the implication that a husband had the right—

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Crean interjecting—
Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There will be no across the table chat.

—Perhaps I should be asking the Prime Minister this question because he clearly endorses the views of Senator Newman, but I am asking the Minister for Family Services why doesn't she repudiate the implication that a husband has the right to send his—
—Order! The honourable member for Fremantle!
—Order! The honourable member for Fremantle! There has been so much disorder that I call the honourable member to begin her question again.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Given your responsibilities for Australian families, will you repudiate the offensive comments the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman, made in Senate question time yesterday and, specifically, will you repudiate the implication that a husband has the right to send his messy housewife packing if she does not manage the family budget properly? Do you endorse that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the hypocrisy is just unspeakable. The thought police ride again. Here we have a woman who walked away from the women in Western Australia, the women who were caught out by the Western Women saga. Here is a woman that says she stands up for women in Australia—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much unnecessary noise.

—What I can say is that there is no doubt that my colleague in the Senate has exposed the disgraceful manner by which the previous Labor government managed the financial affairs of this country—and I will say it again, Mr Speaker, the disgraceful Beazley $8 billion black hole. I will always support my colleagues when they expose the divisive and vindictive approach taken by the previous Labor government toward any female or male who happened to disagree with any Labor policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Speaker, I also support my colleagues who are exposing the hypocrisy of Labor's commitment to women. Look at how many women they have on that side of the House and how many women we have on this side of the House. What kind of commitment is that? Four women is the best they can achieve in the House of Representatives, and the Labor hierarchy showed no display of commitment to women in the lead‐up to the last election. We saw Jeanette McHugh give no support to Labor women candidates in the lead‐up to preselections for the last election. No support, Mr Speaker.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party has shown no support at all for women in this country. They talk about it; the rhetoric is there but the substance has never been there and it is still not there. The Liberal‐National parties have a proud record of supporting the achievements of women on their merits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Turn the page.

—Yes. The comment that was made by Senator Newman was equally directed at the wasteful management of both men and women. This is in contrast with the former minister for family services who denigrated the commitment of men when suggesting that men would need a road map to find their way around the supermarket.
—Mr Speaker, under standing order 321 I ask the minister to table the document she is quoting from.
—Is the minister reading from confidential documents?
—No.
—She was quoting from a document.
—Then I ask the minister to table them. You are reading from confidential documents?
—They are private notes.
—You said they weren't.
—Could I take a point of order, Mr Speaker?
—Order! Given the level of background noise which seems to be debilitating this parliament today, I am sure the minister misheard the question. There will be no further debate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Walter and Eliza Hall Institute: Retiring Scientists

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Science and Technology. Is the minister aware of the imminent retirement of leading figures at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute in Melbourne? What has been the contribution of those individuals to Australia's research effort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Parramatta for his question. It is the second question he has posed on science and technology, which is two more than the shadow minister for science and technology has managed to convince his tactics committee to ask. This side of the House places a great deal of importance on research and development, science and technology. We wish to recognise those who have distinguished themselves in the cause of the nation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that three of the nation's pre‐eminent scientists—Professor Sir Gus Nossal, Professor Don Metcalf and Professor Jacques Miller—are retiring early next week from the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of medical and scientific research in Melbourne. Sir Gus Nossal served 31 years as director of the institute; Professor Metcalf, 31 years as assistant director and head of the cancer research unit; and Professor Jacques Miller, 30 years as head of the thymus biology unit. They now retire from the institute after a remarkable period of some 30 years of leadership, fostering young scientists and breakthroughs that have startled the world. They have individually and collectively inspired successive generations of scientists, doctors, researchers, technologists and, I am happy to say, politicians.

Sir Gus Nossal's research is in fundamental immunology, and he has written five books and 480 scientific articles in this and related fields. He was elected to the fellowship of the Academy of Science in 1967, and he is currently president of the Academy of Science. Many past and present members of this House have enjoyed the friendship and advice of Sir Gus Nossal. He has been, and continues to be, a fearless advocate for science and technology.

Professor Don Metcalf is distinguished for his work on the control of leukemic cells. He has published 500 scientific papers and six books on his research, and he has been recognised internationally as a leader in this field.

Professor Miller's seminal discoveries and subsequent works on the immune system have led to more effective vaccines and immunosuppressive agents. His publications in scientific articles and journals number more than 370.

BREAK.PARA: Needless to say, this is but the most cursory examination of their very long and distinguished service to the country. Each has received national and international honours and awards. I have not begun to touch on their involvement in government advisory bodies and boards or their influence on public policy, nor on their charity work. They are three great Australians of whom we are very proud. How can you measure their contribution to the community? You cannot, except to say that modern medicine would not be so advanced without their efforts.

I should stress that they will not be lost to science altogether. Their work will continue in different ways in different places. Some believe, and have stated recently, that we will not see their like again, but we will because they have ensured we will, for they have prepared and nurtured following generations of scientists. The nation owes each one of them a debt of gratitude. I know the House joins me in expressing our thanks and best wishes for them in their retirement, wherever it takes them in their continuing dedication to science and technology.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. It relates to the Prime Minister's repeated statement that `the burden of reigning in the deficit will be shared equitably amongst all Australians'. I refer to the minister's decision to freeze spending on labour market programs. Has he been advised by his department of other options which would have avoided the freeze? Did they advise him that existing flexibility arrangements could be used to cover any projected shortfall? Was he also advised that it—and I refer to his departmental brief:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . allows us to maintain the momentum of new labour program activity across all programs for the remaining four months to the financial year.
Why then did he choose to make unemployed Australians suffer when he had the means at his disposal to continue the assistance they needed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Batman knows, there has been no freeze; there has been no freeze whatever on labour market programs. Funding is continuing to flow through into programs, particularly the most successful program. I will tell you what we are doing: we are having to manage a sum of money which is—

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the minister is misleading the House. He knows very well that skillshare programs were informed—and I am a chairman of a skillshare program—that they have to cut one-third as from September.
—The member will resume his seat. There is no point of order. If you want to proceed on misleading, do it in a substantive way.

—There has been no freeze on skillshare funding. The government has entered into an agreement with skillshare particularly to continue funding into the next financial year. There has been an agreement to extend funding for three months, and over those three months they will receive funding of two‐thirds of the rate that was made available to them in the previous year.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason there is a squeeze—nobody questions this—on labour market funding at the moment is that the two billion dollar man sitting right there spent $2 billion out of a $2.1 billion budget. He spent and committed 95 per cent of that budget up to the election time. You did that. Ninety‐five per cent of that labour market budget for 1995-96 was committed by the two billion dollar man—the member for Hotham—in an attempt to hide the unemployed from the statistics in the run‐up to the election.

The word went out to the managers of the labour market programs: `Spend up. Get as many off the unemployment statistics as you can and hide as many of those long-term unemployed as you can. Let's redefine them as short-term unemployed.' He is the man who is responsible for the squeeze now occurring on labour market programs. The only reason this squeeze is not more severe at the moment is that we have brought forward $30 million from next year's funding to help ease the situation for unemployed people.

BREAK.PARA: This has been one of the most disgraceful pieces of financial management of any significant federal program since Federation. You ought to be ashamed of yourself for your disgraceful performance in that portfolio. You sacrificed the interests of unemployed people. You sacrificed the interests of the training providers that the member for Batman pretends to be so concerned about. You sacrificed them all for your own narrow political interests. You preferred the jobs for yourself and you preferred a job for the member for Batman to jobs for unemployed people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the advice that you have from your department.
—Our department has given us advice which—
—Mr Speaker—
—The minister will resume his seat. The member for Newcastle on a point of order.
—It is really hard to get your attention, Mr Speaker, I am sorry.
—You are in my good ear, so think how lucky you are.

—It is the eye I am worried about, not the ear; your left eye needs to be open. I draw your attention to the question that was raised, which was quite specific and referred to a departmental brief. I ask you to draw the minister's attention back to the question and to answer the question, not to go off on some rant of his own.
—There is no point of order.

—I tabled in the parliament last week the department's official advice to its own area managers which clearly stated that this government had not frozen labour market programs and that the only reason for the decisions that are being made at the moment is that you had spent the money to defend your own political interests against the interests of unemployed people.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: if the minister will not table the department's brief which was the basis on which my question was raised, I seek leave to table the departmental brief.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Has the minister seen press comments on a report soon to be released by the international federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent societies suggesting that the world will face a massive food crisis within 10 years? What are the implications of this for further liberalisation of world agricultural trade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Corangamite for his salient question. I would like to point out to the House that the best way the world can avoid such a food shortage is, in fact, to continue to progress down the path of fair and balanced trade liberalisation, including agricultural trade liberalisation.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to remind the House that it was only two years ago that Japan effectively ran out of rice before they opened up their market. That was part of the catalyst, including the Uruguay Round outcome, to the opening up of eight per cent of the Japanese rice market. Happily enough, many Australian rice growers—and I acknowledge the work of the former minister for trade, the member for Riverina, me and many others—are now supplying rice to that Japanese market. They are in a better and more secure circumstance as a consequence of those developments, as a consequence of further agricultural trade liberalisation.

Too often, I point out to the member for Corangamite, the words `food security' and `self-sustainability' are a smokescreen for renewed protection. I think that agenda ought to be exposed. Indeed, when I attend the Cairns group meeting in Colombia next month, I will ensure that the reform process does stay on track. I believe that the Cairns group nations will furnish tactics which will help the development of the agenda for the WTO Round set down for Singapore in September.

The world's food supplies are fragile, yes. The world's food circumstance is something which needs to be monitored, and I will read with interest the reports when they are released. But to suggest that the world will run out of food within 10 years is alarmist. Indeed, I would make the additional point that there are certainly places in the world which will suffer acute food shortage—North Korea being one of those right this moment. The sooner North Korea reforms, deregulates and opens up, the better it will be in terms of its food trading circumstances.

Finally, I would make one other point. It does not help this whole equation when the New South Wales state government goes around closing down laboratories in Wagga and Armidale and elsewhere in relation to the proper clearance, development and export activity with regard to the agricultural sector. Shame on them for making that decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the statements that you made on marijuana earlier this afternoon and your comments that society should not signal greater acceptance of substances that may cause serious health problems. In deciding to make these remarks this afternoon, were you aware of an article which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph on 5 May 1996 under the headline `Lift ban on marijuana: Decriminalisation doesn't lead to increased usage'. I will just briefly quote the article. It states:

QUESTION.PARA: Federal Health Minister Dr Michael Wooldridge has called for the decriminalisation of marijuana.
He said that while the Federal government had no power over the issue, it would be a sensible move for the States to make.
" I would support a State if they did that, but it's their decision to do so," Dr Wooldridge told The Sunday Telegraph.
It goes on to state:
Dr Wooldridge's support for the decriminalisation of marijuana comes amid mounting pressure for the move in NSW and Victoria.

Given that quote, do your remarks this afternoon indicate that there is a change in the government's policy on the decriminalisation of marijuana? If not, does the Prime Minister or the minister for health speak for the government on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I ought to tell the member for Dobell that I have discussed this matter at great length with the minister for health. I would have hoped this is the sort of thing that would be discussed within parties. I said, in answer to my question, that there is a range of views on it. We do not have, as such, a formal position for the very reason that these matters historically, and I think for very good reason, have tended to be treated on a non-party basis.
—And you chose to raise it today as a smokescreen.

—I chose to express a view, and I think I have a perfect right as Prime Minister of this country to express a view on an important social issue, unlike my predecessor. Whenever he was asked a difficult social question, he was struck dumb. I do not intend to adopt that approach. I intend to express my view on important social issues. I acknowledge that there is a range of views, and I acknowledge it very clearly. Can I say that, if you were all allowed to speak on it, there would be a range of views in your ranks on this issue as well. I have no doubt about that.

ANSWER.PARA: I just say, quite unreservedly, that of course I was aware of that article. Of course I discussed the matter with the minister for health. Of course there is a range of views on the matter. The view that I expressed is mine. I believe it is the correct view. I believe it is a view that the great majority of Australians have, and I think it is important on occasions like this that political leaders have the guts to express their views and contribute to the debate. I would like to know the views of the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. What steps are being undertaken to implement the government's medals policy to ensure proper recognition for the service and sacrifice that Australia's servicemen and women have given to the defence of our nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do thank the member for her question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I note across the way that there were some disparaging comments about medals, but I would say to you very simply that the government's position is that we value the contribution that was made by every person who served and serves Australia—not just people who have been heroes, not just people who have been recognised for bravery, but people who gave service which was important to defending this nation and to giving service for the ongoing protection of this nation.

BREAK.PARA: For that reason, the medals policy that was announced prior to the last election by the then shadow minister, which was very widely consulted on throughout the community, particularly the ex-service community, is now in the process of being implemented. The required regulations that need to be made by the Governor‐General are prepared. There is also a requirement for Her Majesty the Queen to be involved. That has begun as well.

With regard to the CIDA report, you accepted all but one of those recommendations. We accepted the lot. We accepted all 39 recommendations, and that includes recognition for instructors and officers of cadets because we think cadets are valuable. You apparently did not. We have extended the principles that were used in the CIDA report and, very simply, I will go back to the proposition that I made before; that is, the basis of our policy is a simple one. We value the contribution made by every individual not only the people who are singled out for special bravery awards but also the people who gave simple service, who joined in good faith and wished to serve their nation. Those are the people who will have recognition under our policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper . Are we going to hear from the Leader of the Opposition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the speech I delivered during the debate on the supply bills last week. I deeply regret my actions and omission in giving due reference to other parties and information sources. I also regret the subsequent ramifications such an action has brought to the House and my colleagues. I apologise to you, Mr Speaker, my colleagues and the parliament of Australia. I have also written to Mr Drucker, the key reference used in my address, apologising to him.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been reported that I reflected on my colleagues, and I deeply regret any inference, comment or statement which questioned the legitimacy of the content of any parliamentary addresses. For this, I apologise to you, Mr Speaker, the parliament and my colleagues. Finally, I ask you to expunge the speech from the parliamentary record and in doing so reinstate the integrity of parliamentary records.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Cowan's comments are much appreciated by the House. In relation to expunging records from Hansard , the only circumstances surrounding this that I can recall are various debates conducted during World War I and World War II which were censored for military or strategic reasons. I shall take your question on board, give it due consideration and announce my findings to the House subsequently.
—Mr Speaker, on indulgence: the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) in a difficult situation has shown a grace and a decency which have won him great respect, I hope, on all sides of the House.

—Mr Speaker, on indulgence: I join with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). I echo those remarks. The member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) has done the decent and honourable thing. I am quite thankful that this matter has now been concluded in a satisfactory fashion.
—What about the Leader of the Opposition?
—He has been struck dumb.

—Order! There will be no further debate on this issue. The House in its wisdom has been very gracious to cover a very sorry episode. The issue is now concluded. I will not tolerate debate across the chamber.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sullivan, Kathryn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to you, Mr Speaker, relates to the matter of supplementary questions. I acknowledge that it is within the judgment of the chair whether supplementary questions can be asked at question time. I have no doubt at all that you have made your decision in light of the fact that both Speaker Child and Speaker Martin chose to reject recommendations of previous Procedure Committee reports that there be an arrangement for supplementary questions. Could you give some thought to some of the ramifications which were considered by the Procedure Committee in making those recommendations—namely, if taken to a certain length, this could mean an imbalance in the rights of private members on government and opposition sides?

QUESTION.PARA: Since the previous Speakers chose not to accept the recommendations of the Procedure Committee on the basis that they preferred to give a strict alternation of questions between private members on the government side and the opposition side, would you please give consideration to two questions going to the other side—whether that be government or opposition—when you accept a supplementary question?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moncrieff for her very constructive comments. I shall deeply analyse previous precedents and contact you privately. If necessary, I shall make an announcement to the House.

—Mr Speaker, on the same matter, just to clarify one point from the question that has been directed to you—and I think it is appropriate that you revisit that matter—it is in fact up to the House to make a determination on recommendations of the Procedure Committee, not the Speaker of the day. I am sure you will reflect upon that.
—Mr Speaker, I do believe I was unintentionally misrepresented.
—Do you wish to make a personal explanation?
—Yes, I do.
—Proceed.
—In a speech last night, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) stated:

BREAK.PARA: A public meeting was held in my electorate—
that is, Chifley—

in the last week of the last election campaign. I was assured by the Penrith anti‐airport association, PAAAN, that the member for Lindsay would be a candidate and speaker at that meeting. But I arrived at that meeting and suddenly discovered that the honourable member for Lindsay . . . was not there and that in fact Senator Woods had taken her place.
He went on to say:
She has put out a press release, as has the honourable member for Macquarie . . . claiming credit for having put Holsworthy as a stand‐by site.

The implication is that I avoided the meeting. In fact, I was never invited to the meeting.
