SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Deputy Speaker, while I was in Thailand recently, I announced my determination that there would be an independent inquiry to deal thoroughly with repeated allegations that officers within my portfolio had been involved in paedophile activity and that the management had tolerated such activity. I acted decisively because, along with all Australians, I detest and condemn paedophilia. There is no way, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs, that I will allow officers within my portfolio to engage in such behaviour. If officers of my portfolio have been involved in paedophile activity or if there have been cover‐ups, as has been alleged, I am determined that this will be exposed. I am also determined that if these allegations have no foundation, individuals' names are free of suspicion.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an inquiry that has the power to compel witnesses. This is an inquiry that will allow those people who have any knowledge of paedophile activities to have the opportunity to make that knowledge available, with the confidence that they are protected and suffer no consequences to their positions of employment. At the same time, however, those disposed to make knowingly false, frivolous or vexatious allegations should be on notice that there will be no reluctance to pursue perjury where it occurs.

This inquiry will be headed by someone of absolute integrity, with the capacity to sift through the evidence, uncover the truth, and deal with these serious issues in a rigorous, independent manner. I want an inquiry with sufficient scope so that these matters can be fully and finally dealt with. I am pleased to announce today the nature and powers of the inquiry.

The Public Service Commissioner, Dr Peter Shergold, and the Managing Director of the Australian Trade Commission, Mr Ralph Evans, have established an inquiry and released its terms of reference. I seek leave to table those terms of reference as part of this statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry into the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, including AusAID, has been set up under the provisions of the Public Service Act and will report by 1 November 1996. Mr Chris Hunt will conduct the inquiry. Mr Hunt will head a concurrent inquiry with the same terms of reference in relation to Austrade.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an excellent appointment. Mr Hunt is a lawyer with a record of investigative experience in the public sector. He brings wide experience in public administration, particularly in legal fields, at Commonwealth, state and territory levels. That experience has included seven years as Chief Executive Officer of the ACT Attorney‐General's department.

Mr Hunt was appointed because it was recognised that, to investigate effectively many of the allegations being brought forward, a thorough knowledge of both public administration and procedures, as well as a legal background, would be essential. Mr Hunt is clearly well qualified in both these fields. In addition, he has extensive experience with independent investigations and inquiries, including a three‐year term as deputy Commonwealth ombudsman and as a part‐time member of the Merit Protection and Review Agency.

He has no association with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AusAID or any other portfolio agency and is highly regarded for his integrity, objectivity and scrupulous pursuit of truth. Mr Hunt will be able to seek the assistance of the police and legal and Public Service experts. These qualifications mean that Mr Hunt will be able to address both the legal and the Public Service issues in a complete and comprehensive manner.

An inquiry of this form using the terms of reference that have been developed for it undoubtedly provides the best means for examining the range of allegations that have been made. Being established under the Public Service Act, it will have the scope to consider and make recommendations on issues well beyond those of criminality—which are appropriately the domain of the Australian Federal Police—such as misconduct, unethical behaviour or activity that brings the service into disrepute.

The inquiry will not only concern itself with the behaviour of individual officers but also examine the systems, structure and culture of portfolio agencies to see whether they have been adequate in the effective management of Australia's representatives and their behaviour while overseas. To do this, the inquiry needs to be conducted by those who have experience in and of public administration.

These issues are crucial in so far as many of the allegations have not only focused on paedophile activity itself but also claimed that there have been official cover‐ups of such activity. If there is any evidence of this, any suggestion that these matters have been suppressed by individual officers, the management of the relevant portfolio agencies, or indeed by anyone else, the inquiry will have the power to unearth it.

PARA.BREAK: It might not be appreciated how strong and wide ranging are the powers of the Public Service Commissioner to undertake an investigation of this nature. The inquiry will have extensive powers, including the ability to compel witnesses to attend hearings, whether they be public servants or members of the general public, and whatever their position or status. Penalties for noncompliance range from disciplinary action, in the case of offi cials, to fines and/or imprisonment. Evidence will be taken under oath.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry will be located separately from any premises of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AusAID or Austrade, and no serving or former officers of those agencies will be on the staff, nor anyone related to any individual in those agencies. The hearings will be in camera and individuals will be able to have their legal counsel in attendance. Under these circumstances there can be no question as to its independence or the scope of its powers.

Dr Shergold and Mr Hunt will soon be announcing the procedures guiding the conduct of the inquiry. Privacy issues will be paramount and protection will be available to anyone providing information and evidence, other than wilfully given false evidence. Statutory protection will be provided under the Public Service Act for officers providing information.

I have instructed the heads of portfolio agencies to ensure that officers who provide evidence to the inquiry will not suffer any disadvantage or prejudice to their careers. I have also instructed heads of portfolio agencies to extend the fullest cooperation to the inquiry.

The inquiry will receive evidence regarding criminal matters, breaches of the Public Service Act and improper conduct. In that context, all allegations or information will also be referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation into possible criminal activity as they deem necessary. The Australian Federal Police are already conducting investigations into allegations of paedophile activities and these investigations will continue.

The combination of the AFP investigations and the inquiry ensures that all allegations, whether they refer to criminal or administrative actions, will now be examined in detail. That is the key feature of the inquiry as it has been constituted. Concerns have been raised that some allegations in the past could not be investigated fully by the Australian Federal Police because they were not of a criminal nature. I refer to allegations of paedophilia that predate the introduction of the child sex tourism amendment to the Crimes Act and that portfolio management ignored such allegations as an example. This inquiry will mean that those allegations not covered by the Crimes Act will now be subject to independent investigation from outside the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AusAID and Austrade.

It is important to emphasise that the inquiry will be able to build upon the police investigations, to include matters of an administrative nature, to examine whether allegations have been brought to the knowledge of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AusAID or Austrade in the past and, if so, what actions were taken. The inquiry will seek out whether allegations were investigated, ignored or suppressed and whether the reputation of agencies was put above the best interests of the Australian public.

The inquiry will examine what procedures are and were in place to ensure that officers could report confidentially any allegations of criminal or inappropriate activity by their colleagues in order to ensure their full investigation. The inquiry will be able to judge whether officers have been hindered from coming forward with any knowledge they may have, and whether the system can be improved.

Allegations that aid funds have been disbursed with the intent of benefiting officers in the pursuit of paedophile activities are deeply disturbing and, if true, utterly unacceptable to this government, all decent Australians and, I am sure, the parliament as a whole. These allegations are rightly being investigated by the police. If true, they are doubly criminal—involving both paedophile activity and also what amounts to fraudulent use of government funds. The inquiry will examine what mechanisms are in place for the scrutiny and accountability of these funds, to ensure that they cannot be used for the benefit of paedophiles.

With the establishment of the inquiry, every effort has now been made to determine the truth of all these matters. The AFP will continue their pursuit of any criminal activity and, in the event that the inquiry finds evidence that individual officers have been involved in misconduct of a non‐criminal kind, portfolio agencies will institute disciplinary action as appropriate.

The terms of reference also task the inquiry to make recommendations concerning a code of conduct for all staff representing Australia overseas to ensure that their behaviour is appropriate and beyond question, over and above that applying to public servants in general. We expect and demand that those representing all Australians must be above reproach in both their professional and private lives.

The inquiry is also tasked to recommend improved procedures for handling such issues in the future, so as to guarantee greater scrutiny and accountability. There should be no way that some years down the track we again face the situation we have now. Any and all allegations in the future will be fully and immediately investigated.

As the inquiry gets under way, I want to again make it abundantly clear that I will not tolerate paedophile activity within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AusAID or Austrade. I am sure that all officers of those agencies will welcome the opportunity provided by the inquiry to clear the air on this subject and have the facts determined on issues which have been the cause of speculation and untested allegations. Mr Hunt will shortly be seeking submissions and those persons who have any information or evidence should now produce it to the inquiry. In fact, they have a responsibility to do so.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I regard it as my solemn duty to ensure that these matters are dealt with fully and thoroughly. Paedophilia is an insidious violation of the rights of innocent children. It is a crime I abhor. And I will not tolerate it within agencies under my ministerial control. On that you have my pledge. I will not allow Australia's good name to be tainted by paedophile activity. Nor will I permit toleration of such activity by officers within my portfolio.

Nor indeed will I allow the hundreds of dedicated officers of the portfolio for which I am responsible—who work tirelessly and represent Australia overseas with great dedication—to have their good names besmirched by possibly groundless allegations or the acts of a few. Consequently, the inquiry will seek out the truth of all allegations, those of substance and those made frivolously or vexatiously.

This inquiry has broad‐ranging powers. It can seek evidence. It will protect witnesses. It will have the force of law, but its scope will go well beyond the simple letter of the law. It will make findings. It will make recommendations. And I expect it will result in a code of conduct. Above all, it is an independent, powerful inquiry which delivers on the government's pledge to deal thoroughly and promptly with these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The statement just made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) deals with a very serious issue of deep concern to all Australians. There is no doubt that the exploitation of children by paedophiles, whether it occurs overseas or here at home, is particularly abhorrent criminal conduct of the very worst kind. Two years ago this parliament responded to the deeply felt concerns of all Australians on this disturbing issue of paedophilia with the passage of the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Act 1994 with the unanimous support of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently, we have all been shocked and appalled by evidence concerning paedophilia given before the New South Wales royal commission headed by Mr Justice Wood. I know all members of the parliament share my grave concern over the allegations that have been made and the publicity that we have seen regarding allegations of Australian diplomatic service personnel being engaged in the sexual abuse of children overseas. Nothing could be more repulsive. Nothing could be more reprehensible. Nothing could be more vile.

PARA.BREAK: The allegations concern the ruthless exploitation of the most underprivileged and deprived children in the world, which makes it all the more awful. No member of this parliament would question that every effort must be made to ruthlessly hunt down and bring to justice any Australian citizen who has engaged in such abhorrent and predatory behaviour. Action is also required because we need to make sure that the reputation of our diplo matic service—the international reputation and the domestic reputation of what is a very fine and highly professional diplomatic service—is not tarnished, not damaged, by lingering suspicions that it harbours persons engaged in such loathsome criminal behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: In June last year, the House will recall that the former member for Deakin, Mr Aldred, made a number of very serious allegations against officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade concerning paedophile activity and the alleged toleration of such activity by the senior management of the department. The response by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, now the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), and the then secretary to the department, Michael Costello, was swift indeed. An extensive investigation into Mr Aldred's allegations was conducted without delay by the Australian Federal Police both into the specific allegations concerning particular individuals and into the claim that the department had tolerated and promoted diplomats known to be paedophiles.

The result of the AFP investigation was given to the Senate by my colleague, then Senator Gareth Evans, in answer to a question without notice on 30 November last year. I do not intend to repeat the substance of that statement this afternoon, but the House should note that the Australian Federal Police found that `there is no evidence to support the allegation that the senior management of DFAT had tolerated and promoted diplomats known to be paedophiles'.

The AFP further advised that `during the investigation no evidence was revealed to substantiate the allegation that DFAT has obstructed investigation of this matter, attempted to prevent examination of relevant documents or deter departmental officers from providing evidence'. As honourable members will be aware, one senior officer of the department has been charged under the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Act and investigations by the AFP are continuing.

PARA.BREAK: Since November last year, I think all Australians have been deeply disturbed by the evidence on paedophilia which has been given before the New South Wales royal commis sion and the evidence of the disappearance of the alleged paedophile Phillip Bell and a series of further newspaper reports concerning alleged paedophile activity by DFAT officers overseas. Those included allegations of allegedly misused discretionary aid funds to benefit persons engaged in paedophile activities.

SPEECH.PARA: Those newspaper reports—and there were many of them; there was wide publicity—culminated in April when the Minister for Foreign Affairs correctly concluded that a far ranging inquiry was required to get to the full truth of the issue. In doing so, I think he properly set high standards for such an inquiry. Speaking in Jakarta on 17 April he declared that he will `leave no stone unturned on this issue' and that any allegation of paedophilia would be `fully and vigorously investigated'. Three days later he announced his intention to proceed with an independent inquiry. I think he was in Bangkok at that time. He said that he would be `completely ruthless' in hunting down any paedophiles in DFAT and that any such activities would be `wiped out'.

We need to remember that these were strong commitments indeed given by the minister: `leave no stone unturned', `fully and vigorously investigated', `completely ruthless' in hunting it down and wiping it out. He said:

I tell you, we are going to deal with this sort of behaviour quite ruthlessly. I am not having Australian diplomats' reputations smeared if their reputations do not deserve to be smeared. But if there are Australian diplomats, even very junior diplomats, behaving in a way that does not befit the standards Australians expect of them then we don't want these people any more. No ifs, no buts. If there have been any cover-ups in the past as some people claim there have been, well they'll be exposed. I am really going to dig into this.

They were the words of the minister in Bangkok. Those standards are very high for him to set himself. The opposition, for our part, strongly support such an approach to the investigation of these continuing allegations.

I think the question for the House today is whether the inquiry that was announced barely a few minutes ago measures up to the standards the minister set himself in Jakarta and Bangkok and, I think much more importantly, to the very high standard of inquiry demanded by all Australians to ensure that we can be satisfied that the full truth has been discovered.

I put it to the House that only an inquiry with the powers of a royal commission—that is, unfettered powers to take public and indeed in camera evidence where appropriate—can ensure that the full truth of these matters is determined and exposed so that full confidence in our diplomatic service can be restored. If there is anything less than an unfettered inquiry, we will see a result that will fall short of the standards set by the minister himself and the standard demanded by the Australian people. Anything less will only leave lingering doubts and suspicions and risk permanent damage to the reputation of our diplomatic representatives and to the standing of our nation abroad.

I think what the minister has announced today plainly fails that test. Regrettably, what we are to get is a secret, only in camera, Public Service inquiry which falls far short of what is required to satisfy the concerns of all Australians on this very serious issue. The inquiry will be conducted under the provisions of the Public Service Act. The Public Service Act is an act there to protect public servants from undue and unfair processes. The minister has made much in his statement of the power of the inquiry to compel witnesses, but the inquiry will have no power under the Public Service Act to compel witnesses who are not public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does, in section 19.

—Not to give evidence—attendance, but not evidence. It will have no power to compel witnesses who are former public servants. Let me make that quite clear. For instance, what if Mr Scoble decides that it is his choice not to give evidence, that he is happy to rely upon the excellent reference that he is said to hold from the now foreign minister in support of his Telstra job in South-East Asia? What if he takes the view that that is quite adequate and he does not need to come back for an inquiry with wide ranging powers?
—Do you want to play party politics with this? We could do a lot of damage with that.

—I would be very careful about what you say here in respect of this matter. The fact is that non-public servants who choose to give evidence will have no real protection against defamation. Indeed, there will be no protection for witnesses against self-incrimination. These are all the inadequacies of what has been announced today. The inquiry will have no power to compel the production of documents by non-public servants. The inquiry will have no real investigative powers outside of the Public Service. These are the limitations.

BREAK.PARA: As the minister has said, all the hearings will be held in camera. That is, each and every one of the hearings will be behind closed doors. That is understandable in some cases. You often need to take evidence in camera. With the commission of inquiry into the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, the inquiry conducted by Gordon Samuels, there was an absolute necessity, because of the security issues involved, to keep it behind closed doors, but that should not be the case in respect of this matter.

Regrettably, the inquiry announced by the minister is manifestly inadequate as a response to deeply felt concerns of all Australians on the issue. It fails to live up to the high standards set by the minister when he announced his intention to proceed with an inquiry. I think one might have thought the government could have learnt from the experience of ICAC in New South Wales, which inquired into the allegations of paedophile activities in New South Wales but over a lengthy period of time failed to get to the bottom of them. ICAC had much wider powers—infinitely wider powers than those afforded to the inquiry announced today.

PARA.BREAK: Mr Justice Wood himself has left no doubt that the powers of a royal commission are absolutely essential if the vital truth of matters is to be revealed and the concerns of the public satisfied. I think the less than fulsome inquiry announced today, which does not have any of those powers, is one that tragically will be considered by many critics to be inad equate, no matter how good and how solid the work of the inquiry is. I think that is highly regrettable, but it is inherent in the terms of reference.

BREAK.PARA: I conclude by saying that the minister has failed the test he himself set for the government in Jakarta and Bangkok and he has failed to meet the concerns of all Australians. He has left his inquiry, very sadly, open to allegations that it is nothing more than a Public Service whitewash. I think he has failed in his duty and he has failed his own public commitments.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The impact of the government's policies on educational opportunity for young Australians, particularly in regional Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In a relatively short span of time, this government has managed to achieve something truly remarkable. We have seen over the last couple of weeks the forging of an absolutely unprecedented alliance of people and organisations concerned with Australia's university system. We saw on Monday the formation of a coalition comprising academic staff, students, university administrations from a variety of different kinds of institutions, alumni organisations and learned societies. These are organisations which quite often have found themselves in adversarial situations and often have not found themselves with a commonality of interests.

PARA.BREAK: On this particular occasion, there is absolute and overwhelming condemnation of what this government has indicated it is proposing to do in the higher education area and of the enor mous uncertainty and anxiety that has been brought into existence as a consequence of the handling of the education portfolio by the senior portfolio minister, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone).

SPEECH.PARA: The senior portfolio minister has tried to fend off some of these claims and concerns by saying that universities and their administrations and students and staff are running a scare campaign. One of the university vice-chancellors put it very succinctly the other day when he said, `We are not running a scare campaign, we are running a scared campaign.' They have very good reason to be concerned on the basis of what has been revealed so far about the government's intentions.

There are a number of components to our education and training system: higher education, universities, vocational education and training, TAFE, and the schools sector. No doubt, in the fullness of time, we will see what the coalition has in store for each of those areas. At this point, the clearest indication has come from the senior minister in the portfolio in respect of higher education.

How do we sum up the senior portfolio minister's performance in relation to her responsibilities for education, training and employment programs in this country? Let us focus on higher education. What we have seen is a minister whose performance has been characterised by incompetence. She has shown an almost complete incapacity to provide coherent and genuinely informative answers to questions that have been put to her in question time. Her performance has been marked by ineptitude.

This minister went along to the celebrated dinner held by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. When asked about the possibility of funding cuts, she flippantly said, `How about 12 per cent for starters?' then erupted into giggles. Needless to say, the reaction that occurred in response to that was not only predictable but entirely justified. We have seen the bitter anti-intellectualism of this minister demonstrated at a conference on the education of gifted children at which international observers were present. The transcript of what she said at this conference was circulated extensively over the Internet. It got so embarrassing that the chair of the organisation conducting the conference felt she had no alternative but to shut the conference down and remove Senator Vanstone from the stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is untrue and it has been refuted in the Senate. You know that is untrue.

—That is not untrue. Senator Vanstone later tried to deny the text of what she said at that conference. The text was taken down verbatim by one of those present on behalf of the conference, and it has been circulated. Another feature of this minister's performance has been her sheer lack of commitment to higher education and to education generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Friday we saw a speech made by Senator Vanstone to the Graduate Careers Council on the occasion of a survey of the destination of university graduates. This speech was intended, in part, to be a denunciation of the former government's record. The minister spoke about the situation that the present government inherited from Labor, and then, two paragraphs later—this is rather remarkable—she said:
Over the past 10 years there has been a major expansion of the higher education sector. Between 1983 and 1986 Commonwealth grants to universities grew in real terms by 67 per cent.

That is true, but isn't it interesting that a minister with responsibility for that area cites, in condemnation of the former government, this very large increase? What does that tell us about her intentions? On the next page of the speech she went on to characterise the huge increase in participation and access to education that was delivered by the previous government in this way:
Growth of universities was a handy form of political largess to distribute.

This is the kind of mind-set that is operating. The fears of students and potential students, of parents, of academics and of university administrators about what this sort of attitude means for the future of the higher education sector are entirely justified. On the basis of incompetence, ineptitude, anti‐intellectual gaucherie, sheer bloody‐mindedness and lack of commitment to the sector and to education generally, this minister's performance has been a disgrace.

I can say something good about the minister at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp). He and I have often exchanged unfriendly words. In comparison with his minister, he looks pretty good. You have to feel a degree of sympathy for him. No doubt he would have preferred to have been the senior portfolio minister. By gee, you can really understand that concern.

As I said, the reaction from the higher education sector has been absolutely predictable. In the debate we had last week I made reference to statements by a whole succession of university vice-chancellors, student organisations and others that this situation was absolutely without precedent and of a kind they had never before had to deal with. It is sheer vandalism. I do not want to go over those statements again. But there are a couple of good ones which I thought I might add. Professor Gavin Brown, Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, was reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of 17 May as saying:

By talking of sudden, massive cuts, the Government shows disregard for honour, commitment, cooperation and strategic planning. To our intense distaste, we must stop some of our work of building for the future and divert energy into confrontational politics.
Professor John Niland, Vice‐Chancellor of the University of New South Wales, said:

The Federal Government's reported enthusiasm for `cold turkey' rectification of the deficit could have disastrous consequences if any cuts to university funding go ahead, let alone approach the threatened levels of 5 to 10 per cent. The final cost of such cuts would far outweigh the anticipated benefits.

This is a government that, while in opposition during the period of the so-called unmet demand crisis of 1992, was tearing into the previous government over the fact that significant numbers of students sought a university place but could not get one. It complained bitterly about the slippage in funding per student, notwithstanding the huge real increase which Senator Vanstone herself conceded.

BREAK.PARA: This same government is now preparing to make huge cuts in the higher education sector and, as I believe will become clear, in other parts of the education and training system. What are we to make of this? The justification that is put forward for this is the so-called requirements of fiscal policy, the exigencies of fiscal policy, the $8 billion black hole, which has only just been filled in today as a result of the revised growth forecasts. I do not know how that will affect things.

There is an issue here that goes to the integrity of this government and the commitments that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made to the effect that election commitments and promises would be honoured by this government—in alleged contrast to us. Before the election, on 19 February, the Prime Minister appeared on the John Laws program and the question was put to him, `What if it should turn out that the fiscal position is not as you understand it?':
LAWS: So what you are saying, the answer to the question, is if you had a choice between breaking election promises and running a budget deficit, what would you choose?
HOWARD: Well, we won't break . . . we would always give . . .
LAWS: You'd choose the deficit.
HOWARD: We would always give preference to keep our promises.

That is what he said on that occasion, and he has reaffirmed it on a number of occasions since. One of the points which is starting to emerge about the consequences of what the coalition is proposing is the potential impact on regional universities and educational opportunities in Australia's regions. Frank Hambly, the Executive Director of the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee, said in the Herald‐Sun on 16 May:
Such a cut—
that is, up to $600 million—
would hurt all universities, but could be disastrous in regional areas.
Professor Fay Gale, the Chair of the AVCC, said:
Some of the regional universities will be in very serious trouble.

John Niland, whom I referred to earlier, has talked about not only the importance of univ ersities on the provision of education to people but also the impact of universities on local economies. He made the point that the export of education services, which is being undermined by the crisis of confidence engendered by the government's actions, is an industry which is approaching some of our traditional commodity exports. He also made the point:

A recent scientific study published as `Profitable Neighbours: The Economic Impact of the University of New South Wales on the Randwick Municipality' found a magnitude of benefit even greater than that of the Port Kembla steelworks for the Illawarra. This effect would also occur in Lismore or Wagga or Armidale or wherever a university operates.

The impact of this on local economies and local communities will be dramatic and disastrous. The University of Western Sydney conducted a media conference at noon today about the impact of the cuts that have been mooted in education provision on communities in the west of Sydney. The regional universities themselves have recently issued a press release on this issue, which refers to the impact of potential cuts on local communities. It states:
Proposed cuts to university funding will deliver a savage blow to regional Australia, according to a meeting today of the country's eight regional vice‐chancellors.

This is the situation that we are facing here. This government is, as I say, the same group that talked about unmet demand. It chose to attack us over the lack of adequate funding for universities when we were in office, and now it turns around and completely repudiates a black‐letter election commitment that was given to the sector. What does that say about the integrity and commitment of this government?

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a lie, isn't it; a complete lie?
—It's a lie, is it?
—Order! The minister will not make that comment by way of interjection, and it should be withdrawn.
—I withdraw that, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—And the honourable member for Sydney should ignore interjections.

—Is the minister at the table denying that the coalition's policy on higher education contains the words that `the coalition is committed to retaining university operating grants and research grants at least at their present level'? Is he seeking to deny that? Isn't that interesting? Does that portray an ignorance of what the coalition's policy is or what? It is an extraordinary proposition. What the coalition has in mind for education and training in higher education is transparent—thanks to the ineptitude of the senior minister in the portfolio.

BREAK.PARA: However, there are a range of other issues that are going to become more and more significant. I would be interested to know what the minister at the table has to say in response to a couple of points in the schools area. In the House last week, in answer to a question about the new schools policy, he did something which I suppose in a sense is commendable but unusual. He actually confirmed that he would deliver on a promise. The minister at the table said:
In the election campaign we said:
A coalition government will abolish the Labor government's unfair and inequitable new schools policy.
We will keep this promise.

At least he is prepared to say what the current status and standing of an election promise is. I invite him, since he has shown a degree of candour very unusual amongst his colleagues—certainly for the Prime Minister—to confirm the coalition policy to `at least maintain Commonwealth specific purpose payments to schools in line with the forward estimates, that is, recurrent capital and targeted equity programs'. I challenge the minister in his response here today to confirm that that commitment will be adhered to.

There has been a good deal of concern and speculation about what is going to become of Austudy. Is it going to be removed? I ask him to confirm here and now the coalition's promise that `the coalition, as a minimum, will maintain the current level of real expenditure on Austudy'. You were prepared to confirm one particular commitment. Are you prepared to confirm those other two ironclad, black‐letter commitments that sit there in your policy stand? If not, why not?

If you are not prepared to confirm those other two commitments, would you explain the budgetary processes where, on the one hand, people are saying that everything is on the table and has to be reviewed because of the non-existent $8 billion black hole and, on the other hand, you feel free and capable to come into the House and give us specific confirmation on a particular policy? Perhaps you might either confirm those two promises or explain your failure to give it priority. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALKER.NAME: Dr KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation)

TALK.START.PARA: —The state of the other side of the House demonstrates the fervour that the government feels about this issue raised by the shadow minister for education, the member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin). The benches are largely empty. There is one other person on the front bench there. There is no interest.

SPEECH.PARA: When we wonder where are all the regional members on the other side of the House who are upset about this issue, the answer is that there are virtually no members. There may be two members from regional Australia on the other side of the House. There is a reason for that: you let the regional communities of this country down very badly.
Mr Peter Baldwin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You never got your message across if you did. One of the areas in which you did worst was education. Let me remind the House of the record of the previous government in relation to education, mainly higher education. I will follow the pattern of the address of the shadow minister on this. Let me put before the House exactly what they did for regional Australia. One of the reasons regional Australia turned against the government was its appalling record in improving educational advantage for regional Australia. The participation rate of rural students in higher education in 1995—the latest figures after 13 years of Labor government—was only 73 per cent of the participation rate amongst metropolitan students. This was a matter of continuing concern right through these 13 years, and virtually nothing was done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The devastation that Paul Keating's recession—the recession we had to have—had on rural employment was well noted by regional Australia. Full‐time employment opportunities for students, graduates and trainees was devastated by your miserable economic policies—the policies that have left this country with this enormous $8 billion hole that has to be filled. Youth unemployment in regional Australia in a number of areas was well over 40 per cent and in some cases over 50 per cent. I am talking about areas such as the Wide Bay‐Burnett area of Queensland and the coastal regions of New South Wales, such as Illawarra and Wollongong.

TALK.START.PARA: —But look at the sample.

—They have just been published on an annual basis. The sample size is perfectly satisfactory. Let us have a look at the figures for one year. Nowhere was this betrayal greater than in the metropolitan areas represented by the Labor Party. Some of these safe Labor seats are like war zones; there are hardly any jobs for the young kids. There are only the most skeletal opportunities for higher education in most of these areas. What were you doing for the last 13 years? Didn't you care about the people you represented?

SPEECH.PARA: All they could come up with in the election, Mr Deputy Speaker, was to scare these people they had impoverished over the last 13 years into believing that the coalition would even take away welfare benefits. They did not say that the $2 billion man—the member for Hotham (Mr Crean)—had actually spent the allocation for the year in the first eight months, that 95 per cent of it had either been spent or committed, and that there would not be a lot of money left for the last four months of the year. Now they come in here weeping their crocodile tears and telling us how awful it is that there is some constriction on the funds available to help unemployed people. The hypocrisy that is coming from the other side of the House needs to be exposed and will be exposed relentlessly by this government.

Let us look further at regional Australia. The assistance through isolated children benefit was constantly declining in real value throughout those years. What about apprenticeship opportunities for regional Australians? The apprenticeship system has had a long and very positive history in regional Australia. The number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force was the lowest for three decades.

Let us get on to Austudy. We find continual problems being faced by rural and farming families in sending their children on to tertiary education, away from home and into the capital cities. One of the former government's last actions was to implement something called the actual means test. The principle of targeting Austudy is one that we have long supported. We believe that Austudy should go to those in need. What they put in place is an incredibly complex process. There will not be many members from regional Australia representing farming communities on that side of the House. Actually one of the two is at the table. We on this side of the House—regional Australia knows that it is being properly represented by us—constantly get representations, day in and day out, over the unfair operation of this actual means test.

We promised during the election campaign that we would set up an immediate review of this means test to make sure that it operates fairly. We have done so. That is another promise that we are keeping. As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, the government places very high priority on keeping its promises because we take promises seriously, unlike the previous Prime Minister and the previous government.

PARA.BREAK: Let us just mention the promises that have been kept. Let us look at university funding. Under Labor, real grant funding per student fell some seven per cent over the period you were in office. You cut funding relentlessly per student. You constantly put the universi ties under pressure. Let us look at research funding under the previous government. The previous government invented the claw-back, which took money out of the research funds and put it into operating funds. It had a very damaging effect on Australia's research structure.

SPEECH.PARA: Then the former minister, one of the worst ministers for higher education that we have ever had, came into this chamber and tried to tell us that he was going to help quality in universities by setting up a committee. What did this committee do? It went around Australia ranking Australian universities and telling overseas students that a lot of Australian universities were no good. He put them right down the bottom of the list. It said, `These are the poor universities.' They were the universities that were trying to attract overseas students. Were they poor universities? It was just a typical bureaucratic response to quality from a minister who was a member of the left faction. They love bureaucracy. It is the committee left, the bureaucratic left. All they wanted to do was to impose their central planning ideology on the system.
Mr Peter Baldwin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He cannot restrain himself, because he knows that this is true. What an appalling performance in government. Let us have a look at HECS. We hear him talking, with pain in his voice, about possible increases in HECS, as if the last thing any government would do would be to even consider this. They increased HECS year after year. They started off with thresholds of one, two and three per cent. Then in 1990 HECS went up further to two, three and four per cent. In 1993 they increased it to three, four and five per cent. Last year, 1995, they added four new levels of repayment on top of the existing ones and raised HECS to six per cent. So between 1989 and 1996, they doubled the HECS repayment. Now they have the nerve—
—Three per cent.
—Three per cent was the top rate, and now it is six per cent. We did not legislate that. You legislated that. So you doubled the HECS repayments.

BREAK.PARA: This opposition has absolutely no credibility whatever in relation to higher education and regional Australia. It has given the most abysmal performance that you could imagine. Educational disadvantage still exists. Rural families are still disadvantaged. We have students in this country who are still suffering from the conditions that have been left to them by the former government, all because of an ideological approach which totally neglected the interests of rural and regional Australia. This is the group, now in opposition, with two regional members. Regional Australia certainly made known what it thought about their performance. It made known very clearly what it thought of your performance.

Let me make it clear that this government sees educational opportunity as absolutely fundamental to a fair society. We realise that there are many factors at the root of youth unemployment and that even university graduates have experienced difficulty in recent years in getting jobs. But we have taken immediate action to address these issues. We have taken immediate action to address the literacy problems which lie at the heart of youth unemployment. We have immediately established the first national survey for 16 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which we initiated.

—You could never get all the states to participate. Did you get all the states to participate in it? No. It took the new government to get the cooperation of the states for this survey to be up and running.

BREAK.PARA: We immediately reviewed the actual means test for Austudy. We promised that we would do it, and we have done it. We have taken immediate action to address the problems that young people face around Australia, particularly in regional Australia, in getting the kind of training that leads to real jobs.

We saw the previous government allocate a sum of $2.1 billion to labour market programs, many of which provided training that had nothing to do with the jobs that were available. But, of course, that was not the role of those programs. We know what the role was, and you know what the role was. The role was to try to manipulate the statistics in the run-up to the election campaign. It did not matter that the training did not lead to real jobs. It did not matter if 60 per cent of people involved went back to the unemployment queues. That was the kind of training that you were interested in.

We have taken immediate action to establish a modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system which will provide the kind of training, with the support of employers around Australia—which you could never get—that helps young people get into real jobs. So this government has acted to address the problems that have been left to us after 13 years of the most miserable policy failure.

Despite Labor's black hole in relation to higher education, all 1996 commitments for operating grants and capital grants are being paid to universities, as previously announced. Of course the government has the responsibility to review all spending in the light of budgetary circumstances. Given the appalling budgetary circumstances that have been left to us by the opposition, it is absolutely inevitable—I am sure every reasonable person accepts this—that a thoroughgoing review of federal government spending is conducted to ensure that our policy priorities can be met and met in the best possible way.

In the lead-up to the August budget, the government will be considering the pattern of financial support across the whole range of government programs. We do not deny that. It is the only proper, responsible thing to do. You people come into the House and say, `Yes, maybe we have stuffed it all up, maybe this country is in a bit of a mess, maybe there is a black hole'—although they keep disputing how big it is. The shadow Treasurer cannot make up his mind about the size of it. You say, `Maybe there is a problem. Nevertheless, you should not be allowed to address it. You should not be allowed to review spending. If you do, we will run around the country and scare everyone out of their wits.'

They still have not learned from the election experience. They tried that during the election campaign. The people saw right through them as if they were transparent panes of glass. They told you just what they thought of you. That is why there are so few of you left on that side. The shadow minister at the table, a member of the left faction of the party and a great believer in bureaucracy and in central control and central planning over our universities, the person who is responsible for some—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is very timely. We know that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has been in big trouble, but I am not too sure that she is going to be replaced by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp). Particularly in the last weekend of elections and by-elections in New South Wales and in regional New South Wales, there was a very strong showing by the Labor Party. Regional New South Wales has actually woken up to the fact that this federal government is in big trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that under the coalition educational opportunities for young Australians will be severely limited and compromised, and nowhere in Australia will that impact more strongly and starkly than in regional Australia. And who is leading this charge to decimate education? It is none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself, unashamedly followed by a lap‐dog Treasurer (Mr Costello), the hapless Senator Amanda Vanstone and, of course, the member for Goldstein, who is walking out of the chamber.

The federal coalition wants to reduce the Commonwealth's role in education, and that direction is obviously coming from the Prime Minister himself. When the Prime Minister lost the Liberal leadership to Andrew Peacock, he refused the education portfolio in the shadow ministry, and there is no reason to believe he thinks more highly of education now. In fact, even in his Headland speech in June last year the current Prime Minister said:
We will revert to the practice of former coalition governments of winding back section 96 for specific grants to the states.
The Treasurer, the dear old member for Higgins, believes that federal involvement in school education results in waste and duplication. He said:

BREAK.PARA: This is an area crying out for substantial restructure.
But that is code, and we know what it is code for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chop, chop.

—That is code for chop, chop. This is ripping education away at the seams, and it is following the educational genocide espoused by Liberal leaders such as Jeff Kennett in Victoria and Dean Brown in South Australia. The federal government, the federal coalition, has caught the Kennett and the Brown disease, and the Prime Minister has caught the disease more than anyone else.

BREAK.PARA: When questioned the other day by the shadow education and youth affairs minister at the table, the member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin), about whether the government would keep its promises to the higher education sector, Prime Minister Howard said only that he won't respond. Of course he won't respond; he wants Senator Vanstone to be the patsy, he wants Senator Vanstone to bear the brunt of his ideological frenzy and drive to slash and burn education.

I am led to believe by my Senate colleagues that Senator Vanstone made a reasonable fist of her shadow Attorney portfolio. Of course, we need to understand that the shadow Attorney‐General was in this chamber so she was not really tested, but in the education portfolio she is hopelessly mismatched. It is beyond her capabilities. I suspect Senator Hill is in the same boat because he was a former equally mismatched shadow education spokesperson. I do not think he is much better off in environment. Both these people will be dispensable down the track. The inevitable reshuffle of the government front bench will not save Senator Vanstone, nor perhaps Senator Hill, nor perhaps the regional university in the seat of the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). But, in the meantime, poor old Senator Vanstone will do the Prime Minister's bidding of slashing education at all levels and writing her own personal political epitaph as a minister.

The National Tertiary Education Union background information paper on 23 May this year pointed out quite starkly what a 12 per cent cut to higher education could mean. It could mean up to 48,000 young Australian students could miss out on a place. It could mean up to 19,000 jobs could go, or that HECS could be increased by 120 per cent to $5,700. Even if half of those figures are true, it is a disaster for young Australians, and particularly a disaster for those in regional Australia. Where will this impact most of all? It will be in regional Australia—Lismore, Wagga, Armidale, Bendigo and so on.

And what about Queensland? Two Queensland university campuses of about 3,000 student places are now obviously in doubt. Bad luck if you live in central, southern or northern Queensland. Too bad if you live in regional New South Wales, like the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) does. They will probably close half the University of Wollongong. What will happen to Charles Sturt? It is anybody's guess. What will happen to Southern Cross? It is anybody's guess.

But wait a minute, Mr Deputy Speaker—this is National Party country, isn't it? But where are the Nationals in this debate? In this morning's press I noticed that they have been asking their leader, Tim Fischer, to lobby the Liberal cabinet. I think they are so tied up with gun lobbies, the Telstra legislation and with the expected confrontation with the Maritime Union of Australia and its impact on the export of their products that they have forgotten about the impact of the Liberal legislation on regional Australia. They have been sidelined. To all those over there in cocky's corner, make no mistake: the Liberals think they can get by without you and, of course, in this parliament they can. And the Nationals are letting them; they are allowing themselves to be sidelined.

Frank Hambly, the executive director of the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee, was reported in the Herald‐Sun of 16 May as saying that cuts to universities could be disastrous in regional areas. Professor Fay Gale said a similar thing on the same day:
Some of the regional universities will be in very serious trouble.
Who will stand up for young Australians, especially in regional Australia? We know it won't be the Liberal Party. There is silence from the Nationals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they?

—Where are they indeed? Imagine what will happen if the Prime Minister and the Treasurer get their way on the funding of schools. I am glad that the shadow minister mentioned this. What will happen to the $4 billion of untied grants and the $3.2 billion in tied grants for schools education annually? They will give it to people like Jeff Kennett or Dean Brown. Remember Jeff Kennett? He closed 300 schools and reduced teacher numbers by 8,000, many of them in regional Victoria. And it was not only the government schools that felt the Kennett razor. While the number of students attending non‐government schools in Victoria rose by 1.3 per cent, between 1994 and 1995 state recurrent funding fell by 8.1 per cent. No‐one escapes the Liberals' razor on education.

BREAK.PARA: I hope my National colleagues will have a good listen to some aspects of the record of the Liberal Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown. As you will clearly gather, Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a huge chasm between the rhetoric and the reality, and this happened very quickly following a successful election campaign.

Before I turn to that, I will look at some of the promises of the coalition government. They said that they would maintain the level of Commonwealth funding through operating grants and universities, and they will put $129 million more into research infrastructure, postgraduate scholarships and special research grants during the next three years. Senator Robert Hill assured the universities that:

. . . in contrast to the then government, the Coalition would ensure a swift, fair resolution of their pay claim. Instead, their work environment is threatened with destruction, their very jobs are placed in jeopardy and the prospect of a needed pay rise is treated with derision.

I quoted that from the Adelaide Advertiser in a story by the Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, Gavin Brown. Another quote in the Adelaide Advertiser comes from Ian Chubb, who reminds us of a coalition promise which says that the coalition:
. . . is committed to ensuring that financial, social and geographic factors do not act as a barrier to higher education for appropriately qualified students.
What hollow rhetoric. Perhaps I can give my National Party colleagues an example of what they can expect in their areas. Dean Brown rhetoric says:

Education is the most important investment we can make for our children and the future of our State. That is why creating jobs and providing high priority education will be the key objectives of a Liberal Government.

The reality is that 422 teachers were cut in the 1994 budget along with 37 school service officers, another 200 teachers in February 1995, another 100 teachers later in 1995, 23 music teachers, 93 preschools and child‐parent centres suffer staff cuts and 96 teachers' jobs cut in April 1995. Another Dean Brown promise—a Liberal promise—said:
Our Education policy guarantees more money for our schools. This year's Education Budget won't be cut and next year's Budget will actually be increase.

The reality is $22 million was cut in the 1994 budget, $25 million was cut in 1995 in real terms, capital works underspent by $22 million in 1994‐95, secondary education funds were cut by $17 million in 1995‐96 and—here is the real crunch—funds for isolated children were cut—by the champions of regional Australia. That is the reality. People in Clarence and Orange are slowly waking up and it will happen in a great big rush. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to support my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone). I am disappointed that the member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin) is now leaving the chamber because he obviously has the terms of his matter of public importance totally wrong. It should read:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of the Labor government's policies on educational opportunities for young Australians, particularly in regional Australia.

That is what has occurred. I want to refer to a report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission by Chris Sidoti, the Human Rights Commissioner in New South Wales—right in the area of the member for Sydney. It refers to a speech which he gave in Bathurst, New South Wales, in May 1996

BREAK.PARA: regarding the human rights of rural Australians. He said:

We value our sense of fairness, that is, giving and getting `a fair go'; our camaraderie—`mateship'; our sense of optimism—`she'll be right'; and our sense of equality and egalitarianism. These values have forged our national identity.
He went on further to quote some of the problems in rural and country areas. He stated:
The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's Report on Mental Illness identified many factors contributing to the relatively high levels of suicide amongst young rural males:
. rural economic downturn and the corresponding decline of many country towns and farm properties;
. high levels of unemployment and increasing poverty;
. isolation from further educational opportunities.

I repeat that for the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and the absent member for Sydney. This has not happened just since 2 March 1996—when the coalition was elected—and May 1996. The research done for this document by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, by Chris Sidoti, points out the absolute failures of the former Keating government to implement economic change in rural areas and to provide employment and educational opportunities. That is where the link is between education and employment. The opposition has failed on four counts. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report on mental illness in New South Wales has pinned it right down to the Keating government's failure to acknowledge that there is a link between rural hardship, education and employment opportunities.

I recall in 1995 when I stood on the other side of the House and pleaded with the then government to provide drought relief to my electorate. Many of the farmers and the farming families in that area were wishing to undertake further tertiary educational studies in a cross‐section of different areas. Would the Keating government provide us with any drought relief so that those farmers and their families could go to university to be educated and provide the income for their families to be educated? No—nothing! Quite rightly, the New South Wales Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report highlights that fact.

In fact, the conditions that they point out about employment in rural New South Wales applied right over Australia in the period of 13 years of wasted opportunity by the Keating government. I want to give you the facts. Employment in rural New South Wales accounts for 35 per cent of the New South Wales work force but areas outside metropolitan Sydney account for 43 per cent of people registered as unemployed, 45 per cent of the unemployed people are aged under 25, and 47 per cent of long‐term unemployed people and 52 per cent of long‐term unemployed people are under 25. That applies right throughout Australia. That is where the Keating government failed. They did not provide employment and economic stimulation to enable young people to get a tertiary education in rural areas.

Even when the 1995 drought came in my area, you would not give them one lousy dollar—not one dollar—so that they could send their sons and daughters on to tertiary education. Just think about that. Just think about what damage you did. Not only did you do that, but the ones who were trying to get their sons and daughters into university to continue tertiary studies, the ones who were already there, were being slugged.

I came into this House in 1990 and, since then, you have put up the higher education contribution every year. So the parents who were already sending students to university were being slugged every year. HECS has gone up every year since then, and it has gone up again. So the cost to get students a tertiary education, to send them to university, has been borne by their families. There was no opportunity to help people. There was not one lousy dollar to help the farmers in my community. I think you must look at that situation and see what your policies did to rural areas. It is spelt out very clearly.

So I will commend this paper to you. I am terribly disappointed that the member for Sydney did not remain in the chamber, because I am sure he would be very interested in this. I think the member for Sydney is a very warm and caring person, and I am sure he would read this paper, `The human rights of rural Australians', by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with great interest. It is factual. It is a very intense and accurate survey of the conditions in New South Wales.

I can tell you, from my own experience, that many of those conditions are applicable in north central Victoria in my own electorate. For example, youth unemployment in the Bendigo region has been in excess of 30 per cent for several years under the Labor government, the Keating government. That has not happened since 2 March; that is, until May, when this report was written. It did not happen in that period. That has been going on for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it higher in 1982?

—It has a relationship to education at a tertiary level and the opportunity for young people to receive tertiary education. I want to say to the House that we do have a commitment to regional universities. I want to spell this out in the last remaining minutes that I have. I will quote from our policy document. It states:

BREAK.PARA: Universities in regional areas are important participants in the economic development of their regions. The Coalition recognises that for historic reasons regional universities are poorly resourced, particularly in the area of research infrastructure.
Obviously this document is referring back to the Keating government—`poorly resourced, particularly in the area of research infrastructure.' It continues:

The Coalition also recognises that rural and regionally based students have been historically disadvantaged in Australia's higher education sector. The role of the regional universities in improving access for such students is vitally important.
I could not agree more. The document goes on:

The Coalition will seek to build and strengthen regional universities in recognition of the fact that they are important for regional growth and important in providing rural students greater access to higher education.

I think the member for Port Adelaide needs to get a copy of this document as well and have a very close look at the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission paper which is about rural Australians. It really highlights the failures of the Keating government. As I said to you initially, it is regrettable that the member for Sydney has not remained here to hear my contribution to the debate. I am sure that, if he looked again at the topic of the matter of public importance that he has put forward, he would recognise that he has left out one very important word; that is, `Labor'. It should read, `The impact of the Labor government's policies on educational opportunity for young Australians, particularly in regional Australia.' (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (NEWLY ARRIVED RESIDENT'S WAITING PERIODS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on 16 February gave his personal pledge to those who were concerned about this item. He said at a doorstop interview:

SPEECH.PARA: Can I make it clear . . . Take the migrant waiting periods . . . it doesn't apply to refugees, it doesn't apply in humanitarian circumstances . . . It, of course, doesn't apply to family allowance and other benefits.

This was the man who at that stage was claiming a mortgage on political integrity and was saying in public that nothing so undermines the integrity of the political process than the cynical repudiation of pre-election undertakings by a newly elected government. Pre‐election, we had a clear understanding that all that was to be done was extend from six months to two years the waiting period Labor had introduced. There was no suggestion it be extended by any degree either to new measures or to new classes of persons. We were told expressly by the then Leader of the Opposition, the now Prime Minister, that it did not apply to family allowance and other benefits.
What did we find out immediately after the election? We discovered the Prime Minister wrote to Senator Vanstone on 13 May and said:
I am writing in regard to the Government's introduction of a two year waiting period before migrants can access a range of social security and other payments.

As you will recall, Cabinet decided on March 27 1996 . . . that this two year waiting period would be extended to a range of payments beyond . . . proposed in Senator Newman's original submission. In particular cabinet decided that you should review and report back on the eligibility criteria for labour market programs and access to AUSTUDY.

The list of additional social security payments to which the waiting period will apply has now been finalised. I therefore wish also to finalise the status of labour market programs and AUSTUDY. Accordingly, I would be grateful if you would provide immediately for Cabinet's consideration a submission to changes to extend the waiting period to these programs.

There it is. Immediately after the election, contrary to those undertakings, it will apply to other benefits. We have not seen the full measures yet because legislation implementing those changes is yet to come before the House. The Prime Minister did write in regard to these measures to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) saying:
Thank you for your letter of 30 April 1996 regarding the additional payments to be included on the two year waiting period list for migrants.
I agree to your proposal that the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card and the Disadvantaged Persons Scheme Health Care Cards be included on the waiting period list.
I support your proposal to include special benefit on the waiting period list, with an exemption for the safety net arrangements. I also support the draft revised guidelines for special benefit.

With regard to child disability allowance, double orphan pension, disability wage supplement and mobility allowance, I propose that the waiting period will apply, unless the migrant becomes eligible after his or her arrival in Australia.

Notwithstanding your concerns about Childcare Assistance and Childcare Cash Rebate, and your desire to consult with the Minister for Health and Family Services, I propose that the two year waiting period apply to these payments.

In addition to the payments considered above, I propose that Maximum Family Payment (formerly Additional Family Payment), Maternity Allowance and Multiple Birth Allowance be included on the waiting period list.

How can you square this with the Prime Minister's pre‐election statement, when he said, `Can I make it clear: it, of course, does not apply to family allowance and other benefits'? The people who were given those words of comfort and assurance—those sections of the community who are concerned about these matters—would be feeling sick in the guts now that they are seeing the sort of cynicism that the Prime Minister decried in the public arena when he said before the election that nothing so betrays the nature of the parliamentary process than the cynical repudiation of election commitments by an incoming government.

I will now compare the details of the proposed two‐year waiting period for migrants with the previous six‐month waiting period. I will start with the changes to the exemption provisions. Firstly, absences from Australia during the two‐year waiting period will not count towards that period. For many people this will mean that the waiting period is substantially longer than two years. Secondly, the present exemption for spouses of permanent residents of longer than two years is withdrawn, so that Australian residents of long standing and Australian citizens now cannot meet and marry people from overseas without the spouses incurring these kinds of penalties. Never before has an Australian government told Australians whom they can marry to their prejudice. Yet this is a measure introduced without notice to the public before the election. Holders of subclass 820 visas are specifically mentioned to the effect that they are subject to the waiting period.

I now come to the payments excluded under the proposed provisions. We have previously addressed benefits such as jobsearch, newstart, youth training, parenting and sickness allowances—allowances essentially encompassed by the old concept of unemployment benefits—but the government, unannounced, has added to the list. It has included partner allowance and mature age allowance—because, it says, of the changes to the residency requirement which will take effect from July l996. It has added widow's allowance and carer's pension—which previously carried no length of residency requirement. It has included the disability wage supplement, maternity allowance, child disability allowance and double orphan allowance, which were all paid before with no waiting period. It has included mobility allowance, the Commonwealth seniors card and the health care card.

BREAK.PARA: Family payment will only be paid at the minimum rate of $22.70 per child per fortnight when, previously, it had been available to everyone in Australia who had children. Many of those people are taxpayers, not the people described in the current rhetoric as the `unemployed bludging on taxpayers'. It is the people who have come here to make their home and who are earning income who will be punished in this way.

That raises the issue of discrimination. A two‐year waiting period for these benefits will not apply to people who come from New Zealand. In the case of some benefits, particularly sickness allowance, the waiting period will not apply to people from the United Kingdom. Reciprocal agreements with Italy, Portugal and Spain were negotiated in anticipation that benefits to migrants would be available on arrival and there must be debate going on in the department at the moment in light of these proposed measures.

Children of both new arrivals and long‐term residents and citizens are being treated in a discriminatory way. I asked departmental advisers about this the other day but I could not get an answer about whether they had received advice on the inconsistency of these discriminatory measures with the Racial Discrimination Act. I do not have a settled view yet because I have not had time.

This bill was first introduced without notice last Thursday. Contrary to undertakings provided to me by the minister's office that we could have a draft of this legislation to look at, no such opportunity was presented. We have had no opportunity to undertake the kind of research that would enable us to address the question of whether problems arise because of the inconsistency of this bill with the Racial Discrimination Act. Obviously, that is an issue which will need to be looked at as the debate goes on.

There are a number of implications of this measure. Firstly, there will be great pressure on emergency relief services. Such bodies are partially dependent on Commonwealth funding and will be asking for additional assistance to meet the additional demands placed upon them. There will be great poverty and great inequity between the different classes of persons, and I am certain that a number of examples of that will be provided in the course of this debate.

One example is the carer's pension. Under the previous government there was no waiting period for this benefit. This legislation will mean that an Australian citizen in need of the special care that could be provided by a relative coming from overseas will have to have sufficient means to be able to support themselves and the carer for the first few years of the carer's stay. I cannot see how that would assist in the provision of a comprehensive welfare scheme for Australian citizens.

There are a number of other examples that I am sure other speakers will give. I come back to the Prime Minister. Even after the Prime Minister's letters to his ministers, he came before the House last Wednesday on 22 May and said:
Can I just make it perfectly clear to the Leader of the Opposition . . . You introduced a six‐month period. All we have done is extend your six months to two years.

Mr Howard has said, in another context, that he is desperate to be honest. That really is a mark of desperation. Anyone else who made the commitments that were made by the Prime Minister before the election, wrote to his ministers as the Prime Minister did, and then stood up and made the claim that the Prime Minister made would be entitled to have those remarks called lies. But of course this is the honourable man who is desperate to be honest; this is the Prime Minister who has the mortgage on integrity.

However, the Prime Minister has form in playing politics with the ethnic communities. He is already following a well worn track in what he has done: the abolition of the Office of Multicultural Affairs and taking a minister out of the cabinet and giving that junior minister responsibility for immigration, pretending that minister can have a coordinating role. I suppose what the Prime Minister would defend himself with is the same thing that was said in the fable about the snake.

An old person came upon an injured snake. Having taken the snake home, given it comfort and brought it back to health, the snake then bit the old person. In dying, the old person turned to the snake and asked, `Why did you do that?' The answer was, `You must have known I was a snake when you took me in.'

That can be the only explanation of how the Prime Minister can defend what he has done. When he gave his undertakings to the concerned communities he said the changes would not apply to family allowance and other benefits—but his audience was really to understand that they would. Of course they would. He always intended to do that. Of course he was going to be deceitful. Of course he was not going to change. He would never be anything other than the snake he had always been. That is the only explanation that is possible.

In terms of failure in this area, there is no greater failure than that displayed by the then shadow Treasurer, now the Treasurer (Mr Costello), in the costings. Mr Costello costed the savings for these measures—announced by the coalition before the election—at $616 million: $84 million in the first year of operation, $252 million in the second and $280 in the third. The brief to the incoming government revealed that those costings had been terribly flawed. Based on departmental estimates, and assumptions of a 30 per cent up‐take rate on special benefit under very restrictive circumstances, they estimated savings over a three‐year period to be only $259.1 million—a shortfall on Costello's figures of $356.9 million.
