The explanatory memorandum, which was circulated when this bill first came out, changed those numbers yet again. But since the government has come to office there have been all of these new measures put in which the minister did not anticipate, which were not announced and which were new changes in the cabinet submission. Even with all those, all you get is $29 million worth of savings in the first year, $132.4 million in the second and $171.1 in the third. This assumes that only 10 per cent of those who would apply for special benefit because of the tightening up rules would have access to those benefits—total savings of $332.5 million and still leaving a shortfall of $283.5 million.

But in a later explanatory memorandum circulated by the minister, in what must be the most rubber ball costings of all time, we have another $15 million found. So we now have savings of $31.4 million in the first year, $143.5 million in the second and $185.6 in the third—total savings of $360.5 million, a shortfall of $255.5 million, plus implementation costs of over $17 million, as revealed in the brief to the incoming government. Yet whatever they do, they cannot fill the gap in their own savings measures. The Costello figures were just fraudulent. Even when you lie to the Australian people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should refer to members by their title.
—The figures of the Treasurer, then the shadow spokesperson, were fraudulent. Even when you deceive the Australian public—
—Order! I think the honourable member should use caution with that word.

—Even when you proceed in that manner, you cannot make the savings claimed. So there are three huge embarrassments here—firstly, for the Prime Minister's integrity. He is blaming those who have failed to understand that when he said, `Of course it doesn't apply to family allowances and other benefits,' they really should have understood him to mean, `Of course it does apply to family allowances and other benefits.'

BREAK.PARA: It also shows up the Treasurer's incompetence and gross inflation of his estimates of savings. In the Senate, it shows up Senator Newman's credibility because she is still denying that the government has made final decisions in relation to matters, which correspondence signed by the Prime Minister shows final decisions have been taken on—a misleading of the Senate. It also shows policy ineffectiveness because the outcomes will not be achieved. It is very plain that the government has no chance of affecting the inflow of migration in these areas because, as has been shown in a whole series of reports, chain migration, which sustains population flows, is notoriously difficult to influence, let alone stop. There is no evidence at all that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and migration officers overseas have had any diminution of applications for spouse sponsorship, for example, since the new measures were announced.

It is certainly likely that, while the new measures are unlikely to achieve their obvious aims of dampening family migration, they are likely to cause hardship and deprivation to people and families who are already amongst the most poor and vulnerable in our society. Excluding and marginalising such new arrivals from our social security system will create compounding social welfare problems for the future.

Professor Birrell, who has written quite a lot on this subject in terms of intake and numbers, has argued that it is naive to think that the denial of social security benefits for two years will be a sufficient disincentive to reduce spouse sponsorship from countries like the PRC and Vietnam, which I assume to be the secret agenda behind what is being done by this government. Our approach is very different.

We have moved an amendment to say that we understand the coalition raised these issues about an extension from six months to two years in the election context. We accept that there is an authority from the election to implement those changes, but that is for those changes alone, not the ones that are the subject of lies, not the ones that are the subject of deceit. We will be moving amendments in the Senate. We will ask that these measures be examined by a committee. We are not seeking to be other than constructive. We have not had an opportunity to examine all these measures. There may be one or two issues that we will look at but, essentially, we will hold the government to its mandate and no more. We will not reward dishonesty.

We will not be like Mr Ruddock, whose one defining moment of political morality was when he defied the Prime Minister by voting with the then government on a motion for multiculturalism. That was his high watermark of honour. Now he is the handmaiden of the very Prime Minister who is dismantling the bipartisanship on a whole range of issues including refugees and the Office of Multicultural Affairs.

These discriminatory measures apply to different Australian residents in a way which was never revealed to the public before the election. We will have no part in that. We are not going to tolerate and give comfort to the minister's dirty little job of now having to shovel up the messes that were made by the man he once had the courage to oppose. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment moved by the honourable member for Denison and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) mentioned the ethnic communities. I would like to feel that I have as much contact with the ethnic communities as anyone else in this chamber. I can honestly say that the ethnic communities, by and large, are very supportive of these measures. They feel very strongly that these measures should have come into effect quite some time ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Just before coming into the chamber I had a look at some figures on bankruptcies throughout Australia in the past 12 months. They are very interesting figures that show that in the past 12-month period personal bankruptcies throughout Australia—that is, for the period from March 1995 to March 1996—increased by 26 per cent. That does not include corporate bankruptcies.

Frankly, if those opposite had left us an economy that they could be proud of, that Australians could be proud of, then possibly these measures would not have been necessary. But necessary they are because of the situation that we have found ourselves in following the election.

I will talk very briefly about the question of retrospectivity because that is one of the matters raised by the honourable member for Denison. The member would be aware—if he is not he should be because he was in government at the time—that advice of the impending legislation was sent to the department. That advice was sent to Australian legations throughout the world. In fact, all the people who wanted to migrate to Australia, be it from Vietnam or China, were informed not just through the legations but by direct mail to the individuals.

I rise to join the debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 with a degree of sadness. I am speaking in support of the bill, but I would rather it had not been necessary. The situation that we found ourselves in, as I said earlier, has made it absolutely vital that these measures be taken. Australia is facing huge, monumental financial problems with more than three-quarters of a million Australians out of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?
—Some people say there could be in the vicinity of one million Australians out of work. The tragedy we have with young unemployed—
—Do you think this will do something about it?
—Order! The honourable member for Denison was heard in silence. I think you should give the opportunity to other members.

—I paid you the courtesy of listening to you in silence. I suggest you do the same to me. The tragedy we find with young Australians is huge unemployment problems. This is a great tragedy in Australia that was left by those opposite. We have an ageing population, with fewer in the work force paying taxes to support the burgeoning social security system, and a huge foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, I speak on this bill with a degree of sadness. I well recall my early days in Australia as a migrant and the privations my mother, my father and I had to endure, but endure we did. I am confident that new migrants to Australia will also cope—admittedly under stress but no doubt secure in the knowledge that Australia has provided us and will provide them with a unique opportunity to succeed in life in an environment that guarantees peace, political stability and a health system that is comparable with the best in the world.

Before the two-year period ends—and that is something the honourable member for Denison did not touch upon—these benefits will be available to those who are in desperate need. In addition, provision is made in the bill for a special safety net that will be provided via access to special benefits in the event that new immigrants' circumstances change beyond their control. If their circumstances change significantly for reasons beyond their control, then that safety net will be provided.

I hasten to add that further safety net provisions are also included in the bill. Again, the honourable member for Denison said absolutely nothing about that. He mentioned the People's Republic of China and Vietnam, but he obviously did not read the bill in detail because it is very clearly stated in the bill that further safety net provisions will be available by providing special exemptions for refugees and humanitarian migrants, including special assistance category migrants, as well as for their immediate family members.

I think it is salutary for all, as part of this debate, to point out that Australia compares more than favourably with other countries that have a migration program, especially in regard to social security payments. Australia has a unique non-contributory social security system and the payment of benefits is not based on the contribution based system of payments. Rather, it is based solely and universally on the basis of residence. Of course, it is means tested. In other words, there is no requirement for contributions to a social insurance scheme, as happens in other parts of the world. Offhand, I think Britain and Canada, among other countries, have a contributory scheme. Nor is there a requirement for past employment in one's adopted country, such as in the USA.

As I said earlier, I am sad that this bill had to come forward; however, I believe there is overwhelming support for the course of action that will result from this bill. There is overwhelming support in the community—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you tell the public what you were doing beforehand? If you thought it was that popular, why did you lie about it?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I find what the honourable member for Denison said offensive and I would ask you to ask him to withdraw.
—The honourable member for Denison will withdraw.
—I will withdraw the assertion that you lied about it. Your party lied about it.
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw the word `lie'.
—I will not withdraw the word `lie' in relation to his party. I don't need to. It is not unparliamentary.
—Order! The word `lie' is unparliamentary and I ask the honourable member for Denison to withdraw.
—I have used that expression both in this chamber in this debate and in the Main Committee room. It is plain that there was a lie made in relation to those matters by his party.
—The honourable member for Denison will withdraw the word `lie'.
—It cannot be unparliamentary to refer to the word `lie'. It is unparliamentary to use the word `lie' in connection with a speech of a member. I have withdrawn that and I withdraw it unreservedly.
—You referred to `lie' on two occasions. I ask you to withdraw it on both occasions.
—I have withdrawn it unreservedly in so far as there is any implication that the member lied.
—The words used were `you lied'. It is unparliamentary and I would ask you to ask the honourable member for Denison to withdraw that.
—Which I have done.
—The honourable member for Denison should make it crystal clear that he does withdraw that comment to the member for Lowe.
—I withdraw that comment unreservedly to the member for Lowe, as I have indicated and made plain in my comment previously.

—Australians are generous people who are determined to provide a fair go and are tolerant of each other; however, the economic situation does not allow us to be as financially generous as we have been in the past. I am sure all new immigrants and their sponsors will appreciate the situation we in Australia find ourselves in with regard to the difficulties experienced with the Australian economy. These measures will in no way lessen the Howard‐Fischer coalition's commitment to the long-term welfare of all new immigrants to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a bad piece of legislation which clearly contravenes commitments that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave both before the election and after, not only in the specific terms in relation to the treatment of migrants but also in more general terms in his commitment to maintain a viable social safety net in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The regrettable thing about the way this sort of measure is coming forward is that it is obviously the case that the Prime Minister and his party believe that this is the sort of thing you can do without significant electoral cost. He obviously believes that on the talkback circuits and so forth there will be substantial support for the kind of measure he is introducing. There is a current of sympathy out there for the view that there are people abusing the social security system. The previous government implemented a whole raft of measures designed to minimise that abuse.

I think the problem with this sort of circumstance is that it is very easy to canvass votes, to seek public support and to do the talkback circuits and to do the tabloid media, but the reality at the end of the day is that there are going to be some very disadvantaged people placed in very dire circumstances indeed. It would have been nice to think there was some sort of moral commitment or some sense of moral obligation on the part of the Prime Minister to not set in train legislation which is going to have the sorts of consequences that this legislation potentially will.

I think this legislation is also significant in what it prefigures about the present government's approach to a range of these sorts of issues. Before the election, the coalition, in seeking to argue that its spending commitments had been fully funded, put forward a whole raft of savings measures, including a number in the social security area. This was one. It claimed various savings in respect of those measures.

There are four major measures proposed for savings in the social security area. The first is this particular one, in respect of which savings of $616 million were being claimed over a four-year period. The second one was the pension bonus plan, in respect of which $180 million was being claimed. Thirdly, it was said that by tightening up on the activity test applied to people who were unemployed you could save $331 million over a three-year period. Lastly, there was reference to allegedly additional fraud control measures that could be taken in Social Security that would save a further $180 million.

During the election campaign, we in government argued that savings of this order of magnitude were illusory. Indeed, that point has been well and truly confirmed by what has happened since. For example, take this proposition. At least there are significant savings in this one—we never disputed that. But we certainly disputed the order of magnitude of savings that was being claimed.

The department briefed the incoming government on the estimated savings that were to be attained as a result of this program. The savings claimed by Mr Costello in the document that he issued on costings were: 1996‐97, $84 million; 1997-98, $252 million; and, 1998-99, $280 million. The Department of Social Security savings estimates for the same measures were: 1996-97, $22.7 million; 1997-98, $103.1 million; and, 1998-99, $133.3 million. That is obviously substantially less. When added up it comes to $259.1 million. These were the estimates that were made for the initial version of the proposals as the department interpreted them.

We have since seen the inclusion of a whole raft of additional payments in the ambit of this measure, which were listed by the previous opposition speaker. There has been reference to new payments such as the carer pension, the mature age allowance, the double orphan pension, and the child disability allowance. Particularly significant is the fact that family payment is to be brought within the ambit. The only payment which people affected by this preclusion period will be able to get is the minimum rate, which, I think, is $22 a fortnight. This is a major new element that was not indicated by the coalition when in opposition. In a speech in Queanbeyan the Prime Minister explicitly indicated that the ambit of this measure would not be extended to payments of this kind, particularly family payments.

As a result, the savings which are now estimated and which appear in the explanatory memorandum to the bill are significantly in excess of the $259 million that the department initially estimated. The current estimate in the bill over the four‐year period to 1998-99 is $360.5 million. That is still very much shy of the original estimate of $616 million. At least there are some significant savings in this measure.
The coalition put forward a number of other proposals. One was the so-called pension bonus plan. This was an interesting one. It originally appeared in Fightback.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of things were in Fightback.

—A lot of things were in Fightback. Major savings were being claimed as a result of the so‐called pension bonus plan in Fightback. When Labor was re‐elected in 1993, as the minister responsible for social security, I asked the department to look at this plan. If it actually did achieve the sorts of savings that were being claimed, it would have not been a bad thing to have done. It did not actually harm anybody and if savings of the order of magnitude claimed were there, why wouldn't you take them? The department came back to me with a minute that indicated that not only were the savings in the early years a small fraction of what had been claimed by the coalition in Fightback, but also when you moved to the out years it ceased to be a savings measure and started to be a substantial cost measure—a very rapidly rising one at that.
—This is short‐termism.

—This is short‐termism. As a matter of fact, the minute that the department prepared for me on that occasion indicated that the Department of Finance were not even prepared to concede savings in the early years. This is the other great saving—this line in the coalition's costing document—of $290 million.

SPEECH.PARA: Then the coalition reckon they can get $331 million from the activity test on the unemployed. The problem with that was that the Department of Finance could not even cost the thing because no specific set of measures was described. It is one thing to say, in a general sense, that further savings will be achieved through tightening the activity test, but you have to describe a set of administratively feasible, cost‐effective measures to give effect to that proposition. That is what the coalition singularly failed to do. They were repeatedly challenged to do so. When Mr Costello released the coalition's costings document, he said that all would be revealed when the coalition's social security policy was released. It was released a couple of days later, but there was absolutely no attempt to describe the specific measures that would be implemented to achieve the savings on the activity test.

In the brief to the incoming government on this matter there is a description of a number of further measures that could be taken, but there nothing like the order of magnitude of savings. There are the sorts of things that, when challenged, the coalition talk about, such as telephone contact with employers. In that regard, the brief makes this point:
Given that 20 million fortnightly forms are lodged each year, the administrative cost of a 100 per cent check of this type would be prohibitive.

It was obviously a ludicrous proposition, something that the coalition spokesman on social security thought of on the run during the election campaign. It was obviously not practical. So there was the alleged saving on the activity test on the unemployed. Then there were additional fraud control measures, with savings of $180 million. Again, the finance department could not even cost it because no actual specific measures were put forward. Interestingly enough, in the brief to the incoming government, there is no reference to this measure. So presumably the departmental officers putting it together and scratching their heads could not even think of what, in specific terms, the coalition might have been talking about.

So across the range of these social security measures, including this one, there is a huge overestimation of potential savings, with some measures having simply non-existent savings. Having established that the savings simply were not there for the proposal as described, we then see clear commitments in regard to these proposals being breached and a whole raft of extra nasties being worked in—extra payments, extra categories of people, spouses of people with more than the exclusion period. We see more people and more categories being worked in.

I think we are going to see a recurring phenomenon. When they finally work out and accept that the savings in the activity test that they talk about simply are not available, I think we will start to see some very nasty things being done to the unemployed. I would not at all rule out a breach of the Prime Minister's commitment not to cut the rate of payment to the unemployed.

Pensioners will finally accept that the savings from the pension bonus plan are a fraction of what they are claiming. I believe that we are going to see measures that really will disadvantage pensioners. There might be a bit of sleight of hand involved. It may not be done by an actual cut in the rate of pensions per se, but anybody who is heavily dependent on pharmaceuticals had better watch out. It is fairly clear that concessional arrangements in regard to access to pharmaceuticals are going to come under challenge in this budget. Having been on the ERC, I know that there are things that you can do in that area that do reap savings of hundreds of millions after a period of a few years, but those hundreds of millions are being taken off pensioners and other severely disadvantaged people.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if you can't get a special benefit?

—I am coming to that. The hundreds of millions in pharmaceuticals is a de facto reduction in the pension. It might not be done by an actual cut in the pension, but the effect on the disposable income of pensioners would be exactly the same.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been mentioned, there are four measures in the social security area. I will come back to this particular proposition, which is a thoroughly objectionable thing. There has been some discussion about the existence of a safety net and the fact that people will be able to access a special benefit. In order to access a special benefit under this legislation, people will have to meet standard requirements: that is, having absolutely no other available means of support, either in cash or in kind. You will have to meet this additional test of having been subject to some unforeseen and unforeseeable change of circumstance, which might seem reasonable to some. We need to bear in mind that we are not just talking about the principal individuals concerned. These people may well have dependants or dependent children.

The effect of this measure is that it is going to render a number of people absolutely and totally destitute—without any source of income support. You might be moralistic and say that these people brought it on themselves, that they did not anticipate the circumstances that would apply when they came to Australia. There might be some on the government side who would say that they are in some sense blameworthy and that they ought to be subject to this, but how does that apply to their dependent children?

When I was in San Francisco recently—the United States is a country without a decent social security safety net—I walked around the downtown streets of San Francisco late at night. On virtually every street corner you see people rattling styrofoam cups and begging for money. I do not deny that we have homeless people in this country, but one of the things that this government has tried to do is to construct a comprehensive social safety net in addition to providing basic income support entitlements. We tried to do this in such a way that everybody who had a reasonable claim did not—as with breaches of the activity test for the newstart and jobstart allowances—consciously fail to comply with a reasonable requirement for qualification for payment. We had a safety net that picked up everybody who was not in that category. That is not the case in the United States, and you see the consequences of it.

The most pitiful sight I saw when I was there—I saw it a couple of times—was a mother with three or four children sitting around on a cold night, again with a styrofoam cup, begging for support. This seemed to be the standard way of doing it. You can moralise about the principal individual here, but how on earth can this government justify reducing people to that type of circumstance?

TALK.START.PARA: —People come here as permanent residents.

—Yes. Even if people do satisfy this requirement for a special benefit, what do you get? The maximum rate is set at the same rate as the maximum rate of the jobsearch and newstart allowances—that is, the maximum specified in the legislation. If people have other sources of support, the secretary has discretion to set a lower rate of payment. But, again, people may not be able to access anything but the minimum rate of family payment—they cannot get guardian allowance and they cannot get rent assistance. They might have large families and have an income which is patently and totally inadequate based on any conceivable civilised measure. Even the lucky ones who manage to satisfy this test—
—They are the deserving ones.

—Yes, they are the `deserving ones'. Even the people who come to this country with the best of intentions, having looked into the practicalities of it, may have an unforeseen change of circumstance. They are going to be reduced to this terrible state of deprivation. What is being proposed here is absolutely morally abhorrent, and it typifies the mind‐set of the coalition. The coalition went into the last election saying, `You don't have to worry about anything. We'll preserve this basic social safety net. Nobody will suffer a cut in wages. Universities will get all their money. The schools will get all their money. Everything in Medicare will be left intact.'

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to all the features of the policy framework that the previous government put in place over a period of years—anything that had any degree of popular support—the government says, `Of course we'll keep that. We absolutely promise that.' `I am a man of integrity,' says the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). `Unlike you lot, I'll stick to my promises.' You will recall that, before the election, he went on the John Laws program. When challenged and asked, `What if it turns out there is a black hole? What would happen to the promises then?' he said, `In that circumstance sticking to the commitments comes first, even if it means delaying the achievement of a budget surplus.' That is what he said. That in itself is another broken election promise.

The really appalling thing about this is that I believe this will typify the approach to legislation in respect of the social safety net. As I said, the savings and relatively painless measures are ones that the opposition thought people would regard as essentially legitimate. The proposals they put up before the election are simply not there. They knew that. With the tightening of the activity test, they were pressed to actually say how, in concrete practical terms, the savings that they were talking about would be achieved. They failed to do that. I am sure that we will see measures that really do represent a major detriment to unemployed people and really do make pensioners and others who are on low incomes and who are disadvantaged in our society worse off.

It is just extraordinary to think that this self same coalition had the hide before the election to talk about rates of poverty and inequality. The previous government made a fundamental commitment to constructing this safety net, making sure there were not major holes in it and targeting it properly.

BREAK.PARA: The previous speaker spoke about burgeoning social security payments. If you look at our social security payments as a proportion of national income, you find it is one of the smallest in the developed countries. That is because the previous government put a huge effort into effectively targeting programs. We have one of the most efficiently targeted social safety nets in the world. That has been confirmed by a number of academic studies. A huge effort has gone into that and a major effort has gone into anti‐fraud measures. Our anti‐fraud measures have been recognised as being amongst the most effective in the world, as has our approach to data matching. The suggestion that the coalition put forward that there are easy additional things to do in that area is false. This legislation deserves condemnation by this House and by the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brough, Mal, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia would not be the country it is today without the diverse range of nationalities which has ensured that our nation is one of the most multicultural in the world. The Liberal Party recognises the enormous contribution migrant people have made to our nation in terms of their contribution of capital, skills and their culture. This government and, in particular, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised the people of Australia before the last election that we would retain our migrant intake levels the same as they were for the previous government. Recent reports show that migrants entering Australia under categories such as the business skills category will contribute more than $1 billion to the economy and create more than 7,200 jobs. Therefore, in all aspects and all respects our immigration program is an important part of what we see as our national development.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout its history Australia has had a very diverse immigration policy. Between the 1880s and the 1890s we deliberately insulated ourselves from our geographical region by adopting the White Australia policy. Officially known as the restricted immigration policy under the Commonwealth Immigration Restriction Act 1901, this policy had popular support, not only amongst the community but also by the likes of Alfred Deakin.

BREAK.PARA: I note that history books show that the White Australia policy was actively pursued by the Australian Labor Party, with the Australian Workers Union being amongst the most enthusiastic supporters of the White Australia policy well into the 1960s. This fact alone puts to rest the false claims continually made by those opposite that they are the party at the forefront of the immigration debate. Tit for tat, which party is the most immigrant friendly really has very little benefit to the Australian community.

I remind those opposite that Prime Minister Menzies was in office in the 1950s and the 1960s when we built the Snowy Mountains scheme, Australia's largest single engineering project. We literally had boatloads of Europeans coming to Australia bringing their expertise and, of course, bringing with them their culture. We have a bit of that culture here with Aussie, an Italian who has his cafe right here in the House.

I am sure that most members would agree that the White Australia policy in today's thinking is a blight on the immigration history of our nation. This policy was dismantled under successive governments of both persuasions. However, it took a Liberal government under Malcolm Fraser to fully embrace the concept of multiculturalism and ensure that Australia became the diverse nation that it is today. It is therefore very significant that today we also have a Liberal government once again prepared to take responsible decisions and achieve a fairer and more equitable system, a system which reflects the attitudes of the Australian people.

Those on the other side of the House never had the courage to implement such reforms. They recognised the need for this legislation when they introduced the six-month waiting period. But like so many of their political agendas, it introduced cosmetic changes rather than achieving its intended aim. The backward ideological left wing of the ALP has ensured that the Labor Party pursued a patchwork quilt approach to the immigration reform. I might add that most of its policies have been just that—a patchwork quilt between the unions, the Labor Party and its many factions. Of course, we have seen the breakdown of a few of those factions in Queensland. As the Prime Minister said the other day, it no longer has a left and right wing; it only has one wing between the two of them.

Since my election in March a considerable number of my constituents have contacted me seeking my assistance with matters on immigration. Often they have a relative or a friend who may be trying to migrate to Australia, yet are unable to do so as a result of their failure in some respect to meet the present criteria. Out of the thousands of people who are not successful in their bid to migrate to Australia, most of them would make a worthwhile contribution to our country. The reality is that we as a nation have to impose some restrictions because of our economy and the state it has been left in by Labor after 13 years of mismanagement. As a result, the government has an obligation both to those applying and to the wider Australian community to ensure that our immigration system is both fair and equitable.

It is this overriding need for equity that brings this legislation before the House today. The following quote comes from the Department of Social Security points test information sheet, produced in November last year under the previous government. The quote reads as follows:

When a person seeks to migrate to Australia they must in most cases provide evidence that they have skills and other attributes which will allow them to quickly enter the Australian work force and support themselves and their family without relying on the Australian government.

I find it ironic that Labor laid down a test for prospective migrants which was subjected to the phrase `without relying on the Australian government'. Their action in the House of not properly supporting this bill will perpetrate a system in which some migrants will rely on the Australian government after a very short period of time in Australia. If Labor was serious about its previous policy positions, it would be fully supporting this bill today. However, it comes as no surprise that the opposition intends to vote against this bill, as it has opposed every other major piece of legislation that has been put to this House by the government. So why stop now?

Under the Westminster system, an opposition is meant to be constructive. Yet all we have seen from the electorally decimated Labor Party is an opposition which is being deliberately obstructive. Whether it be the partial float of Telstra, which plan we went to the people with—it would have been sold in full, under the previous government, without consulting the Australian people—or the provisional tax uplift factor, which it spoke long and hard about and which it never bothered to reduce in its own time in government, it continually opposes legislation simply for the sake of opposing it.

The previous speaker spoke about pensions and the unemployed, and tried once again to put the fear of a coalition government and its plans for pensions and the unemployed into the minds of the Australian people. It is nothing more than scaremongering. It is nothing different from what they did in the 1993 and 1996 election campaigns. Of course, they go on with the same rhetoric today.

The Prime Minister has already stated—he is a man of his word—that we will not be disadvantaging those in our community least able to afford things. But the opposition will continue to talk about the way we will decimate pensions and unemployment benefits. After all, it would be pretty hard to see the leopard over there ever changing its spots.

One would think that after being rejected at the ballot box, for playing juvenile games while in government and failing to listen to the electorate, the opposition would now try to win back some respect from the Australian people by showing at least a semblance of maturity. Their actions in the last two weeks show very directly that that is the last thing on their minds.

In general terms, there are three major criteria that form part of the point system which has been identified for the selection of immigrants: their family ties, humanitarian needs, and economic skills and resources. For too long under previous governments, the obligations of both the sponsors of migrants and the migrants themselves have been breached in a way which has created large inequities in the system.

In recent times, there have been many examples of where sponsors and migrants have not kept their obligations. The result has been that a lot of migrants have, after a very short waiting time, headed straight for the social security system, creating a massive and unnecessary drain—not on the government but on the taxpayers of Australia.

One of the central tenets of this legislation is therefore aimed at ensuring that these people who immigrate to Australia keep their promise and contribute to the nation by earning an income. In other words, this legislation hopefully ensures that people considering migrating to Australia do so for the many benefits that this country offers—such as the quality of life—and not for what might be seen as a taxpayer funded handout.

This country offers great opportunities. We offer a clean environment, freedom of speech and democracy. I would hope that these are some of the reasons that people would consider moving to Australia—not for the generosity of our welfare system.

Often it is easy to forget that the money put into the running of the parliament, the construction of our roads, the Medicare system, defence, pensions, education and the environment is given to the government out of the earnings of the taxpayers of Australia. I believe that it is those taxpayers of Australia who are prepared to make this sacrifice for the greater good. But they have a large expectation that this government will ensure that their money is equitably distributed.

The failure of the previous Labor government to perform their duty in this respect was a major contributing factor to their failure at the polls on 2 March. In relation to our social security system, which the opposition have waffled on about at great length tonight, they say that it would be irresponsible of our government not to protect those in our community who are least able to support themselves. We support them on that, and we have no intention whatsoever of ever dropping the social security net for those who are most in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will see.
—Yes, you will see, the member for Batman. The social security which we enjoy today is paid for by the Australian taxpayers. We should never, ever forget that.

BREAK.PARA: Australians do not want to see people who come into this country who, after a very short period of time, take advantage of the system. Take the example of someone deciding to emigrate to Australia for a working holiday. Many Australians do that. They might visit the many beautiful regions of Australia. They go to the Barrier Reef, and then whiz over to Perth and the Pilbara. They might even come and visit Canberra. What are they doing? Are they using up their savings and planning, at the end of that six-month period, to go onto social security after realising the generosity of it? Or should they be looking for work from day one?

When my father-in-law emigrated to this country, he was at work within three days. Many people of his generation had the same experience. There was not the social security available to them which the Labor government had made available to people emigrating to this country over the last 13 years. We are here to redress that imbalance and to ensure that people earn their stripes, so to speak, and earn their rights to the Australian social security system.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't mind the child endowment he brought you up on.
—I am afraid that I was not brought up on child endowment, and I am afraid that you were probably brought up on—
—The honourable member for Longman will address his remarks through the chair and ignore interjections.
—My apologies, Mr Deputy Speaker. He is sometimes a very hard man to ignore, even though he is rather ignorant at times.
—You ought to talk, you ignoramus.
—Order! The honourable member for Batman will withdraw that remark.
—With all respect to the chair, I will withdraw my remarks. I also request that the honourable member for Longman withdraw his remarks so that there is some evenhandedness from the chair.
—At the time, you did not raise any objection, so there is no point of order raised.
—With respect, I ask that the honourable member for Longman also withdraw his remarks so that there is evenhandedness from the chair.
—Order! If the honourable member found any offence in the honourable member for Longman's remarks, he should have taken a point of order at the time.

—Whilst I am not suggesting that the majority, or even a large number of immigrants take this view of taking a holiday on entering Australia, surely it would be remiss of us as a responsible government not to remove this option for those seeking to immigrate to Australia.

BREAK.PARA: A report late last year showed that people from non‐English speaking countries now face an unemployment rate 50 per cent higher than Australian‐born residents. In this time when the government has an $8 billion hole to fill in the budget, it would be betraying the people of Australia not to address this situation. The legislation therefore recognises the wishes of the majority of the Australian community in ensuring that our social security budget is distributed on a basis which is fair and equitable to all.

Under the current system, after 26 weeks and provided that they can show continuous residence for that period, migrants are eligible for the entire range of social security payments. These include: carers pension, disability wage supplement, widow allowance, jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance, mature age allowance, sick allowance, special benefits, partner allowance, maternity allowance, parenting allowance, child disability allowance, double orphan pension, mobility allowance, and youth training allowance, on top of a seniors healthcare card, to name but a few. The new legislation will ensure that a waiting period of two years will be applied to these payments at a saving to the Australian taxpayer of $171.1 million per annum. As was stated by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) in his second reading speech, the changes to the newly arrived residents waiting period encapsulated in this bill are modest and reasonable. (Quorum formed)

It is important that I point out that this government is not saying that migrants should at no stage be entitled to these payments. Instead, this legislation is saying that the people who migrate to Australia have an obligation to look for employment opportunities and to make a contribution to our nation, otherwise they should think twice before coming here.

When people from another country become Australian citizens they say that they are prepared to live up to the rights and the responsibilities of being Australian. In the same way, those people seeking to immigrate to Australia have similar obligations, unless there are factors beyond their control, in which case they will be covered under the government's legislation in the form of a discretionary special benefit. This benefit has already been derided by those in opposition. This is nothing more than I would ever expect because they deride any responsible piece of legislation brought into this House.

There is one final point I would like to make and that is the point that was raised in a newspaper article relating to slave labour in this country. Quite often we see Asian migrants who have a very poor command of the English language working for, it is claimed, $2 an hour. I believe that this is very true. My understanding of it is that you have unscrupulous fellow countrymen coming here who inform these workers that the government is going to employ them but that they are not going to pay them enough. These unscrupulous persons will supplement that wage by $2 an hour and it is not until such time as the workers get a better command of the English language and understand that they have been conned by fellow countrymen, and that they are now defrauding the federal government and the Commonwealth, that they feel they have been blackmailed. This provision will also put a stop to that, because nobody can live on $2 an hour without social security benefits to prop it up. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a couple of points arising from the speech of the honourable member for Longman (Mr Brough). Firstly, this bill arises from Liberal Party policy; it does not arise because of the consequences of 13 years of Labor government. This policy was announced by the Liberal Party in March 1993. When the honourable member suggests that this bill relates to an action of the former Labor government, it is a fallacy and it does not justify this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of the matter are that, when people apply to migrate to Australia, they have to meet the points criteria to obtain entry. The other undeniable fact is that absolutely no-one can guarantee that any individual will face two years of full‐time employment without hardship, whether that hardship be the result of a work related injury, a personal illness or a family illness.

Indeed, the honourable member for Longman cannot, in all sincerity, guarantee that he will necessarily be employed in his current occupation for a continuous period of two years. For instance, there may be a double dissolution and he may well not win his seat. That should not mean that the honourable member for Longman and his family should be cast into destitution as a result of those perhaps unforeseen events.

In making this presentation to the House, I would like to indicate my appreciation to the St George Migrant Resource Centre not only for the work it does within the community but also for the assistance it has provided to me in addressing a number of the issues relating to this government's bill.

The government has presented the two‐year waiting period as being merely an extension of the Labor government's 26‐week waiting period. That, however, is a significant misrepresentation and it is essential to acknowledge that there is a fundamental difference between the situation faced by a person precluded from income support for a period of six months and the options available to a person facing a two‐year preclusion period. Any form of waiting period clearly imposes a significant burden on any individual but, going from six months to two years, introduces a lot of uncertainties and many more vicissitudes that could result in an individual worker and/or his family not being able to sustain themselves albeit for some of that time, at least.

The government's representation of its policy, contrary to the promises prior to the last election, is baseless in the sense that it has significantly moved away from merely extending the period during which the items of benefit which were included in the Labor government's six months preclusion in what it has imposed, namely, a two-year preclusion.

Specifically, in addition to the preclusion applying to jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance, youth training allowance, parenting allowance and sickness allowance, the new legislation adds a number of additional benefits which will be precluded from migrants to this country. That includes the partner allowance, the mature age allowance and the widow allowance—in this category, if a new entrant suffers the misfortune of the death of their spouse, they will be precluded from a benefit, the carers pension, the disability wage supplement and the maternity allowance.

Heaven help a family migrating to this country if they are blessed with a child, because that family will not receive any maternity allowance or any child disability allowance. Indeed, if both parents should die in a car accident, the orphans resulting from that tragedy will not be entitled to receive an orphan's allowance. Families will not be able to receive a mobility allowance, a family payment or a special benefit allowance, which applies in exceptionally distressed situations.

New arrivals without means of support, who are refused the special benefit under the proposed restrictive policy, will be forced to approach charitable organisations for their assistance. This will mean that those charitable organisations, which already have insufficient funds to support and protect asylum seekers, will have a massive demand on their resources. Any attempt to meet the needs of this group of extremely vulnerable people displaced from the social security safety net will clearly be an enormous burden on those community organisations. They simply will not be able to cope with the additional impost on them, and they will have no alternative but to turn to the federal and state governments for resources.

So, while it may be window‐dressing for the government to take away this benefit, supposedly for a saving of $600 million—more realistically, half that—the public purse will simply be required to supplement what community organisations will be forced to pick up. The fact of the matter is that these decent people in the community organisations will not let people starve; but that is no basis upon which this government is entitled to formulate its policies. There can be no doubt that this legislation will create a subclass of people in the Australian community. While under Labor every permanent resident in Australia has been able to qualify for some sort of subsidy in cases of destitution, that can no longer be guaranteed.

The honourable member for Longman said—I am not sure whether it was in entirely justified tones—that Asian migrants to this country have a very poor understanding of the English language. I must say that that is a sweeping generalisation, significantly without foundation in my experience. Be that as it may, it must be accepted that a number of migrants coming to this country from non‐English speaking countries will be at a disadvantage. The honourable member for Longman acknowledged that those people have fallen prey to unscrupulous people, whom he again generalised to be their own countrymen. That may or may not be the case; but certainly there is a substantial cash labour market which is developing, just as it has developed in the United States, which preys on migrants.

The reality is that if a family migrating to Australia faces starvation, or if one of their children is in need of medical help and the family cannot turn to anyone—to Medicare or to social security—for such medical help, what will they do? Will they sit there and watch their child become even more ill, will they sit there and watch their family become malnourished, or will they be inclined to accept a job which, the honourable member for Longman indicated in his knowledge, can result in the payment of $2 an hour? Far from removing that unscrupulous cash labour market, the government's policy is going drive a number of migrants into that desperate situation.

The lack of assistance to migrant families—including the parents and the children—for a period of two years is going to significantly retard the opportunity that a family will have to be trained in the English language and in other essential vocational skills. That is, in itself, a very poor administration policy. We bring migrants to this country not only for humanitarian reasons, but also—and this is the reality in most cases—for our own interests.

Either we are going to have a trained and sophisticated addition to the resources of this country by assisting them to learn English, or we are going to develop a subclass. Unfortunately and regrettably, the actions of this government are heading down the latter of those two paths. The government is well and truly heading towards developing a subclass not only for the parents but, worse still, for the children.

The coalition has consistently focused on the need to protect family life. Indeed, we heard many coalition maiden speeches in which government members claimed a monopoly on reverence to the institution of the family. The coalition has, in the past, declared its commitment to the family reunion program. The coalition's two‐year waiting period, as it has framed it, would severely affect the capacity of families to consider applying for residence for a family member under the family reunion program. It would expose to poverty the children of people entering Australia as permanent residents. Quite frankly, it makes a mockery of the coalition's claim to a monopoly on respect and reverence for the family unit.

Perhaps they can retain that reverence and that respect for the family unit if that family unit is independently wealthy such that, in all circumstances that might confront that family—whether it be injury, illness or unemployment—that independent wealth can sustain the family unit for two years. Very few families are sufficiently independently wealthy to be able to assume the burden which will be placed upon them as a result of this government's policy.

This government's policy unquestionably raises inconsistencies with United Nations conventions, including the rights of the child convention and conventions relating to migrant workers. The government has simply failed to contemplate and appreciate the repercussions, other than the short‐term social security savings, anticipated by the measure. Even if the government is talking about a $600 million saving, it has not contemplated the longer term repercussions.

If these measures are not reversed—and, specifically, the measure of the government, by administrative decision on 1 April, to cut out the special benefits payments to migrants coming to this country and facing situations of desperation, and enacting the current legislation before the House effectively by executive direction—many families will be severely affected. A decision to migrate is not made lightly. It involves, firstly, selling up your assets, your home in the country of origin, resigning from employment, taking children out of school and packing up.

We have had, and indeed have, a situation where a number of people have already put those plans in train; they are already doing just that. They are going to arrive on these shores in the expectation that they have saved sufficient funds to insure themselves against adversity for a period of six months. They are going to arrive here and find that, as a result of executive direction, that situation is now changed. They are going to be faced with that burden, or those who have sponsored them are going to be faced with that burden, for a period of two years. While undertakings are often made genuinely, as I have mentioned, circumstances can arise which are not contemplated but which can result in a family having to turn to, for at least a short‐term period, social security assistance.

No government can morally justify retrospectivity and that is precisely what this government has done. A number of people, as I have mentioned, have already made plans and are acting on those plans. They are acting on those plans because of the representations made by the existence of government policy, which they were well and truly entitled to rely upon. Just as, in the case of any transmission of business, the incoming business owner must continue to honour the commitments, the undertakings, the representations of the former business, a government, if it is to act responsibly and morally, must honour the commitments and the representations made by a former government, when these representations have resulted in people taking a particular course of action to their detriment.

It is no excuse for any government to say, `That wasn't us; that was the former political party in government.' The facts of the matter are: political parties may make government but the institution is the government itself, and taking over the reins of government involves that responsibility. This government has ignored that responsibility and many people will suffer as a result of that.

The insidious thing about this policy is that it is easy to look to, criticise or put down a grouping of people for populist measures. It harks back to the 1984 days of Professor Blainey and his attacks on migration and multiculturalism because—I won't attribute any necessary motives to Professor Blainey—it was convenient.

We see in the Mark Twain stories that quite frequently, because people in a particular situation want someone to look down on; want to feel superior to a class of people, they find it easy to mock, criticise or brand as bludgers or parasites a particular grouping of individuals. Mark Twain succinctly portrayed the views of the Southern Americans and their bigotry to the American black race.

This government has a job of leadership. It must lead the Australian population beyond that limited bigotry rather than pander to it with populist measures. We have humanitarian responsibilities. The government has a position of leadership and it should get on with the job of properly governing this country and honouring its commitments to existing migrants who have made plans and taken steps to come to this country, rather than adopt these populist measures. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of fundamental tenets which have to underpin the social stratum and I do not believe there would be much argument on either side of the House about the importance of remembering that there are some people in Australian society with a genuine need to be helped. I think all members of this House would recognise that.

SPEECH.PARA: These tenets include, firstly, the genuine need for help that has to be addressed. Then there is the matter of fairness to the taxpayers of this country and to the needy people themselves, and then we have to look at the capacity to pay, because there are competing needs in the community. Next, there has to be a safety net we must always keep in place for people who, through no fault of their own, just cannot support themselves. Finally, there are the really exceptional cases of refugee and humanitarian needs.

The Sydney Morning Herald today reports on the catastrophic situation looming—from the study undertaken by the Red Cross—of a starvation crisis within 10 years. At present there are hunger spots in countries such as Africa, with 459.2 million people; Asia, 262.4 million people; and Latin America, 67.2 million people. When you look at the catastrophic conditions which some of those people are suffering, we would all like to say, `Yes we should provide for every one of those people.' I think everyone in this House would say that we really have a responsibility to do it, but in doing so we have to sustain the economy that we have. Some would argue that there are certain things that need changing within that economy and certain standards of living that perhaps ought to be looked at in terms of whether or not they are fair, and that—to get an across‐the‐board understanding of it all—some people should look at their own standard of living. But there are very many competing issues that have to be addressed and that issue surely is one of major proportions that we must look at.

Bearing those issues in mind, we cannot take the approach that we must address every single need. In this bill before the House the government really is introducing legislation to provide some contraction in expenditure in some areas, because that is for the benefit of the whole country. If the whole country is better off we will have a greater capacity perhaps to address some of the very serious issues in humanitarian and refugee areas.

It is important to bear that in mind when considering what this measure is about. I think that issue is sometimes forgotten in this debate and we launch into a `them and us' approach. In other words, there is a suggestion that we on this side of the House do not really care for people who are less fortunate than us and that the people on the other side of the House care a bit more than us. I think that sometimes that political debate clouds what really should be a bipartisan approach to helping those who are in genuine need.

Certainly this bill extends the current 26‐week waiting period to two years, but there are savings measures attached to that. We must remember that those savings measures will assist the economy as a whole and will make the economy as a whole better able to provide. The consideration of this matter has to be brought back to that each time. I think there is a tendency to lose sight of that.

A friend of mine was as socialist as you could possibly imagine. He was a solicitor who worked in a working‐class area. If I said to him that there was social security fraud, people ripping off the system and inequities because of that, going through the usual list, he would laugh at me. He would say, `You're a right‐wing Liberal. You wouldn't know.' However, after working in that area for five years, his tune changed.

He saw that the system was attempting to work but, because of what is an almost overgenerous approach in the legislation—and we all want to help—people who were prepared to abuse the system were able, unfortunately, to take away that bit of cake that was needed for the genuine people—in the Third World, in the Fourth World, the Aborigines—and so they were deprived of much needed funds. He learnt that particular lesson. He admitted that to me. In fact, he left the area and, as I understand it, he now practices in a middle‐class area. That is not a comment on him but on what he experienced first‐hand.

BREAK.PARA: With a measure like the one before the House, I would like members to think about the fact that there is not an unlimited cake. We have responsibilities in a lot of areas of this country and, I believe, having read that article this morning, in other parts of the world. If I may digress just slightly, Madam Deputy Speaker, without incurring your wrath, I hope the government thinks very hard about the aid budget and reads that particular article before coming to terms with where we are in this country.

Getting back to this measure, it is a matter of looking at the measures and looking at the situation in much poorer countries and then developing a strategy whereby, if we are going to get firmer in some areas—which we have to—we should also be looking very kindly on those much poorer areas.

To get back to the bill, it does allow for a safety net. That should not be forgotten in the overall debate. It will not leave people in genuine need out in the cold. The member for Barton (Mr McClelland) mentioned a couple of cases such as a death in the family when the person was within the two‐year period and someone was unable to earn income. The bill actually covers that particular area. If there is a tragic event like a double fatality, there is a safety net for children and others in the bill, as I understand it.

So it is not correct to say that they are going to be left out in the cold or cast out onto the resources of the general welfare community, including private welfare agencies. It should be remembered that the initial 26‐week waiting period was introduced in l992 by a previous government and took effect from 1 January l993. As I have said, the savings should not be understated. I do not pretend for one moment that the savings that are involved are massive savings, but in the context of a budget, as I understand it, our social security commitments are getting close to $1 billion every week.

PARA.BREAK: These sorts of savings will help to provide in a better way for people who need it. At the same time, they will assist the overall budgetary constraints that have been imposed on us by the state of the economy. The projected savings are $29 million in the coming finan cial year, $132.4 million in the following year, and $171.1 million in l998‐99. There are not insubstantial savings over that period of something like $365 million. That is not an insubstantial amount over that more lengthy period.

BREAK.PARA: The element of retrospectivity, which was mentioned by my learned colleague the honourable member for Barton, is something that one has to be very careful of in any legislation. Madam Deputy Speaker, I can assure you that, if I considered that this was a particularly serious example of retrospectivity, I would think very carefully about voting in favour of it. But there was a clear announcement made by the government in relation to the matter, and what the bill says to people who are contemplating coming here is that, instead of making provision for that 26‐week period, you now must make provision for a two‐year period.

I think that most people wanting to come to this country—I am not talking about the exceptions now; I am talking about the people who have actually made specific arrangements to come to this country and who are keen to start a new life—are wanting to be part of the Australian economy and part of the Australian society and, obviously, they are wanting to work. I would argue very strongly against any suggestion that people are really looking to come here just to use the system. I think that most people who come to this country want to come here to start a new life and to work. So, in reality, that suggestion of retrospectivity is illusory. It means that they must take into account that extra period in planning their migration to Australia.

I mentioned the matter of refugees. We can still perform this very important humanitarian role under the exemptions—and it is important to mention that. It is also important to mention the safety net, because there is a discretionary payment in the department. The exercise of that discretion can be monitored by the appeals tribunal. Members will know from experience that that tribunal is very independent. It is made up of very eminent people in the community. Frequently discretions by the department have miscarried. The tribunal would, I imagine, look at every case on an individual basis and review any exercise of discretion which, for example, may have had regard to irrelevant considerations. So, there are safety procedures in place.

The suggestions that have been made by the other side, might I respectfully say, perhaps get back to the old rhetoric about `them and us', which I indicated before. I think it is important for the opposition to realise that we cannot keep going on that road. We all want to be generous, we all want to help, but there is not an unlimited supply of funds to do that. The reason why we have a national debt of something over $100 billion is that there is not this monitoring process of expenditure, and expenditure has gone haywire in recent years. We have to pull that back. This is a measure which, in my submission, is fair to all people. It is fair to the community and it shows a responsibility to the Australian people. It is the fulfilment of an election promise and it shows responsibility.

As the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) said, he would rather this measure had not been implemented. I think that is a fair comment. Probably most of us would have preferred that. But, in reality, as part of the overall package and as part of recognising the reality of our budgetary situation, we would like to help and be more kindly disposed to all people if we could. We would like to be able to help those 700 million people out there who are hungry. But within the limits of our budgetary constraints, immediately, we are not able to do that. Let us hope that, with this measure, there is going to be a means of indicating first of all that we cannot be a repository for people whose countries are not exercising that responsibility of caring for their own people. So, we cannot be that either. But what we are trying to do by this measure, in my submission, Madam Deputy Speaker, is provide the budgetary caution that is needed at this time and fulfil our election policy commitment, but, at the same time, provide adequate safety nets for the people involved if misfortune should befall them. So, in all of the circumstances, Madam Deputy Speaker, it is my pleasure to support this bill and its passage through the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with a certain sadness to discuss the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Residents Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill. It is very sad that it is the Howard government which has put forward this particular piece of legislation. I say that because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is a person whom most of multicultural and ethnic Australia is observing very closely in terms of his actions with respect to the ethnic communities, migrants and the policy of multiculturalism.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for that, as you will know, Madam Deputy Speaker, is historical. It has to do with the history of John Howard, parliamentarian and former Leader of the Opposition, and what he attempted to do with the policies of multiculturalism and immigration in this country. It was to be hoped—and I said this on a number of occasions last year before the election—that when he made a statement a year ago that he had reformed his views on multiculturalism and immigration that he had genuinely done so; that he had recognised the hurt he had caused and the problems he had created as a parliamentarian and as a leader of the opposition at that time.

Therefore, we would have expected that someone with his record, and about whom so many people in Australia's ethnic communities have concerns, would have been extremely sensitive to introducing any legislation of this kind into the parliament. Instead, in answer to questions in question time, the Prime Minister has virtually gloated about this policy. He has virtually said, `Look, we stand for this policy. We are about to cut off these rights for people in terms of extending this waiting period to two years and, if you don't like it, go out and tell the average Joe Blow about it.'

It is obvious what the political strategy is. The approach is that they are saying, `In the mainstream media we can attack migrant communities and migrant people in this way and we can get away with it because there's a whole group of people out there that we give a message to, either directly or indirectly, either subtly or non‐subtly, that we are against them. We are against the rights of migrants.' That is the message which this legislation is giving. That is the message which has been given by the comments of the Prime Minister and other ministers in relation to migrant and multicultural affairs since the election of this government.

As I said, it is very sad because we were led to believe that there was a different view. The situation is that this legislation is being interpreted in this way. I know it is possible to go to some ethnic groups, especially some older ethnic groups, and to find some individuals in those groups who say, `Well, we're not really concerned about this issue.' But, as a person who is very close to Australia's ethnic communities and who has been for many years, I must say that people are very concerned about this, especially members of the newly arrived communities whose relatives are going to be most affected by this legislation.

Until recently, Madam Deputy Speaker, we had a principle in this country that people's relatives had a certain priority in our immigration program. This whole idea of migration of relatives has been a factor in our migration program for virtually 30 years. What are we doing to this factor now? We are effectively introducing an element which will discriminate. It will discriminate between those people who are in wealthy circumstances—circumstances where they can afford to maintain their relatives in Australia—and those people who are not in that situation.

This kind of discriminatory situation also results, and this is a very important point, in actual outcomes which are discriminatory in terms of sources of migration. It is true to say that there are people coming from one country who are significantly poorer and in a significantly different situation than those coming from other countries. So although it is not the intention of the policy, the consequence will be that family reunion migration will end up effectively supporting one group of countries vis‐a‐vis another. We will get into a situation which, although it may be an unintended consequence, will lead to complaints from particular communities that they are not getting a fair deal in relation to the family reunion program.

BREAK.PARA: We have already put a number of controls into the family reunion program. One of the things that really disturbs me is the lack of effort by members of parliament, and I blame everybody in this situation, to explain to the Australian people exactly what has been going on in the area of migration and especially family migration. Myths are everywhere. There are people who think that people arrive automatically under family reunion, or as refugees, and have no obligations. They do not pass any tests. They do not pass any criteria. They just happen to come here whereas, as you know, we have had a situation in this country for a number of years, certainly during the whole period of the Labor government, where tough criteria were used in terms of the individuals able to come on extended family migration.

Of course, this did not apply for spouses. At one point some people went so far as to suggest that we should limit spouse immigration, not even recognising that this would create a situation where we were in contradiction with fundamental principles of human rights as declared by the United Nations. Imagine a situation where a person's spouse would be affected in this way. But the basic point is that family reunion migration will be severely affected by this provision.

A further point is that this extension to the two‐year period is being done in a way which the current government, in opposition and during the election campaign, did not indicate was their intention. As the shadow minister has said, the reality is that the original proposal was a simple extension of the former Labor government's six months waiting period. No statement was made beyond that. No statement was made that the criteria would change, those receiving the benefits would change and those not receiving the benefits would change. It was put to us that there would be a simple extension of that principle.

And what has happened? We find that the criteria have been significantly widened so that other forms of benefits are affected which were not indicated in any of the statements made by the coalition during the election campaign. For example, the then shadow minister, Jim Short, said this:
The coalition's proposal to extend the six months period to two years is simply an extended application of a principle established by Labor in 1993.
That is what he said—nothing about the fact that they intended to extend it to other forms of benefits which they did not indicate at that time.

But it is not only an extension in terms of the number of benefits that will be cut off; it is also an extension in terms of the number of people and the groups of people that will be affected. We now find, Madam Deputy Speaker, that even spouses are going to be affected. Can you believe that? The situation will be that a person's spouse will be affected by this legislation. A spouse will not be given the same rights. In other words, if an Australian citizen goes overseas and marries someone, who comes over here—not for the purpose of general immigration, but for the purpose of being with their spouse—what do we have in that context? We have a situation where they will be subjected to the cutting off of all benefits, including medical benefits. If that person's spouse happens to become ill in that two‐year period, even though the Australian spouse may actually be paying the Medicare levy and paying taxation, that person will be affected in terms of the spouse's claims for Medicare benefits.

So we have the absurd situation that even a person in the most intimate relationship—the person who has to come to be with their partner in this country—is going to be affected by this cut‐off. Even if the Australian spouse happens to be working, happens to be paying taxes and happens to be paying the Medicare levy, their spouse will be affected. What kind of message is that supposed to send in terms of the Liberals' much touted support for the family? I am not sure. It obviously shows that they support the family, except when it comes to migrants, when it comes to spouses of migrants and when it comes to anything else that suits their purposes in terms of significant cuts to the budget.

As I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, this situation is going to create a context in which many people from particular groups of countries will be severely impacted. If people come here as refugees and they want to bring their relatives here, what is going to happen to the relatives of the refugees? They are not refugees; they are relatives of refugees. Are they not entitled to make a claim on the family reunion program? Of course they are. Previously they would have made that claim. Now the situation is that we have a person who is a refugee. That person may be coming here and establishing a life in Australia. They want to have a relative of theirs here. They sponsor that relative to come here. The refugee, the original sponsor, becomes unemployed for some reason. Maybe that person has worked for six months after arriving here but suddenly loses their job.
