The relative will not be eligible at any period in the two years for those benefits.

So what does this say about the fundamental Australian idea of fairness? Obviously, it says that, when it comes to the conservative parties and their cutting exercises, you can forget about it. Indeed, as I said in a speech last week, when it comes to the concept of social justice and the concept of fairness, we are seeing increasingly that the conservative parties are bringing back the New Right agenda. The agenda that they told us was forgotten about—the Fightback agenda, the Thatcherite agenda—is all coming back. They are bringing that back and doing great damage to other people. In fact, we have only seen the beginning of the process.

As we go towards the budget we are going to see other vulnerable groups of people attacked. I do not mean just the migrant communities—although you can be sure there will be more attacks on them and more migrant programs will be cut. The other vulnerable groups of people—the poorer sectors of the population, people who cannot defend themselves, people who rely on the government for welfare services—will be affected as we go towards the budget. What is the excuse—the justification—for this? As was proven conclusively today, it is nothing more than a myth created by the conservative parties who were not even prepared to wait until the growth figures came out—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—They were not even prepared to wait until the growth figures came out. They could hardly wait to create this myth—the claim about this so‐called $8 billion hole—in order to abandon all of the moderate proposals that they put before the election and to get back to the New Right, Thatcherite agenda. And they think that the Australian people are going to swallow it. They think the Australian people are going to believe them when they say, `We have to make these cuts because we have got to achieve fiscal balance.' In fact, the fiscal situation is much better than they claim and they have created a mythology in order to be able to bring in the agenda they always intended to have. As I mentioned, the Prime Minister should have been particularly careful in this area because of his record over the years. This is a cut that certainly should not be made in this way.

BREAK.PARA: The government claims a mandate for the increase in waiting time to two years. But it has no mandate for the increase in the number of benefits to be cut or for increasing the number of groups that are going to be affected. It has no mandate for either of those proposals and the opposition will oppose both of them. And we are correct in opposing both of them because what is being put in place is inhumane as well as contradictory. You will have a situation whereby, for example, if a migrant arrives in Australia under the family reunion scheme, gets a job and pays the Medicare levy and then pays taxation, they will not be able to claim the additional family payment. Can you believe that? A person who performs all their functions in Australia, including employment, will not be able to claim the additional family payment for their children. What sort of a nonsense is this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Even taxpayers.

—As the honourable member says, even taxpayers, people who are meeting all the criteria, who are getting a job, who are contributing to society, and yet are to be cut off from these benefits. That is discrimination, and that proposal will remain a shame for the conservative parties if they persist with it. In fact, it contradicts their whole claim in this area that they are doing all of this in order to get at those people who are not making sufficient effort to get employment and to make a contribution.

BREAK.PARA: The reality is that this is nothing more than an extensive cost saving measure which has the side effect, as I mentioned, of sending the message to the mainstream Australian community that `a little bit of migrant belting here and there will do us a lot of good out in a few electorates.' That is a disgraceful political position and one which has to be reversed. Those members of the government parties who understand multicultural issues and who believe genuinely in the rights of migrants ought to be opposing these provisions and ought to continue to oppose these provisions. In fact, these provisions should never have gone through the conservative party rooms.

I conclude with this point: we are at a crossroad in this country. The media have suggested that, because two or three members were elected by taking what one might call a very negative position on race and multicultural issues, somehow there is an overwhelming reaction against the idea of multiculturalism, against the idea of migrant rights, and against the idea of fairness for our ethnic communities in Australia. Let me say that a big mistake is being made by those who suppose that this is the case. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of reasons why an incoming government would want to make the changes in the legislation before the House. One of the concerns constantly expressed by those people who have the privilege of working with migrant community groups is the uneven approach that is taken by people coming to Australia. The fact is that some are willing to take the benefits of Australia, no matter what the circumstances and no matter what their claims. In fact, one is led at times to believe that people come to Australia to take advantage of our welfare benefits, despite the responsibilities of sponsors and the undertakings given by them.

In more cases than not—and the member at the table (Dr Theophanous) knows those statistics—the guarantees given by sponsors are overturned and denied. They are not followed through. This is a measure to correct that process. The former government saw the difficulty and itself put a six‐month period in. Where was the bleeding from the member for Calwell at that point? I did not hear one comment from him. I did not read of the honourable member in the ethnic press and I did not hear him on radio or television complaining about his government when it took that dreadful step of putting in place a six‐month barrier to the claim of welfare benefits for newly arrived migrants.

Of course, as soon as the opposing parties extend and rationalise and make a very sensible decision along the same themes and along the same pathway already taken by his own party in government, he complains. There are some extremely good reasons why we should undertake these decisions as we have. I would, however, in the process of supporting these proposals, point out to the House the rationale for the decisions. Migrants who come to Australia should be prepared, in our view, to be able to support themselves for two years.

I think that everybody who is concerned about the employment prospects of newly arrived migrants is concerned that we must be selecting to come here those who can play a full and a proper role in our society, who can gain employment, make a contribution to this nation and gain benefits for themselves and their families. So it is a proper thing in our view that newly arrived migrants should be prepared to support themselves for at least up to two years.

Many migrants who enter Australia have a sponsor or an assurer who has agreed to support them. That is part of the settlement process that has been adopted since, I believe, the mid-1970s, when ease of settlement was linked with the person whom you linked up with on arrival. That proposal does not go without some responsibility. Some migrants are granted visas on the basis that they can support themselves. There is often an unfair treatment in my view of the independent migrant who comes here with high knowledge and high skills but has to jump a higher barrier than those with a family sponsorship. This proposal levels the playing field in the way that it applies to both those who are sponsored or not sponsored. They will have to be prepared to look after themselves for a two-year period.

Newly arrived migrants should not expect immediate access to social security. That was the very fact that the Australian Labor Party had made. We have increased the waiting period for eligibility for social security and we have extended the range of those benefits that will be denied to newly arrived migrants. Of course, however, it would be unconscionable for us to apply those conditions to the humanitarian or refugee category. Australia has obligations to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and we will continue to fulfil those responsibilities.

The House will be aware that there is an extended range of benefits that will be denied to those who come to Australia. But there are also some exceptions that I think the House needs to be aware of. Some of the rantings and ravings, some of the extravagant claims being made by those opposite about the harshness of these conditions, should be put in the context of some of those areas where there can be exceptions. I draw the attention of the House to the statements made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), which set out the criteria for access of special benefits during the two‐year waiting period and the circumstances under which people can gain access to special benefits.

You would recognise if you were frank with the House that some of the conditions have a sense of fairness about them. There is toughness, but there is fairness for those in real need. I will just read to the House a couple of those circumstances that can apply to individuals if something goes wrong. Special benefits are available to newly arrived migrants if the sponsor becomes unemployed or if the migrants are receiving job search or newstart allowances. That is fair. If the sponsor is declared a bankrupt, benefits may be available. If the sponsor is imprisoned or enters a psychiatric institution or a nursing home on a long-term basis, if the sponsor has been reported to the police as a missing person and the police have been unable to locate them, if the sponsor leaves Australia permanently, or if the sponsor dies, then special benefits are available to the newly arrived migrant. I think that takes into account just about every situation where a sponsor cannot fulfil their obligation.

The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) would probably think that that is probably erring on the side of being a bit too fair. I understand the way in which he approaches this issue, he being a migrant himself—he has quite different attitudes from those expressed by the member at the table who, in government, denied benefits to people but when in opposition wants to give migrants everything. That is rather typical of the approach of the Australian Labor Party—make extravagant promises and claims when they are in opposition but not fulfil them when they are in government.

If migrants are sponsored by a business or employer there are certain circumstances whereby they can still gain benefits: if the job is withdrawn after the person arrived in Australia, if the business goes into receivership and the migrant's employment is terminated, if a business ceases to operate during the migrant's first two years in Australia, or the worker is retrenched. What is fairer for the availability of special benefits than that? For a worker who is sponsored there is still that opportunity if something goes wrong with the job—if the job is withdrawn, the business goes into receivership, the business ceases to operate or the worker is retrenched.

I think that is fair enough, and people on this side think that that is fair enough. The member for Calwell does not think it is fair enough. He wants them to have it come hell or high water—come into Australia and fill your pockets up with the taxpayers' funds and the funds of people who are battling trying to find jobs.

BREAK.PARA: Some might say that this legislation does not go far enough. It will, however, make a saving of millions of dollars that will help to plug the hole. It is legislation in keeping with the commitments we made to the Australian people prior to the last election. What is more, that which we are arguing before the House tonight is consistent with the attitudes of the Australian people, including the migrant population.

No other country would be such a soft touch. What other country would say to the whole world to come here and join us, and immediately you arrive you can get on the dole queue? We are saying that people should wait not for the six months that the previous government suggested but for two years. This is reasonable, moderate and good legislation that will encourage the nation towards responsible economic management.

I am very proud to support this legislation. It is a major piece of legislation, it is good legislation, it is necessary legislation, and it is legislation that has the backing of Australians throughout this great continent.
