DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (NEWLY ARRIVED RESIDENT'S WAITING PERIODS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, the theme of the coalition's election campaign was `For all of us'. Now we have seen this social security bill, we know when the coalition says `For all of us' the coalition really means `For some of us'. The effects of this bill give the lie to the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) because what this bill does is deliberately make Australia a less attractive proposition for prospective migrants. It deliberately undermines our enviable reputation. It deliberately dismantles the fabric of a society that the Prime Minister has acknowledged is tolerant and compassionate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded of a pertinent cartoon in the Sydney Morning Herald some weeks ago which had a sign down the bottom which said, `Welcome to the land of milk and honey, but you can't have any.' I do not think anyone could describe the Australian social security system as milk and honey, but the latter point—that newly arrived migrants cannot have any for two years—will certainly be true if this legislation is passed in its current form.

Let us have a look at what the Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions, most recently in his talk to ACOSS last Friday, I think it was. In that talk to ACOSS last Friday, he reiterated the commitments he made to ACOSS on 13 October 1995 in a speech called `Fair Australia'. In that speech he said:
I want to make it unambiguously clear today that we will not be eroding—
not be eroding—
the safety net that underpins our social security system.
He went on to say:
I repeat so that even my Labor opponents can understand: we will not be eroding the safety net that underpins our social security system.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lie that was.

—That is exactly right. The changes to special benefit provisions do undermine the social safety net. This is the payment of last resort. To get special benefit now under this bill new arrivals in Australia will have to jump through a large number of additional hoops. This provision is callous and bad.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to go on to some other things that the Prime Minister said in this speech to ACOSS last year—and this is something that we have heard regularly from this government—he said:
Protecting and strengthening the family unit is the key to making social cohesion and economic stability in the future. The family unit—a very important part of Australian society.

But which families are going to be most hurt by this legislation? The families who will be hurt by these measures are families coming to a new country, families without the immediate support of community networks or their extended families, families who may not be fluent speakers of English, families whose experience in the first two years of arrival is critical to their settlement.

What do we find in this bill? Even if you are a relatively wealthy migrant family with an income of up to $63,000 or higher you would be eligible for the minimum rate of family payment. But if you are a less wealthy family, a family on a low income, who could do with some extra help to feed, clothe and house children, then according to this government, according to this bill, bad luck. They will still get the minimum family payment but they will not get the higher rates which are available to other low income families.

What will happen in that situation is that responsibility for caring and helping these families will fall to the voluntary organisations. It will be those organisations that will deliver emergency relief. This is yet another example of this government handing its social security responsibilities over to community organisations.
Just going back to the speech of the then Leader of the Opposition, he said:
All Australians should have access to an adequate income, affordable housing, quality health care and a level of education that enables them to fully achieve their potential.
That is unless they are newly arrived migrants because rent assistance will not be available to them and health care cards are specifically excluded.

A little later on in the speech we might have expected to hear a bit about the provisions in this bill because there is a segment in this speech to ACOSS where Mr Howard spoke about people from non-English speaking backgrounds. But there is absolutely no mention—no mention at all—of a two-year waiting period. He says:

One of the main reasons why Australia continues to be such an attractive proposition for prospective migrants is that over an extended period of time we have built an enviable reputation as a tolerant and compassionate society.
This bill deliberately makes Australia a less attractive proposition. This bill deliberately undermines our reputation as a tolerant and compassionate society. He went on to say:
Given the direct link between unemployment and poverty—
I remind you this was in the section about people with non-English speaking backgrounds—
this disparity clearly demonstrates that as a nation we have a duty—
we have a duty—

BREAK.PARA: to ensure that newly arrived migrants are able to acquire the language and vocational skills needed to participate fully in the labour market.

Now we hear that labour market programs, as well as all the other things in this bill, are under threat. In a letter to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), the Prime Minister said:

Cabinet has decided that you should review and report back on the eligibility criteria for labour market programs and access to Austudy. I want you to finalise the status of labour market programs and Austudy.

What we see here in this bill is not the end of the road. These are not the only things that newly arrived migrants are going to find themselves excluded from. Despite the fact that the Prime Minister said to ACOSS last year that vocational skills are needed to fully participate in the labour market, there will be no help from the government.

The Prime Minister went on to say that the coalition is committed to policies that will ensure that newly arrived migrants, particularly refugees, have access to retraining and language courses. How can we believe that now that we also know that this bill exists, that Austudy and labour market programs are likely to be excluded and that the Prime Minister has also asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) to look at whether child‐care assistance and the child‐care cash rebate should also be excluded from access by new migrants? We have a major effort by this government to remove what this side of the House considers basic support for people newly arrived in this country.

Let us look at another document in which we might have found reference to these new exclusions. A document called `A social security safety net' was the Liberal-National parties' social security policy. There we have mention of people with disabilities, widows, carers and families. There is also a section on people of non-English speaking background and reciprocal agreements with other countries. But nowhere in this document is there any mention whatsoever of a two-year waiting period. That is the first thing. Secondly, there is absolutely no mention under any of those headings of people with disabilities, widows, carers or families—no mention whatsoever that new migrants to this country will have to wait two years for access to any of those payments. In none of those areas where commitments to payments are set out is there anything about new migrants.

In the section on reciprocal agreements with other countries there is no mention that the then opposition intended, if they won government, to dramatically alter the conditions that would apply to new migrants in this country. As the member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin) said in his speech to this bill, this is a very bad piece of legislation—one that will certainly not add to social cohesiveness in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the contribution of the member for Longman (Mr Brough), who cited historical racism by the Australian Workers Union. No doubt if he did more reading in that field he could find articles about the Victorian furnishing trades and their problems with Chinese labour, but he could also find comments by Cecil Rhodes and Winston Churchill. Quite frankly, I think anyone with half a historical bent would appreciate that these comments are often made in different contexts, different historical periods, and they should be seen in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: I am perhaps more interested in the current context and the forces that drive this legislation. They are epitomised in the Governor-General's speech on behalf of the government. The rhetoric of that speech is what really propels this legislation. It said:
The government's commitment to govern in the national interest, and not for vested interests, will build community confidence and respect for the rights of all Australians.
All the measures and policies so far described are aimed at promoting the interests of the Australian community as a whole.

What is really behind that is the reality that there is in the Australian electorate at the moment a very hard edge in this policy area. To be honest, the previous government to some degree vacated the field by a preoccupation with multiculturalism without explaining a large number of measures that it had under taken in this field. I will go through some of those.

These things should have been indicated more firmly in the previous three years. I agree with the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) that all members have a duty to explain the policy, to explain what is going on. There was a failure to really articulate to the Australian electorate that it is not a free-for-all, that it is not just a matter of walking through the door and getting benefits.

If we look to the history of the last few years we see that in 1989 the previous government increased the emphasis on the English language and the points test to ensure that there was some targeting of the migration intake, that it was not just anyone's cousin who left school at six years of age and looked after sheep on a mountain. They introduced the health levy and the bond to ensure the recovery of welfare benefits paid to some sponsored family reunion migrants. So the government did move in the direction of sponsorship, getting money at the initial entry. There was the introduction of user pays in sectors of English language instruction. There was, as many have said, the introduction of this six‐month waiting period.

The reality, unknown to the Australian electorate, has been the introduction of a number of measures to try to ensure that there was some legitimacy in the system, that it was not, as the current government tried to pitch it in the lead‐up to the election, essentially a situation of bludging on the Australian taxpayers.

There is no doubt about the reality out there in the electorates. In places like my own electorate, there are the families of former Maltese poultry workers, the second generation Lebanese who work at James Hardy, the Turkish shopkeepers in Auburn and the people who came here in the 1920s without any expectation that they could bring their families here. Those people are concerned.

There must be a reappraisal of the migrant intake. There must be an attempt to ensure that migration in this country is driven by this country's population requirements and long-term needs rather than by lobby groups, which some people might feel should dictate the direction we take. There should also be an even greater emphasis on bonds before people arrive. These are the solutions we should be looking at. It is interesting to note that, whilst there is a possibility of requiring bonds for spouse entry, the latest figures indicate that a bond is required for only six per cent of prospective spouses. These are areas where something can be done to make sure there is legitimacy in the system, to make sure Australian taxpayers can have respect for the system, to make sure migration is not undermined by its lack of respectability.

This matter is driven by politics, and the opposition does have a number of concerns with this legislation. Firstly, there is the issue of retrospectivity. It is quite clear from Senator Newman's statements that a number of people—probably significant numbers—who have already been approved will be affected by this. The conservative parties in this country usually have a great passion for this issue. There is great passion by the current minister for what we might be doing to illegal entrants to this country. On 28 February 1995, in relation to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), he said:

We are reluctant converts in relation to this matter. We opposed the bill on the last occasion because of its retrospectivity. The bill is still retrospective in its impact. We took an on balance decision, taking into account a number of matters, particularly the potential cost to the public purse . . .

We had to drag those opposite screaming to support that legislation because it was retrospective. That legislation was not aimed at people who had entered the country illegally; it was aimed at protecting the Australian taxpayer from very large compensation payments for supposed illegal detention. Further, the minister bemoaned the fact that the legislation:
. . . condones the proposition that wherever unlawful administrative action has been taken the parliament may by a retrospective initiative cure it.
Acceptance of this proposition would, as the Law Council of Australia says, destroy or at least significantly diminish the Commonwealth administrative law system.

The minister is on the record as saying what a dreadful concept retrospectivity is. In that case he was crying tears for the people who had been detained by the Australian legal system for illegal entry into the country. We do not see those same tears today when he retrospectively hits a large number of families who went through the migration processes required by this country.

Secondly, the opposition has concerns with the way in which this measure has been extended. As I said earlier, there is a view in the electorate—fashioned by the inability of people to articulate what has been happening in the last few years in regard to our laws, to explain the tightening of requirements—that severe measures have to be taken. This is not driven by any attempt to worry about what will be saved or to really look at the way in which people will be hit.

If there was ever any evidence as to what was behind this, it was the performance of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We know what he said at Queanbeyan. We know he gave the commitment that this measure would not affect a wide range of benefits. We know the way in which it has gradually been extended to cover Austudy, Medicare and family payments, et cetera. It is interesting to note that, on 21 May, when he was first asked about this in the parliament, he said:
. . . it was my understanding when I wrote that letter that it was completely consonant with the commitment that had been made.

It was quite clear on 21 May that he was considering adherence to and integrity and honesty about the commitment the government made before the election. Overnight, he obviously reconsidered the political situation. The next day he was able to say that he `makes no apology whatever for making a policy change'. It was a matter of great moment when this man went to the Australian electorate with these rather high standards in Australian politics and said that he never lies or deceives. In this policy area he decided to take the opportune possibilities to extend the mandate to a large number of other benefits. This legislation, retrospective in its nature, is providing an inadequate safety net, extending to a range of payments far more diverse than those the coalition had originally spoken of. As other speakers have noted, a more diverse range of people have been covered.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Longman talked about the experience of relations who got jobs easily. The reality in this country is that over the last decade it has been difficult to get employment. People complain about others getting benefits. The reality is that the Australian electorate as a whole was not getting these benefits in the 1940s. It is not just a matter of benefits being extended to new arrivals. We are talking about a different reality for all Australians.

It is a matter of concern that this measure is going to hit people, and I will detail that in a few moments. There is a wide variety of articles that go to the question of the impact of our current economic situation on new arrivals.

Again, I want to join with those other members who have accentuated the way in which there has been deception about savings. Despite the blowing of horns and the wild projections of what was going to be saved through this measure, in reality the savings have been roughly half of what was originally forecast. That is a pretty wide difference. As I indicated, there has to be a lot more targeting in the program. As far as I am concerned, there is nothing wrong with giving a degree of national interest greater prominence in this program, and, at the same time, having a reasonably high refugee intake.

This is going to impact on people who have already been given permission to come to this country. What is the situation they face? Janet Taylor and Helen Macdonald, of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, noted in an article entitled `Disadvantaged children of immigrants: a longitudinal study':

The need to ensure adequate wage levels for all workers, in particular NESB workers, in the face of economic restructuring is highlighted by the number of NESB families in the Life Chances Study with incomes below the poverty line despite the parents' employment. The issue of working conditions and safety is also raised by the frequency of mothers being employed in outwork as machinists.

The study confirms the concerns . . . about the relative under‐representation of children of NESB families among recipients of Additional Family Payment for low wage earners and raises questions about how this payment can best be advertised in non-English families.

That indicates the severe problems that people coming to this country without English, without skills, without recognition of skills obtained overseas and without networks already in employment face when they go into areas like my own electorate. In places like that they do not have these networks, and there has been a retraction of manufacturing employment. Even when they get employment, they are basically condemned to the worst jobs in this country.
The Centre for International Economics in 1992, in the document `Immigration and the Commonwealth budget', noted:

It finds that in the first one to two years, assuming normal `non-recessionary' labour market conditions, the intake marginally increases the budget deficit, by a total of $57 million. But under depressed labour market condition assumptions, this deficit rises to $208 million. Over a three‐ to four‐year term the deficit increase is $139 million in total under normal labour market conditions . . . After ten years, the net contribution of the intake is $317 million surplus.

What most studies in this country have shown is that the first three to five years of arrival are characterised by an over‐representation in unemployment, particularly of communities such as Turks, Arabs and Vietnamese, but that their employment levels become closer to the Australian mainstream over time.

Essentially, what we are going to do with these people is condemn them even further. We are going to ensure that, whilst the government gets rid of the assistance to the textile workers enduring outwork in this country, these people—people who have been deprived of their benefits for two years—are going to be forced into that marketplace. The member for Longman talks about the fact that a lot of these people do not have English and therefore people in their communities persuade them to go and outwork. The previous government had policies in place to attempt to undermine outwork and the way it was eroding migrants' conditions in this country. This government is going to force these people into these kinds of areas, and that is a clear reality.

There are measures in this bill that are worthwhile. I want to strongly associate myself with those sections dealing with data matching. It is interesting to note an article by Holly Idelson in the United States Congressional Quarterly Report Vol. 54(5) dealing with the current debate in the US Congress to pressure employers more in regard to checking the bona fides of employees, and employees having a system to ring in and verify whether they have the right to work. This bill does do a few things about simplifying cross‐referencing of various records. It does assist in regard to data matching. I for one have no problems with that.

If this government were genuine about it, there are a lot of areas where it could do something about illegals rather than worrying about legal people. For instance, I have heard no talk from this government about the reality of tax file numbers in this country. Illegal entrants do not have to establish that they are permanent residents to get a tax file number. It is an invasion of privacy. I for one have raised in the parliament how Australia's tertiary institutions are being accessed by illegals.

The minister is poll driven; he has been the most active minister in regard to actions and press releases. He has come in here retrospectively hitting the people who went through our proper processes—the people who have followed the legal requirements of this country. He has no concern with retrospectivity as it hits them, but he has certainly been very concerned in the past about the fact that retrospectivity might hit illegals. It is on these kinds of matters—on the question of illegals in this country—that he has been silent.

This kind of measure is going to hurt my kind of electorate. The atlas of the Australian people shows an increasing concentration of Turks, Arabs and Chinese new arrivals in the Parramatta electorate. The reality is that those areas are significantly identified with an over‐representation of unemployed people and problems in regard to the ability to speak English.It is interesting to note that, in the last medium income of families with dependent children figures, the Australian average income for two‐parent families with dependent children was $39,500; for those of Lebanese extraction it was $26,500; for those of Turkish extraction it was $28,700; and, for those from Vietnam it was $31,300.

If the people cannot get out there and get illegal jobs, if they cannot avoid the taxation system and if they cannot rob people and basically break into homes, they will become more dependent on their communities. These are communities that already have very deep problems.

Essentially, at the end of the day this legislation does not have a mandate in the way in which it winds its net. The government does not have a mandate to retrospectively hit those people who come here not as tourists and do not flagrantly ignore our laws but who actually go through the processes we require. Some of them went through those processes two or three years ago. They entered our system, in attempting to come here, thinking that there would be certain rules, processes and expectations when they arrived in this country.

The current government has become aware of a concern which is based upon ignorance. The solution is to look at the way we actually take people in, look at a policy directed at the requirements of the country but which does not target social security. If there is any problem, it is fundamentally around the immigration area rather than the area of social security.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Leo McLeay ) put:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The policy basis of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill is bad. It raises some fundamental questions. One question is whether this government accepts multiculturalism as the basis of our society. The attacks on new arrivals that this bill would encourage indicate that the government does not. Another question is whether the government accepts its obligations to ensuring that the disadvantaged in our community receive proper protection. Again, the bill indicates that the government feels it is under no obligation.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill before the House is based on a punitive approach to politics and comes straight out of Fightback. Let me quote from that infamous document. It says:
The coalition will not permit future migrants access to benefits for two years after they first arrive, unless they are given refugee or humanitarian entry status.
For the sake of proper attribution, that quote can be found in chapter 16, on page 289. At the time of the last election, the coalition policy read:
Access to welfare benefits for migrants other than refugee and humanitarian migrants will be available after two years under a coalition government.

Let there be no doubt about it: this policy comes straight out of the most pernicious manifesto ever put before the Australian people. Now we have found it regurgitated in this bill. It is not about ensuring that sponsors fulfil their obligations; it is about putting obstacles in the way of people seeking to come to this country, hoping to discourage them altogether.
This government is actually proposing to be more punitive in its approach than Dr Hewson was. If you look at Fightback, it states:
Access to family allowances will, however, be maintained.

Last week we saw, as a result of leaked correspondence, that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has insisted that what was the family allowance supplement will not be available in that two‐year period following arrival. Let us be clear: what John Hewson was prepared to give, John Howard will not. Not only does this policy make a comeback from Fightback, but also the new version is decidedly more sinister than the original.

The government has been manufacturing a fiction that this measure is all about cutting out welfare for migrants; the leaked correspondence exposes this fiction. The family allowance supplement is paid to those in employment. These people are not getting off the plane and onto welfare—they are low‐paid workers. Like all low‐paid workers in this country, they deserve the protection of the social safety net.How does this fit in with the Prime Minister's commitment to no worker being worse off?

Newly arrived migrants in employment and on low wages now face the double injustice of no family payments and the proposed changes to the industrial relations system. This group of workers is definitely worse off. As we saw in studies of the new enterprise bargaining arrangements towards the end of last year, it is migrant workers who need special assistance to ensure that they get the same gains as the rest of the work force. One consequence of the measure will be to place further strain on the already overstretched resources of the emergency relief programs. Newly arrived migrants who are denied access to the social security system and other programs of income support will increasingly turn to emergency relief programs. Anecdotal reports from service providers in my electorate indicate that this has already begun.

The significance of this bill reaches far beyond those it purports to target; it would affect Australian citizens too. Let us assume an Australian citizen is married to a citizen of another country and that they reside in that country with their children. After returning to Australia, the children must wait the two‐year period before they are able to qualify for full family payment. This situation where Australian citizens are unable to have access to family payments arises out of the proposed measure. This is certainly the most bizarre outcome.

There is speculation that the introduction of these measures was designed to reduce demand for preferential family migration. It was hoped that restricting the availability of these benefits would lower demand by some 10 per cent over a full financial year. Since the announcement of these measures, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is said to have experienced no reduction in demand for spouse migration, so this bill will not achieve this aim. It ends up punishing a group which is already among the most exposed in our community.

These cuts were supposed to mean projected savings in the budget of some $616 million over three years. Even with the inclusion of a whole host of other programs, only $332½ million over three years would be saved. It is therefore legitimate to ask where the difference of $283.5 million will be made up.

What other pernicious measures does the government have in store for migrants in order to recoup this amount? Where are these savings going to be made within the portfolio and which group will be singled out for this treatment next time? This measure is indeed short‐sighted and callous. It will undoubtedly create more problems than it seeks to solve. The government fails to take into account the fact that it is consigning a proportion of the Australian community to severe hardship.

The supposed savings to the budget are nothing compared with the long‐term damage done. The Australian community will have to deal with the enormous drain on emergency relief services and charities resulting from this legislation. The Australian community will have to deal with long‐term structural problems through the creation of a permanent underclass of newly arrived migrants. The long‐term costs to the budget and to Australia appear to outweigh any short‐term gain. Ultimately, relegating new arrivals to this underclass only undermines Australia's tolerance for absorbing people through a program of immigration. None of these things can be good for Australia.

In this debate various speakers have indicated other particularly disturbing aspects of the way in which this legislation has been presented. I for one would like to place on record my disquiet in that here we have a piece of legislation that was first introduced late last Thursday before the House adjourned for the weekend break. The debate has been resumed today and then, for the second time in the first four weeks of sittings, there has been an extension of time beyond 8 o'clock on a Wednesday night.

This extension has been brought in to rush this piece of legislation through. This, I believe, is quite extraordinary, given that the government supposedly made a commitment to ensure that this place would work in what they regarded as a better, more efficient manner and that, in fact, we would be given the opportunity as a parliament to properly review the executive. I do not believe that the action being taken with this piece of legislation is in that spirit.

Also, I found it interesting to read the communique of the meeting of the Ministerial Council of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs held in Canberra on 17 May 1996. That communique, on page 2, amongst all the issues that were discussed at the meeting, states that other issues discussed at the meeting were:
. The two-year waiting period for social security entitlements for migrants. Ministers noted that the new provisions will be implemented in the context of a package—
and I repeat: a package—
which addresses broader issues including immigration procedures, sponsorship responsibilities and employment opportunities . . .

There was no mention in the minister's second reading speech of any such—(Quorum formed) I thank the members of the House for coming in and making a quorum so quickly. As I was saying, one of the disturbing aspects of this debate is that the minister, in the second reading speech, has not gone on in any fashion to talk about a package—and I quote again from the communique from the meeting of the ministerial council—`which addresses broader issues including immigration procedures, sponsorship responsibilities and employment opportunities'.

As the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) said in her speech, the Prime Minister was allegedly elected on the basis that he was going to govern for all. There is no evidence in this legislation that this particular group of people is, in fact, included in the `all'. I cannot understand why they believe that this should be forced through the parliament in such a quick manner on the basis that it has some popular appeal.

In my electorate, the North East Region Settlement Issues Network had a meeting and put together a number of concerns that they have about this piece of legislation. I thought it might be appropriate to quote some of those concerns from a letter that they have sent to me. The letter states:
There are a number of issues that are of concern in regard to this legislation and these are:
. The lack of consultation with Ethnic community members on the implications of this change for their communities.
. The discriminatory aspect of this policy which targets a specific group (new migrants only) in an attempt to save the government money.
They go on to say this:

. This policy has also not factored in the long term effects on new migrants who are likely to end up alienated and open to exploitation in the workplace. And the effects that alienation and disaffection will have on the wider community.

Other speakers, especially those on the other side and the one Independent member who entered this debate, also raised this point in the debate: there is a targeting on the group that we are talking about here, new migrants, as if they carry out wholesale, 100 per cent, abuse of social security—100 per cent abuse of working on the side. I think that this is a nonsense. Nowhere in the debate, not in the second reading speech or in anything that I have read outside this chamber, has that been placed on record. All this is doing is attempting to try to put a lid on a group of people, to try to prevent and discourage them from entering Australia. In fact, in the main, they basically enter Australia for family reunion.
The group from the North East Region Settlement Issues Network have commented on the undue haste in bringing the legislation in. They have commented on the change. They go on to say this:
. The change does not acknowledge the fact that the first two years in a new country are essential for settlement to occur effectively and thus ensure an appropriate avenue for integration.

The cutting of these benefits for an additional 18 months over and above what was already in place does not assist in the settlement or integration of these people. Also, they were concerned about this:
. The retrospective aspect of this change which does not give migrants adequate time to prepare and make alternative financial arrangements.

During the last parliament, how many times did we hear the cry that a measure that was being introduced by the then government was legislation by press release? What have we seen in this case? On 1 April, the announcement was made by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, about the new access arrangements for social security for migrants from 1 April. Whilst some of the measures contained in this legislation form part of the policies that the coalition went to the people on, what they did not indicate—beyond saying that they would happen soon after their election—was when the start‐up date would be.

As has been indicated by other members from the opposition side, there were plenty of people who would have held valid visas to come to Australia; who would have been making their arrangements. These arrangements would not have been made in the short term because, as a previous speaker said, they are arrangements of some moment—disposing of housing, disposing of goods, arranging for the proper transition for any children, arranging a family's education and the like. These are things that need long lead‐in times. It is completely unfair that over the space of a short election campaign, during which this policy was announced, and then soon after the election of this government, this arbitrary date, 1 April, was implemented. That is wrong. It is quite unfair and unconscionable that it was, in fact, contained in this legislation.

As I have said, I have great disquiet about the policy on which this legislation is based, particularly the fact that this present government has taken those benefits that the previous government had put a six-month waiting list on and has increased the waiting list to two years. Even given the disquiet about that element of it, it is quite incredible for the government to then expand the number of benefits that this proposal is to cover and to expand the groups of people that it covers.

That aspect has been addressed in the second reading amendment of the member for Denison (Mr Kerr). We believe there is a great element of deceit in the way in which the government has gone about this piece of legislation. In fact, they are matters that we believe should be taken away from this place and looked at again. The second reading amendment says that the waiting period will be extended to new groups of citizens and residents—they have been outlined previously in the debate. The legislation extends the waiting period to a wider range of new benefits entitlements. During the election campaign, the Prime Minister is on the record as saying that this new range of benefits entitlements would not be involved. Since the election, he has asked his ministers who have carriage of this area to have look at widening them.

The simple fact is that we cannot even be convinced that the measures that are in this legislation will be the end of it. There is every indication that other benefits will be looked at and that other benefits will be denied to new migrants. Nothing has been said, by way of answers to questions in this place or by way of contributions in the debate, that could give us any idea other than that these are the facts. (Time expired)
Motion (by Mrs Crosio) put:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Having lost the earlier debate, I stand very proudly to support the amendment before the House. I certainly stand to oppose the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Residents Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996. You only have to look at the amendment moved by the shadow minister for immigration, the member for Denison (Mr Kerr), to know what we are saying about this bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the House is of the opinion that the Bill should be withdrawn, redrafted and re‐presented to the House in a form which applies the two year waiting period only to those payments to which the six month waiting period currently applies because in its present form, and despite assurances from the Prime Minister that the measure simply extends the six month waiting period to two years, the Bill—
(1) extends the waiting period to a new group of citizens and residents;
(2) extends the waiting period to a wide range of new payments, benefits and entitlements;
(3) provides an inadequate safety net; and
(4) is retrospective.

I read that out because when I read the bill as presented by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) I could not help but recollect that something like three years ago—it was during the 1993 election campaign—the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, made a speech in which he stated quite clearly his and, as we thought at the time, all Australians' objections to those who would work against fairness and injustice in our society. He said:
Today we stand against radical right wing proposals which are hostile to fundamental beliefs and Australian institutions and all that we have achieved in recent years.

He made these comments during a time when Australia was under threat from the then opposition's Fightback policy, a manifesto in which the members of the coalition, many of whom remain with us today, sought to transform Australia by their own meanness. They were rejected outright in 1993. The Australian people chose not to inherit the mercenary and selfish society dreamt up by the former member for Wentworth, Dr Hewson, and his close henchmen at the time—the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

The coalition then went back to their blackboard—they went back and stirred their cauldron—and by the time of the 1996 election they had a new plan. The present Prime Minister and his team had seemingly deferred to the wishes of the Australian people as exercised at the ballot box in 1993. They returned as a caring, sharing bunch who abhorred injustice in our society. They appealed to the people to forget Fightback, to forget the previous evils; they, like many previous reformed offenders, deserved a second chance. The Australian people obviously believed what they heard. The rest is now a matter of history.

Since assuming the role of opposition in the parliament, the Australian Labor Party has declared its intention to keep the government to its election promises. While we are sure that the government's proposed two‐year waiting period will generally be detrimental to the welfare of our migrants and against the spirit of fair play expected by the majority of Australian people, we do not intend to oppose the legislation in that respect. We object to, and will oppose until our last breath, the government straying from its election commitment.

We will stand against the backdoor approach of crucifying migrants on a scale not announced before the election. We will oppose the instigation of policy by stealth. We will resist the government's attempts at constructing the mean and wretched society that it envisaged three years ago when in opposition and on which grounds the government is now facing the Australian people. I would like to read something that others may have read in part before:

In relation to eligibility for benefits, we have made it very clear . . . we would not provide benefits unless there had been a marked change in circumstances. That period of exclusion would be two years.

That statement was made by the present Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs when debating the Fightback policy in this House on 5 May 1992. How little things have changed. He was then, as he is now, in charge of coalition immigration policy, only now he is in government. He later said in the House on that same topic:
These are the sorts of changes this Government—
meaning us at that time—
could well adopt in a realistic and sensible way if it wanted to further constrain the immigration numbers.

That was said on 12 October 1992. So here we have in this House tonight, in this bill, the real reason behind the government's two‐year waiting ban. It was the same reason then as it is now—to cut as far as possible, without creating controversy, the numbers of migrants arriving in Australia.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer can go on as much as they like about cutting costs or even lifting burdens from our social security system, but that is really all they want. The Prime Minister in August 1992 said it himself when asked on the Lateline program about Dr Hewson's plan to dramatically cut the migrant intake to 50,000. Mr Howard replied:
I would, for one, argue very strongly that it ought to be dramatically less.

He is now so very close to realising his long‐cherished dream.The Prime Minister knows that extending the waiting period to two years would not be enough on its own. Short of coming out and reducing the numbers outright in the migrant intake, such a regulation would do little to stem the flow. For example, chain migration—migration relating to and resulting from family links—is notoriously difficult to control and it will not be reduced by simply increasing the waiting period by 1½ years. The government had to find a way to bring to fruition its plans to reduce the migrant intake. It found it in the level of benefits, welfare and otherwise, which it could withhold from migrants during the two‐year waiting period to which they would now be subjected.

PARA.BREAK: Restrictions from benefits would now cut deeper than those announced before the election in their policy document Meeting our Commitments and, I imagine, even deeper than those foreseen by any member of the government, apart from the Prime Minister and his little inner circle. The Prime Minister's words, and the words of his former shadow minister for immigration, the Assist ant Treasurer (Senator Short), before the election were clear. They said the coalition's policy on waiting periods for migrants was exactly the same as Labor's, the only difference being the extension of time from six months to two years. Let me read to government members the words that came from their own leaders' mouths, just in case they needed reminding. They said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition's proposal to extend the six months to two years is simply an extended application of the principle established by Labor in 1993.

Thank you Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short. That is from your press release of 19 February 1996. If the government was going to keep its promise and if the Prime Minister was going to live up to his word—which I think most Australians would expect him to—the stated policy of the coalition would have the government applying the two‐year waiting period to the following benefits: jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance, youth training allowance, parenting allowance and sickness allowance. These are all benefits to which the current six‐month waiting period, brought in by the Labor government, applies.

When the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs announced in his second reading speech last week the government's amendments, they applied to a whole raft of benefits not included under the present act. Here we begin to appreciate the government's real agenda of cutting migrant numbers and here we have a very serious breach of an election promise.

For the edification of those members who may have missed the speech by the minister for immigration last week, let me tell you what extra benefits the government's new waiting period will now ban migrants from: carer pension, mature age allowance, partnering allowance, disability wage supplement, widow allowance, maternity allowance, mobility allowance, special benefits other than when a migrant's circumstances change beyond their control, double orphan pension and child disability allowance.

These are not benefits that the government went into the election claiming they would withhold from migrants. In fact, as you have already heard in the statement made by Senator Short, they are benefits that the coalition said they would preserve by maintaining the policy followed by Labor since 1993. They said they would keep everything begun by Labor and change only the waiting time in force.

The Prime Minister went so far as to say exactly the same thing in this House just a day before the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs inadvertently trapped him in his deceit. The Prime Minister said, `Can I just make it perfectly clear to the Leader of the Opposition that you introduced a six-month period. All we have done is to extend your six months to two years.' Thank you, Prime Minister. But the Prime Minister's deception goes even further than that. He says one thing in question time and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs says something completely different in the House the following day. It involves a deception of the Australian people of a much higher order.

While the Prime Minister was in this House publicly stating just how far his government's policy would go, he knew that earlier in the month he had sent letters to both the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), proposing that those ministers find further benefits from which to bar migrants access. He even hinted at a couple of his own. The Prime Minister suggested to the Minister for Social Security that she look at denying migrants access to family payments within their first two years.

In his letter to Senator Vanstone, he proposed that the minister draw up plans to bring before cabinet prohibiting migrants from Austudy and from gaining access to non-welfare labour market programs. I am sorry, but I thought the Prime Minister said in a statement in Queanbeyan on 16 February:
Can I make it clear . . . take the migrant waiting periods . . . it, of course, doesn't apply to family allowance and other benefits.
The coalition's policy statement `Meeting Our Commitments' states:
Full access to family allowance will be maintained for all migrants immediately upon arrival.

BREAK.PARA: I really appreciate members of the government coming in to the House so I can remind them of what their Prime Minister has said, `I make it clear—I'm not going to break any promises.' This is the man who said, `I am desperate to be a very honest man.' This is the man who said, `We want to assert the very simple principle—truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life.'

Truth is never disposable? The Prime Minister has quite obviously been caught throwing his incredibly sacred truth into his incredibly sacred and rapidly overflowing garbage can. If just for a moment we can excuse the Prime Minister, if we can stand here in his supposedly rejuvenated parliament and say that it is okay that he has broken his word to the Australian people, if we can forget all that just for a moment to ask whether any of this is going to do Australia any good, the rather hollow answer is no, it is not.

It should not surprise the House that the Treasurer's numbers on how much the two-year waiting period and its ban on benefits will save the government are incorrect. In his pre‐election costings, the Treasury projected savings of $616 million over three years. Yet, despite widening the range of benefits to be excluded and despite including groups in their plans who were never before subject to the waiting period, such as married partners of long-term Australian residents, the explanatory memorandum circulated by Senator Newman and tabled by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs when he introduced the bill last week shows that these measures will save only $332.5 million over three years, leaving a shortfall of $283.5 million. Again why am I not surprised?

So the government's changes cannot be a cost‐cutting measure, because the figures do not add up. They are, of course, a cleverly disguised number cutting measure. On top of this you will have added costs to the Commonwealth down the line. The government obviously has not considered the hardship and depravation the changes will force upon new migrants, already among the most vulnerable in our society, and how they will create social welfare problems in the future. Quite likely, the money the government saves now will be lost down the line, perhaps to an even greater extent. Migrants, with the rug pulled out from under them by the government, will be forced to rely on the generosity of welfare organisations—organisations which already rely on Commonwealth funding and will perhaps need extra assistance from the government in order to meet extra demand.

We keep running across this constant theme in the government's program of revision and cost cutting—both revealed and rumoured. Very little of what we have seen or what we can expect to see exhibits evidence of having been approached with any level of intellectual rigour, neither by the Prime Minister or his Treasurer nor by those very contented members of the government's razor gang.

The cuts may look good on paper—lots of big red lines running through piles of numbers—but thoughtless cuts such as these not only hurt at the beginning, they continue to hurt long after the slashing has taken place, long after society and governments have moved on. But, of course, what does the Prime Minister care? Saving money in this regard is not really his main objective. I will continue.

How can the government stand amongst the nations of this world and claim to operate a just and non-discriminatory policy on the grounds of race, ethnicity or nationality once these changes are brought in? Under this government there will be widespread discrimination. While an Australian family will not have to wait for benefits and a migrant family from New Zealand will still have to wait only six months, migrants from anywhere else in the world will have to wait two years. While an Australian citizen may marry overseas and have children overseas, when he or she chooses to return to Australia, the children will have to serve out a two-year waiting period before qualifying for benefits.

The legislation, tarted up to look like the actions of an administration interested in reining in expenditure, has revealed a government so intent on cutting migrant numbers that it does not mind breaking the promises it supposedly holds so dear. It does not mind supplying Australians with a fraudulent financial argument to achieve its objectives. It does not mind steeping this nation in shame thanks to a policy on migrants that is riddled with discrimination. I quote again:

Australia is one of the great immigrant nations in modern history. We have a rich heritage of development as a multicultural society. Our multicultural communities from some 200 countries have helped Australia forge a nation that is tolerant, harmonious, freedom loving and culturally rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha! Ha!
—The member for Mitchell can laugh at that, because this is a quote from the Liberal Party's confidential speakers notes published in November last year. I shall continue reading from those notes:

BREAK.PARA: We will maintain a positive and ongoing immigration program. We will continue our strong support for all Australians, whatever their background, and for the building of Australia as a co‐operative and tolerant multicultural society within the framework of an overriding and unifying commitment to Australia.

That is from the Liberal Party speakers notes before the election. Not only is the government failing in its specific promises, both prior to and after the election, some made no more than a week ago in this House, but it is jeopardising the very essence of multiculturalism for which it purports to stand.

It is not enough that the Prime Minister betrays his own promises and those of his cabinet colleagues prior to the election for the sake of reducing migrant numbers, but he intends to make a deceiver out of every single member of the Liberal Party who travelled the highways and byways of their electorates during their campaign using their speakers notes and convincing Australians of their support for a strong migrant policy.

As I began by saying in this speech, Australians rejected the evils of Fightback in 1993. They rejected a coalition which sought to govern through malice and spite. They rejected the society that Fightback would bring and on their behalf, we, the Labor opposition, do the same today.

These changes included in the two-year waiting period will not help us. They will not strengthen us. They will not build us as a nation. They will not help us stand proudly with other nations and, for the benefit of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, nor will they save us any money. The coalition charged Labor before the election of failing to address—(Extension of time granted)

I felt sure that members of the government would have bowed their heads in shame instead of laughing at what was quoted as the Liberal Party policy just prior to the election. They provided those documents to every Liberal candidate in the 147 electorates, but not the National Party candidates. They did not want to upset the National Party. But they gave the documents to all the Liberal candidates to make sure they went out and sold that policy, which has now been proven in the House to have been lies and deceit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Prospect should just take a pill and relax a bit. She has been going on for her time—
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Order! The honourable member for Watson will resume his seat! I will hear the honourable member for Ballarat.

—She has been going on for her allotted time, less the time taken to get a quorum present. Mr Deputy Speaker, I bring to your attention the question of relevance. The member for Prospect has gone well away from the provisions relating to this bill.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I think the abuse of the honourable member for Prospect by the honourable member for Ballarat was disgraceful. In line with the rulings of the Speaker in the chair earlier this evening when he asked one of my colleagues to withdraw, I think you should ask the honourable member for Ballarat to withdraw the remarks he made about the honourable member for Prospect.
—The honourable member for Ballarat might withdraw those comments that he made before when making his point of order.
—Which comments, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—The honourable member knows which comments he is to withdraw.

—I do not. On indulgence, it is a bit rich from the bloke who comes into this House day in and day out and throws abuse from that side of the chamber to bring on this ridiculous point of order like that.
—Order! The honourable member for Ballarat will withdraw.
—In the unlikely event that the member for Prospect took objection to it, I will withdraw.
—No, unreservedly withdraw.
—I have unreservedly withdrawn.

—As I was saying before I was asked to take a certain substance, which I do not require nor ever need—the honourable member should take a Bex and lie down because it may help him—the coalition charged Labor before the election with failing to address the needs of Australia's migrant communities. Yet now it strives to commit the same crimes of which we then stood accused.

BREAK.PARA: I ask the Prime Minister and particularly all the members of the government who are now in the House tonight—and there are very few of them—whether they will keep true to their words. Will they remain true to the spirit of our historically successful immigration policy from which we have all benefited so much? Will they really think again before pressing ahead with the government's excessive changes to its two-year waiting period?

Having heard it from the government's own mouth, both when they were in opposition and when they were campaigning prior to the 1996 election, it is what Australians expect them to do. But, most particularly, the Prime Minister indicated not only prior to the election but also after he was elected that he would make sure it was carried out. He said, `All of our commitments, all of our promises, will be delivered. We are honest. I am an honest Prime Minister. I will make sure that I deliver everything I have said.'

I have repeated just a few of the extracts from Hansard, from press releases and from the information that was supplied to me during the pre-election campaign. The migrants in our communities have been hoodwinked. The migrants out there who have not only arrived but have also applied to have their families or spouses join them have really been hoodwinked. They are the people who are going to suffer and, in the long run, their contribution to Australia, the great nation that it is, will suffer. We will suffer with them, too.

I say to the government that the savings it is purporting to make are not achievable. If the Treasurer can pluck out figures like this prior to an election, God help us when we come to the budget on 20 August! Those figures have been shown to be false. Those figures have also shown that there is no way savings are going to be achieved by extending this mean legislation and making it retrospective.

What is going to be achieved is division within a community. What is going to be achieved is the haves and the have nots. What is going to be achieved is division where people down the road are going to say, `I'm entitled to it but you're not. So there!' What is going to be achieved is half of our community saying, `But we came here. We are contributing to it. Why not? I have worked. I have only been here six months. I have now lost my job. Why aren't I entitled to it?'

We are going to say, `Bad luck, mate. You may have come here. You may have worked for six months. You may have now lost your job because of the IR regulations that are just about to be introduced into this House. You are not going to be entitled to anything because you now have to wait those two years. You have been misled. You really have been lied to.' I am told that is not parliamentary language. I believe, from the statements that I have now made in this House—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. That is the second time that the member for Prospect has used the word `lies'. Previously it was `lies and deceit'. I ask that those words be withdrawn.

—On the point of order, the honourable member for Prospect did not accuse the minister of lying. Of course, the last thing the minister would ever do is lie. She never accused anyone in this House of lying. She said that people had lied. During the election campaign, people did lie. We all know that.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. On this occasion, the way in which the honourable member used the word did not offend, but I am not sure whether she should withdraw the earlier occasion that may have been let through.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I cannot withdraw retrospectively. That is what this legislation is all about.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, you did not make a ruling on that. You said, `I am not sure.' I asked you to make a ruling on `deceit and lies', the two words that she used before.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you have made some remarks. If the minister wants to canvass those remarks, he can do so by dissenting from your ruling. The point that the minister tries to make here is that the member for Prospect should be asked to withdraw something she said some time ago.
—Ten minutes ago.

—Earlier in this debate, the member for Batman asked that a comment be withdrawn which had been made 20 seconds earlier. He was told by Deputy Speaker Reid that the caravan had passed on. Now, if the caravan had passed on after 20 seconds, certainly after 15 minutes it has gone over the horizon. The member for Prospect has nothing to answer for.

—The honourable member for Watson will resume his seat. On the point of order, the minister has drawn my attention to a form of words that was used in the sentence before he rose to his feet. On that matter, I do not find that the honourable member for Prospect has anything to withdraw. Whether the minister wants to pursue words that were from some earlier stage in the speech, I leave in his hands. I remind members that if these matters cause offence, they really do need to raise them as they happen. It is a bit difficult for me to make a ruling on something that has happened quite some time ago. The minister has the call.

—I raised the subject because we gave the speaker a little latitude before on the basis that she had already had a quorum called on her by her own party and needed the extra four minutes. I think if she is allowed to get away with this, then it demeans the standards in the House. This time we accept your ruling, obviously. This time we will not call it but, in future, if those words are used, we will call it every time.

—To assist the minister in the chair, if he feels that the community has not been lied to, I will withdraw those remarks. I will say that the migrant community has been deceived, both before and since the election. Comments have been made publicly in press releases and at meetings in Queanbeyan that the previous shadow minister attended. Those comments have been made ad nauseam to migrant groups throughout all of the communities.

BREAK.PARA: I have one of the largest migrant communities in my electorate. I know what they were saying to me. They were providing me, in detail, with what the then opposition said when they were campaigning. If the minister feels that those people there have not been deceived, he does not know what deceit is. Those people who thought they could now sponsor their spouses, their family reunions—particularly Australians who are expatriates who have now married overseas and are about to bring their children back—now realise that those children are going to have wait two years before they are entitled to anything. If he does not feel that those people have been deceived, I do not know what other word to put on it. I do not think they have been praised. I do not think they have been congratulated. I think they have been deceived up hill and down dale.

These people have been told untruths. They have been hoodwinked as to what the coalition's policies were. When you said it, you did not deliver it. When you came into this House with this legislation, the migrants and the groups who now support them learned what you truly mean. You mean to deceive them continually. You are not now, through this action, going to deceive Australians with this very small bill at this early stage of this parliament; you are not going to deceive the community at large and no-one will trust this government ever again. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: — The honourable member should be very careful with the use of the word `you' and should address her remarks through the chair.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Leo McLeay ) put:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As a new member to this place, I am finding this debate more fascinating than I thought I possibly could. I am fascinated with this debate because the level of deception that has been woven on the Australian community by the policy decision taken by this government in relation to the amendment to this bill is just appalling. I cannot believe that this Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and this government based their whole election campaign on honesty and forward thinking in terms of their presentation to the community. They said to the community, `We disagree with the way the country has been governed to the point where we are going to do something totally different. We are going to set a whole new standard of honesty and openness in government.' What do we see? Total deception.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members have heard much of this before, but it is so important that it is said again and again on the public record so that people really understand what this government is about. On 19 February this year the then shadow minister for immigration, Jim Short, said:
The Coalition's proposal to extend the six months to two years is simply an extended application of the principle established by Labor in 1993.
The coalition's February 1996 policy document Meeting our Commitment clearly states:
Access to welfare benefits for migrants other than refugee and humanitarian migrants will be available after two years under a Coalition Government.
Full access to Family Allowance and Medicare will be maintained for all migrants immediately upon arrival.

As well, the Coalition will provide a "safety net" in the form of a special allowance for those migrants whose circumstances change significantly after their arrival in Australia for reasons beyond their personal control.

Prime Minister Howard—our new, honest Prime Minister—gave a personal pledge when he was visiting St Gregory's Primary School in Queanbeyan not so long ago that the increase in the waiting period would not apply to refugees, it would not apply in humanitarian circumstances and `it, of course, doesn't apply to family allowance and other benefits'. Honestly, one has to really question the meaning of these words, which can be found in any dictionary, to understand why cynicism about this government continues to build in the community. Mr Howard reiterated this with his statement in question time in the House last Wednesday, 22 May. He said:
Can I just make it perfectly clear to the Leader of the Opposition . . . you introduced a six‐month period. All we have done is to extend your six months to two years.

Let us now talk about the deception. In a letter written this month by Mr Howard to his social security minister, Senator Newman—our famous Senator Newman; we must talk about her another time in another debate—Mr Howard approved a proposal by the minister to add a host of welfare benefits and payments to the two-year waiting list. Mr How ard, the Prime Minister, also added his own suggestion that the higher rates of family payment to migrants also be included on the waiting list.

In another letter the Prime Minister directed Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, to bring proposals to cabinet for cutting access by new arrivals to labour market programs and Austudy, thus broadening the reach to non-social security measures. By no definition in anybody's language or understanding can these measures be referred to as social security benefits. This is yet another broken election commitment in a long line of them by this government.

Need I remind the House of the government's commitment not to introduce new taxes or raise existing ones. The three per cent import tax as a result of changes to tariff concessions put paid to that. What about the promise of 7,500 job cuts in the Public Service over three years and no forced redundancies? Is it any wonder that people have stopped believing?

The coalition's proposed higher education cuts are another example of a serious breach of faith, but let us talk about the adequacy of the safety net involved in the legislation we are looking at. One consequence of the coalition's reduced safety net for new migrants will be greater demand for emergency relief from voluntary organisations. These people, these organisations, are partially dependent on our Commonwealth funding, and they will require extra financial assistance to meet those new demands. Has the government even thought about this? Do they even care? Have they considered discussing this with the organisations concerned? No, not at all.

I turn to the extension of the new waiting period to other classes of people. The government proposes to extend the range of new arrivals subject to the waiting period to include groups which have never been subject to the waiting period, such as spouses who have married a long-term Australian resident. They have never been included. How on earth can those opposite sit there and say that this is an honest approach to government when on the one hand they say that all they are doing is extending an existing regime and, on the other hand, they weave this deceit?

The extension of waiting periods to a new range of benefits and support payments is another area of deceit. The present six‐month waiting period applies to the jobsearch allowance, the newstart allowance, the youth training allowance, the parenting allowance and the sickness allowance. The government's legislation imposes a waiting period on a range of benefits. They have been mentioned before, and I am going to mention them again. They include the mature age allowance and the widow allowance. For heaven's sake, in the case of a poor migrant family which arrives here looking forward to a life in our wonderful country and one of the spouses dies, we will have to say to them that we are really sorry but our government believes they have to be on the hardship line for two years.

The carers pension is another terrific example. Let us talk for a moment about the carers pension. Under Labor, no waiting period was applied to the carers pension—none. This legislation means an Australian citizen in need of special care which can be provided by an overseas relative will have to have sufficient means to support both himself or herself and the carer for the first two years. Obviously, we do not care about the human element. Obviously, we do not care that a newly arrived migrant family in this country could have some terrible accident or illness befall them and this government will say to them, `I'm really sorry. You will get care and compassion from us after two years—not before.' I think it is just disgraceful.

The government's legislation also imposes a waiting list on the disability wage supplement, the maternity allowance, for heaven's sake, and the child disability allowance. Again, these are areas of social policy—(Quorum formed)

A moment ago I was outlining to the House some of the disgraceful effects that are going to occur in areas of social policy, areas that have been hard fought for many years and social policies that this side of the House believes should apply to everybody. We do not have a divisive attitude to social policy—quite the reverse. But the people over on the other side of this place tend to have a view that the best way to govern this country may be to divide it. I do not share that view. I am horrified at the thought that they believe they are here with that idea legitimately in their head.

Child disability allowance is another area of social policy where I do not believe anybody should be excluded, should they need it. Thankfully, none of the normal citizens already in this country have to wait two years to qualify for it. Why should new arrivals? Why should a newly arrived family which has an accident befall it, or an illness or disease come across a member of that family, have to do without for two years? It is disgraceful. The mobility allowance, family payment and special benefit have been talked about at length. I will not go on about them. We have to drive home to these people the absolute immorality of their stance on this issue.

The other angle in relation to this legislation that I find quite fascinating is the philosophy underpinning it. The government has admitted that these measures will save $332 million. I believe that the barometer on the saving moves somewhat each day. The pre‐election costings by the current Treasurer, Mr Costello, projected savings of $616 million or so over three years. At the moment, over three years we are looking at savings in the vicinity of $330 million, which leaves a shortfall in excess of $280 million. The coalition has a choice: either you have a hole in your costings or you continue to find ways of filling the hole.

I wring my hands in despair if you do the latter because in doing the latter what you will do is continue to cast your eyes over lists of benefits and lists of people and say, `We're here because we believe we need to control in some fashion a balance sheet. We don't believe we're here in any way whatsoever, in any shape or form, to have any compassionate view of the community. So what we'll do is we'll continue to look for ways to save money. We'll do that and we'll think we're pretty terrific at the end of it, and basically to billyo with the people who might be suffering as a result.'

BREAK.PARA: I repeat my opening words: as a new member in this place, with maybe the naive attitude that honesty is part of the representation in this House—and I stand on a very strong platform of personal honesty—I am appalled that the Prime Minister and his government come in here day after day and declare themselves the new, honest, open government of the country, when all they are doing is predicating every statement they make on the basis of open dishonesty and deceit. I find it an appalling con of the people of this country. Not only do I refer to the effect of this piece of legislation on our migrant population but also I remind members that there are members of our community who are either migrants or Australian born, so they are already citizens, who may not agree with this either. There are people out there who may be appalled to find that their next‐door neighbour, a new arrival, cannot get a carer's pension, cannot get a family allowance, that they have been told in a deceitful manner that they can come here under another aspect. I find it appalling. I think the government should hang its head in shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the government's proposed changes to social security relating to newly arrived migrants. The changes will affect all newly arrived migrants with the exception of those entering Australia as refugees on humanitarian grounds. I believe that these changes represent a massive breach of faith with the electorate. Prior to 2 March, we heard a lot of rhetoric from government members opposite about how they were going to make people feel relaxed and comfortable, about how they would represent multicultural Australia, and about how they intended to represent—
