SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is very important to members on this side of the House—not simply because of its content, not simply because of the people involved in it, but because of what it symbolises in connection with those now in government. If we look back at the election campaign and at the areas and people targeted for cuts, we see a very divisive and very unpleasant aspect. Those now in government picked on three groups of people. One of those groups was migrants.

SPEECH.PARA: But more than that, the projection of costs savings involved was not accidentally costed, as some people think. In fact, many on this side held the view that somehow the government had made a mistake in its costings. There was no mistake; it was deliberate, as were other costings. The costings that were inflated were those which were more likely to bite. The costings that were exaggerated were those which were more likely to fit with anecdotal attitudes.

The idea that people come to Australia to get on the dole—and that is what is being put across—and the fact that this measure will save $616 million have just reinforced all that stereotyping, all those subliminal messages. It was a very nasty strategy, it was a very divisive strategy—but it was not accidental. The costings were not a mistake; they were known to be false.

The irony is that those in the community who agreed with that particular point of view, that this massive number of people come here deliberately to get the dole—and I have heard those opposite say how we are regarded as a bunch of mugs, how stupid we are and how the whole world regards us as being absolutely foolish for allowing this to happen—have not worked out yet that the vast bulk of those on unemployment benefits who are migrants will not be affected by this legislation because they are here on humanitarian and refugee grounds. The fact is that those who find it hardest to get work are those who have come from national disasters—those who have not been to school, those who have been raped or assaulted or had their families brutalised. They are the ones who find it hard to get work.

And what has the government done? Those people are not part of this scheme. So the number of unemployed people from overseas will not be reduced, unless the government reduces the number of humanitarian and refugee classes—which they are also doing in a separate way.

Just last year I took part in a parliamentary inquiry with the now Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), and I recommend to the parliament the report A fair go for all. I should point out, in terms of the Cowan precedent, that the author of the title of that report is the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. He endorsed every word in it. I point out that part of that endorsement was an endorsement of the access and equity strategy of the then Labor government, and it is now endorsed by the current government. One of the points in that report, on page 25, refers to equality of opportunity for participation in personal development, community life and decision making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member for Hotham will do his colleague the courtesy of not passing between his colleague and the chair when he is speaking. Before the member for Newcastle gets started again, I point out to the honourable members for Warringah, Sydney, Stirling and Dobell that they should either resume wearing their jackets or leave the chamber.

—I commend the report entitled A fair go for all to the House. As I pointed out, the title was recommended by the now Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. He endorsed the report and, since there has not been a debate on that report, I would express my appreciation to the secretariat—Bjarne Nordin, Marie Kawaja, Lynette Sebo and Jodie Williams—for their excellent work. I recommend the report to all members. It is an interesting report because it does strongly reinforce the fact that this country has had a policy of access and equity, of fairness and a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing tonight is not a fair go at all. What we are seeing tonight is a creation of two classes of Australians: where a person at work on an income paying taxes will not be entitled to family allowances—will not be entitled to a whole range of services which are not social security but which are support for families—but where a colleague on the same salary, with the same job in the same location, living in the same street will be. For a government that is supposed to be so supportive of families, this legislation creates two kinds of families: those who came from overseas and those who did not. Even with the overseas ones there is more than one group.

BREAK.PARA: I have a case right now of a constituent who has been required to take out American citizenship because their father is now hospitalised as a result of a stroke. That person may have to apply to migrate back to Australia. If they do that, they will have to undergo the two-year qualifying period. I suppose the government would prefer that we put people into a nursing home instead. That will cost twice as much. Forget about the carer's pension, forget about this person coming home and caring for their father, because that is not what you want. The kind of discrimination being involved in this goes against all the rhetoric, all the philosophy and all the idealism that those opposite espoused for years—not just during the campaign but for years before.

I think the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has been caught by his words. I think the words used in the previous parliament—`mean' and `sneaky'—start to have a real meaning to them. It is mean and sneaky and weak. The strength in all of this is not with the Prime Minister but with others. Where is the toughness in the government coming from? Where is the gung-ho ideology? Who is behind all the cuts? I suggest that the word around the corridor in recent times is that it is not the Prime Minister—he is actually quite kind, because we keep hearing him making nice remarks and nice statements. The word coming around the tracks is that the real power behind all of this is not the Prime Minister; it is somebody else or more than one person. Certainly, one should look at the election costings of those opposite. I do at times feel a bit sorry for those government backbenchers who thought the costings were accurate as well. They are suddenly discovering that what they thought they campaigned on is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on these bills, I remind the committee that it has been agreed that a general debate covering the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1996‐97 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1996‐97 be allowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad we have some latitude in discussions on these supply bills because I intend to talk about industry policy, the lack of which is going to make provision of supply in this country increasingly difficult. I do not watch much television, but in my motel room the other night I saw a debate chaired by that intellectual giant Kerry O'Brien. He was interviewing a lot of so‐called leaders of industry. These are the people who, in a sense, have Australia's future in their hands. I was appalled at their apparent inability to grasp what needed to be done. While it did not stop the entire debate and there may have been some speakers there who did realise it, these people seemed to be pushing strongly for the development of the service sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The service sector is code for tourism. Tourism is basically low paid jobs, part‐time jobs and jobs for women and kids. It is not replacement jobs for blue‐collar workers. It is a great industry to have as an ancillary, but as a replacement industry it has potential for disaster. Yet I saw this being put forward—the talk was about the service sector replacing manufacturing.

It is my view that governments have an absolute responsibility to achieve full employment. It is part of the contract that people have with government. That does not mean that governments supply the jobs. Indeed, I do not think governments are good at it and the world is littered with examples of where governments have failed at doing this. But government has an absolute responsibility to create in the community the pre‐conditions which will make industry thrive. I respectfully suggest that, in recent times, all governments have failed in this regard in Australia.

We chant mantras: the problem is industrial relations; the problem is tariffs; the problem is one thing or another. These mindless mantras are chanted by people who have not got a clue what the real problem is. It is my contention that all decisions, whether they are personal decisions made in the household, or decisions made by governments, are made on the basis of two things: hope of gain or fear of loss.

It is very fashionable to blame 40 years of tariff protection for our failure to develop competitive industries. While there have certainly been some bad results from that—brought about largely by cooperation between unions and the metal trades manufacturers—this opinion simply ignores the lessons of history.

I think the Japanese situation is a useful example. The Japanese still have very stringent trade barriers. But the Japanese use their trade barriers to build up their industries. It should be remembered that in 1959, Australia produced more motor vehicles, and much better motor vehicles, than did the Japanese. In 1990‐91, Australia produced 368,000 vehicles, while Japan made 13½ million vehicles. This demonstrates what has happened here. The Japanese used their protection to build up their industry. They acted out of hope of gain.

In 1946, when the Chifley government was contemplating the establishment of the car industry in Australia, it was advised by Mr Hartnett, who, in my view, is one of the great Australians. Mr Hartnett was then the general manager of General Motors in Australia and his advice to the government was that if it was contemplating a car industry then it was essential that it had its own car—it should not build someone else's car. The government did not do that, however; it took the easy road and invited General Motors in. By doing this, of course, it could not fail, but neither could it ever succeed.

Had we gone our own way and built a car for Australia's unique conditions, we would have built one suitable for long distances. It probably would have had a six‐cylinder motor and higher ground clearance. It would have had a large radiator, it would have been one of the first in the field with airconditioning and it would have had good suspension. For the conditions that prevailed then and still prevail in Australia and throughout large parts of the world—across the South American and Indian subcontinents, Africa and many other places—such a car would have been the ideal. We could have had the Volvo of the Southern Hemisphere, entirely Australian made and Australian owned. Instead, we did not. We built a second‐rate American design. Although we improved it as time went on, we could never sell it anywhere that the Americans did not want us to, because we did not own it. That was an enormous opportunity lost for Australia, because we as a nation acted out of fear of loss.

I believe that, if we are going to have a viable industry, we as a nation must have the confidence and unity to act in hope of gain; which brings me to industrial relations, which is very much on the agenda at the moment. The truth about industrial relations is that while ever there is high unemployment, there will inevitably be a lot of downward pressure on conditions of employment. While unions may be able to make some barricade defences in some industries for some time, inevitably that pressure will be the consequence. I say that the only future for Australia is as a high wage, high productivity country. We must have high wages and high productivity to service them, and that means we must be involved in industries in the manufacturing sector, which requires a high degree of intelligence.

Let us look at what is happening in Australia. Plagiarising has become quite popular in the parliament, but I am looking at a paper written in 1992 by—oh, it was written by my good self! I am sure I will be excused for the plagiarism. We ought to look at the mining industry because mining is extremely important to Australia. It is by far our biggest export earner and has the potential to increase those earnings considerably. In the Western Australian economy in the year 1990‐91, the value of mineral production, mostly exported, rose 15 per cent on the 1989‐90 figures. It rose to $12.7 billion while employment in the sector fell marginally and there was a reduction in just about every commodity price. In fact, I cannot think of one commodity for which there was not a reduction in price in that year.

BREAK.PARA: Productivity increased a lot more than 15 per cent, but we had a reduced labour force and that is going to continue. The reason that we are the most efficient miners in the world is that we apply all the technology. We are frontrunners in this area and we are going to continue replacing jobs with technology. Yet mining is very important in many areas because it is the only industry that can operate there. In many outback areas, it is the only hope for the provision of employment for Aboriginal people. It is an absolute travesty that we see native title in Western Australia now holding up so many mining developments.

This fact is being hidden. It was hidden by the last government and it has been hidden by this government. The present Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), as the last minister did, will say to you, `Nonsense! Gold production is in fact rising in that part of Australia.' This is the part of Australia which produces 75 per cent of Australia's gold and, yes, that statement is true; but production is rising because the exploration has so far been on brownfield sites, on extensions to existing mines where native title is not a consideration and not a problem. The problem is that those mines are all going to run out at about the same time. You will see in Australia, in about four years time, a whole swag of these mines going out of production at the same time. It takes four or five years to get a mine into production, and every week and every day of delay puts at risk this very important earner for Australian exports.

It grieves me that many of the people who lead this charge and put these pressures on industry are on all sorts of government funded wages in the cities and their welfare is being underwritten by the mining industry.

While the mining industry is very important as an export earner, it could be even more important if it were a basis for a manufacturing sector. Here we are, with the best miners in the world. You have to ask: what do you need to start a new industry in this country? You need basically three things. You need a large customer. Yes, in the mining industry we have customers who are large by world standards. You need a state-of-the‐art customer. Yes, certainly in hard rock mining we are the best in the world and we are very good at open pit mining. We have those two. The third thing is government will—not necessarily government funds but government will—and I think that is sadly lacking in Australia. We therefore do not manufacture the equipment for our mining industry.

Dr Hobbs from the CSIRO said that every year we import into Australia something around $1.5 billion worth of mining equipment that we could make better or cheaper in Australia. It must be remembered that with respect to the mining industry `better' is the same as `cheaper'. Those figures are a little rubbery. If you reduce them to $1.2 billion it is still a basis for a substantial industry that could create a lot of employment. The employment would inevitably be in places along the eastern seaboard and Victoria.

We could use that industry to generate a very large number of jobs in our cities and also export potential. A lot of the Third World mines that are opening up are doing so with the very best equipment; they do not spare themselves on capital at all. The fact that some is provided by the World Bank is beside the point. If Australian equipment were the best they would buy it. We could have a very good industry here based on the needs of our own world-class mining industry. But you see very little evidence of this happening and one has to ask why. I believe there is no understanding and no will from governments, either past or present, to achieve this.

There are other areas we have to look at. Our wool industry is in crisis. It is in crisis because returns to the growers are simply not enough. It is hard to know what can be done about this. I would suggest that what we are doing is entirely counterproductive. I noticed that we voted in the parliament the other day to give Wool International Holdings $24 million to find new selling initiatives for wool. This was a nonsense because all the selling initiatives are there. Wool Holdings International will not come up with anything new at all. What they are likely to do, however, is to use other people's money to distort the market, which is the last thing the wool industry needs.

I believe there is hope for the Australian wool industry by going further down the processing chain. Throughout the world where commodity prices have had downward pressure on them, the people who have been successful have gone down the processing chain to recoup for the growers more of the value of their product. It would be nice to say that we could set up spinning mills to spin wool in Australia. However, I suspect that doing that, while it would potentially create jobs in country towns or in cities in Australia, would not necessarily return more money to the grower.

In India, a country with enormous capacity in the wool area, and which has technology which is generally better than that in China, wages are 25c an hour. It is probably a good thing for us to exploit that situation so that our growers can retain ownership of their wool further down the process. My calculations show that probably $1.50 per kilo could be returned to growers. If a percentage were taken off for someone managing this, someone in the private sector, someone with potential such as Elders, it would probably be something in the line of $1.20. The $1.20 increase in the price of wool would be very acceptable, and that would do a lot to give stability to country areas.

If nothing is done, the great wool industry that was for so many years the backbone of Australia will become a peasant industry of little consequence. If people do not believe this can happen, they should look at what has happened to the United Kingdom where governments went down the Thatcher road of importing rather than manufacturing. The industries that Britain was a world leader in simply do not exist there any more, and it is quite possible that the great Australian wool industry could disappear as an industry of any consequence in Australia unless we take dramatic action now.

One of the things which should be done in this regard is the banning of the export of our intellectual technology. We have spent 150 years developing merino wool to the fine fibre it is today, and we have certain advantages over other countries. In fact, there is very little in Australia that is unique, but Australian merino wool is one of those things. Yet the industry and the government continue to endorse the generic promotion of wool when they should be promoting Australian wool—in fact, regional Australian wool.

Our genetic material is being given away overseas with reckless abandon. In a former life, as a member of the Labor Party, I got through the caucus a resolution to ban the export of genetic material. I went to New Zealand and spoke to breeders in New Zealand about this problem and had their wholehearted support. They were very keen to ban exports from Australia and New Zealand. I spoke to the single biggest exporter there, who said he would stop tomorrow, and that the only reason he did it was because, if he did not, somebody else would, either in Australia or New Zealand.

I think I had all the arguments. I won the battle in the caucus, and then Senator Bob Collins, who never understood the wool industry, simply bowled into caucus and my colleagues supported him without any argument whatsoever. He gave no argument as to why we should not be doing this and, indeed, there are no valid arguments. I hope that the present government will have more commonsense and more backbone. When I look at the reactions of the present government to such things as gun control and its ideology in industrial relations and Telecom, I see little hope that we are going to fare much better under this government either.

The subjects of industrial relations and industry policy are interrelated. If the country has a vision, if it is a competent country confident that there will be jobs in the future, the industrial relations climate will be much better than if people are in fear of the future, in fear of finding jobs for their children. I believe it is simply shifting the deckchairs on the Titanic to talk about industrial relations in isolation. We have to base it on the development of the manufacturing industry in Australia, and it is only the manufacturing industry in Australia that can hope to provide the jobs.

In my town, the city of Kalgoorlie, people have told me that they cannot get a boilermaker for love nor money. Every boilermaker will increase the productivity of this country. He will increase the job opportunities for other people. But the boilermakers are not there. I was in the caucus when a decision was taken that the future was in service industries, and manufacturing was going to be a thing of the past. That was a nonsense concept, but it is one of those concepts that seem to be a worldwide fetish at the moment—certainly a fetish that has hindered Western countries.

If I had more time I would delve into the class war started by the United States on its people in 1974, a war which has destroyed many jobs across the United States and which has caused class divisions. I believe those divisions will inevitably lead to the destruction of the United States as a stable, united country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the supply bills and, by implication, supply would seem to indicate that there would be a flow of funds to Commonwealth government departments to enable them to operate. It would also, by implication, mean that that would flow across into regional Australia so that departments of the Commonwealth government would be in a position to deliver services. As was pointed out very clearly in an editorial in the Illawarra Mercury on 23 May:

SPEECH.PARA: Government is supposed to be for the people, by the people—or so the theory goes. But sometimes, you have to wonder.
In respect of Wollongong, and the Illawarra more generally, you well and truly do have to wonder about some of the decisions that have been taken very recently by the present government.

I would like to take this opportunity today to point out to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), his ministers and, indeed, his government the effect that some of the decisions already announced for Wollongong and the Illawarra will have. I would urge upon him and his ministers a sense of caution and a sense of reflection about some of the decisions which they have taken, and ask for a review. I would also like to ask him, in the context of deliberations in the coming weeks of the Expenditure Review Committee, to seriously think about what some of these decisions that have been floated in the media might mean for areas like Wollongong and the Illawarra.

Firstly, let me take the question of the immigration department's decision to close its regional office. One would have thought that if there were a part of Australia where a regional office of the immigration department needed to be located it would be the city of Wollongong, to service the Illawarra. After all, we only have 82 different ethnic nationalities represented in our city and, on a weekly basis, we only have 200 clients seen by officers in the department's regional office. We only have approximately 45 a day coming in to seek advice about immigration matters. And that does not count, of course, the countless numbers that come through the offices of local members of parliament—such as myself, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and others—seeking advice on immigration matters before we, in turn, refer them to the department.

So what do we see? We see the decision taken to shut down this service, notionally to save $10 million but to create enormous angst in the very multicultural community that is Wollongong and to say to these people, `For the future, go to Sydney—go to Rockdale.' It is saying to these people, `Spend time and effort racing around getting the necessary papers and talking to people'—often these are people who need some form of assistance in terms of language—`but don't go to a local office, don't go to where the people actually are. You have got to move on.' And the cost of that is also going to be six full‐time staff.

What an absolute joke! If it wasn't so serious you would have a bit of a laugh about this because, as I say, our area is one with such an enormous number of people from non‐English speaking backgrounds and from multicultural Australia. If you want a definition of multiculturalism, come to Wollongong. Yet here we have a decision, taken because of bottom line economics, to shut down an office.

I have to say that some years ago this was a matter which the former government actually visited. The former government, for its own reasons of cost cutting, thought it was a great idea when all the economic rationalists and the economic ministers in the ERC said, `We will cut some of these offices out.' At that stage, though, through community outrage and, I might say, the combined efforts of the local members, that decision was overturned. I would like to think that we are going to be able to do that again. The only trouble is that two of us who represent Wollongong properly do not come from the Prime Minister's party which is now the government. One therefore wonders whether they are going to take much notice of people such as the member for Throsby and myself in our pleas to look after the people who really need to have an immigration office locally based to service the needs of this community. But we will try.

What we are going to do is go and talk to the member for Hughes (Ms Vale)—that is, if she knows about anything other than the questions of airports that get raised. She might get told silently about this somewhere. We will also go and talk to the honourable member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash). This particular office gives service in their areas as well. We will try and elicit their support to go to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock)—and, indeed, to the Prime Minister—and say that this is a nonsense.
It was summed up nicely in the `Opinion' column in the Illawarra Mercury of 23 May:
Take, for example, the extraordinary decision by the Federal Government to close its Immigration Department office in Wollongong.
Now it is no secret that the Illawarra is one of the most multi‐cultural regions in Australia, absorbing migrants in wave after wave in the half century since World War II.

You'd think that Wollongong would be one of the most logical sites for an Immigration Department office in the entire country. But no, the department has announced its Wollongong office is one of six to be axed before the end of the year.
A little further on in that same editorial it was said:

BREAK.PARA: The Howard Government is showing little feeling for migrant issues, which should come as no surprise to those who have followed the Prime Minister's pronouncements on immigration over the years.
Well said, Illawarra Mercury !

Mr Deputy Speaker, it does not just stop there, regrettably. There are the pending cuts to higher education, which will have an effect on the University of Wollongong. It is no secret that, ever since I have been in this place, I have been a great champion of, and advocate for, the University of Wollongong. I will put my hand up and say, `Sure, I have an interest in it,' because, firstly, I used to teach at it and, secondly, I am a student at it these days. But, putting that to one side and having declared that interest, I cannot believe the short‐sightedness of the minister, Senator Vanstone, in advocating cuts of 10 to 12 per cent in funding for universities such as the one located in Wollongong.

It means not only that there is a substantial cut in the direct funding to those universities, but that the multiplier effect down the track is absolutely enormous. For example, on recent calculations, the University of Wollongong is the third major employer in the Illawarra region. It is also a major contributor to the local economy. The Vice‐Chancellor, Professor Gerard Sutton, has estimated that the impact on the Illawarra of lost revenue and expenditure will be something like $50 million per year if this 10 to 12 per cent cut to higher education funding that has been foreshadowed by Senator Vanstone takes effect in respect of the University of Wollongong.

Do Senator Vanstone and the Prime Minister genuinely understand what the pursuit of bottom‐line economics means for regions like our own? Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that a number of people from your party have raised this issue very seriously within your party room—at least if you can believe the media today. I understand that regional universities right around Australia will be lobbying National Party and Liberal Party members long and hard about these decisions.

The University of Wollongong is in the top tier of universities. It is the undisputed pre‐eminent regional university in Australia, according to all the assessments that have been done on quality. It is also in the top four or five universities in this country. It has got world leaders when it comes to research. Importantly, they do not simply sit in ivory towers doing research; they get into the community and they marry it with what happens out there in terms of research, development and manufacturing. They actually create additional jobs and contribute greatly to the economy of the Illawarra.

In a region like ours—which, regrettably, still has unemployment at unacceptably high levels and still above the national average, although it is much better than when we came into government in 1983 and put in place a series of industry plans such as the steel industry plan—these sorts of cuts in the local economy are intolerable. People have to understand that, in the engine room of Australia, in the economic heartland of Australia, where you have a major industry such as education, as exemplified by the University of Wollongong, cuts like this are profound. They have implications that go well beyond simply looking at a bottom‐line figure and saying that we are going to have a 10 or 12 per cent cut in the funding for higher education.

My colleague the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) would know from her own experiences in the University of Adelaide, which is in her state, the effect that that would have. The impact of those sorts of cuts on Adelaide—being a capital city, but in a state with a reasonably small population compared to the rest of Australia—would probably be even more dramatic. I simply appeal to her, in her capacity as a member of the government, to look very seriously at these matters.

I have not mentioned the other issues advocated in the media as apparently being leaks from the government: that is, increases in HECS fees for students and perhaps cuts in higher education and research grants. To sum up my concerns regarding the University of Wollongong, we are not asking for much. All we are asking is for the Prime Minister to keep his promise which he made before the election and which is contained in the Liberal Party's manifesto on higher education that funding for higher education would be maintained at the levels established by the former government. That is there in black and white for everyone to see. We will be reminding the Prime Minister of that commitment between now and when the budget is handed down. If he does not deliver on that promise, we will make sure that every university student at the University of Wollongong and all students right around Australia are made aware of that.

The Australian Customs Service is another area that is being slashed by this government. I would have thought over the last few months following the tragedy that occurred in Port Arthur that concerns about the importation of illegal weapons—not to mention drugs and other illicit cargo—and illegal immigrants coming through ports like Port Kembla might be at the forefront of the minds of government members, but it seems not. In question time yesterday I directed a question to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) concerning Port Kembla, and the minister gave me an answer about Dampier, in Western Australia. I pointed out to him that staff at the Port Kembla customs office, which looks after not just Port Kembla but all the way down to the Victorian border, including the port of Eden, are going to be cut from 15 to 5—15 to 5!

The intelligence work which the minister believes is the panacea to any concerns expressed about the Australian Customs Service is going to be conducted from Sydney with flying squads. We all know what risk assessment is about. The only trouble is that the flying squad is also going to be cut by 10. On top of that, in Port Kembla Customs Service officers have been told to work nine to five, five days a week. There is to be no weekend work, no shift work and no overtime. In question time yesterday I asked the minister whether he honestly believes that criminal activity occurs only between the hours of nine to five Monday to Friday and that nothing happens on a weekend. Obviously the government does believe that. What an absolute joke! The way in which the Australian Customs Service is being treated by this government is scandalous. This short‐sighted decision will have a drastic effect on areas such as Port Kembla and Eden and on revenue collection, which goes with schemes like the diesel fuel rebate scheme and others.

I now turn to DEETYA. I received a copy of a letter addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) from the New South Wales adult migrant education service in the Wollongong region. This letter points out what I think is absolutely scandalous and outrageous about this government. This government has refused to fund 17 classes that were planned to start on 13 May for English either for work or for literacy‐numeracy skills. Some 278 students are waiting for those classes to start. Of those students, 211 are from non‐English speaking backgrounds, and 51 are from the former Yugoslav republic and are mainly refugees. What a caring, compassionate government! This is the same government whose leader said before the election, `No‐one will be worse off. We really do care for refugees and people from non‐English speaking backgrounds.' Yet it has cut the funding of these classes.

At the end of June, an additional 57 students who are registered with the CES will complete the 510 hours of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs funded classes. They have an expectation that additional class work will be made available to them through DEETYA to provide them with a leg up so that they can compete equally in the Illawarra work force with people from English speaking backgrounds. But will that happen? No, it will not. This uncaring, insensitive government has frozen funds and refuses to fund these sorts of classes.

It is not only the adult migrant English service in Wollongong that is being affected by DEETYA cuts; there are going to be skillshare closures—we have heard announcements about that today. The department in Wollongong has been told not to spend any more money on any further projects. In fact, it has been told to look at ways it can rationalise its service. In my colleague's electorate of Throsby, unemployment is still 15 to 18 per cent in pockets, and youth unemployment is probably about 20 per cent. In my own area where it is about 10 per cent and youth unemployment is about the same, the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is talking about closing CES offices.

Why? Because it has said that it is going to give that to the private sector, that they are the best ones to find people jobs, and that the Commonwealth cannot do it. Not only will we see the closure of CES offices in areas such as Dapto, which is operating on a month to month lease at the present time, but some of the regional and area offices of DEETYA are going to be amalgamated because they believe that they can slash the numbers. We are going to see at least 50 staff in DEETYA given the old heave‐ho in the Illawarra region, all under the guise of economic rationalism.

It is unacceptable to the people of the Illawarra that we should be treated in this way. It is unacceptable that this area, which is the economic engine room of the Australian economy, should suffer the sorts of cuts that I have outlined: the immigration office closure, potential cuts to the University of Wollongong's funding, the gutting of the Australian Customs Service, the cutting of the adult migrant English service in DEETYA, and the reorganising of DEETYA's structure down there. It is unacceptable.

We are trying to stimulate economic development in our region with some new, expansive and enhanced programs. I feel it is rather sad that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) chose not to contribute towards funding a major form of infrastructure, which would have had enormous impact on tourism and, indeed, on sport. I know the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) is well aware of the Illawarra indoor entertainment sports centre. His government, when he was the Premier of New South Wales, generously promised $14 million towards that centre. Mr Carr, his successor, has honoured that commitment. We have asked for a $4 million contribution from regional development funds because of the tourism and employment generation impact it would have, particularly for young people. What was the minister's response? `Sorry, no way. That doesn't stack up against regional infrastructure program initiative guidelines.' Garbage, garbage.

I am chairman of the Illawarra regional economic development organisation. I helped write the guidelines; I know what the guidelines are all about. I used to be a town planner; I know a little bit about the subject area—and the minister turns around and tells me that it does not meet the guidelines. The guidelines were fine before the election. The department officers came down and had a look at all of these things. They said, `$2 million over two years out of regional development funds to stimulate the local economy, no problem at all.' After the election, the advice suddenly changes and it no longer meets the guidelines.

I appeal to the minister on this matter. He is regarded as an Illawarra member because of the location of his constituency; he was a friend to the Illawarra in his former life. He and I have worked very closely on many other projects. I appeal to him in respect of this matter. Will he have a chat with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development? Will he see what he can do for us because this will affect his electorate, it will draw people from the Southern Highlands down to Wollongong. It is something which is desperately needed.

I conclude by saying, once again: caring John Howard, the Prime Minister, has slam dunked the Illawarra by the withdrawal of these facilities and services in the Illawarra. We will not stand for it, we will protest long and loud. We have done it before and I am sure we will have to do it again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the numerous contributions that have been made by all members in respect of the bill before the House. There has been a long list of speakers and many of them have touched upon matters concerning their electorates. An example of that was the previous speaker. Many of them have expressed their views on the current state of the economy and a number of opposition members have levelled criticism at the government in the course of the debate over the past several days. I do not accept that criticism. It is a little difficult to understand how members of the opposition can criticise the management of the economy by this government in the very few months that we have had to look at the state of the accounts. It is necessary to address the state of the accounts and that has been the manner in which the government has brought this forward and the manner in which it will approach the budget to be delivered in August.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been an opportunity to address the economy in a wide ranging debate. There have been some useful suggestions, from my following of the debate, from both sides of the House. I thank all the honourable members who have spoken for the contributions they have made and for the spirit in which they have put forward their own points of view. I commend the bill to the House.
