SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this bill. It essentially is a machinery piece of legislation to assist the implementation of provisions in the new Customs Tariff Act 1995 from 1 July this year.

SPEECH.PARA: That act was passed last year with the support of both sides of the House. It had the effect then of implementing over 500 tariff classification changes, including changes pursuant to the Harmonised Commodity Description and Coding System of the World Customs Organisation to which we are a signatory. That 1995 act gave effect to Australia's obligations to align our tariff structure with the international standard.

This bill which is before the House effects technical amendments to several pieces of legislation as well as to other instruments and they are consequential amendments on the passing of the 1995 act. For example, the bill updates references in Commonwealth legislation to the 1987 Customs Act so that it is changed to refer to the 1995 act. The bill preserves the operation of most of the by‐laws and determinations and concession instruments made under the 1987 act and without such provisions those instruments would lapse on 1 July of this year.

The bill also establishes a mechanism for continuing the operation of instruments made under the 1987 act where tariff headings have not been translated across from the 1987 to the 1995 act. The bill also contains transitional provisions for applications for concession instruments lodged before, but not dealt with, by 1 July 1996.

For all of those things that the bill does we commend the government for enacting these machinery provisions because they clearly will ensure the effective operation of an act which we introduced in government last year. However, I do want to take the opportunity in this debate to indicate that what the opposition does not support is the manner in which the government intends to cut the budget of the body which administers this legislation and that is the Australian Customs Service.

We have been seeking in question time to ask the minister many times over the last few weeks about the staff and budget cuts to the Customs Service and the impact, in particular, that those cuts are going to have on the asserted claim to a crackdown that this government says it has the intention of making on illegal drugs, on prohibited firearms and on pornographic material. Sadly, we are still waiting for the answers despite many questions to the relevant minister.

We know, for example, from an internal minute from the Australian Customs Service—a minute, I might say, that the government would not let us table in the parliament—as well as from other sources, the extent of those cuts. We know that there is to be $31 million cut from the overall budget of the Australian Customs Service and that this is going to result in some 400 jobs being lost, particularly in regional locations. Effectively, they will be gone from the department. That is a 36 per cent reduction in overall staff levels.

We know, for example, that the Tasmanian investigation unit is to be closed and we know that the effect will be to reduce the customs presence in important outposts of the Australian Customs Service. For example, at Port Kembla the staff is to be reduced from 12 to seven, shift work is to be abolished and there is to be no weekend customs surveillance.

When we asked the question as to why those cuts are necessary, against the background of the government's commitment to crack down on the prohibited imports—the firearms, the pornographic material and the narcotics—we were initially told by the minister that the reason for these cuts was the so-called deficit that had been inherited by the incoming government in relation to the previous government's activities. Yet when one reads this minute one sees that the cuts have got nothing to do at all with anything that the government claims to have found on coming to office. They are all entirely due to promises made by the then opposition when it was seeking office to effect savings in their document, `Meeting the commitments', or whatever the precise title of it is.

I want to refute the notion that the so‐called $8 billion black hole is the reason for the cuts. The minute that I referred to before says that the meeting, convened to discuss the way in which the cuts would be effected, was undertaken against the background of the government's foreshadowed across‐the‐board two per cent efficiency dividend. This was additional to the pre‐existing one per cent dividend already included in departmental forward estimates, further expected reductions in information technology and consultancy resources, and further running cost savings of $50 million over three years identified specifically for Customs. All those reasons and parameters within which the cuts are now being effected were commitments that the then opposition made in the lead‐up to the election.

At the time, the government said that there should be cuts in running costs across all departments of two per cent and that it would hold up certain programs on the implementation of information technology procedures. This information was put in a document to the electorate before the government attained office to indicate the way in which it would pay, in part, for promises that it made. We know that what it was asserting to pay for was not able to be justified appropriately in any of the material it put forward. The government professes to be open and honest. We are still trying to get it to open the books so we can see the accounts; we still cannot get the material that Finance gave the government in regard to its other promises.

I underscore the point that the reason for these cuts has got nothing to do at all with the $8 billion so-called black hole; it has got everything to do with promises made by the then opposition in the lead-up to the election. The effect of these cuts is a significant closure of Customs offices. From advice that has come into our hands, we know that there is going to be a significant closure and/or reduction of district Customs offices. The customs offices proposed for closure are in Fyshwick—which is now to be done from Canberra—Griffith, Geelong, Mildura, Albury, Port Walcott, Whyalla, Wallaroo and Berri. To indicate the extent of the staff reduction in those places, in New South Wales alone the staffing level will come down by almost half and in Victoria there will be a staff reduction of 25 per cent. These are cuts which the government has made as a result of commitments that it entered into prior to the last election.

BREAK.PARA: Another point that is worth while making is that when the minister was seeking to justify the basis for the cuts, he said that the service would now be able to rely on more efficient targeting and it could rely more effectively on the introduction of information technology. Because of recent progress in information technology, the Customs Service would be able to cope with the cuts. But the reality is that, in the same election commitments, we have a government committed to substantially cutting the progress of the implementation of information technology. One of the big savings that the government announced prior to the last election was the holding back of progress in the implementation programs of information technology.

The departmental minute that I referred to talked about further expected reductions in information technology. We have exposed the fact that the $8 billion black hole is not the justification for these cuts. Information technology should be able to ensure a crackdown on crime, illicit firearms and drugs, but the departmental minute reveals that the Customs Service is under pressure to reduce the information technology program. Try as we might in question time in the Parliament, we have been unable to get the minister to come clean and tell us how the Customs Service is supposed to operate. He refuses to accept the obvious: that the cuts to the Customs Service will drastically reduce its capacity to perform functions, especially in relation to the illegal importation of drugs, firearms and pornographic material.

It is interesting that when the current minister was the shadow minister responsible for Customs, he actually penned a letter to—if you like—the shadow Expenditure Review Committee. After the analysis of the effectiveness of the Customs Service was done, he had this to say:
While there are infrequent complaints about Customs inspection and clearance procedures, overall they—
that is the Customs Service—
run a smooth and efficient operation. Any budgetary cuts to this area would slow down the clearance of goods, holding up businesses and result in a lesser frequency of inspections.
And this is the important point. This is Mr Prosser in a letter to the shadow finance minister of the day, continuing:
. . . I do not believe that there is room for cuts within these areas. Any decline in the intelligence activities will impact on Customs' law enforcement activities and, in particular, their success.

It is true that that was a letter written some five years ago in 1991, but when the then opposition had to look for savings in the context of putting together Fightback—and this was in the context of the Fightback exercise, a much harsher regime, one could argue, in which they were trying to find savings—this was the conclusion that the then shadow minister, now current minister, came to. He did not believe that there was any room for cuts. Those are his own words.

So we have got to ask the question: what has changed since then? Why should there be a retreat from that position? The then shadow minister had responsibility for going around the country looking at the way the Customs Service operated, and at the conditions under which it was expected to function. He had analysed the situation and had come to the conclusion that Customs was a smooth and efficient operation. He came to the conclusion that any budgetary cuts would slow down the clearance of goods, hold up businesses, and result in lesser frequency of inspections.

Now he is going to put in place the very things that he argued against some years ago and which will slow up the business processes. For a government that claims to be committed to assisting small businesses and cutting the red tape, this is going to slow up their proceedings, and it will result in lesser frequency of inspections. It will do all the things that he argued most strongly against. He said that he did not believe that there was room for any cuts in these areas and yet, within two months of being sworn in as a minister, he is presiding over these same savage cuts to a department that he now administers.

Little wonder that the Australian public is now starting to see what we tried to expose during the election campaign: the duplicity of this government in office. They would say anything in opposition to try to ensure that different groups in the community who potentially could be threatened were satisfied and were put at ease. As soon as they get into office they scrap all of those commitments and move on to gutting the organisation and its effectiveness.

We know from the information that we have already that this is starting to have a major impact. The other day in Mayfield in the Hunter area, a sports supply business received two packages of hand guns from Europe containing a total of 26 revolvers and automatics. They passed through Customs and police without any examination because when the boxes arrived they still had lead seals placed on them by the manufacturer. The seals were still intact and there had been no police permits issued. The two boxes of firearms were delivered to the sports supplier on 22 May and the guns are believed to have been picked up by Customs at a later date. In circumstances involving an authorised gun dealer there is the capacity to track these things down at a subsequent stage. But we have been talking about the issues of gun control and the ease of access to illegal weapons. Here we have a situation on 22 May where a package of this sort of material can get through Customs and end up at the supplier before it is tracked down. I think this highlights the fact that, with the reduction of services and the cutting back of facilities with the ability to scrutinise, this sort of activity could clearly occur all around the country.

It is not only guns. I used this example because it has been brought to my attention and because we are giving bipartisan support on the problem of guns. I do not want to use it to inflame the situation in any sense but I do want to underscore the fact that there is no point in passing these pieces of legislation to bring about a more effective system, if you are going to gut the very organisation which is expected to operate the system.

As the minister is here, another point I would highlight is that we have tried to get from him the logic for these cuts. We have asked many questions of him in the parliament and we still have not got a satisfactory explanation. I hope the opportunity presents itself for him to actually explain the logic to us. There is no point pretending that you are serious about the crackdown on illicit imports when you are not prepared to provide the facilities by which that can be undertaken; when you run counter to all of your own advice in opposition about what should be cut out of the service and what should not be; when you advise by way of internal information to the department that there is no room for cuts in these areas and then you proceed in office to implement those very cuts.

I will give an indication of how the minister stumbles on these things. Yesterday he was asked a question about how in the light of all of the cuts to the regional areas that I talked about before and the areas of Mildura, Albury, Port Walcott, Fyshwick, Whyalla, Wallaroo, Berri, Geelong and Griffith—the cuts and closures to those offices—he proceeded to give an answer that started to explain that it was not Alsatian dogs that were under threat, they were in fact Labradors.

That highlights the sort of non‐answer that we continue to get from this minister. He knows that what he has got himself into here is a commitment to introduce cuts that he does not believe in. He is on the record himself saying that he does not believe there is any room for cuts in these areas. That is what you said when you were asked in opposition, as a shadow minister, to assess the opportunity for cuts in this area and report where the savings could be made. Your response at the time then was, `I don't believe there is room for any cuts.' In fact, you went further and said, `Any decline in the intelligence activities will impact on customs law enforcement activities and in particular their success.' We agree wholeheartedly, and that is why we have been trying to get you to come clean and explain what has now changed.

What is it that now can still result in 440 cuts which you said previously could not be justified, and which will not impact on enforcement activities? We know these cuts will impact on enforcement activities. There is no point trying to hide behind the $8 billion black hole—these cuts are everything to do with your election promises. There is no point trying to pretend that this is just a crackdown on Canberra bureaucrats, because these are cuts that are going to affect the regional offices. Don't you think that the people who are the crooks, the people who are going to try to ensure they don't get detected, are going to jump with joy when they know we are closing the regional offices—the points which they know they can come into because you are closing them down?
It is not just loss of jobs in the regions, it is diminishing our very capacity to cover the whole of this nation's huge border.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Sorry to interrupt the flow, but could I just ask you not to use the word `you' unless you are referring to the Speaker.

—I am sorry, Madam Deputy Speaker. It is hard not to get engaged in the across‐table dialogue. At every point where I have referred to `you', I was referring to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), because he is the culprit. The minister has changed his tune. The minister when in opposition didn't believe that cuts were justified and now he has been directed to implement them and he does not know how to defend those cuts. He has been given a line by Peter Costello that says to just blame the $8 billion black hole, but his own Customs Service completely rejects that as the basis upon which the cuts are being effected. It says that the cuts are due entirely to the coalition's election promises of the two per cent cuts, the hold‐back in information technology and the need to reduce running costs in this department. The minister still has a lot of answering to do but, as we have found out, he doesn't know how to answer the questions in the parliament. I hope this debate gives him some opportunity to do so when he gets up on his feet.

BREAK.PARA: From our point of view, we are not opposing the bill itself but we are expressing very serious concern about what is happening to the very fine Customs Service which we have established in this country and which has served this country well. We share, on both sides of the House, the need to ensure that at our borders we can hold back the illicit imports; that we can stop the illegal firearms; that we can stop the narcotics coming in that affect many in the population, particularly the young people; and that we can stop the pornographic material and the way in which that is able to be used in the community. We agree on those things, but you cannot do it unless you have an effective customs service and you cannot have an effective customs service if you cut 440 places from it.

The reality is this: because the government knows that the cuts cannot be at the point that is going to impact upon people it cannot implement many of these cuts so far as passengers are concerned. The last thing it would want is queues of people at airports, slowed up in their clearance into this country, because passenger movement operations had been cut back.

The instruction, as we understand it, is not to target the cuts to passenger activities—which the minister tried to argue were not being cut when he answered some questions in parliament a couple of weeks ago—but, indeed, to target them at the behind‐the‐scenes areas, such as investigation and cargo examination.

The investigation units are to be closed down in a number of different ports. We accept the notion that every piece of cargo coming in cannot be inspected. But the investigation units are there to develop the intelligence, to identify what should be the focus of investigation and to try to catch the activity that way. If the investigations unit is abolished, what is the means to target? As I indicated before, that example in terms of Newcastle is an important case in point.

What we are seeing here is a minister who cannot defend his department. He is not prepared to go out and back the Customs Service that he has responsibility for administering. The minister is telling the service that there is a responsibility on its part to give effect to government decisions to crack down on illegal imports. Yet he is gutting its very capacity to do so. He is not prepared to defend the basis upon which the service can function correctly because the minister has been given an instruction to make cuts at any cost, to look at the bottom line and not at the impact it is going to have on the service's activity.

We reject that approach. Sensible government has to be about identifying what the priorities of government are. Where there is the bipartisan support that is needed to crack down on the illegal importation of drugs, firearms and pornographic material, the body that is responsible for that crackdown must be resourced with the necessary wherewithal. If you are going to cut savagely into its ability to do it, its ability to influence the outcome is going to be seriously diminished.

The minister's excuses in the House do not stand up. He cannot use the Costello line—the Costello con, if you like—of the $8 billion black hole. He has now been caught out trying to justify the cuts on that basis. The minister must come clean and explain how he expects the customs department to function with 440 fewer people. The minister cannot rely on the fact that improved information technology is going to help in that regard because his own government is hell bent on holding up the progress of information technology changes. It has put a stopper on information technology progress. That is going to impact on many departments, but one which it is definitely going to impact upon is the Customs Service.

We support the legislation, but we oppose most vehemently the cuts that the minister is now imposing on his department. It is a bottom line cut. It is an accounting procedure. It has no regard to ensuring that the service can function correctly. It affects not just the service here in Canberra, but also in the regions. Honourable members opposite should be interested in this because, when one looks at what is going to happen to regional employment and the ability for the illicits to come across the regional borders, come through their areas, one realises that that is going to cause not just a loss of job opportunities, but huge dislocation and have a huge social impact on those communities. They ought to be concerned about what the minister is doing and get on to him about ensuring that the job cuts do not occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been fascinated, while listening to the shadow minister for industry and regional development, Mr Crean, in trying to find in the Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill any relevance between it and what he is saying, but I suppose that is not unusual. It is part of the problem of where the former government and its ministers went. They went off on tracks of their own and, regrettably, the product did not achieve a great deal.
—You go off on a few tracks of your own too. Ian Armstrong, Tim Fischer—who's next?

—I would far prefer to be on my track than yours, Simon, I can tell you. As far as the legislation itself is concerned—which is really the reason that I rose to speak—I think it is interesting that, although the minister spent a great deal of time talking about cuts, there is, of course—
—Shadow minister!
—Shadow minister, I beg your pardon.
—That is in the past—he is a former minister.

—How right you are! The never-to‐be‐again minister is one who spent a great deal of time in the past talking about budget economies. One of the things he needs to understand is that we need to address budget economies because of the way in which he and his colleagues administered Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very interested in the comments made by the former Treasurer in his contribution on the bill. He, of course, is trying to portray the picture as one of absolute fiscal purity. If only it were so. The trouble is that we all know that the bureaucracy has blown. We know that there are enormous additional consequences for working Australians in the way in which the system imposes added costs because of the blow‐out in the bureaucracy.

I think it is important that efficiencies and economies be introduced throughout the whole of the system. But to talk about specific cuts as though they were already in place—and as though there was certainty about future changes in the budget, in particular—is entirely speculative.

I want to talk a little bit about the legislation, but I also want to talk about the way in which the whole of the customs process is administered, because that is essentially what it is about. The minister and I were talking a moment ago; let me start by saying how great it is to see the Main Committee attracting ministers and parliamentary secretaries—

TALK.START.PARA: —And shadow ministers!

—And even shadow ministers; that is right. I am delighted to see the honourable member participating. Shadow ministers have been participating in this place for a while. But under the former administration you would have had one or two of the more senior members of the Labor Party sitting in this place, and there would have been absolutely no relationship between the debate and the contribution of the members and the reaction or response of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important, if this chamber is to exist and survive, that there is an opportunity to actually have a dialogue. Therefore, it is particularly important that ministers such as the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), who is with us today, and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), who was here a few moments ago, actually participate in the debate. If we are to have meaningful opportunities to talk about the content of legislation and where we go in departments, there will have to be more of an interchange between the executive and the legislature than was previously the case. So I am delighted that the minister is here at the moment.

In our discussions a moment ago, we were talking about the extent to which customs checking and procedures are changing. Coastwatch, in particular, was a facility that we were addressing. I think it is important that we understand how technology has made that system so much more efficient than it was in the days when, as Minister for Defence, I had responsibility for it.

It seems to me that we have to not only address the way in which modern technology allows greater supervision, but also recognise that those who seek to import goods into Australia as contraband, against our customs regulations, are also moving into a more sophisticated era. We cannot expect to be able to exercise adequate supervision unless we are able to at least match in technology those processes that people pursue.

The shadow minister was talking about narcotics a while ago. The field of narcotics is a major trade. It is a trade where, inevitably, there are some who escape the supervision of Customs. But, at the same time, we can be proud that so many are in fact being caught.

It is also important to register, as far as narcotic smuggling is concerned, how great international cooperation has been. There is now a great deal of coordination and effort amongst the governments of all the countries in our region. For example, there have been, and remain, customs officers and officers of the Australian Federal Police working in Thailand in conjunction with their American counterparts. That trade is directed at ferrying narcotics not only to the United States but also to Australia, and through Australia, for consumption. They are trying to ensure that they coordinate their efforts internationally.

I think we are very fortunate that there has been such a development in technology in the application of customs checks within Australia and in the coordination of efforts between the countries in our region. I believe customs surveillance is of a much higher order than it was a few years ago.

That has a particular relevance, of course, in terms of how Customs itself should exercise its function. In the reviews that are now under way we have to identify the best means to ensure that the task can be undertaken. I know that in the days gone by, for example, if you went into the United States you would spend an hour or two standing, after your aircraft had landed, before you were allowed to go through any of the entry procedures. Their approach was that the longer you stayed under camera surveillance, the more they were likely to find out who the people were who were carrying goods. I know that, in some ports of entry into the United States, that practice continues.

The United States has always used that idea of leaving people standing around, shuffling and wondering when the devil they were going to be able to get through and get on with whatever their particular activity might be, as a means of surveillance. In Australia we have not used that technique. Yet I believe we have had at least as good a record in surveillance—and, in many instances, a lot better record—than that of our United States counterparts. But in international coordination, there is little doubt that in the work we have undertaken with the officers of the United States narcotics agencies and in other fields of Customs activity, a great deal has been achieved to help those in our region—particularly in the Golden Triangle, as far as narcotics are concerned—to ensure that we do have better inside information as to the drug routes and the course that drugs take so that there is some chance of detecting them when they land on our shores.

This legislation is specifically designed to pick up the new commodity description and coding system of the World Customs Organisation. While many of us are generally aware that the World Trade Organisation and the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade had consequences, this is one of the practical consequences of those negotiations. They are negotiations which do not put a bottom line under world trade. But they do allow significant progress and freedom of movement of goods compared to that which was negotiated in the Kennedy Round and earlier rounds that, over the years, have been the main fields of initiative and emphasis by successive governments in Australia and successive ministers for trade in the various hats they have worn.

Indeed, I can remember participating in some, long since, as minister assisting John McEwen when he was Minister for Trade and Industry. In terms of the degree to which there is now coordination and cooperation around the world, where customs and tariff barriers have been eased there is also a far greater cooperation. But essential to achieving that is common terminology. And that is essentially the product of these changes in the Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1996 to the Customs Tariff Act 1987.

There are also a number of consequential amendments designed to ensure that, with the termination of the l987 act which will take place when this bill is written into law, there will still be a capacity within the legislation to enable a continuity of the provisions of that 1987 act, to the degree that they still have present relevance. For example, in the minister's second reading speech there is reference to some 22,000 tariff concession orders and commercial tariff concession orders, and processes that relate to their continued interpretation, which must be continued. Similarly, there is reference to some 800 tariff concession order applications and determinations in relation to the passenger motor vehicle plan and to by‐laws.

Having identified the nature of these changes, and talked a little about what I see as the efficacy of Customs work and my concern—which I think all of us share—that, resulting from budget analysis, there is not a reduction of the capacity of the Customs organisation, I would like to talk about three other fields. The first is my worry about quarantine. Quarantine is not strictly within the embrace of the administration of Customs in Australia; it is more within the ambit of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. But it has always been very closely associated with the point of entry inspection that is part of migration and part of Customs.

One thing we need to understand is that, not only in the checking processes but in the procedures and the inspections that follow, it is absolutely essential that we recognise the enormous advantage Australia has had by being an island continent, shut off from some of the diseases and infectious complaints that affect particularly the livestock industries in other countries. Mad cow disease and its impact in the United Kingdom is but one example. It is so easy to feed to livestock animal offal or offal from, for example, fish and chip shops and other consumptive‐type processes and not to understand the impact they have. Yet, essentially, that was the source of mad cow disease in Europe, and it is having a disastrous effect on the United Kingdom beef industry.

We need to understand that, in the future, some of our principal competitors in the livestock industries are going to be the South American countries. The reason is that they have applied very strict control processes. Just as BTEC—our brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign—has helped in ensuring access to European markets for our livestock, in South America they are cleaning up the disease problems they have had. The point is that we cannot afford to allow the introduction into Australia—whether it is into our livestock, our tree species or our native flora—of the types of diseases that are prevalent abroad.

There are a number of biological control species that have been introduced from abroad which have had a tremendous impact. We need to be cautious about what we introduce, what the effect will be and what repercussions they are going to have that might not necessarily be recognised. So, within the nature of our customs organisation, I think there is a parallel responsibility with that of all other associated agencies to guard Australia's borders.

The second thing that I wanted to comment on was the fact that we have all been conscious of the number of refugees that have come down, by boat in particular, from Asia in recent times. The effect on customs and the surveillance of our borders is different from what it used to be. Now far more frequently we have people who come to Australia by sea without giving any indication of their departure or even any indication that they are coming to Australia. The coordination, which I mentioned a while ago, between customs agencies and migration agencies ensures quite often that we have a general idea of the way in which those people are heading. But I think it is important that we find ways to establish the same coordination for stopping those people who come to Australia as purported refugees as we have for stopping, for example, narcotics and other forbidden substances and products coming into this country.

I think it is particularly important, as far as our neighbours are concerned—and I think of Indonesia in particular—that, if boats call into Indonesia on their way to Australia or on their way to Christmas Island or whatever is their final destination, we try to stop them there. It is important that we try to find ways by which unwanted movement can be regulated, as those people, when they arrive in Australia, inevitably are going to be returned to their country because so many of them are no longer under `reasonable fear of persecution'—which are the words used to establish the category of a refugee within our legislation and, indeed, within the definition of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

It is important that we retain our willingness to accept those who are genuine refugees, but people who seek to be economic refugees should know of the procedures that are available for people coming to Australia as migrants. Part of the objective of Australia's migration program has been to welcome people to Australia, irrespective of class, race or background, if they seek to make a different way of life. Economic refugees do have a vehicle by which they can come to Australia, but it is not by getting into a boat and travelling in extraordinarily perilous conditions, and doing it in such a way that it not only affects our right to maintain the sanctity of our borders but also runs the risk of bringing in products and other substances that are unwanted and which really do threaten what we see as the sanctity of our own environment.

The third thing I want to briefly touch on relates to an area that has often concerned me, especially with the many islands and waterways around Australia. It concerns the degree to which light aircraft and small boats can breach the customs barrier. I have been conscious, because of my wife's origin in Lord Howe Island, of the fact that when aircraft move between Norfolk and Lord Howe a customs officer has been there. In recent times, aircraft services have reduced and, therefore, the availability of customs procedures is lessened.

We need to make sure that we retain a customs presence on the smaller islands that surround Australia as well as on the mainland. Of course, Lord Howe is only one Australian territory. We also have Christmas, Cocos and Norfolk islands. This relates more to the territories to the north than to the south. However, I believe that the sanctity of our customs borders, our migration borders, and our animal and plant disease borders is absolutely critical. It is in that area that the Australian Customs Service has rendered wonderful service over the years. I believe that, under the present minister, it will continue to do so.

This legislation does not specifically relate to any of those three latter issues but it is a piece of legislation designed to facilitate the legitimate movement of goods across international boundaries. It is an objective of the new status of the World Trade Organisation that all of us endorse. It is a movement which will help make the world a common market and help it move from the inefficiencies of the past with subsidised products to that of freer access, which these new regulations will permit. I commend the legislation, and wish the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs well in what I am sure is going to be a very interesting and effective term and one that he will enjoy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank members for their contributions. It was a fairly wide ranging debate on what would normally be a fairly narrowly defined customs bill. I want to respond to some of the points that the shadow minister made. He made a comment about a `very fine customs service' and it is one that I would agree with. The inference the shadow minister made with regard to the service was that any proposed reduction in efficiency or any efficiency dividends gained under the present government would have some impact on what he described as a `very fine customs service'.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind the shadow minister that, for the four years from 1991‐92 to 1994‐95, the Australian Customs Service suffered a reduction of 1,000 personnel under the term of the previous government and that it was during the period that he described it as a `very fine customs service'. I think is should be borne in mind, as my colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has pointed out, that the Customs Service has changed substantially over the years.

The shadow minister also made reference to the investigations unit. The investigations unit now is mainly concentrated on Melbourne and Sydney and that comes principally out of the Conroy report, again another report brought down under the previous government. I endorse the comments in that report about centralising the investigations unit. However, the shadow minister seemed to confuse the nature of border and barrier control with the role of the investigations unit.

I might add, as my colleague the right honourable member for New England has mentioned, the Customs Service has changed very substantially over the last decade, particularly, the Coastwatch operations of the Customs Service. Coastwatch, comes under, I guess, the administration of Customs. It is now a contracted service and it is a very professional service. Indeed, because of a longer contractual term, the Coastwatch arm has now been able to acquire, in the main, a completely modern, brand‐new fleet of surveillance aircraft. There are 13 fixed‐wing aircraft in the fleet and one helicopter service operating out of Cairns and the Torres Strait. Again, as my colleague for New England mentioned, customs officers in the north‐west of Western Australia particularly are apprehending everyone from boat people to illegal fishermen. It is the agency for quarantine inspection, immigration and a whole range of other services. The nature of customs has changed.

In the borders area, Customs processes just on 13 million passengers—six million of them coming in—and a number of cross‐border transactions as well. To be able to process those people within a reasonable and acceptable time frame, we operate on a risk management basis. That is the same process that Customs operates in relation to the inspection of goods. One only has to look at the nature of incoming goods. Thirty years ago there was no such thing as containerisation; we do have that today.

The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) made reference to a crate of guns coming in. Indeed, it is the coalition government that very much tightened up the importation of guns. I am pleased to see that we have bipartisan support in that area and I am disappointed that the shadow minister is trying to say that it has not been the case that there has been a substantial tightening up in that area.

To go back to the question of the investigations unit, it is not the barrier control. The investigations unit does not go and rip open crates, as in the old days. Their role is very specifically different: to investigate when there is fraud, across a whole range of areas, and other matters that need to be investigated and followed up on the advice, normally, of the barrier people.

I would like to thank members for their contributions and support for this bill. It finished up being a very wide ranging debate on matters that were not contained in the bill. But I do thank members for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially, the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Amendment Bill 1996 reaffirms Australia's commitment as a contributor to the International Telecommunications Union and provides for the Commonwealth to pass the cost of ITU participation on to carriers. It basically confirms legislation which had been introduced under the former government but which did not proceed because of the dissolution of the last parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: When one discusses Australia's ITU obligations, one is reminded that the telephone has become the prime, if not sole, means of communication for many people in Australia. For many people residing in rural and regional areas, their only contact with communities outside their own is on the phone. For elderly people and those confined to their homes it is a lifeline. The irony in this legislation is that it highlights the conflict between the functions of the ITU, which are noble and should be pursued by Australia in every forum, and the government's policy to sell Telstra.

Australia is bound to the ITU under the International Telecommunications Convention. But how ridiculous will it look when we cannot even fulfil our obligations under the convention to Australians themselves. The convention states that each country has the right to regulate its own telecommunications. But, by the same token, its function includes the promotion of telecommunications as a means to secure safety and social development.

BREAK.PARA: One of the primary functions of the ITU is to promote telecommunications development in new or developing countries and to provide technical support to assist in that task. Furthermore, it also has functions to promote the use of telecommunications in the pursuit of peace, the safety of human life, and the social and economic development of all countries.

This bill may be meeting our obligations overseas to developing nations, but it stands in stark contrast to what this government proposes to do with Telstra. How will selling Telstra contribute to the promotion of the safety of human life, and the social and economic development of Australia? In fact, it will do the opposite.

The bill is now subject to a provision, as it was under the previous government, that universal service obligations are to be provided as economically and efficiently as practicable. The massive change proposed by the new government is that the definition of economic and efficiency feasibility will no longer be made just by the government of Australia, acting in the public interest; it will be subject to the definition and understanding of those considerations by private enterprise, by foreign‐owned economic interest. It is clear that they would take a jaundiced view of those universal service obligations.

It is incredible that the National Party, mouthing platitudes about how it is the voice for rural people, would not acknowledge this fact. The universal service obligations provide that, for each telephone line in Maranoa, for example, some $3,300 is provided in subsidy. It is extraordinary that when we talk about elderly people in a community like Charleville, in the electorate of the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), those lines would be $3,300 a year more expensive than they are at the moment in a totally competitive environment. How is this contributing towards promoting the social and economic development of Australia?

All it is promoting are the profits that will be relocated for maintaining an affordable link with outside communities around rural Australia. All it is contributing, in terms of economics, is that residents in the bush will be paying their telephone bills to a partially foreign‐owned company. National Party members, supposedly acting as the voice for rural Australia, have been exposed as nothing more than sell outs when it comes to Telstra. They are sell outs to their constituency, to the people whose interests they are supposed to represent.

It is interesting to note, since the election of this government, the massive swings against the National Party in the New South Wales divisions of Clarence and Orange. It is interesting to note how around the bush, and among the opinion leaders in rural Australia, the National Party has become known as the patsy for the Liberal Party. In the bush, the National Party is willing to sell out interests as diverse as Telstra and the introduction of the ISDN link, questions of subsidies for diesel fuel in rural Australia and the importation of chicken meat. Across the board, they have become known as the patsies to the Liberal Party. It is repeated in this legislation.

Under current telecommunications laws, the minister responsible can direct cross‐subsidies towards rural and regional areas. That authority is now threatened in practical terms by the proposed privatisation of Telstra.

In the Deputy Prime Minister's own seat of Farrer, some of the towns receive a universal service obligation of some $1,500. In the Deputy Leader of the National Party's seat of Gwydir, Narrabri received some $1,530. Nyngan, in the electorate of the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), receives well over $4,000. In the electorate of O'Connor, some of the towns receive over $5,000. In the division of Wakefield, the subsidies are over $4,000 and the subsidies in Grey are substantial.

Under a privatised Telstra, the minister cannot just tell the company where to direct its cross‐subsidies because company law dictates that minority shareholders would have been oppressed. Unless the government is intending to alter the Companies Code, this will mean that all those subsidies will be lost. Even if a universal service obligation still exists, the government cannot instruct the company how it should be allocated. The government would be acting contrary to the provisions of the convention contained in this legislation. A perfectly competitive market with a privatised Telstra would dictate that areas of high demand return the greatest profits. It is not profitable to subsidise Narrabri, Nyngan or Charleville. It is more competitive to subsidise Vaucluse, Kooyong or Dalkeith on the cost of local calls, so subsidies will be reduced throughout rural Australia.

It is regrettable that the government is pursuing a backdoor way to sell Telstra. It is regrettable, under the terms of the convention contained in this legislation, that there will be backdoor ways by which the universal service obligation is reduced. Those who will benefit will be the well off. How expensive will it be for elderly people or those who are housebound in rural areas to maintain contact outside their home? How does that promote safety, Minister, under the terms of our commitment to the ITU? How will this contribute to the safety of human life and the social development of rural communities, as advocated by the International Telecommunications Convention?

We have the hypocritical situation of the government attempting to sell Telstra through the back door, despite the fact that it will cost a billion dollars in stamp duty as a result of adopting that method—the same amount of money as the government wants to spend on the environment. If the government were serious about conserving our natural heritage, this proposition would not even be examined. All it does is expose the fact that the government is driven by purely ideological desires to flog Telstra, with no benefit for the environment and no benefit for rural Australia. It now wants to throw away all the money that could have been spent on the environment just so that it can bypass the democratic processes of this parliament.

A fact overlooked by the government, again in proving its complete hypocrisy on this issue, is that Telstra is so profitable, it having returned nearly $2 billion profit for the 1994‐95 financial year. Its profits alone could fund two or three coalition environment packages until the next election. Three times over, the government could save the environment if it were really serious about it. The profits raised from Telstra in one year could fund the package and keep Telstra in public ownership.

Yesterday the government was happy to cite examples of other countries that have turned to privatisation of their communications markets, including the Netherlands and the United Kingdom. But all Australians—except those on the government benches—living in the bush and in regional centres would acknowledge that you just cannot apply arguments used in those nations to a large, diverse, geographically broad nation like ours. Countries like the Netherlands and the United Kingdom are tiny nations without Australia's demographics and our vast distances between rural and city centres where people rely on the telephone in unique ways as a form of communication.

Even if Telstra is only partially subsidised, there is no way in which it will be able to support the cross‐subsidies, and the assurance of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this issue will be shown to be hollow. What will French bankers care about people living in the bush? As if company directors in New York care about an elderly couple living in Nyngan not being able to afford a telephone line but relying on that telephone line, cross‐subsidised around the nation, as their lifeline, their safety line, their basic form of communication for a whole range of emergency reasons and, of course, the very important social reasons for our senior citizens.

Let me conclude by noting that since the 1989 ITU conference in Nice the need for a more active role by the private sector has been recognised but only in tandem—and this is what the government and the minister should acknowledge—with the need to raise the level of awareness of its importance in financial planning. It is clear from the government's blind obsession with the privatisation of Telstra, to the detriment of rural and remote areas, that under this Howard‐Fischer administration there is no intention of fulfilling the sentiment of the ITU when it comes to objectives in Australia. Its social development goals are being thrown out the window with the government's foolhardy pursuit of the privatisation of Telstra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has made some tired old observations about Telstra that, I suppose, we have heard for the last six months. But we are actually here today to talk about the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Amendment Bill, which the minister brought into the parliament on 22 May. It is a fairly straightforward piece of legislation, which honours an election commitment, and the extra finances for this very important work are to be collected from the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some things that the member for Werriwa has said which I need to address. In 1989 the Hawke Labor government brought in extra competition in a very profound way to the telecommunications industry of Australia. The effect of this was the loss of thousands of jobs, particularly throughout rural Australia. At that time we did not oppose the added competition because we also thought it was the way to go. In other words, there has been a profound change in the direction of the telecommunications industry in Australia and that of Western democracies over the last decade. If the Labor Party intends to go to the people at the next election with this tired old story about the extra cost facing people in the bush, it should think again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six thousand, eight hundred—

—According to your figures. I would like to see those figures, because it is actually very difficult to get the accurate figures from Telstra. I would need to see the numbers before I would even be remotely convinced by that argument.

SPEECH.PARA: What we should not forget is that USO provisions are protected under the partial privatisation of Telstra in any case. Not only do we protect the country areas by including a capped pricing system; we offer a much improved service with the opportunity to take on mobile phones. One of the great issues facing many rural communities is the provision of mobile phones. Under the legislation approved by the previous government, many areas of rural Australia are totally excluded from having mobile phones. It is that legislation which provides this restriction. A mobile phone could have been very valuable to the mining town of Coober Pedy, for instance, where there is always the chance that a mining accident could occur.
