For the member for Werriwa to suggest that there is in some way some sinister plot to disadvantage rural Australia when it has the absolute 100 per cent support of the National Farmers Federation is well beyond the pale.

I want to briefly comment on French bankers, New York financiers and profits going out of Australia—this whole attack on the concept of private enterprise. The tired old rhetoric of the Labor Party seems to suggest that if there is some private enterprise component in any of these institutions then it is bad. I will not waste the time of the Main Committee talking about the Commonwealth Bank or Qantas because we all know the story behind those issues. To suggest that to partially privatise an organisation is a bad thing shows the tired old philosophy and rhetoric that the Labor Party is locked into.

To conclude my response to the comments made by the member for Werriwa, my understanding is that Australia remains almost the only Western democracy which retains full public ownership of its telecommunications carrier. There is perhaps one other such democracy in Europe. So we have this new era of communications throughout the world, and Australia is dragging the chain. Telstra has done a good job in the past. But if you look at its record of overseas investment and the efforts it has made in that area—that is, if you can get to the bottom of the figures—you will see that they are very unsatisfactory.

So, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is with pleasure that I support the introduction of this measure today. Obviously it has the support of the parliament. The cost impact on consumers is quite minimal, and it fulfils an election promise. I am sure that the ITU will go on to have an oversight of these issues throughout the world in a very positive way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will be very brief. I introduced this telecommunications bill into the House a little while ago. It is a very short piece of legislation which will assist the government to give effect to our obligations under the International Telecommunications Union arrangements. We stated, prior to the election, that we want to adopt a user‐pays approach to the funding of the government's contribution to the union. In my second reading speech I outlined some of the reasons for that and the costs involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that this bill does enjoy the support of both sides of the chamber, although it was hard to detect that from the contribution made earlier by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). He talked about issues unrelated to this piece of legislation, in a re‐run of his arguments in favour of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill, which I introduced into the House some time ago. So it is not really appropriate that I respond to those remarks of his. In any event, the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) adequately canvassed those issues. But there is one fundamental point that I think needs to be made in this debate. That is that the universal service obligations are enshrined in the government's legislation. As I pointed out to the member for Werriwa at the time of the debate in the main chamber on the bill to which he then referred, the words in the bill that went through are the exact same words as were in the bill of 1991. He still persists in trying to draw his long bow about the removal or the dilution of the universal service obligations.

The other point that he made, and it was also made by the member for Grey, was that the ITU is committed to the social and economic development of nations in the delivery of its telecommunications services. Most certainly, we subscribe to that view. As the member for Grey pointed out, Australia is one of only two countries left in the OECD that are not moving to some liberalisation of ownership structures of their telecommunications delivery networks, giving effect to the movement in technology and the increasing market competition available in these particular industries. We will be left behind in the delivery of these services in our region and in the world if we persist in adopting the attitudes espoused by the member for Werriwa.

The one thing I would make comment about is mobile telephony. I agree absolutely with the member for Grey about the need for an expansion of mobile telephony into the broader community. There is a great need for that, and I am sure that the member for Werriwa would subscribe to that view. That is best achieved by allowing Telstra to have the flexibility, in competition with the other carriers, to deliver those services.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I have pleasure in proposing that the bill be accepted by the Main Committee. The opposition having already indicated that it agrees with it, I commend the bill to the committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Main Committee for the opportunity to conclude my remarks about this bill. On the previous occasion when we were discussing this bill, I think it had been well canvassed that the purpose of the bill was to bring the Australian legislation into line with the requirements of the Basel convention. One of the important aspects of this amending bill is to enable the definition of hazardous waste to include that waste that might be recovered by the receiving country only on the basis that in that receiving country it would be dealt with in an environmentally sensitive manner. I also indicated my disquiet at what is believed to be the intention of the government to wind back the Commonwealth EPA.

SPEECH.PARA: In the public debate about this legislation, whilst it has been minimal, there was an interesting exchange of ideas in the Financial Review earlier this month. Alan Oxley, Australia's former ambassador to the GATT, made comments about this legislation indicating that it was not in Australia's best interests; that it in some way permitted a unilateralism in Australian law on extraterritoriality; and that it harmed Australia's trade interests. I believe that the fact that there is unanimous agreement in this debate in support of the legislation debunks the position that has been put by Oxley.

A week after the Oxley article appeared in the Financial Review, there was a reply by way of a letter to the editor by Peter Christoff, a member of the Commonwealth Hazardous Wastes Policy Advisory Committee, where he went into some detail about the matters that Oxley raised. Where Oxley had suggested that the treaty was almost unimplementable because its basic terms cannot be agreed, Christoff indicated that in fact that was not the case because the convention went into some detail about defining the list of material and the criteria by which that material would be examined and determined as being hazardous waste.
I wish to quote the important final paragraph of Christoff's letter because I think it is important in the context of what may or may not be considered for the EPA. Christoff said:

Finally, Oxley's opportunistic shot at the federal EPA, at a time when the EPA is under threat of significant cuts or abolition, is predictable given his radical deregulatory agenda. Those with longer memories will remember that the EPA was created largely at the behest of industry, seeking coherent and reliable national environmental benchmarks, standards and processes in the wake of the Wesley Vale fiasco.

I indicate that that is a theme that I agree with and it is a theme that I will return to, because it is in the protection of the national benchmarks and having a national policy that I believe the Commonwealth EPA can play a great role. I think that, just as this Australian parliament has a role to play in debating and looking at matters that had to do with the health of Australia's economy, likewise this parliament and the government should be playing a role in ensuring the health of Australia's environment.

In this debate, the issues of hazardous waste are being discussed in the broad international and national context. It must also be remembered that hazardous waste is something which impacts very heavily on the lives of individuals, in their neighbourhoods, in their communities. In researching for this debate, I pulled out some comments that were made back in April 1982 about a report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. I went to some remarks that my predecessor as the member for Scullin made at that time where he indicated, as a very keen local member, that there was a lake in his electorate which had been polluted by polychlorinated biphenyls—PCBs—that had been stored at a nearby junkyard with inadequate precaution and regulation. The PCBs then found their way into this recreational lake, which was used for sailing and had picnic areas around, and the PCB levels were unacceptably high.

The problem that that illustrated to the then Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation was the lack of proper regulation about the storage, disposal and transport of hazardous wastes in the domestic Australian scene. Fortunately, since then there has been much work done on bringing the state and territory guidelines and regulations about the movement of hazardous waste into line.

During this debate there has been some comment about the handling of radioactive waste. Whilst radioactive waste does not fall into the operation of the Basel convention, I wish to highlight yet another example in the northern suburbs of Melbourne which demonstrates clearly the possibility of dramatic effects on the quality of life of individuals if we do not dispose of hazardous waste appropriately.

Serious claims have been made regarding the disposal of army hazardous waste over 30 years ago in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. A former army mechanic has claimed that contaminated vehicle parts from the British nuclear tests at Maralinga in South Australia—as well as asbestos and acid drums—were deposited at an army dump at the Magyar barracks in Broadmeadows. This person has said that he was required to strip down vehicles brought in from the test site in South Australia and then wash them in acid. They were then buried as landfill. It is now proposed to build a 117-hectare industrial, commercial and residential development on the former army dump site. The residents of the northern suburbs of Melbourne have the right to feel confident and safe that the area they choose to live in is free of such contamination. This applies especially to those who will be buying properties on this site. They have the right to know that such claims will be investigated properly at the highest level. For that reason I call upon the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) to have the claims of hazardous waste—possibly radioactive landfill—at Broadmeadows investigated thoroughly. These serious allegations obviously need to be dealt with before any idea of such a development at this site can be earnestly entertained.

Residents of Melbourne remember well the problems in the western suburbs at Ardeer during the 1980s. It was discovered that houses had been built where battery acid had been disposed of many years earlier. A situation like this must not be allowed to develop in Broadmeadows.

In conclusion, this is a very important piece of legislation. It is very important for the way in which Australia as a developed country sees itself joining in trade with developing countries. Many of the treaties that we enter into have that as their base. In this case, it is to show that we do not condone shifting what might be perceived to be a domestic Australian problem onto another country. We have entered into this agreement so that we ensure that our disposal of hazardous waste is both appropriate and does not shift the problem onto others. I believe—and it is interesting given former Ambassador Oxley's comments as the representative of Australia to GATT—that there are many other areas where, under GATT agreements, we might look at not only environmental policies but social policies. We should ensure, in trade between nations, that environmental aspects and social aspects such as child labour are taken into consideration. I thank the Main Committee for allowing me to conclude my remarks and I indicate my support for this amending legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation was introduced by the previous government. It essentially stems from the 1989 adoption of the Basel convention and Australia's ratification of it in 1992. The main thrust is to cover areas that were not originally envisaged and areas where there has now been an area of divergence between the convention and Australian legislation. That is mainly in the expansion of recycling in the developing world.

SPEECH.PARA: We can find a variety of indications of the realities in this area. If we see corporations in their own countries performing activities which occasion some disquiet, then one has to question in a very real sense the controls that the developing world would have over the abilities of these corporations to recycle and to ensure there are no hazards to residents.
Instancing some of the problems, the Australian of 10 June 1995 reports:

A World Vision spokesman, Karen Medica, said in Indonesia—where Australia sold 10,000 tonnes of lead acid batteries in 1993—a survey of workers found most had blood levels 10 to 20 times higher than concentrations considered dangerous in Australia.

`You cannot just pick up what you do not want from your own backyard and transfer it to someone else who may be in a position where, for economic reasons, they have to accept toxic waste just so they can meet their basic needs.' she said.

Similarly, in the International Environment Reporter, there are details about the $US5.2 million settlement by German companies C.H. Boehringer Sohn and E. Merck to the Basque area in Spain. So one European community member has two of its companies having to clean up a very serious toxic waste dump in northern Spain. It is stated in that report that the agreement paved the way to construct a storage deposit for up to 100,000 metric tons of hexachlorocyclohexane waste from lindane production and soil contaminated by HCH.

This happened in the Western world, in our own front yard, and this is apparently an indicator to the reason why there had to be some legislative action. On 21 February 1995, Greenpeace raised the question of Pasminco and its export of a toxic chemical cocktail `of lead, cadmium and arsenic to Russia on the cargo ship MV Smolensk, which left Melbourne on 7 August 1993'. There were 220,000 kilograms of this material being exported to Russia. It was classified in Australia as cement copper, with a value of $105,000. I think that we are all aware—whether it is a nuclear industry or anything else in Russia—of the state of collapse of government structures, the unemployment of skilled people, and the threat to any kind of environmental controls there, that indicate that Russia, on some level, should be treated as a developing nation at the moment.
It was a recognition of this very real problem. Mr David Stewart, Pasminco's executive general manager, was able to claim compliance, saying:
Pasminco has complied with all relevant Australian legislation.

Greenpeace was putting its concerns on the record that Australian legislation was not up with the pace. What has been happening, of course, in the developing world is an increasing ability to recycle and an increasing penetration of those markets. Australia, as a developed country, would not like to do some of these things here these days, and there is an option to go into these countries.

Similarly, we can look at the problem in one of its own corporations in one particular nation. In an article by Joshua Karliner in the Ecologist in March 1994, a company, Waste Management Technologies (WMX), described in 1991 as the 89th among global corporations in terms of revenue with 64,000 employees, making it the 66th largest corporation employer in the world—quite a sizeable operation—in 1992 WMX's subsidiary, Chemical Waste Management, pleaded guilty to six felony violations for, as the article said:
. . . failure to notify the United States when reportable quantities of hazardous substance were released into the environment.
That was within the United States. The article further stated:

After reviewing such evidence, a lengthy report by the San Diego District Attorney concluded that WMX's history presented a "combination of environmental and anti‐trust violations and public corruption cases which must be viewed with considerable concern".

So there we have a major global corporation within the United States undertaking very serious and hazardous activity. We have to be even more concerned when we look around the world at the lack of infrastructure in a large number of developing and underdeveloped countries, and at their total inability to police these kinds of movements, or to ensure that their own residents are protected—as demonstrated by the desperation of civil servants in a lot of these countries, such as in all of Africa at the moment. You go through half of those countries and the public servants are not paid for months on end.

We have seen instances particularly of German and Italian companies, in a number of countries in western Africa, dumping this kind of material. So it is an international problem and it has to be faced up to.

The previous speaker referred to Alan Oxley's comments which, of course, show a certain emphasis in this policy area. It was illuminating to look at some of the debate around the earlier attempt by Norway to totally ban the movement. And whilst that was a contentious measure, it was quite alarming, I think, to see the attitude of a number of employer groups in this country.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry spoke in rather rhetorical terms about eco‐colonialism. I quote from a media release dated 22 September 1995 in which the ACCI said:

The G77 countries stood up to the eco‐colonialists and insisted on their rights to national sovereignty. No‐one wants hazardous wastes to be dumped on unsuspecting and unwilling people, and what has been achieved in Geneva this week will strengthen the Convention in preventing it.
It went on to deplore the Basel conference decisions, saying:
. . . the definitions of hazardous waste in the Convention are so loose as to catch many valuable secondary materials such as scrap steel, glass and paper and prevent their trade . . .
It then went on to say:
. . . it assumes non‐OECD countries are not able to regulate their own industries.

The ACCI then conveniently cited a few countries that none of us would dispute are ahead of the pack, such as Singapore and Israel—I think Brazil is more questionable—but it left out a large number of non‐OECD countries that are not really up to the mark in these areas.

This was part of a fairly trenchant attack by Australian industry on aspects of the Basel convention, putting forward the proposition, essentially, that to put any restrictions on these countries was a repetition of colonialism and an attempt by the Western world to dominate their internal institutions. We are quite aware that in a large number of these countries the people, essentially, have no say in the first place. So that proposition is extremely dangerous.

The ACCI further commented, on 20 September last year, that this whole thrust by the international community `establishes arbitrary and inequitable geographical and regional trading barriers (OECD/non‐OECD)'; that it `will not achieve the objective of environmentally sound management'; that it `will deprive rapidly industrialising non‐OECD countries of much‐needed secondary raw materials'; and that `the full implications of a trade ban in secondary raw materials cannot be known until the scope of the Basel Convention has been properly clarified through extensive technical work'.

That media release was endorsed by a large number of fairly major players in Australian industry—including the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—and a number of international bodies such as the Indian Non‐Ferrous Metals Association and US Business Recycling Coalition. What they are trying to say is that we, in the Western world, should not in any way try to ensure that there is proper protection of the populations of these countries and that the ability of institutions to recycle and destroy these hazardous materials should be up to a certain standard. It is interesting to note, in contrast, the reality, when we saw the World Bank a fortnight ago deploring Indonesia's increase in the minimum wage. So we have a situation where it is all right for the World Bank and it is all right for other international banking institutions to dictate industrial relations and to attack efforts by the ILO and other bodies to raise living standards, wage standards and occupational, health and safety standards; but it is the end of the world and it is totally atrocious that environmental groups would seek, externally, to try to do something in relation to these areas.

The legislation, as other members have described, sets up a technical committee to give advice to the minister. It ensures, for instance, that there is insurance; it increases the penalties on companies; it tightens up in the area of liability within corporations; and, essentially, it allows an exemption with proper safeguards for movement. It allows the one permit to last the year in a number of cases. All of these things are matters on which there would be broad agreement. I support the legislation. As indicated, there is a responsibility by this country and the Western world to make sure that we are attempting to go towards minimisation. The thrust should not be, basically, to say that we can throw the problem sideways to those countries that are so desperate in fields like recycling or taking these products regardless of their danger. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I have pleasure in summing up the debate on the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill which has been conducted over two sittings of the Main Committee. I thank honourable members for their contributions. This legislation gives effect to Australia's decision back in 1989 to sign the Basel convention, which has been articulated by the two previous speakers. It is one of the three multilateral environmental agreements that Australia subscribes to, the other two being the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.

SPEECH.PARA: This piece of legislation has gone through extensive consultation. It enjoys the support of all parties. As I said, it gives effect to the 1989 act which the then opposition supported and, indeed, listening to the two previous speakers, there were examples given in the 1989 consideration of the legislation which have a ring of familiarity about them. On that occasion, members might recall, there was a vessel called the Khian Sea which left Philadelphia in about August 1986, and was still at sea in November 1988, sailing the world looking for somewhere to unload its cargo, which was a toxic acid and ash waste from incinerators. They were particular examples that, at that stage, made the parliament feel that we needed to subscribe to the Basel convention, and we did.

Some issues were raised by members, who will be aware that the government intends to achieve suitable budget outcomes which has necessitated putting all programs under scrutiny, including the EPA. I think the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) mentioned the EPA, and I know the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) also mentioned it. The government is well aware of the importance of ensuring that its statutory obligations, also created under our agreement to this bill, are given the necessary resources. Savings measures will obviously be managed in ways that ensure that those statutory obligations are met, so I hope that will allay your fears.

The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) and the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) described some past practices of Australia's trade in hazardous wastes; in particular the export of used acid batteries to developing countries such as the Philippines and Indonesia—I think the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) cited Papua New Guinea as well—where inadequate processing had led to exposure of local populations to elevated lead levels in the air. They are quite right in noting that all the amendments will bring such activities under control, and that is the primary purpose of the bill to which the parliament is now subscribing.

It is also worth noting that the debate in Australia surrounding the convention and proposals for amending the act has led to voluntary action by several Australian companies to restrain exports of hazardous wastes to developing countries. There has already been a significant shift in Australia's pattern of trade in hazardous wastes. I am sure that will be welcomed by everybody, but it does require us to be continually vigilant in this regard.

More broadly, the government has made a commitment to reducing amounts of waste going into landfill in Australia and is developing a comprehensive program with the states and territories to deliver that goal. That was a point made by the member for Scullin, in particular. An important part of that program is the development of an awareness program which can help to change attitudes in Australia and so go some way to bringing about the attitudinal and behavioural changes needed if levels of waste generated in Australia are to be reduced.

The honourable member for Prospect argued that the bill merely catches up with international opinion and does not take Australia into the lead. I fundamentally disagree—and I did not hear any other member of the opposition make that observation. With this legislation, so far as we can determine, Australia will be complying more conscientiously with the requirements of the Basel convention than any other country. Further, we will have more rigorous technical processes in support of our regulatory controls—which I detailed in a lengthy second reading speech to the chamber—and the most open and transparent system of decision making, and that is an important consideration in an area of such sensitivity.

We will have very tight controls over exports for final disposal, controls which go beyond what the convention actually requires. There is no doubt in my mind nor, indeed, in the government's mind that Australia will be a leader in its implementation of the convention. On a related point, there is some suggestion that the government has been swayed more by trade interests than by environmental interests in drafting this bill. I should remind members that this bill was drafted by the opposition when in government and has gone forward unchanged, apart from two amendments made in the Senate. Further, the second reading speech which I delivered was very similar to that used by the minister of the former government when introducing this legislation into the parliament. So, if there are any sins, I guess we all share them. You will be pleased that I have attributed the work to the previous minister.

I believe that if honourable members look carefully at the legislation and second reading speech they will see that what we have here is a very careful reconciling of the balance of different interests; in particular, environmental and trade ones. It is because those interests have been so carefully balanced that this government decided to proceed with the bill without further amendment. Indeed, the debate about trade and environment is a very active one, amply illustrated by the quotations that were made from the debate that was going on between Mr Oxley and another.

It is a very active debate, and the Basel convention is an example of that debate. We can use the convention in some ways as a test case now in order to find solutions which provide the best level of environment protection for the vulnerable without imposing unnecessary constraints upon trade. Australia, once this bill is passed, will have put itself in a position where it is actually in front of the argument and will be able to actively contribute to the development of the international debate that is taking place in these very important and complex areas.

It would be appropriate to pay tribute to the departmental officers who have worked in this area, because it is a very complex piece of legislation and has taken a considerable amount of time and wide consultation—and not just within Australia—to reach the position that we have today. It is good to see that it has been achieved by the departmental officers involved. One in particular happens to be sitting here: Mr Hyman needs to be congratulated for the work that he has done. I therefore have pleasure in commending the bill to the chamber for further consideration if necessary.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 23 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, may I congratulate you on your appointment. I would also like to thank the opposition for their cooperation on this piece of legislation and note that it follows on from about 12 months of cooperation between government and opposition on this particular bill, which has had an increasingly tortuous history since it was first introduced in parliament in early 1995.

It was initially part of an omnibus bill, the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995, which was subsequently divided into more manageable parts. The bill incorporates the provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1995 which was passed through the House of Representatives on 28 September 1995 but was still awaiting consideration by the Senate when the parliament rose at the conclusion of the 1995 sittings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A quorum not being present, I will resume the chair at 12.47 p.m.

—To continue: as a result, over 600 applications for listing particular products for supply in Australia have been delayed, which has incurred considerable financial distress for the applicants waiting to have their products listed prior to marketing. These applications comprise relatively simple, low risk products such as vitamin, mineral, herbal, homoeopathic and sunscreen products. The government believes that, given the long gestation of this bill, it is in the public interest to relieve this financial distress as soon as possible. The provisions of this bill will establish a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, ARTG.

SPEECH.PARA: The new process will significantly reduce product approval times to a matter of weeks without in any way affecting the quality or safety of the medicinal products. Under the new scheme, products must meet the same criteria as currently exist. These criteria include a statement that the goods are safe for the purposes for which they are to be used, being the purposes identified in the application for marketing and not other purposes which go beyond the accepted indications for the therapeutic uses of the product.

The bill also provides a much better definition of some poorly understood aspects of the national regulatory scheme for therapeutic goods which have been identified in its first five years of operation. A mechanism to address shortages or lack of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations has also been included, along with amendments that update and consolidate in a new part of the act the entry, search and warrant powers to enforce the legislation.

BREAK.PARA: The bill introduces changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the penalty units classification used in other Commonwealth regulatory legislation, as well as closing a gap in the current scheme in regard to the removal of illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality, safety or efficacy from the market. Also included in this bill are provisions to permit warrantless entry of premises to seize goods, but limiting this power to situations where there is an imminent public health risk of death or serious injury, and where there are reasonable grounds for believing that illegal activity is taking place.

A definition for food has been inserted to clarify the interface between food and drugs. Problems have arisen from the present definition of therapeutic goods, which excludes food but fails to define the term. What constitutes food in the bill will be linked to the presentation and promotion of a product in the market. The words `prescribed dose' and `frequency of administration' included in the definition are to be read in a pharmaceutical sense, and are not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages.

The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act (1989) relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This will ensure that technical and scientific data that should be lodged in connection with a general marketing application will be evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The bill also corrects a defect in the legislation regarding the ability of the secretary of the Department of Health and Family Services to approve the inclusion on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods products for export only where those products have been refused marketing approval in Australia. In these circumstances, the secretary is currently empowered to require confirmation that the relevant authority of the country to which the goods are to be exported is willing to accept the goods. This power is, however, limited to goods that have been manufactured in Australia for export only and does not extend to products imported into Australia solely for re‐export.

The bill proposes that this provision be amended to ensure that the secretary's ability to require confirmation from Australia's trading partners of their willingness to accept goods refused marketing approval in Australia extends to all products, irrespective of whether they have been manufactured in Australia or elsewhere.

Overall, this bill will benefit Australia's therapeutic industry and further enhance Australia's role as a leader in drug evaluation, registration and regulation in this region. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum on the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If you believe in third time lucky, this bill has a good chance of passing on this occasion, having been introduced on two previous occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a few remarks about the measures that are contained in this particular bill. The bill has been discussed in the parliament in different manifestations, and the details of the bill have been discussed on two previous occasions.

One reason why the therapeutic goods industry is so keen to have this legislation enacted is that this bill will implement a much speedier process for dealing with goods that come under the administration of the act. As the minister indicated, it is understood that there are about 600 applications waiting for listing under the provisions of the act. I appreciate the minister's assurances that despite the fact that the provisions of the act will allow goods that are applying for listing on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods to be considered and then listed within a period of a few weeks—a much shorter period than under the current process—this new process will not affect the quality or the safety of the products concerned. That is an assurance the parliament would expect to get from the minister.
The bill also provides for a number of other changes, all of which are welcomed by the opposition. Similar measures were introduced in the last parliament when we were in government.

One significant change in the bill is that it now includes Senator Harradine's amendment, which requires that drugs within a certain category have the specific approval of the Minister for Health. Unfortunately, some people are claiming that Senator Harradine's amendment bans the trial or marketing of any of the drugs that fall within the particular category of abortifacients, for example, RU486. Senator Harradine's amendment should not be changed or demonised in some way; it does not ban those sorts of drugs, whatever people might feel about the worth of such a ban. The amendment simply requires the drugs to be put in a special category and these drugs will require direct ministerial approval for further trials or marketing. The Labor Party does not think it is unreasonable that these drugs are put in that category. It is in accordance with undertakings that were given by previous Labor ministers and we are not opposed to the measures that Senator Harradine has successfully moved in the Senate.
The other issue I would like to touch on very briefly is one that was mentioned in the Senate. Senator Woods, the parliamentary secretary who has responsibility for this area, said:

As a result of that, the government will be reviewing the workings of the bill and reviewing the bill in consultation with the appropriate industries, some members of whom I see in the gallery here today, and we hope to do that in the fairly near future.

That is a commitment by Senator Woods that the government will be conducting a review of the provisions of the act and the way that the act is worked. The statement was made there that it would be conducted in the `fairly near future'. Could the officials in the gallery, or whoever is summing up for the government, convey to the minister that it would be a help if we had some form of timetable so that we know when that review will be initiated, and when it is expected that the review will be completed so that people can have some idea as to what time frame we are working in. Given that the government has stated that that will be completed in the fairly near future, I assume it will be one that will be relatively focused but one, I hope, that will allow for wide consultation before any recommendations are made to the government.

Having spoken to members of the Nutritional Foods Association, I know that they have some strong views that they would like to put to the people as part of that review. I am certainly prepared to work with the government in a constructive way in making sure that that review is one that works in the best interests of Australian consumers, as well as the many Australians whose jobs depend on a continued reassuring and practical approach to therapeutic goods.
Debate (on motion by Mr Vaile) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether the tendering process conducted by the Government Health Supply Council of Western Australia to select a private sector operator to build Joondalup Hospital was in the best interests of public and private hospital users.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Responsibility for the planning and provision of hospital services, including the licensing of private hospitals, rests with the States. The Commonwealth has a legislative function of declaring private hospitals to enable the payment of health insurance benefits, and has established guidelines to assist in this process.

These guidelines are designed to ensure that arrangements such as those planned for Joondalup do not result in cost shifting to other parties, do not reduce public patient access to services and allow patients to freely exercise their right to be treated as public patients.

I will examine the issues relevant to the Joondalup re‐development, having regard to the Commonwealth's private hospital guidelines, when formal application is made to me for Commonwealth recognition of the private hospital facility. The Health Department of Western Australia has provided my Department with preliminary assurances and undertakings in relation to the Joondalup hospital re‐development.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What action is his Department taking to ensure that (a) Liverpool Teaching Hospital and (b) the South West Sydney Area Health Service have a supply of magnetic resonance imaging devices which satisfy the national per capita standard for health regions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The current arrangements for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) services are that Commonwealth funding is provided to 18 publicly owned MRI units via a grants program to States. This approach is based on the results of a comprehensive national assessment program of MRI which was established as a joint Commonwealth‐State initiative and carried out under the auspices of the then National Health Technology Advisory Panel (NHTAP).

Under the MRI program, the Commonwealth provides grants to the States for the purchase of MRI units and about 80 per cent of recurrent costs. State governments are responsible for locating the units within major neurological centres, choosing the physical locations of units and providing the remaining 20 per cent of recurrent costs. States are also able to purchase services from privately owned units.

In New South Wales, there are four units funded under the program. These units are located at the Royal North Shore, Royal Prince Alfred, Prince of Wales and Westmead Hospitals in Sydney, and at the John Hunter Hospital in Newcastle. The location of these units was decided by the New South Wales government.

In the light of developments in the technology of MRI and its clinical use, the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee (AHTAC) is undertaking a comprehensive review of MRI in Australia. AHTAC advice is being sought on a number of issues including the accepted clinical role of MRI in the light of these developments and Australia's resulting needs for MRI services, including the number of units, their locational requirements and other measures to promote quality, appropriate and cost‐effective use of this technology.
This review is well advanced and will provide the Government with a sound information base for examining current funding arrangements for MRI services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 2 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have funds been allocated for the insulation of houses, schools, public premises such as hospitals and other premises in the electoral division of Barton because of heavy usage of air space over Barton; if so, what sum.
(2) Upon how many (a) homes, (b) schools, (c) public institutions and (d) other premises in Barton has insulation work been performed at Commonwealth expense.
(3) What sum has been spent on the works referred to in part (2) to the date of answering this question.
(4) Upon how many (a) homes, (b) schools, (c) public institutions and (d) other premises in Barton is insulation work yet to be performed at Commonwealth expense.
(5) What funds have been allocated for the work referred to in part (4) to be performed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3), (4) and (5) The government has committed itself to continuing the existing Sydney Airport acquisition and insulation program and to extending it to cover buildings that qualify under the scheme in the noise affected areas under the flight paths for the east‐west runway. Funding to enable commencement of insulation of properties in areas affected by operations on the east‐west runway will be addressed by the government as part of the 1996‐97 Budget process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) How many suppliers paid an administrative charge for use of Common Use Contracts in 1994‐95.
(2) What total sum was raised by the administrative charge in 1994‐95.
(3) What is the scale of administrative charges and how is each level determined.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The administrative charge, which was introduced in 1989, is intended to recover the costs of establishing and maintaining the common use arrangements. The amount charged varies between one tenth of one per cent (0.10%) and four per cent (4%) depending on the nature and complexity of the arrangement, projected sales and anticipated customer demand.
